headline: Gen. Sir Robert Ford Is Dead at 91; British Commander on ‘Bloody Sunday’

headline: Turnover at Alabama Would Give Rivals a Rare Opportunity to Pounce

Coach Nick Saban, who is in his ninth season with the Crimson Tide, has led them to three Southeastern Conference championships and three national championships, and they will play for a fourth SEC title on Saturday in the Georgia Dome here against Florida.

headline: As a Deadline Looms, Paul Ryan Finds Himself in a Boehner-Like Spot

headline: Eldar Ryazanov, Russian Film Director Known for His Satire, Dies at 88

headline: Become Hardened
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of the issues that constructors have with creating a quip or quote puzzle is that not all quips or quotes break into “chunks” that scan well. For solvers, working a puzzle that has a quip or quote that is broken up into weird or partial phrases is not as much fun as one that reads beautifully. For an editor like Will Shortz, who has seen his share of quip or quote puzzles, it can become tiresome to run this type of theme on a regular basis, because repeating themes is boring and because they probably need a lot of work before they’re ready for prime time.

headline: Hillary Clinton Email Released by State Department

headline: Clinton Email Is Released After Security Concern Is Dismissed
text: WASHINGTON — A trove of Hillary Clinton’s emails released by the State Department on Monday shows efforts by aides to solicit advice for a concussion she sustained in 2012 and illustrates Mrs. Clinton’s personal difficulty with technology. The department also made public one email after rejecting concerns from an inspector general that it contained classified information.

headline: Taiwan: Old Enemies Exchange Spies
text: China and Taiwan have engaged in rare exchange of spies, the office of Taiwan’s president announced on Monday. The exchange, while made public now, actually took place in mid-October, Taiwan’s Ministry of National Defense said in a statement. China released two officers from Taiwan’s Bureau of Military Intelligence, and they were returned to Taiwan. The men, Chu Kung-hsun and Hsu Chang-kuo, had been arrested in Vietnam near the border with China in 2006 and given life sentences, which were later reduced to 20 years, according to the Taiwanese newspaper China Times, which first reported the exchange. A Chinese spy imprisoned in Taiwan, Li Zhihao, was given early parole as part of the exchange, Charles Chen, a spokesman for Taiwan’s presidential office, said in a statement. The exchange of spies, Mr. Chen said, was a sign of improved relations between China and Taiwan.

headline: Russia: Turkey Returns Pilot’s Body
text: The body of Lt. Col. Oleg A. Peshkov, the Russian Air Force pilot killed after his warplane was shot down by Turkey on Nov. 24, was returned to Russia on Monday. Turkey secured the release of his body from inside Syria, and it was flown from Ankara to a military airfield near Moscow, according to Russian news reports. Defense Minister Sergei K. Shoigu and Gen. Viktor N. Bondarev, the commander in chief of the Russian Air Force, met the plane. After his Sukhoi Su-24 bomber had been shot by a Turkish F-16, Colonel Peshkov parachuted from the plane and was killed by ground fire as he floated into Syrian territory. Turkey insisted that the plane had briefly violated its airspace, a claim Russia denied.

headline: Baruch Fraternity Leader Says He Knew Rite That Turned Fatal Was Banned
text: STROUDSBURG, Pa. — As the president of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity at Baruch College, Daniel Li acknowledged that he knew the rules forbidding hazing. He also found the rituals that stood between a pledge and membership in a fraternity to be degrading.

headline: Russia: Moscow Delays Enforcing Ban on Turkish Produce to Avoid Inflation
text: Although Russia has said it would ban fruits and vegetables from Turkey in response to the shooting down of a Russian warplane, it will wait several weeks to enforce the sanctions to avoid creating sudden shortages that could fuel inflation, Arkady Dvorkovich, a deputy prime minister, said Monday. The delay will enable Russian importers to identify alternative suppliers, he said. Officials are not considering a ban on industrial imports at this time, said Igor Shuvalov, another deputy prime minister. The list of banned items might be expanded in the future, officials said. Among the measures already announced are limits on travel and tourism between the two countries. Russia has spent almost $750 million on importing Turkish fruits and vegetables so far this year, according to government statistics, and Turkey accounted for about 4 percent of all foodstuffs purchased abroad in 2014. About 90 percent of all lemons sold in Russia come from Turkey, as well as significant amounts of tomatoes, grapes and apricots. About 1,250 Turkish trucks are now stacked up along Russia’s southern border, Interfax reported.

headline: Lawyer Is Refused Boarding on La Guardia Flight After Revolving-Door Mix-Up

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 2, Episode 8: A Man Without a Country
text: Last week, the critic Alan Sepinwall wrote a persuasive defense of the individual TV episode in the age of serialization. A key part of his argument is that satisfying, distinct episodes needn’t be the enemy of novelistic storytelling: Hours like the “brain-shredding” trip inside Kevin Garvey’s head in “The Leftovers” or last week’s “Rio Bravo”/“Assault on Precinct 13”-inspired siege in “Fargo” are stand-alone pleasures that can give a show texture and variety without seeming like a detour. It was nice to see Mr. Sepinwall cite the latter in his piece, because “Fargo” had been a counterexample all season, a 10-episode narrative juggernaut that seemed entirely of a piece until last week.

headline: The Dubious Carbon Budget
text: Berlin — OVER the last few years, the concept of a global carbon budget has established itself as a key element of the international climate policy debate. The budget defines the total amount of carbon dioxide we can emit into the atmosphere and still keep warming below 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit, or 2 degrees Celsius, the goal set by the United Nations.

headline: Tell Consumers What They Are Eating
text: In approving genetically engineered salmon as safe to eat and safe for the environment, the Food and Drug Administration rejected petitions from environmental and food safety groups asking that companies selling this salmon be required to label it as genetically engineered. headline: Sheldon Silver’s Albany, Guilty on All Counts

That verdict, coming at a time when Dean Skelos, the former State Senate majority leader, is also on trial on federal corruption charges, should sound a loud alarm to all the players in Albany who have become so accustomed to the abuse of power  that they can’t see how it infects every aspect of lawmaking. Or perhaps they have been perfectly happy to live with criminality because it suits them politically and financially.

headline: Amid the Buying, a Tuesday Devoted to Giving

That field has been pretty narrow lately, with so much of the news focused on murderous violence — from Paris to Colorado Springs. So let’s take note: today is #GivingTuesday, the fourth anniversary of a day that offers a glimpse of the world beyond the pathological extremes: a view of the commonplace generosity and social concerns of millions of people.

headline: Statement Suits at a White-Shoe Law Firm
text: As far as modern white-shoe law firms go, few are as prestigious as Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. For the last 15 years, Skadden Arps has also shared its New York headquarters at 4 Times Square with the fashionable editors of Condé Nast (before the magazine giant relocated to 1 World Trade Center). The editors’ highfalutin style may have rubbed off on the firm’s well-compensated associates and partners.

headline: ‘Map: Exploring the World,’ ‘The Curious Map Book’ and More
text: What is it about maps that we find so fascinating? Ever since the Babylonians scratched two parallel lines and a circle — representing the Euphrates River and their walled capital — on a clay tablet almost 3,000 years ago, we humans have been producing flat spatial imagery to locate our place in the world. Maps anchor us, give coherence to our environment, help make visual sense of otherwise intangible realities. The most skillfully done maps, moreover, can be thrilling to look at, elevating cartography into art. Renaissance mapmakers filled the borders of their works with beautifully rendered dragons and wind-puffing gods; the modernist painter Jasper Johns playfully reimagined the standard road-atlas depiction of the continental United States in his 1961 work “Map.” Maps can solidify national identity, expose societal problems, illuminate trends and whip up jingoistic emotions in wartime. “The map as a concept is complex and ever changing,” the Library of Congress cartography expert John Hessler writes in his introduction to “Map: Exploring the World.” But “it is the cartographic image’s intricate and abstract visual element that is the locus of its strength and lasting appeal.”

headline: Hollywood: Debbie Reynolds, Mickey Rooney, David Lynch and More
text: Hollywood means so many things to so many people: a town where deals and dreams are made and broken, a crazy place in which to grow up all wrong and yet turn out all right, an abstract Eden whose soil has yielded all kinds of flora, from rapturous Greta Garbo silents to weedlike “Star Wars” sequels and reboots. And no matter what we think of it today, it has been forever since Hollywood was all it’s cracked up to be. As Marlene ­Dietrich once wrote, “When I came to Hollywood, the great era of silent films was over and done with. The village was not ‘gay and reckless’ anymore. The studios operated like any other establishment — one had to clock in at a certain hour and heaven help you if you failed to do so. It remained like this all through the rest of the ’30s until I left to join the Army.”

headline: ‘The Book Cover in the Weimar Republic’ and ‘Graphic Passion’
text: Last week I brought Taschen’s gorgeous new collection “The Book Cover in the Weimar Republic” to the art department of the publishing house where I work. I left the book out on a table and watched as my colleagues drifted over, crowded around and riffled through it.

headline: Michael Riedel’s ‘Razzle Dazzle: The Battle for Broadway’
text: Could it be that there were saints walking among us in 20th-century Manhattan? And could it be that those saints were a couple of Jewish lawyers? Who lunched at Sardi’s?

headline: Photography: Carl Van Vechten, Cecil Beaton and More
text: Carl Van Vechten (1880-1964) was a big white man with big white teeth who came from Cedar Rapids, Iowa. He cuts an odd figure as portraitist of the Harlem Renaissance and its successors. He was a culture vulture and party-giver who liked to be in on the latest thing, and maybe his friendships with African-­American artists and intellectuals represented nothing more than a kind of cultural tourism. Certainly W.E.B. Du Bois mistrusted him, and Ralph Ellison “despised his photography,” and he alienated many with his sensational 1926 roman à clef, “Nigger Heaven.” But he got Langston Hughes published, and furthered the careers of others; Walter White, head of the N.A.A.C.P., named his son Carl. And whatever the motivations behind them, his portraits are extraordinary — lapidary and noble and often majestic — and it is clear that he had a genuine rapport with many of his subjects.

headline: The Profound Emptiness of ‘Resilience’
text: There are many versions of the bird’s death, but in each, it rises the same way — out of its own ashes and into the sun. The myth of the phoenix, that symbol of endurance, began in Arabian and Egyptian folklore and was brought to the West by Herodotus 2,500 years ago.

headline: The Last Dalai Lama?
text: On a wet Sunday in June at the Glastonbury Festival, more than 100,000 people spontaneously burst into a rendition of ‘‘Happy Birthday.’’ Onstage, Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, blew out the solitary candle on a large birthday cake while clasping the hand of Patti Smith, who stood beside him. The world’s most famous monk then poked a thick finger at Smith’s silvery mane. ‘‘Musicians,’’ he said, ‘‘white hair.’’ But ‘‘the voice and physical action,’’ he added in his booming baritone, ‘‘forceful.’’ As Smith giggled, he went on: ‘‘So, that gives me encouragement. Myself, now 80 years old, but I should be like you — more active!’’

headline: There’s a Formula for Deciding When to Extract Fossil Fuels
text: “Drill, Baby, Drill” became a popular campaign mantra back in the 2008 election cycle. But now we’re hearing the opposite call: “Leave It in the Ground.”

headline: Amid Smog Wave, an Artist Molds a Potent Symbol of Beijing’s Pollution
text: Beijing has been swamped for days in a beige-gray miasma of smog, bringing coughs and rasping, hospitals crowded from respiratory ailments, a midday sky so dim that it could pass for evening, and head-shaking disgust from residents who had hoped the city was over the worst of its chronic pollution.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 24-30, 2015
text: Have you been following this week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Uncertainty. Frenzy. And Then Donald Trump Appeared.
text: Donald J. Trump’s campaign aides may have canceled his news conference announcing endorsements from black pastors. But he rarely lets an opportunity to speak to the news media go to waste, and he did not disappoint on Monday afternoon.

headline: Digital Report Singles Out Fashion’s ‘Gifted’ and ‘Challenged’
text: L2, the New York-based think tank that tracks brands’ digital competency across platforms and rates their annual performance, just released its 2015 Fashion Index, and it makes for some pretty eye-opening reading. Not just because, as my colleague Mark Scott noted in a piece for our special luxury report, 10 brands drive 65 percent of site traffic (though that is a kind of astonishing fact in itself) but because it contradicts some pretty widely held beliefs about which brands are good at this digital stuff, and which brands are not.

headline: The Best Teams? Look at the Big Games
text: In this world of data-driven precision, we’ve come to expect everything to the fifth decimal place. Tuesday Morning Quarterback says there’s still room for totally unscientific back-of-a-cocktail-napkin thinking. Enter my Authentic Games Index.

headline: Holiday Favorites and a Celebration of the New
text: Ailey at City Center

headline: A Lineup of Missteps
text: This week’s grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

headline: Mantle on Commerce Street
text: Dear Diary:

headline: It Might Be a Young Man’s Game, but These Three Are Still Winning
text: Indianapolis quarterback Matt Hasselbeck, who turned 40 in September, is the oldest quarterback in the N.F.L. San Diego tight end Antonio Gates, 35, is the active leader in career touchdowns. Adrian Peterson, 30, ranks second among all active players in both career rushing yards (behind Frank Gore) and career touchdowns (behind Gates). On Sunday, all three players showed they still have something left in the tank.

headline: Small News On The Yuan
text: So the IMF has included the renminbi in the SDR, adding a world of hurt to newspaper reports; now everyone will have to deal with China’s awkward currency nomenclature. (As I understand it, you should use renminbi and yuan more or less as you use sterling and the pound; the RMB is the term for Chinese money in general, the yuan a denomination of its notes.) It’s a symbolic event — the first developing country to achieve that status. And if you ask me, it was a bit rushed: China is big, but it still has capital controls, so that its currency really isn’t freely negotiable the way the other currencies in the basket are.

headline: Out of Danger, After 48 Years
text: How does an endangered species get out of danger?

headline: Russians Unlikely to Attack ISIS in Syria, Obama Says
text: LE BOURGET, France — President Obama said Tuesday that despite repeated meetings with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on efforts to defeat the Islamic State, no one should be “under any illusions” that Russian forces would now start attacking the extremist group’s positions in Syria.

headline: At the Gothams, ‘Spotlight’ and Spontaneity Win the Night
text: Is it humble to publicly propound the virtues of humility? The Bagger can’t quite decide (leaning toward a no). But humility is what Robert Redford said was his “equalizer” amid the gale force winds of stardom — “so I wouldn’t take myself too seriously” — while accepting a tribute award at the IFP Gotham Independent Film Awards at Cipriani Wall Street on Monday night.

headline: A Conversation With Black Women on Race
text: In this short documentary, black women talk about the challenges they face in society.

headline: ‘A Conversation With Black Women on Race’
text: This latest installment of our “Conversation on Race” Op-Doc video series highlights the negative emotional impact of racist attitudes on black women’s lives. Everyone we reached out to for this project was eager to tell her most intimate stories of pain and discrimination, from childhood, to work, to profiling by the police. We hope that in sharing them, we are helping to complicate the public representations of black women and girls — highlighting the unique challenges they face, as well as experiences and feelings that are universal.

headline: Browns Find a New Way to Lose
text: Browns fans are used to losing. Twelve seasons without a playoff spot, 21 years without a playoff win, 51 without a championship.

headline: 1915: German Spy School At Antwerp
text: GENEVA — The trial of Philipponat, charged before the court-martial at Geneva with espionage in the interests of Germany, brought to light the fact that the German Headquarters Staff has installed at Antwerp a school for spies. The methods of this school are as follows: The individuals, brought to Antwerp by the recruiters whom the German information service maintains in neutral or occupied countries, follow for a month a course of lessons, which are given by staff officers, police commissaries, and a professor of chemistry, who teaches the elements of cryptography. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 2, 1915

headline: Should You Update to Apple OS X El Capitan?
text: Q. My MacBook has been nagging me to update to OS X El Capitan for the last few months, but I have read a lot of negative feedback about the system. How bad is it and is it worth upgrading?

headline: BlueCrest to Close Hedge Fund and Refund Outside Investors
text: Less than three years ago, BlueCrest Capital Management was one of the biggest hedge funds in Europe, managing $37 billion of investor money.

headline: Spain’s Prized Ibérico Hams Can’t Cure Fast Enough for China
text: JABUGO, Spain — On a vast farm dotted with oak and cork trees, about 350 pigs are enjoying the final weeks of a short but blissful life. They roam freely, sleep outdoors or shelter in spacious pigsties. Above all, autumn is when they get to feast all day on acorns recently fallen from the trees.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Culture Across Continents, From Hacker to Satire
text: The techie culture of coders and coding has spread across the globe as Internet companies have become ascendant and usage of computers and mobile devices has become an everyday habit for many. Yet that culture is far from uniform and has evolved differently in different places.

headline: U.S. Still in Danger of Losing War on AIDS, C.D.C. Director Says
text: Despite major medical advances and more than 30 years of effort, the United States is still in danger of losing the war on AIDS, according to the country’s top disease-control official.

headline: ISIS Followers in U.S. Are Diverse and Young
text: WASHINGTON — American authorities this year have arrested nearly five dozen people in the United States for helping to support or plot with the Islamic State, according to a new study, the largest number of terrorism-related arrests in the country in a single year since September 2001.

headline: ‘The Man in the High Castle’: Watched It All? Let’s Talk About It
text: Spoilers for the full first season of Amazon’s “The Man in the High Castle” follow.

headline: Rushing to End Mass Shootings, Police Face Greater Danger
text: Even before teams of armed terrorists struck Paris last month, briefly holding hostages in a theater, officials in New York had been altering their approach to school shootings and other murderous attacks that erupt and are frequently over within minutes.

headline: 1940: Avila Camacho Is Inaugurated in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY — Gen. Manuel Avila Camacho, soldier and rancher, became Mexico’s President today [Dec. 1], succeeding Lazaro Cardenas, and as he took office demonstrated that his government stood shoulder to shoulder with the United States and other sister American republics in the defense of democracy. The forty-three-year-old former Minister of War was inaugurated soon after 11 a.m. in the presence of special envoys from thirty-one foreign nations. Henry A. Wallace, Vice-President-elect of the United States, received a standing ovation when he entered the hall. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 2, 1940

headline: Rudolph Giuliani Cites 9/11 Celebrations, but Disputes Donald Trump
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani weighed in on the question of Muslims cheering in America after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and concluded that while he recalled some pockets of celebration in New York City, Donald J. Trump’s claim about thousands of revelers in New Jersey was an exaggeration.

headline: Tahir Elci, Human Rights Defender
text: It is not often that I encounter someone who makes me think that peace and justice in the hardest of contexts can be more than just quixotic ambitions. Tahir Elçi, the president of the Diyarbakir Bar Association, was one of those rare people for me.

headline: Steve Jobs 2
text: excerpt

headline: Steve Jobs 3
text: excerpt

headline: AirAsia Flight 8501 Crash Findings
text: An AirAsia passenger jet plunged into the Java Sea in late 2014 because of a faulty component coupled with the crew's response, a crash investigator said on Tuesday.

headline: Submit Questions for Damon Lindelof of ‘The Leftovers’
text: Damon Lindelof answered the questions here.

headline: Life in a Japanese-American Internment Camp, via the Diary of a Young Man
text: NEW HAVEN — Until recently, Yonekazu Satoda says, he did not recall the diary he had written in neat cursive in the laundry building of an internment camp in Arkansas. He would eke out his entries at night amid the washboards and concrete sinks, the only private space in the camp with light.

headline: Bronx Woman, 28, Fatally Shot Inside Her Apartment
text: A 28-year-old woman was fatally shot on Tuesday inside her Bronx apartment during an argument with her former boyfriend, while the couple’s 6-year-old son was in the home, the police said.

headline: The Curious Incident of the Duct-Taped Dog on Facebook
text: People with pets are discovering that their private treatment of animals can easily make them the targets of a social media manhunt, and, in some cases, formal police inquiries.

headline: Supreme Court Says Woman Injured in Austria Can’t Sue in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that a California woman injured in a train accident in Austria cannot sue in an American court. It was the Supreme Court’s first decision of the term in an argued case, and it was unanimous.

headline: VW Argued for Easing New E.U. Tests on Emissions
text: LONDON — Volkswagen successfully lobbied to remove two key parts of Europe’s forthcoming auto emissions tests, an internal email shows, including a provision to measure the significant pollution released when an engine is started but hasn’t yet warmed up.

headline: Vaucluse
text: A new French restaurant on the Upper East Side from Michael White’s Altamarea Group.

headline: At Vaucluse, Michael White Takes a Step Toward France on the Upper East Side
text: A critic could run out of new ways to express disappointment in Altamarea Group restaurants if Altamarea didn’t keep coming up with new ways to disappoint.

headline: Discontent Over Migrants Takes a Toll on East German City
text: DRESDEN, Germany — More than one year later, they are still here, the thousands of people who rally every Monday under the banner of the Pegida movement to vent their rage against Muslims, migrants and especially the government of Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Mayor Rahm Emanuel Fires Chicago Police Superintendent
text: CHICAGO — A week ago, Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Police Superintendent Garry F. McCarthy stood together, shoulder to shoulder, as this city released long-sought video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times along a Chicago street last year. But after nights of demonstration that followed the video’s release and growing calls for changes at the city’s Police Department and beyond, Mr. Emanuel stood alone at a lectern on Tuesday to say that he had dismissed Mr. McCarthy.

headline: Folk Hero Furniture by Brazilian Brothers
text: The Brazilian furniture designers the Campana Brothers are known for elevating humble materials such as rope, scraps of wood and even stuffed animals: In one memorable work, a patchwork of teddy bears became a comfy chair. Their latest collection, unveiled by the São Paolo gallery Firma Casa at Design Miami, is inspired by the Cangaço, nomadic bandits who roamed northeastern Brazil in the 19th century. Intricate leatherwork recalls the elaborately embellished hats, boots and vests worn by the swashbuckling thieves.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Gets a Regular Gig at the Beacon Theater
text: At this point in his career, Jerry Seinfeld is a comedian who can work as often or as little as he wants to. And now this popular stand-up performer, sitcom star and digital host is offering New York audiences the opportunity to see as much of him as they can take.

headline: Rye Adds an Authentic Touch to the Holidays
text: Three men sitting in a Midtown Manhattan restaurant one recent afternoon represented three generations of the Kentucky clan whose hand has been on the tiller of the Wild Turkey distillery for more than half a century. There was Jimmy Russell, the legendary distiller; Eddie Russell, his son, a veteran distiller in his own right; and Bruce Russell, Eddie’s 26-year-old son, a relatively new addition to the firm.

headline: Puerto Rico Begins Choosing Which Debt Payments to Make
text: WASHINGTON — Puerto Rico avoided its first major default by making payments of $354 million on its debt on Tuesday, but the island’s governor said that he had already taken steps to halt certain payments on other debt coming due on Jan. 1.

headline: David Letterman, Even Retired, Keeps On Interviewing
text: MUNCIE, Ind. — Six months into retirement, David Letterman stepped onstage here at Ball State University looking much the way he did as host of “Late Show”: suit and tie, loafers and white socks. But he has grown the kind of beard a man wears when he doesn’t have to get up for work every morning — looking not so much like Santa Claus but, as he said, like Charles Darwin.

headline: Race in America: Your Stories
text: As part of a series of Op-Docs videos about race, we are featuring personal stories that reflect the breadth of experiences in the United States.

headline: Coaching Carousel Spins Ever Faster
text: Before the 1987 season, Virginia Tech hired a new football coach. The new boss was 2-9 in his first season. A half-dozen recruiting classes later, he finished his sixth season with a record that was, on paper, only microscopically improved: 2-8-1.

headline: Airbnb Releases Trove of New York City Home-Sharing Data
text: Airbnb has had a rough history with regulators in New York City. Now the company is playing nice.

headline: Young Palestinian Women Join the West Bank Turmoil
text: NEW ASKAR REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — The 16-year-old gave clear warning that she was up to something days before she swapped her schoolbooks for a knife and headed to a nearby Israeli military checkpoint. If I am killed, Ashrakat Qattanani told her father, “Don’t cry for me, cry for Palestine.”

headline: Chicago Mayor on Firing of Police Chief
text: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said that the police superintendent, Garry F. McCarthy, had been "excellent" in his role but that the public trust in the department's leadership had been shaken.

headline: Jimmer Fredette Steps Back, but Scores 37, in D-League Debut
text: WHITE PLAINS — Tony Hammel, who coached Jimmer Fredette for four years at Glens Falls High School, still connects with him every couple of weeks. They text or chat on the phone, even as Fredette continues to hopscotch the country on a seemingly endless basketball odyssey.

headline: Adele on Love, Fame, Ego and ‘25’
text: Adele has everyone talking. Drake has offered to do her laundry. Britney Spears has professed her love for “Hello.” But conversation about Adele has mostly focused on numbers — and her (ultimately lucrative) decision not to make her new album, “25,” available to streaming services — rather than her music.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda Contributing  Music to ‘Star Wars’
text: Lin-Manuel Miranda is still performing on Broadway, but he also has a gig in a galaxy far, far away. J.J. Abrams, the director of “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” revealed on the “Tonight” show that Mr. Miranda helped write the music for the movie’s cantina scene.

headline: U.S. Special Operations Force in Iraq to Grow, Pentagon Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will expand its Special Operations force in Iraq as part of a ramped-up war effort against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter told a House hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Student Activism and Free Speech at Amherst
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 8: This Power Was Forced on Me
text: Episode 8 is a welcome corrective to the pity parties that were Episodes 6 and 7.” Here, Jones returns to her childhood home, now renovated by Kilgrave, and confronts her guilt directly. Jones may not have been in control of her actions before but that’s not the case here, as the episode’s writer, Scott Reynolds, reminds us immediately, by having Kilgrave tell Jones: “I was serious when I said I wanted you to choose.” Jones’s free will makes all the difference in “AKA WWJD,” a thoughtfully focused episode that swims around the idea that some people just don’t feel remorse about their actions.

headline: Luke Walton, With 0-0 Record, Is Named an N.B.A. Coach of the Month
text: Settling the debate once and for all, the N.B.A. issued a statement on Tuesday clarifying that it would not alter its policy of not crediting wins and losses to interim coaches in most instances. Golden State Coach Steve Kerr will receive credit for the Warriors’ record under Luke Walton, who has been running the team in Kerr’s absence.

headline: Wary of Donald Trump, G.O.P. Leaders Are Caught in a Standoff
text: WASHINGTON — For months, much of the Republican Party’s establishment has been uneasy about the rise of Donald J. Trump, concerned that he was overwhelming the presidential primary contest and encouraging other candidates to mimic his incendiary speech. Now, though, irritation is giving way to panic as it becomes increasingly plausible that Mr. Trump could be the party’s standard-bearer and imperil the careers of other Republicans.

headline: While U.S. Car Sales Jump, VW’s Plunge
text: DETROIT — While other automakers were reporting gains in a strong market for new vehicles in November, Volkswagen said on Tuesday that the impact of a widening emissions scandal caused its sales in the United States to plunge nearly 25 percent during the month.

headline: Two New York City Workers Charged With Stealing $2.1 Million From Benefits Programs
text: The New York City employee’s plan, as described by investigators, was elaborate but efficient. She had people pay welfare recipients for access to their benefits cards and directed money to their accounts. Then an associate used some of the fraudulent benefits to buy Red Bull in bulk and resold the energy drink to bodegas. Some of the cash then made its way back to the city employee, the authorities said.

headline: A Twist on the Traditional Challah
text: Bread — shaping it, baking it, blessing it and sharing it — is part of almost every Jewish holiday.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Rangers and Isles Meet in Brooklyn
text: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players.

headline: Challenging the Oligarchy
text: I review Robert Reich’s new book in the New York Review of Books. Things have changed a lot since 1991.

headline: An Artist and a Poet on Life’s Little Mysteries
text: For T’s ongoing series, the poet Carl Phillips and the painter Howard Hodgkin make tangible the most fleeting of life’s daily wonders.WHAT I SEE IS THE LIGHT FALLING ALL AROUND US

headline: Chartreuse: Holiday Greenery in a Cocktail Coupe
text: In the French Alps, après-ski, a mug of verte chaude often awaits. This regional warmer (the name means hot green) consists of hot chocolate revved with a generous splash of Chartreuse, the strong, verdant spirit that is made nearby. The drink may also come crowned with a pouf of freshly whipped cream.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Strange New Ad
text: All Americans should be grateful to those who have earned the Medal of Honor, an award of valor often granted posthumously because of the high degree of personal sacrifice it represents. But individual acts of bravery don’t confer any special knowledge of what it takes to be the commander in chief.

headline: Avars, Arabs, and History
text: The historian David Potter had a great letter published in the Financial Times, correcting the really bad history of the Dutch president, who suggested that migrants brought about the fall of Rome. (Bad history is all the rage these days.) Potter:

headline: For Robert Dear, Religion and Rage Before Planned Parenthood Attack
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The man she had married professed to be deeply religious. But after more than seven years with Robert L. Dear Jr., Barbara Micheau had come to see life with him as a kind of hell on earth.

headline: Paul Ryan Pushes Changes in Mental Health Care After Colorado Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — Efforts to overhaul the nation’s approach to mental illness gained momentum on Tuesday as the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, urged lawmakers to “do more” to protect people after the deadly shooting last week at a Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado.

headline: Wanted: More Women on the Slopes
text: Ski resorts have spent considerable resources in recent years making sure they nurtured the next generation of skiers and boarders by creating innovative and fun classes for children. Now their mothers and older sisters are increasingly getting attention as women-only programs multiply across the Rocky Mountain range.

headline: Broad Effort Aims to Expand Financial Services to Low-Income Consumers
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, teaming with private partners including the Gates Foundation and JPMorgan Chase, announced initiatives on Tuesday to expand banking services to millions of Americans and others worldwide who lack essentials like checking or savings accounts and access to credit.

headline: Joba Chamberlain Returns to the Land of the Midges
text: The signing of a journeyman pitcher to a minor league contract does not ordinarily raise much interest in the hot stove league.

headline: At Home, Chris Christie Hears a Dissenting Newspaper Voice
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is riding high after a coveted endorsement from The New Hampshire Union Leader, but he is not winning such accolades at home.

headline: A New Sports Company Serves Up Wellness, and Sunglasses
text: Sports culture tends to revolve around competition, victory and defeat. So it’s a bit strange at first to hear the terms Tom Daly and Max Vallot use when talking about their new athletic company, District Vision: “community,” “participation,” “inclusiveness,” “meditation.”

headline: New York City Aims for Vast Electric Car Fleet by 2025
text: By 2025, New York City is planning to employ the largest municipal fleet of electric vehicles in the country, along with a sprawling network of charging stations to go with it.

headline: Nocino, an Italian Walnut Liqueur, Is Also Made in America
text: The holidays are shot through with nuts. We stuff them inside our turkeys, cookies and fruitcakes. Without them, decorative nutcrackers are just garish tchotchkes.

headline: Helen Mirren, Robert De Niro and More at the Gotham Independent Film Awards
text: Luminaries of the film world gathered in New York for the unofficial kickoff to awards season.

headline: Imagining a World Without Growth
text: Could the world order survive without growing?

headline: Gotham Independent Film Awards’ Red Carpet
text: See what Maggie Gyllenhaal, Julianne Moore and Dascha Polanco wore to the award show.

headline: On Hanukkah, the Latke Road Less Traveled
text: Each year before Hanukkah, which begins this year at sunset on Sunday, I wonder why I labor so over potato latkes. I grate the potatoes and onions by hand, often skinning my knuckles. I squeeze out the water so the potatoes fry crisper and won’t discolor — but sometimes they still do.

headline: Why the Pro-Life Movement Opposes Violence
text: In the wake of the Robert Dear shootings at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado, the tendency from pro-choice writers has been to get the pro-life movement coming and going — on the one hand accusing pro-lifers of at least semi-deliberately fomenting violence, on the other accusing them of being inconsistent for abjuring the violence that their own premises seem (to pro-choice eyes) to inevitably justify.

headline: Charlie Savage’s ‘Power Wars’
text: When Paris was attacked last month, politicians and pundits fell all over themselves rushing to proclaim what Washington should do next in the war on terror. The vast majority of them would have done better to keep quiet and read Charlie Savage’s new book, “Power Wars,” instead. It offers a master class in how to think seriously about crucial aspects of the subject.

headline: Votes in Congress Move to Undercut Climate Pledge
text: WASHINGTON — Hours after President Obama pledged Tuesday in Paris that the United States would be in the vanguard of nations seeking a global response to climate change, Congress approved two measures aimed at undercutting him.

headline: A Powerful Curator’s Idiosyncratic Genius
text: Carolyn Christov-Bakargiev has worked with the biggest names in contemporary art and organized its most prestigious exhibitions, including the Sydney Biennale and the 13th edition of Documenta. Next month, she will become director of Turin’s two major contemporary art museums, which are merging. She has the power to influence artists’ work and to sculpt artists’ careers — and yet she rejects the idea that she ‘‘selects’’ artists for her shows. ‘‘ ‘Selects’ reminds me of 1943,’’ she recently told the press.

headline: Leader of Taliban Splinter Group Allied With ISIS Is Killed
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — After months of Taliban infighting that has left hundreds dead, the prominent head of a splinter faction allied with the Islamic State has been killed, government officials and Taliban commanders said on Tuesday.

headline: Steve Jobs 1
text: excerpt

headline: Helen Mirren, Robert De Niro and More at the Gotham Independent Film Awards
text: Luminaries of the film world gathered in New York for the unofficial kickoff to awards season.

headline: Facts & Figures: Attacks on Muslims in America
text: Attacks and threats against mosques and individual Muslims in the United States have surged since the Paris attacks, according to a report by the Council on American-Islamic Relations. ThinkProgress has a breakdown of some of the incidents cited in the report, including these:

headline: New Rules on Reporting Brokers’ Dismissals to Begin Dec. 12
text: New rules significantly shorten the window of time brokerage firms have to report the details of a broker’s departure from their firm — an effort by securities regulators to make background information about brokers more accessible to consumers.

headline: Gotham Independent Film Awards’ Red Carpet
text: See what Maggie Gyllenhaal, Julianne Moore and Dascha Polanco wore to the award show.

headline: “Leap of Faith,” by Bruce Weber
text: The latest volume of the iconic photographer’s annual cultural anthology collects stories that might not otherwise be told.

headline: Around the World With Bruce Weber
text: In ‘‘Leap of Faith,’’ the 15th installment of his annual cultural anthology, ‘‘All-American,’’ the legendary photographer Bruce Weber collects stories, both historical and contemporary, that might otherwise not be told. Here, a snapshot of images from the book’s wide roam, from a dance for incarcerated fathers and their daughters in Richmond, Va., to the reportage of war photographer Lynsey Addario.

headline: Ex-President of Argentina Is Sentenced in Embezzlement Case
text: BUENOS AIRES — Carlos Saúl Menem, the former Argentine president, was convicted and sentenced on Tuesday to more than four years in prison for overseeing the embezzlement of public funds to pay bonuses to government officials during his presidency in the 1990s.

headline: A Foundation Says the Joffrey Ballet Owes Licensing Fees of $373,000
text: A foundation which says it owns the rights to the ballets created by the founders of the Joffrey Ballet, Robert Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, said this week that the ballet company owed it more than $373,000 in back payments for performing the works in recent years.

headline: New Options Abound in the Former Macy’s Cellar
text: Chef Street and Rowland’s Bar & Grill The pots, pans and blenders from the former Macy’s Cellar have been moved upstairs, replaced by clothing for millennials. But there are new places to eat, starting with a food court where four Airstream-style trailers dispense name-brand dishes: There’s Taquitoria, serving Marc Forgione’s tacos; Crumb on Parchment, with salads, grain bowls and sandwiches from the Miami chef Michelle Bernstein; ramen, bao buns and dumplings by Takashi Yagihashi of Chicago; and Rollie’s, for sandwiches on rolls. Nearby is a new pub, Rowland’s (Rowland is the “R” in R. H. Macy), with bar, banquette and table seating for shrimp salad, fried chicken, burgers, grilled fish and steaks. (Chef Street opens Wednesday; Rowland’s opens later this month): Chef Street, Macy’s lower level, 151 West 34th Street; Rowland’s Bar & Grill, 212-868-3001.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Viewing Economy’s Past Through Gold-Colored Glasses
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans unhappy with the Federal Reserve are circulating an idea that long ago lost currency with most economists: a gold standard.

headline: Kobe’s Poem to Basketball
text: From The Players’ Tribune

headline: Pfizer’s Deal for Allergan Is a Dubious Milestone
text: Pfizer’s $160 billion takeover of Allergan reached a few milestones in the mergers and acquisitions trade.

headline: Before Giving, Check Out Charities and Their Policies on Privacy
text: As the year draws to a close, many people are considering charitable donations. But before writing a check or clicking to make an online donation, it’s best to do some homework.

headline: The Sober Proprietor of a Bar on Avenue B
text: True artifacts of the East Village’s punk heritage are few and far between these days. One of the few is Manitoba’s, on Avenue B.

headline: Students’ Protests May Play Role in Supreme Court Case on Race in Admissions
text: WASHINGTON — As student protests over racial injustice are exploding at campuses across the nation, the Supreme Court is preparing to hear a major case that could put an end to racial preferences in college admissions.

headline: Volkswagen’s Software Was ‘Illegal Defeat Device,’ German Regulator Says
text: LONDON — German regulators said on Tuesday that the software Volkswagen used in many of its diesel vehicles constituted illegal cheating on emissions tests, deepening the company’s problems.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Vows to Donate 99% of His Facebook Shares for Charity
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, the co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, announced on Tuesday that he and his wife would give 99 percent of their Facebook shares “during our lives” — holdings currently worth more than $45 billion — to charitable purposes.

headline: New Peace Talks on Syria Could Be Held This Month
text: UNITED NATIONS — The world powers that met in Vienna for landmark talks aimed at ending the war in Syria could meet next in New York in mid-December, diplomats here said, as long as the latest tensions between Russia and Turkey can be calmed.

headline: On the Hunt for Gluten-Free Holiday Cookies
text: You don’t have to shop for gluten-free all-purpose flour to make great gluten-free Christmas cookies. Every holiday season, in addition to the sablées that I always make but that my sister, who has celiac, can’t eat, I make coconut macaroons and regular macarons, cookies that don’t call for flour. This year I wanted to expand my repertoire. So I solicited ideas for cookies that don’t require any wheat flour from a few pastry chefs around the country.

headline: Columbia Disputes Exxon Mobil on Climate Risk Articles
text: The dean of Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism published a letter on Tuesday strongly disputing accusations by Exxon Mobil that journalists from the school had produced inaccurate and misleading articles about the company’s knowledge of the risks of climate change.

headline: Inside Art Basel Miami Beach’s Most Anticipated Collaboration
text: On Monday evening, a crowd filed out of the Pérez Art Museum Miami (PAMM) after a private dinner toasting Jorge M. Pérez. At the same time, a steady stream of dancers, musicians and stage handlers flowed in for a different kind of spectacle — the first rehearsal of the artist Ryan McNamara and the musician Devonté Hynes’s collaborative, one-night-only performance, “Dimensions.” Commissioned by PAMM as part of its annual multimedia series, which partners artists with musicians, “Dimensions” has been in the works since the last Art Basel Miami Beach — but with three days until showtime, last night was the first time the full cast had been assembled. “I hadn’t even seen the stages until today,” laughed McNamara, who stole the show at last year’s fair with “ME3M,” his hybrid, Internet-themed ballet at Miami’s Grand Theater. “I think Dev said it best when he described it as a two-hour dance/soul/opera experience.”

headline: Iranian Diaspora in California
text: Iranian Diaspora in California by Javad Parsa

headline: Research Group Funded by Coca-Cola to Disband
text: A group called the Global Energy Balance Network, led by scientists and created by Coca-Cola, announced this week that it was shutting down after months of pressure from public health authorities who said that the group’s mission was to play down the link between soft drinks and obesity.

text: The dean of Columbia’s Graduate School of Journalism rebuts suggestions that journalists from the school had produced inaccurate and misleading articles on Exxon Mobil.

headline: Jeb Bush Says He Would Have Probably Skipped Climate Conference
text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Jeb Bush on Tuesday belittled President Obama’s trip to Paris for the global climate conference, saying that if he were president, he most likely would have skipped the meeting, where officials from nearly 200 nations are seeking to avert potentially catastrophic damage to the environment.

headline: Crimean Residents Still Don’t Have Power
text: Residents in the Crimean peninsula have been living without electricity since Nov. 22, when protesters blew up the power lines.

text: There were days as a kid when I was so bored, I organized my entire day around the mail delivery.

text: Photos from Greece, Burkina Faso, South Korea and Nepal.

headline: How to Cook American
text: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

headline: Mother: Television’s Favorite Role
text: Mothers are all over the small screen, both in high-profile prime-time spots and on more obscure outlets. Good mothers, indifferent mothers, confused mothers, condemnable mothers — take your pick.

headline: Review: ‘The Fiery Angel,’ Devilishly Tough Prokofiev
text: MUNICH — Occultism and masochistic obsession; demons, orgies and writhing nuns. These were some of the topics Prokofiev was wrestling with in 1923 when, deep into work on his opera “The Fiery Angel,” he married his first wife, Lina, in southern Bavaria.

headline: Washington’s Shaw Neighborhood Is Remade for Young Urbanites
text: WASHINGTON — Over time, neighborhoods rise and fall and then rise again.

headline: Pop-Up Bars Proliferate During the Holidays
text: Pop-up stores trading in Christmas trappings are commonplace in shopping malls across the country in December. Now, urban mixology has added its own peculiar twist: the seasonal cocktail bar.

headline: Scholars Unveil New Edition of Hitler’s ‘Mein Kampf’
text: BERLIN — Not since 1945, when the Allies banned the dubious work and awarded the rights to the state of Bavaria, has Hitler’s manifesto, “Mein Kampf,” been officially published in German. Bavaria had refused to release it. But under German law, its copyright expires Dec. 31, the 70th year after the author’s death.

headline: In Chinatown, A Busy Day
text: In New York’s Chinatown, Thanksgiving is a day to celebrate a marriage. The holiday allows more family members to attend because they already have a day off from work.

headline: For Some Chinese-Americans, Thanksgiving Is for Wedding Receptions
text: To many immigrants from Fujian Province in southeastern China, Thanksgiving does not mean turkey, stuffing and football. It is instead a rare day off that many use to give or attend wedding receptions.

headline: A Tour of Joel Chen’s Antiques
text: The Los Angeles design dealer favors an unpredictable mix.

text: Mr. Parker, 34, is a senior vice president at Marcus & Millichap and the district manager of its tristate region. He joined the 44-year-old brokerage firm, which specializes in commercial real estate investment sales and advisory services, in 2004.

headline: Whistle-Blower Complaint Directed at Whistle-Blower Group
text: When Lindsey Williams lost her job, the news arrived abruptly, in a voice mail message from her boss. A co-worker, Richard Renner, said he was given just an hour to hand in his keys, collect his personal effects and leave.

headline: After Passing Up David Price, Yankees Will Face Him With Red Sox
text: David Price made his major league debut at the old Yankee Stadium, in the final month of its final season. Some hitters he faced were Xavier Nady, Wilson Betemit and Ivan Rodriguez. Yes, Price goes back a long way with the Yankees, and he will go forward against them for many years, too.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls for Overhaul of Justice System
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — In the church here where, 60 years ago, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. inspired residents to boycott the local bus network, Hillary Clinton on Tuesday called for overhauling the criminal justice system, saying there is something “profoundly wrong” when black men are disproportionately stopped and searched by the police, arrested or killed.

headline: Shigeru Mizuki, Influential Japanese Cartoonist, Dies at 93
text: TOKYO — Shigeru Mizuki, an influential and widely popular Japanese cartoonist with a talent for humanizing mythical monsters and dissecting the monstrous side of humanity, died here on Monday. He was 93.

headline: Verdict Sheet From Sheldon Silver's Trial
text: A jury found the former Assembly speaker guilty on all seven counts, including fraud and extortion.

headline: Review: ‘Commedia Rapunzel,’ With a Bit of Seasonal Spice
text: The Spaghetti and Meatball Players have folded a lot of camp and not much Christmas into their new family show, “The Commedia Rapunzel: Holiday Extravaganza Pumpkin Spice Latte Edition.” Although this production has its inspired moments, it often resembles the heroine’s hair: too tangled, too long and simply too much.

headline: Clinton Pays Tribute to Rosa Parks
text: Hillary Clinton saluted Rosa Parks in Montgomery, Ala., on the 60th anniversary of Mrs. Parks’s refusal to give up her seat on a public bus.

text: If you were Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan, how would you give away $45 billion, and why?

headline: Review: Lena Hall Barrels Through Her Musical Career at Feinstein’s
text: Lena Hall wasn’t even born when Jefferson Airplane’s “White Rabbit” marched onto the airwaves on a bolero strut just in time for the Summer of Love. But her parents, artists living in the Haight Ashbury district of San Francisco, were charter members of the hipoisie in the emerald city of groovy enlightenment. And as Ms. Hall recalls in “The Villa Satori Growing Up in Haight Ashbury,” her show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, the neighborhood was still a bohemian mecca when she came along in 1980.

headline: The Questionable Ways of Albany, Exposed at Sheldon Silver’s Trial
text: Assemblywoman Amy Paulin had finished testifying for the government at the corruption trial of Sheldon Silver, offering a primer on how New York State government works, when one of Mr. Silver’s lawyers caught her by surprise.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: The Toll of Violent Anti-Abortion Speech
text: HERE are some things abortion opponents have said about Robert L. Dear Jr., the shooter accused of killing three and wounding nine at the Planned Parenthood clinic in Colorado Springs last Friday. He was just a lunatic. He wasn’t attacking Planned Parenthood, he ran in there after trying to rob a bank. My personal favorite, from the Republican presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz: He is reported to be a “transgendered leftist activist.”

headline: Review: ‘Hitchcock/Truffaut’ Revisits the Master of Suspense
text: “Psycho” (1960) was the first film I saw in a movie theater, an experience that my 7-year-old self was ill-equipped to parse. Surrounded by jittery adults, I puzzled over everything, and not just the frantic screaming that mimicked Bernard Herrmann’s devilishly clever musical cues. Why, I wondered, was Janet Leigh wandering around in her bra in the middle of the afternoon?

headline: Ted Cruz Mocks Clinton’s ‘Condom Police’
text: At a town hall meeting in Iowa, the Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz derided Hillary Clinton. He said the G.O.P. was not waging a war on women, calling that “made-up nonsense.”

headline: Ex-Citigroup Construction Executive Admits Taking $500,000 in Bribes
text: The bribes were sometimes delivered as cash-stuffed envelopes to the Citigroup executive. Other times, contractors seeking business sent checks to a fake company that the executive ran from his house. One electrical company bought him a lavish hunting trip in Alaska. Another contractor built a patio and barbecue at the executive’s home.

headline: Review: ‘Sound of Redemption’ Traces Frank Morgan’s Route From Jazz Musician to Prisoner and Back
text: In the 1950s, some jazz musicians believed they couldn’t get that Charlie Parker “happy-sad feeling without using drugs.” So says a friend of the saxophonist Frank Morgan in “Sound of Redemption,” a documentary that revels in the happy despite some seriously sad events.

headline: Negative News May Alter Statin Users’ Behavior
text: A Danish study has found that news articles that focus on the risks or adverse effects of statin drugs may lead people to stop taking the medicines, and probably contribute to increases in heart attacks and deaths.

headline: ‘Amy’ and ‘Hunting Ground’ Lead Documentary Shortlist
text: The Oscar race for best documentary feature came into sharp focus on Tuesday when the Academy released its shortlist of the 15 nonfiction films in contention.

headline: Romania’s Dancing, Drinking Bears
text: In a corner of Romania, the holiday season is ushered in by troupes of bearskin-clad revelers dancing, singing and drinking.

headline: Months After Russian Annexation, Hopes Start to Dim in Crimea
text: SHCHYOLKINO, Crimea — When residents in this typical Soviet factory town voted enthusiastically to secede from Ukraine and to become Russians, they thought the chaos and corruption that made daily life a struggle were a thing of the past.

headline: Protection Bureau’s Stormy Path to Reform the Auto Finance Industry
text: House Republicans are trying to shut down the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s attempt to regulate the $900 billion auto finance industry. It’s a political battle that just might lead to the end of the fledgling agency’s mission to regulate every nook and cranny of consumer finance.

headline: Cleveland Officer Says He Shot Tamir Rice After Fake Gun Was Pulled
text: Officer Timothy Loehmann, the rookie Cleveland patrolman who fatally shot 12-year-old Tamir Rice last year, saw the boy “reaching into his waistband” and “pulling the gun out” before firing his own weapon, the officer said in a statement released Tuesday by the local prosecutor’s office.

headline: The Hard-Working Italian Origins of the Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree
text: Dressed in overalls and jackets, wearing work boots and hats, the men lined up five dozen strong on Christmas Eve 1931 for that week’s pay at a Midtown Manhattan construction site.

headline: A Young Islander Gears Up for the Rangers
text: SYOSSET, N.Y. — The Islanders have found lineup stability leading into Wednesday’s first game against the first-place but struggling Rangers at Barclays Center.

headline: Economic Report Adds to Brazil’s Mounting Woes
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — It keeps getting messier.

headline: Student Protesters Self-Absorbed and Narcissistic, Oklahoma College President Says
text: The president of an evangelical college has jumped into the latest campus culture wars with a complaint about a student who said he felt “victimized” by a sermon on love, and should not have had to listen to it.

headline: Janet DiFiore, Westchester Prosecutor, Is Nominated as New York’s Chief Judge
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Tuesday nominated Janet DiFiore, an experienced prosecutor and fellow Westchester County resident, to New York’s highest judicial post.

headline: ISIS Promise of Statehood Falling Far Short, Ex-Residents Say
text: SANLIURFA, Turkey — After the Syrian government stopped paying him, a technician who had spent two decades pumping the country’s oil received an enticing offer: do the same work for the jihadists of the Islamic State — starting at three times the salary.

headline: Receding Waters in California Expose Artifacts to Plundering
text: CLEARLAKE, Calif. — Along cracked-mud shorelines and beneath tangles of weeds on parched riverbanks, artifacts and archaeological sites that have rested in peace beneath the water for hundreds and even thousands of years have become increasingly visible as the state’s drought has lingered, leaving them susceptible to plunder by opportunistic looters.

headline: Replacing a Green Card, and a Home
text: When Elda M. Kriss was released from the hospital in September 2013, she hoped to return to the life she had built over more than three decades in the United States. Instead, she found that everything was gone.

headline: In Philadelphia, a Feel-Good Moment for Kobe Bryant, if a Brief One
text: PHILADELPHIA — Kobe Bryant was feeling nostalgic Monday night, so he drove around and visited some of his favorite childhood haunts, including the playgrounds where he honed his game. He recalled how he went scoreless one summer in the Sonny Hill League. He was 11 years old.

headline: Dave Roberts, Dodgers’ New Manager, Reflects on Team’s Ties to Breaking Barriers
text: LOS ANGELES — When Waymon Roberts moved his family around Marine bases, from Okinawa to California, Hawaii and North Carolina, he knew it was not easy, especially for his children. So he regularly repeated a mantra that can be useful for military families.

headline: Bipartisan Talks Yield $300 Billion Highway Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional negotiators clinched a deal on Tuesday for a five-year, roughly $300 billion transportation bill that would inject badly needed investments into the nation’s deteriorated highways and other infrastructure and also reopen the Export-Import Bank.

headline: Maurice Strong, Environmental Champion, Dies at 86
text: Maurice Strong, a former industrialist and confessed ecological sinner who was in the vanguard of placing environmentalism on the world’s agenda as a high-ranking United Nations official, died on Saturday. He was 86.

headline: Bronx Man Stabs Wife and Flees With Their Daughter, Police Say
text: A Bronx man stabbed his wife several times on Tuesday, then fled with their 3-year-old daughter, the police said, prompting the authorities to issue an Amber Alert.

headline: Worldwide Support for Ending AIDS
text: World AIDS Day celebrations around the globe.

headline: The Marshall Islands Are Disappearing
text: Most of the Marshall Islands rise less than six feet above sea level. For the residents, the destructive power of the rising seas is already an inescapable part of daily life.

headline: California: State Falls Short of Water Goal
text: For the first time since emergency drought regulations took effect this year, Californians failed to meet the 25 percent water reduction target set by Gov. Jerry Brown. Residents reduced their water used in October by 22.2 percent compared with 2013, the state’s lowest conservation rate since mandatory water reductions began in the summer. Over all, residents remain on a pace to meet the 25 percent goal, having saved 27.1 percent over 2013 in the five months from June to October. State water officials have said saving water will be more difficult during the winter because Californians used less water during the winter in years past. They said they expected conservation rates to remain lower during the colder months. “I was relieved at the numbers,” Felicia Marcus, chairwoman of the State Water Resources Control Board, said of October’s 22 percent figure. The emergency drought regulations will be in effect through February, but officials are considering a new set of emergency regulations if the drought continues.

headline: U.S. Plans to Counter Arms Breach by Russia
text: WASHINGTON — Frustrated by Russia’s refusal to address the Obama administration’s concerns that it has violated a landmark arms control accord, the Pentagon is moving ahead with plans to strengthen defenses in Europe against Moscow’s military programs, including the threat posed by cruise missiles, a senior Defense Department official told Congress on Tuesday.

headline: The Chicago Police Scandal
text: The cover-up that began 13 months ago when a Chicago police officer executed 17-year-old Laquan McDonald on a busy street might well have included highly ranked officials who ordered subordinates to conceal information. But the conspiracy of concealment exposed last week when the city, under court order, finally released a video of the shooting could also be seen as a kind of autonomic response from a historically corrupt law enforcement agency that is well versed in the art of hiding misconduct, brutality — and even torture.

headline: Judge Gives Push to Deadlocked Jury in Massey Mine Safety Trial
text: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — On its seventh full day of deliberations, a federal jury said Tuesday that it was at an impasse in the trial of Donald L. Blankenship, the West Virginia businessman who led Massey Energy Company when 29 people were killed in a coal mine.

headline: Luc Bondy, Swiss-Born Theater and Opera Director, Dies at 67
text: Luc Bondy, a Swiss-born stage director whose productions, known for their shrewd probing of human behavior and attention to acting subtlety, were featured in Europe’s most prestigious theaters and opera houses, died on Saturday. He was 67.

headline: Review: Jane Martin’s ‘H2O’ Explores the Interdependence of the Sacred and the Profane
text: Jake Abadjian became famous overnight playing the big-screen superhero Dawnwalker — as Jake describes him, “an ordinary cabdriver born without a tongue.” Yes, Dawnwalker is mute; no, Jake didn’t toil for years onstage before stumbling into stardom. But his three blockbusters did make many millions for DreamWorks.

headline: Fabulous Deli Delicacy
text: Administrivial Stocking Stuffer Alert! St. Martin’s Press has released a new book of puzzles from Will Shortz’s favorite constructors, just in time for you to start thinking about what to get your favorite solver. You can read more about the book here.

headline: American Convicted in Peru Plot Plans to Return to U.S.
text: LIMA, Peru —  Lori Berenson, an American who has completed a 20-year sentence for aiding a rebel group that planned to take members of Peru’s Congress hostage, could be deported as early as Wednesday, a government official here said.

headline: Yemen: Red Cross Worker Is Held by Kidnappers
text: The International Committee of the Red Cross said that two of its staff members were abducted by gunmen as they drove to work on Tuesday in Sana, Yemen’s capital. One of the workers, a Yemeni man, was later released, but the second, a Tunisian woman, was still being held, the group said in a statement. It was the latest in a series of attacks in Yemen against the Red Cross, one of the few international humanitarian organizations that has continued operations in Yemen since a civil war started in March. The Red Cross said it did not know who was responsible for the kidnappings.

headline: Cuomo Tempers Hopes for Tougher Ethics Laws
text: For those advocating ethics reform in New York’s scandal-sullied capital, the  conviction of Sheldon Silver, the once-untouchable State Assembly speaker, on corruption charges should have marked a permanent change in the tides — the beginning of the end for public officials who used their posts for private gain.

headline: On Tape at Skeloses’ Trial, Son Talks of Senator’s Pull
text: Senator Dean G. Skelos’s son sounded as if he thought he had a pretty good plan.

headline: Kean University Graduate Accused in Threats Against Blacks
text: A black graduate of Kean University in New Jersey was accused on Tuesday of fabricating threats on Twitter against black staff members and students that led officials to heighten security on campus, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Scream Queens’ Season 1, Episode 11: Unbreakable Dean Munsch
text: Did anything of substance happen on this week’s episode of “Scream Queens”? Of course, using the word “substance” in connection with this show is an incongruity, but you know what I mean. We learned that Dean Munsch, whom the Chanels tried to kill several times, is apparently immune to puffer fish venom and to being frozen to death in a cryotherapy chamber. We learned that Pete has apparently murdered someone. But did the story move forward much? Did any major characters or even minor ones die? Did the episode have some redeeming value, like being amusing? No. Maybe this should have been a 10-episode series. (Two more to go.)

headline: Yahoo’s Board Is Said to Weigh Selling Off Core Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The board of Yahoo will discuss potentially selling off the beleaguered Internet company’s core business during a series of meetings this week, people briefed on the plans said on Tuesday.

headline: Singapore Police Again Arrest Suspect Accused of Fixing Soccer Matches
text: The Singapore police have again arrested a man accused of running one of the world’s largest soccer match-fixing rings, just days after a court in the city-state had ordered his release.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
text: Gather round, viewers, as Rockefeller Center flips the switch on its big, beautiful Christmas tree. Then get out your tissues as you watch animals fight for their lives. And there are apparently no words for the season finale of “Empire.”

text: What is your perfect childhood holiday memory? For New Yorkers, it might be seeing the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall, going to midnight Mass, large family gatherings or braving the crowds in Times Square for the New Year’s ball drop.

headline: Putin’s Syrian Misadventure
text: When President Vladimir Putin of Russia announced he was setting up an air base in the middle of Syria to take on the Islamic State and bolster President Bashar al-Assad, more than a few analysts and politicians praised his forceful, game-changing, strategic brilliance, suggesting that Putin was crazy like a fox. Some of us thought he was just crazy.

headline: An Opening in the War Against AIDS
text: International health agencies continue to lose ground in the struggle against H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Each year the number of people who become infected outpaces the number of people starting treatment for the virus. That is discouraging given that the opportunities to control the spread of the virus have never been better, scientifically and financially. It is imperative to move aggressively to change the trajectory of this epidemic.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Worst Budget Riders
text: The short-term spending bill that is financing federal government operations will expire on Dec. 11, and unless Congress and President Obama agree on another extension or a final bill, there will be a shutdown.

headline: Anyone but Ted Cruz
text: You’re evaluating candidates for an open job in your company, and you come across one who makes a big impression.

headline: Donald Trump’s Appeal
text: The continuing strength of Donald J. Trump’s bid for the Republican presidential nomination has dumbfounded his own party, the media, political scientists, donors and pollsters.

headline: The Real Problem With Police Video
text: A CHICAGO police officer shot and killed a teenager named Laquan McDonald in October of last year, but most of us learned about Mr. McDonald only last week, after a judge ordered the release of police video footage of his death. That is also when prosecutors finally brought first-degree murder charges against the officer. Clearly, such footage has considerable power.

headline: A Fight Over Fish
text: Is the F.D.A.'s approval of genetically altered salmon dangerous or a sign of scientific progress?
