text: Julia Wolfe’s galvanizing score — alternately clamorous, haunting, exhilarating and sometimes all three simultaneously — provides a sturdy musical spine for “Steel Hammer,” a theatrical meditation on the legend of John Henry being presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday.

headline: Fox Neighbor
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We’ve discussed constructor signatures over the past few days, and I have to admit that seeing David J. Kahn’s byline occasionally sets off a knee-jerk response in me that sounds something like this: “Oh dear, who died?”

headline: The Right Stuff
text: Administrivial Poor Excuse For a Blogger Alert! Hi all, I apologize for the mix up, which delayed the blog for Martin Ashwood-Smith’s post and inadvertently published another one with spoilers. I was sick yesterday and messed this up. Additional apologies to Mr. Ashwood-Smith for delaying his post, and let’s just pretend you didn’t see the Saturday post, which comes out tonight.

headline: Review: In David Mamet’s ‘China Doll,’ Al Pacino as an Urban Warrior in Winter
text: No matter what his salary is, it seems safe to say that Christopher Denham is the most underpaid actor on Broadway. Mr. Denham — a young man with, I sincerely hope, a very resilient nervous system — is one of a cast of two in “China Doll,” the saggy new play by David Mamet that was finally opened to critics on Wednesday night at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, and he is onstage for almost the entire show.

headline: Review: ‘Dream/Killer,’ a Father’s Battle to Free His Son in a Wrongful Conviction
text: I won’t reveal the end of “dream/killer,” but I will predict what you’ll feel after watching it: This documentary elicits large measures of incredulity, frustration and astonishment.

headline: Donald Trump and Ben Carson Face a Foreign Policy Test Before a Republican Jewish Group
text: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump and Ben Carson may not have reduced doubts about their seriousness as leaders and their understanding of global affairs on Thursday as they delivered meandering speeches to one of the country’s most influential Republican Jewish organizations.

headline: Dreaming of a Southern Life, but First, Her Education
text: Moments of calm are rare and fleeting in Tomar Coke’s home in the Bronx. If her two sons are peacefully watching television or playing with action figures, getting along in any way, she knows a clash is imminent.

headline: Connecticut Craft Distillers Are in a Growth Spurt
text: On the list of Connecticut-made food and drink, already bulging with cheese, eggs, beer, beef and bacon (to name just a few), one category is often overlooked: handcrafted liquor.

headline: Automation Is a Job Engine, New Research Says
text: The fear that technology is poised to kill jobs in unprecedented numbers is widely prevelent these days. Nothing is likely to ease that anxiety much, but a new research paper might prompt some second thoughts.

headline: An Officer Who Trained for the Worst and Faced It: ‘This Was Actually Happening’
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — He had trained for active-shooter situations. He recalled the drills where trainers barraged officers with everything they could — sounds, bright lights, smells — to overwhelm them.

text: John Martin became the first full-time dance critic at a major American publication when he joined The New York Times in 1927. Before his appointment, music or theater critics wrote on dance, the stepchild of the arts, satisfying no one.

text: The New York Times film critics review “Chi-Raq,” “Creed” and “The Good Dinosaur.”

headline: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 4-10
text: When you consider the ingenious ways that marine creatures maneuver, you have to feel sorry for humans. Walking seems so, well, pedestrian.

headline: Bill to Repeal Health Law Passes Senate
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved legislation on Thursday night that would repeal President Obama’s landmark health care law, a goal of Republicans since the law was adopted in March 2010.

headline: ‘Dietrich & Riefenstahl,’ by Karin Wieland
text: The German historian Karin Wieland buries useful information on the acknowledgments page of “Dietrich & Riefenstahl: Hollywood, Berlin, and a Century in Two Lives.” She reports that her original manuscript “contained at least three additional books” before her German editor set about pruning.

headline: ‘Frank Stella: A Retrospective,’ by Michael Auping
text: A professor I know teaches that a work of art will give clues to how it wants to be discussed: It will suggest whether to dwell on its sense or its structure, whether to meet it with passion or calculation.

headline: Aftermath of the Massacre in San Bernardino
text: Police officers sorted through evidence and mourners gathered after the shootings in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline: New York’s Week in Pictures: Dec. 4
text: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a ceremony for birds, the trial of Sheldon Silver and a museum of feelings.

headline: Presidential Candidates on Gun Violence
text: All of the Democratic candidates want new gun laws, while nearly all Republicans are against additional restrictions they see as harmful to Second Amendment rights.

headline: ‘Notorious RBG: The Life and Times of Ruth Bader Ginsburg’
text: Clark Kent had Superman. Ruth Bader Ginsburg has Notorious R.B.G. For 80 of her 82 years, the Supreme Court justice was known for being brilliant, reserved and a little dry. Then in 2013, the Internet gave her a super-hip-nerd alter ego. On a Tumblr created by a law student, Shana Knizhnik, fans posted ­photoshopped tributes to Ginsburg. In one frequently shared image, she wore a crown with the caption “Can’t Spell Truth Without Ruth.” She also appeared as a bobblehead doll, a tattoo on a bicep, a decal on a fingernail, and a baby wearing a huge pair of glasses.

headline: Molly Crabapple’s ‘Drawing Blood’
text: As her fast-paced autobiography attests, the artist Molly Crabapple was a quintessential wild child, irrepressible, pouty and proud, born determined and angry. At 12, she discovered punk rock. At 17, she traveled to Europe alone, slept in the famous Shakespeare & Company bookshop in Paris, walked the streets of Fez with her sketch pad, an artist-­wanderer, claiming for herself the space formerly reserved for men.

headline: ‘Food Whore,’ by Jessica Tom
text: Please allow me to introduce Michael Saltz, a man of wealth and no taste. Not bad taste — no taste at all. One day he finds that he can no longer detect sour, salty, sweet and bitter. This is inconvenient because he is supposed to be the restaurant critic of The New York Times.

headline: ‘About Women,’ by Lisa Alther and Françoise Gilot
text: “About Women” should inaugurate a series in which accomplished women of different backgrounds talk candidly about their lives. This book pairs an American novelist, Lisa Alther, the author of “Kinflicks,” and a French-born painter, Françoise Gilot, the author of another masterpiece, “Life With Picasso.”

headline: ‘The 613,’ by Archie Rand
text: Let’s hear it, in the pages of this liberal, freethinking bastion of progress, for God.

headline: What to Watch Friday
text: Stream, sing along, repeat: Bill Murray and company serenade the holidays in “A Very Murray Christmas.” A heartbroken Christmas-tree salesman searches for love in Brooklyn. And Kristen Stewart adds another award to her mantel for “Clouds of Sils Maria.”

headline: ‘My History: A Memoir of Growing Up,’ by Antonia Fraser
text: When she arrived as a boarder at the Godolphin School in 1944, at the age of 12, Antonia Pakenham — who would grow up to be the novelist and historian Lady Antonia Fraser, Dame of the British Empire, mother of six, grandmother of 18, wife of the Tory M.P. Hugh Fraser and, later, wife of the playwright Harold Pinter — made the startling discovery that she was “not really a girl.” That is, having just spent four years learning Greek and Latin at a school for boys (mostly) called the Dragon, next door to her family’s home in Oxford, England, she excelled at ancient languages and at the knock-’em-sock-’em sport of rugby, but was completely unschooled in conventional girlish behavior. In her new memoir, “My History,” she recalls, “I was like Kipling’s Mowgli in ‘The Jungle Book,’ the feral child who had been brought up by wolves and had difficulty adjusting to existence among human beings.”

headline: Bee Wilson’s ‘First Bite: How We Learn to Eat’
text: For a long time, the British food journalist Bee Wilson automatically craved something indulgent before boarding a train. In “First Bite: How We Learn to Eat,” she traces this instinct to a ritual she had with her father when she was a teenager. Her parents had just split up, and whenever her dad would send Wilson on a train back to her mother’s house, he’d buy her a magazine and a box of chocolate-coated malted milk balls, something that, before her parents’ divorce, would have been deemed a special-occasion treat. She felt powerless to refuse the candy, even as she was struggling with a disconcerting weight gain. It took Wilson years to realize that her father’s gesture was as much about making him feel like “the generous provider” as it was to reward her with a happy sugar high. She writes: “To give a child the things she loves to eat bestows a heroic glow. It feels almost as wonderful as eating.”

headline: ‘Chapter and Verse: New Order, Joy Division and Me,’ by Bernard Sumner
text: The glamorous rock-star life, circa 1983: The gawky Manchester kids in New Order visit the legendary New York disco Funhouse to shoot a video for their new single, “Confusion.” They hang with their producer, Arthur Baker, and the superstar D.J. Jellybean Benitez, watching from the booth while the crowd moves. It’s poignant how dazed New Order looks in this video — a couple of years earlier, they were your basic mopey indie twits, and here they are making the scene as their music plays at the world’s hippest dance club. Yet the most poignant sight is that of the singer Bernard Sumner, who spends the first half of the clip wearing deck shorts and white tube socks. It’s impossible to imagine any other British new wave singer of the MTV era dressing this way for a quick dash to the hotel ice machine, much less for a video.

headline: ‘Hear My Sad Story,’ by Richard Polenberg
text: Long before she died in 1952, Frankie Baker was quoted as saying, “It’s funny, but most people think of me as being dead a good many years.” Most people today would probably be surprised to learn that she was ever alive.

headline: ‘Sinatra: The Chairman’ and ‘Sinatra’s Century’
text: Anyone who wants to contend with 20th-century popular music, or popular music, or the 20th century, has to contend with Frank Sinatra.

headline: ‘The 6:41 to Paris,’ by Jean-Philippe Blondel
text: If you travel alone on French trains, the seat next to you in second class is either empty or occupied by someone you don’t know. Or do you? Given the choice of standing for over two hours from ­Troyes to Paris, Philippe Leduc excuses himself and takes the last free seat in the carriage. Only then does Cécile Duffaut look up to see who has invaded her space.

headline: ‘The Big Book of Animals of the World,’ and More
text: Even as children these days are beckoned by new forms of digital storytelling, nothing quite equals the immersive experience of a bigger-than-usual book enriched with visual, tactile and even the occasional kinesthetic extras. These five large-format books invite young readers to look and touch, linger and explore. (Grown-ups welcome, too!)

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Just as I naturally consider how I would survive if there was an earthquake, now I have added mental contingencies for a shooting — and THAT is a sad state of affairs!”

headline: Scott Weiland, Singer Who Helped Found Stone Temple Pilots, Dies at 48
text: Scott Weiland, whose mercurial vocal style was a signature of the rock band he helped start, the Stone Temple Pilots, and later of the band Velvet Revolver, died on Thursday in Bloomington, Minn. He was 48.

headline: Humans and Animals: A Complicated Bond
text: Jayanti Seiler is not shy about expressing her feelings for animals. But when she meets the subjects of her project “Of One and the Other,” she keeps those feelings to herself.

text: THREE months after starting college, Brooke Evans found herself without a place to live. She was 19.

headline: Republicans’ Climate Change Denial Denial
text: Future historians — if there are any future historians — will almost surely say that the most important thing happening in the world during December 2015 was the climate talks in Paris. True, nothing agreed to in Paris will be enough, by itself, to solve the problem of global warming. But the talks could mark a turning point, the beginning of the kind of international action needed to avert catastrophe.

headline: No, Donald Trump Won’t Win
text: A little while ago I went rug shopping. Four rugs were laid out on the floor and among them was one with a pink motif that was dazzlingly beautiful. It was complex and sophisticated. If you had asked me at that moment which rug I wanted, I would have said the pink one.

headline: Russia’s Fury Over Montenegro and NATO
text: It is a measure of how cold the West’s relations with Russia have become that NATO’s membership invitation to Montenegro — a small, poor Balkan state with a military force of 2,000 and no strategic significance save putting the last bit of Europe’s Mediterranean coastline under the alliance — would provoke furious cries of “provocation” and “encirclement” from the Kremlin.

headline: A Battle in San Bernardino
text: Riverside, Calif. — IN the spring, I was asked to write a story called “Bang or Whimper,” about the end of the world.

headline: Tough Talk and a Cowardly Vote on Terrorism
text: Investigators now believe that what initially seemed a workplace shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., was a well-planned attack by a married couple with at least some contact with Islamic extremists.

headline: The Latest Attack on Climate Science
text: Earlier this year, scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration published research contradicting earlier reports that global warming had slowed in the past decade. But Representative Lamar Smith, Republican of Texas and chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, is accusing the agency of rushing data to publication, and is demanding access to the internal communications of its employees.

headline: 9 Samsung Executives Are Subject of Insider Trading Investigation
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean financial regulators on Friday said they were investigating whether nine executives from Samsung, the country’s largest conglomerate, used insider trading to profit illegally from a merger of two subsidiaries.

headline: Audi Executive Resigns After Suspension Over VW Emissions Scandal
text: FRANKFURT — An executive linked to Volkswagen’s emissions scandal has resigned his post as a top manager of the Audi luxury car division, the company said late Thursday.

headline: 1965: An American Space Odyssey
text: The European edition of the New York Herald Tribune tracked the flight of Gemini-7, a spacecraft manned by Frank F. Borman and James A. Lovell Jr. that blasted into orbit on Dec. 4, 1965. When it returned nearly two weeks later, Gemini-7 had set 11 records for manned spaceflights. Below, a few clips from our archives, from before liftoff to the spacecraft’s return.

text: See what Adrianne Curry, Eva Marcille and Brittani Kline did after their America’s Next Top Model win.

text: In the continuing debate over how to stop mass killings in the United States, Australia has become a familiar touchstone.

headline: Can a Christmas Sweater Be Fashionable? Gucci and Prada Say Yes
text: The holiday season allows for sartorial excessiveness. Break out the ugly sweater with the nog.

headline: New Apps and Services for Renters
text: Of the many things that make New York renters miserable, hunting for an apartment ranks pretty high. Getting out of a lease early is up there, too.

text: Consider it a done deal.

headline: America’s Next Top Model, Deconstructed
text: And so it has come to an end. After 289 episodes, 22 seasons and 12 years; after airing in 100 countries, and inspiring 20 foreign spinoffs from Brazil to Finland to Taiwan; after acquiring 7,903,827 likes for their Facebook page and 254,000 Instagram followers; after providing the Urban Dictionary with assorted new verbs and adjectives, including “smize” (smile with your eyes) and “flawsome” (awesome because of the flaws), after Friday night, “America’s Next Top Model” will be done.

headline: Ryan Seacrest: The Mogul Next Door
text: “Is he ever not working?” Kevin Systrom, the 31-year-old chief executive officer and co-founder of Instagram, recently asked about his good friend Ryan Seacrest. The question, to be clear, was rhetorical.

headline: Aishti Foundation Puts Shimmering Works Amid the Turmoil of Beirut
text: BEIRUT — On a warm evening this fall, the cultural scene here was in full bloom. Members of the international art world, Lebanese government ministers and fashion executives had gathered to celebrate the grand opening of the Aishti Foundation, a private museum showcasing the growing contemporary art collection of Tony Salamé, the founder of Aishti, a Lebanese luxury retailer.

headline: The Modern Meeting: Call In, Turn Off, Tune Out
text: The minute Marvin Avilez gets on a conference call, he is on his hands and knees.

headline: How Do You Try to Reduce Your Impact on the Environment?
text: For the world to slow down or stop human-generated climate change, governments and corporations will need to enact major policy shifts. But still, each of us plays a small role in Earth’s overall health — through our everyday decisions like turning on or off the lights, buying and reusing clothing or electronics, littering and recycling, or turning up or down the air-conditioning and the heat.

headline: ‘The Washingtons,’ by Flora Fraser
text: One of the great challenges of setting down the history of marginalized people is how to amass enough information to provide a clear picture of subjects who didn’t write letters themselves or only appeared in the letters of others, who didn’t enter the public realm through the legal system or gain notoriety in other ways. It’s hard to imagine two people less marginalized than George and Martha Washington, a couple at the very pinnacle of society in the nation George helped to create. Martha lived this very public life with him, garnering enormous respect.

headline: Patti Smith’s ‘M Train’
text: Many people, especially those who came of age in the 1970s, view Patti Smith as an inimitable punk-rock poet with an edgy, unforgettable voice. But she is also a regular person. Her new memoir, “M Train,” can be seen as a plea to acknowledge her as one. Like the rest of us ordinary folk, she endures the frustrations and banalities of everyday life — keeping despair at bay with TV crime shows, cats and caffeine. She identifies unapologetically with the detectives on “The Killing” and “CSI: Miami.” I “adopt their ways,” she explains, “suffer their failures and consider their movements long after an episode ends, whether in real time or rerun.” Her cats are not cuddly and decorative but authentic. One wakes her in the morning by throwing up on the edge of her pillow. Her drug of choice is black coffee. Much of “M Train” takes place in different cafes, and the reader can map the effect of the substance on her imagination. With each sip her mind awakens and her ruminations deepen.

headline: ‘St. Marks Is Dead,’ by Ada Calhoun
text: New York breeds mourners. If you grow up anywhere in the city, there is a good chance your childhood memories will be bundled with tangible goods and sold to the highest bidder before you reach adulthood. You won’t be invited to the memorial service — New York runs a red light past sentiment. The city grows on the frictional power of millions chasing The Now. Money is New York’s longest-­running Now, and it probably just ate your favorite sandwich shop, the apartment you first rented or your go-to record store. Mine disappeared a few weeks ago — it was on St. Marks Place and was unassuming in aspect and name: Sounds.

headline: ‘The Catskills: Its History and How It Changed America’
text: In 1824 a group of businessmen opened the Catskill Mountain House, America’s first grand resort hotel, in a spectacular but logistically challenging location at the top of a ledge about 1,500 feet above the Hudson Valley hamlet of Palenville, N.Y. Not long after, the promising young ­British-born painter Thomas Cole, sent to the environs of the Mountain House by a patron, produced “The Falls of the Kaaterskill,” a dramatized rendering of the leading natural wonder in the hotel’s vicinity. This was a big event in the cultural history of the United States. Finally, half a century after the Declaration of Independence, there was a distinctively American form of artistic expression: the depiction of pristine and forbidding wilderness.

headline: Roger Angell’s ‘This Old Man’
text: The author and editor Roger Angell, who has had a long, distinguished career, is principally celebrated for his unparalleled sports writing. Angell writes about baseball the way M.F.K. Fisher did about food, as a metaphor for life’s complexities of desire, defeat, utility and beauty.

headline: Chief of House Science Panel Picks Battle Over Climate Paper
text: In Paris, representatives from nearly 200 countries are discussing how to fight climate change. But in Washington, some congressional leaders continue to wage a battle over climate science itself.

headline: Your Friday Briefing

headline: ‘Clementine: The Life of Mrs. Winston Churchill,’ by Sonia Purnell
text: When Winston Churchill took office as prime minister of Britain in May 1940, Nazi Germany had brought Continental Europe under its domination, and it seemed as if, barring a miracle, Britain would be next. Churchill couldn’t promise a miracle, he told the House of Commons: “I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat.” He forgot to mention a possibly more potent weapon: his wife, Clementine, the subject of Sonia Purnell’s thorough and engrossing (if occasionally overdramatized) biography.

headline: As Aging Population Grows, So Do Robotic Health Aides
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The ranks of older and frail adults are growing rapidly in the developed world, raising alarms about how society is going to help them take care of themselves in their own homes.

headline: Renewal of Export-Import Bank Stings Conservative Republicans
text: Score one for the Republican establishment.

text: Updated at 8:30 a.m.

headline: Online Classes Appeal More to the Affluent
text: Free online educational courses may not be democratizing education as much as proponents believe, a new study reports.

headline: German Parliament Votes to Send Military Assistance to Fight ISIS
text: BERLIN — The German Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Friday to send reconnaissance planes, a frigate and midair fueling capacity to the Middle East to support the campaign against the Islamic State in Syria, although German forces will not be involved in direct combat like airstrikes.

headline: In ‘The Wiz Live!’ on NBC, a Search for More in the Emerald City
text: “Empire” syndrome has now become so dire that NBC finally went and got its own lion. This one didn’t run a record label, suffer a major medical misdiagnosis, or spend an hour of television in prison alongside a cannibal.

headline: Britain to Extend Lloyds Share Sale for 6 Months
text: LONDON — The British government said on Friday that it would extend a plan to sell its stake in the Lloyds Banking Group for six months as it prepares to exit ownership of the lender as early as next year.

headline: Morning Agenda: Avon Said to Discuss Selling North American Business
text: AVON SAID TO DISCUSS SELLING NORTH AMERICAN BUSINESS | Avon Products is in talks to sell its North American business to Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm,Michael J. de la Merced and Leslie Picker report in DealBook.

headline: ‘How To,’ ‘Variations on a Rectangle’ and ‘The Art of Typewriting’
text: Although they take different approaches, these three books are profoundly enmeshed in words, images and meanings. While two are wide-ranging compilations by contemporary masters of commercial graphic design, the third explores the visual possibilities offered by the most rudimentary of typographical tools. As a young designer, I was taught that everything communicates, that nothing is mute. These books raised new questions for me about meaning — whether it is fundamentally local and whether it is indeed possible to cleave meaning from words.

headline: A Few House Democrats to Attend Prayer Services at U.S. Mosques
text: A small number of House Democrats will attend prayer services at mosques on Friday in what is intended to be a show of solidarity with American Muslims.

headline: Bribery Confession in China Calls Into Question Integrity of College Admissions
text: HONG KONG — The children of the wealthy and well-connected in China enjoy enormous educational advantages, gaining access to elite kindergartens, primary schools and tutors beyond the reach of most Chinese families. But strict meritocracy was thought to reign at one crucial stage: college admission. To gain a spot in a top Chinese university and a ticket to a prosperous life afterward, a student needed a high score on the country’s famously difficult national college entrance examination, not a father with a thick wallet.

headline: Firebomb Attack on Cairo Nightclub Kills at Least 16
text: CAIRO — A firebomb attack on a nightclub in central Cairo early Friday killed at least 16 people and wounded three others after a dispute involving staff members at the club, Egyptian security officials said.

headline: Donald Trump’s Speech to Jewish Group Is Criticized in Israel

headline: Taliban Say They Will Release Recording of Leader to Prove He Is Alive
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban officials on Friday strenuously denied claims that their leader, Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, had been killed or wounded and promised to soon release an audio recording of him to prove he is still alive.

headline: Ted Cruz to Discuss Gun Rights at Iowa Shooting Range

headline: A Guide to Shopping America’s Biggest Malls
text: Malls are ever-popular standbys when it comes to holiday shopping, but some are so expansive in their offerings that they have become tourist destinations in and of themselves. With that in mind, we’ve shared the scoop on the five biggest malls in the country (as measured by square feet of gross leasable area according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, the global trade association for the shopping center industry). Here is the lowdown on the shopping, the amenities and where to eat and sleep during your retail getaway.

headline: Familiar Ground
text: In August, I went back to Italy for a family reunion. I’m part Welsh and part Italian, but growing up I lived in Italy. My earliest memories are of the farm where we lived and of the piazza at Vernole: There were horses and carts and Lamborghinis, barking dogs, leather-faced men and women dressed in black. My father had died recently, and in keeping with Italian inheritance law, our property in Salento, right on the heel of Italy, had to be split among all the siblings. There are six of us, and it’s not often that we can all get together. Because my son, Sean, was about to go to college, I thought it would be nice to bring him along as well, an opportunity to spend some time together.

headline: ‘Snowflakes’
text: Poetry and walking each invite a kind of meditation. In this poem, the contemplation of snowflakes — the precise seeing of the external landscape — gives way to the landscape of the speaker’s psyche.

headline: How to Skin a Cat
text: ‘‘Go with the grain of the hair,’’ says Anthony Eddy, a taxidermist who has worked on house cats, bobcats and mountain lions. The cleanest of the many ways to skin a cat begins with a so-called dorsal cut. Start at the bottom of the skull, and cut a straight line to the base of the tail along the spine. ‘‘Always use a sharp blade,’’ says Eddy, who prefers a carbon steel scalpel. Peel the skin back as you would an orange. Trim carefully around the paws, mouth, nose and eyes. This is obviously not work for the squeamish, but to make a lifelike remembrance of an animal means doing things that make its death inescapable.

headline: In Other Countries, You’re as Likely to Be Killed by a Falling Object as by a Gun
text: Two young campers were sleeping in Yosemite Valley this August when a tree branch snapped and fell on their tent, killing them both. “We don’t know what caused the limb to fall,” said the park’s spokeswoman, Jodi Bailey. “It seems like just a freak accident.”

headline: The Legend and Lore of Notre-Dame de Reims
text: The story goes that in the 13th century, when three great French cathedrals were being built — Notre-Dame de Paris, Notre-Dame de Chartres and Notre-Dame de Reims — the builders of Notre-Dame de Reims, determined to achieve primacy over the other two and perhaps employing a bit of industrial espionage, managed to make their massive edifice just a little bit more massive than the other two. As in, a few extra feet.

text: BEIJING — China held its second-ever National Constitution Day on Friday, when citizens are supposed to renew their loyalty to the Constitution that both enshrines the Communist Party’s power and promises freedom of expression and other rights — so long as that power is not challenged.

headline: Benicio Del Toro on What ‘Sicario’ Got Right (and Wrong)
text: Natural-born brooder and a man in possession of Hollywood’s slinkiest pair of bedroom eyes, Benicio Del Toro fits seamlessly into characters who at a moment’s notice might either pull a shiv or erupt into twitchy, maniacal laughter. In Denis Villeneuve’s drug war opus, “Sicario,” it is hard to fathom any other actor as Alejandro, a tormented Mexican ex-prosecutor turned avenger who alternately menaces and protects the F.B.I. agent played by Emily Blunt. Mr. Del Toro’s performance has foisted him into Oscar contention for best supporting actor, a category he won in 2001, for his role in “Traffic.” He was nominated again in 2004 for “21 Grams.”

headline: 1890: King William Laid in His Grave
text: THE HAGUE — The Hague is teeming to-night [Dec. 4] with joyous crowds after the burial of the last of its Orange Kings, which was, in point of fact, a brilliant pageant. The population, amounting to 183,000, reached this morning to 400,000 by the influx of foreign Princes and their suites, crowds of Belgians, Germans, Luxemburgers and Dutch provincials; 25,000 visitors came from Amsterdam alone, and many spent the night in the streets, finding no lodgings. Many of the streets were decked with tricolor flags, and the balconies and windows were decorated with black hangings. Wooden stands for sightseers were erected in all the streets, in the shop fronts and even on the decks of the barges on the canals, and places were paid for at extraordinary prices. An Englishman gave 300 florins for a window. The procession formed, one mile long, and taking seventy-five minutes to pass a given point, the principal features were the muffled drums, the military bands playing Chopin’s and Handel’s funeral dirges. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 5, 1890

headline: Norfolk Southern Rejects $28 Billion Bid From Canadian Pacific

headline: Nick Sandow, of ‘Orange Is the New Black,’ at Home

Set in front of a window wall overlooking the neighbors’ backyards, the tub is the focal point of a sight line running from the second-floor living room at the front of the house, through the stair landing, to the master bedroom and the open bathroom.

headline: A Grim News Playbook in Repeated Mass Killings

There had been another shooting, this time in San Bernardino, Calif., he said. There was not much information, but she would have to break away and relay it to viewers immediately.

headline: Using Card and Board Games to Keep Minds Sharp
text: MARK A. WIEDER began playing chess at age 8. Now the owner of a consulting firm in New Jersey, Mr. Wieder, 65, played competitively throughout high school and college. According to the United States Chess Federation, he is among the top 5 percent of federation members age 65 and older.

headline: ‘The Spectacle of Skill: Selected Writings of Robert Hughes’
text: Robert Hughes was a large, ruddy, passionate man with a mordant, propulsive prose style, an acid sense of humor and a keen appreciation for the ridiculous in American culture, a quality that is never in short supply. He was also an art critic for Time magazine for 30 years; the author of more than a dozen books, including a best-selling history of Australia, “The Fatal Shore”; host of a television tour of modern art, “The Shock of the New”; and an avid fisherman. I knew the man, and I liked and admired him, although I did not always share his opinions about art and artists.

headline: G.O.P. Field Continues to Chase Donald Trump, New Poll Says

headline: Anchors Away (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Last week I wrote about what in our macroeconomic models has and hasn’t worked since 2008. As I said, demand-side events have been very much what people using IS-LM would have predicted (and did). But on the supply side, not so much. For one thing, the “accelerationist” doctrine that has dominated economic discussion of inflation and unemployment for 40 years has fallen flat. If inflation had responded to the Great Recession and aftermath the way it did in previous big slumps, we would be deep in deflation by now; we aren’t.

headline: In Paris, Negotiators Trim a Draft Climate Agreement, Climate Scientists Press for Nuclear Energy, Activists Prepare for Failure
text: In theory, the goal of the Paris talks over a new global climate agreement is to create a more sustainable human relationship with the climate system by curbing emissions of greenhouse gases and boosting poor countries’ capacity to withstand climate shocks.

headline: ‘Portraits: John Berger on Artists’
text: Has John Berger mellowed? Apparently not. In his new book, the passionately wayward and contentious English writer, who once shared his Booker Prize money with the Black Panther Party, recalls being ejected from the National Gallery in London. “You have insulted one of my men,” the security chief tells Berger. “You have shouted obscene words in a public institution. You will now walk in front of us to the main exit.” Berger’s crime? He refused, after a quarrel with a guard, to put his bag on his shoulder while drawing from a favorite painting, Antonello da Messina’s “Crucifixion.” Now almost 90, Berger still has the deep devotion to pictures, not to mention the reflexive anti-­authoritarianism, that you might associate with a first-year art ­student.

headline: In Greece, Shift From Cash to Plastic Could Undercut Shadow Economy
text: ATHENS — In the central market here recently, hanging above the trays of cod and the slabs of pink meat, was evidence that Greece’s near bankruptcy last summer was having an unexpected impact — shiny new placards advertising that, at least in some stalls, customers could now pay with debit and credit cards.

headline: 1940: War Prisoners to Be Sent Food
text: WASHINGTON — The American Red Cross announced today [Dec. 4] that war prisoners in European camps will receive 5,000 packages of food before the end of the year as a result of an urgent request of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva. The shipment will be the first of what is to be known as a ‘‘prisoners-of-war package service,’’ the Red Cross said. The Red Cross announced that food would be sent first because of the great need, but that later shipments would include clothing also. The food now is being purchased and will be packed by a merchandising firm for the Red Cross. The parcels will weigh eleven pounds each, will cost approximately $2.75 and will contain evaporated milk, oatmeal, cheese, sardines, oleo margarine, dried fruit, corned beef, orange juice, sugar, cigarettes and vitamized dry beverages requiring only the addition of water. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 5, 1940

headline: Don’t Assume a Fed Action Will Move the Market
text: Humans don’t behave like computers. That makes life interesting, but it has a serious downside for economists: It is exceedingly difficult to predict the short-term directions of major markets, even when events seem to be entirely predictable.

headline: ‘The Uncollected David Rakoff’
text: In his foreword to “The Uncollected David Rakoff,” a book that understandably, if ultimately ill-advisably, attempts to squeeze and preserve every last drop out of the late essayist, humorist and performer, Paul Rudnick calls Rakoff “my favorite breed of artist, because his work promises pleasure.” Remembering the delicious experience of encountering Rakoff’s name in a magazine, Rudnick writes, “I’d either catapult right to his words or I’d save them for last, as an earned dessert.”

Left unchanged it could produce a crisis on the scale of the 1980 Mariel boatlift or the 1994 balsero (rafters) crisis — if one hasn’t begun already.

headline: ‘Lady Byron and Her Daughters,’ by Julia Markus
text: Annabella Milbanke has historically gotten bad press. During their uneasy courtship, her future husband, Lord Byron, christened her the “princess of parallelograms”: a backhanded accolade to bestow on even the most mathematically inclined 19th-century bride. By September 1816, a few months after the end of their short and disastrous marriage, he had labeled his wife a “moral Clytemnestra.”

headline: Death Takes No Holiday

headline: 100 Miles, 10 Days, Three Countries and a Lot of Cheese
text: The quest story that enjoys the greatest currency in America, aside from the postapocalyptic road trip, is the grueling distance hike. The genre is capacious, and can be inspirational (Cheryl Strayed’s ‘‘Wild’’) or slapstick (Bill Bryson’s ‘‘A Walk in the Woods’’), but the plot doesn’t vary much: Out of a sense of profligacy or shame, one takes to the long narrow path as a kind of purgatory, stripping off various regrettable excesses — drugs, sex, food, Internet. At the trail’s end one emerges remade: chaste, humble and slender.

headline: FIFA’s Message Is at the Mercy of the Wrong Messengers
text: ZURICH — The FIFA officials tried hard. They did. On Thursday afternoon, the acting president and the acting secretary general and the permanent reform committee chief (who just seems to like acting) wanted desperately to talk about change. About progress. About the future.

headline: ‘Jessica Jones’ Episode 10: 1,000 Cuts
text: One of the things that instantly distinguished “Jessica Jones” from other live-action Marvel TV adaptations was its forward momentum and sense of mystery. Integral characters like Luke Cage, Will Simpson and Dorothy Walker were introduced quickly in order to set up the urgency of Jones’s hunt for Kilgrave. And until Episode 10, the show’s creators had done a fine job of making Jones’s search for Kilgrave feel genuinely urgent, which is pretty impressive given how many times she’s caught him, lost him, then reluctantly rendezvoused with him, and back again. “AKA 1,000 Cuts” is the first episode that has an arrhythmic pace and a generally messy structure.

She presents the scope of his corruption in damning detail, cataloging cases of money laundering, bribery and election fixing, all designed to benefit the country’s elite. text: “Flamenco is clandestino,” said Soledad Barrio, the star of the renowned company Noche Flamenca, who moved with her family from Madrid to Washington Heights two years ago. In a flamenco studio, she continued, “you don’t need big windows — or beautiful space.”

headline: ‘What the Eye Hears’ and ‘America Dancing’
text: To an extent that seems counterintuitive from the quaint, straw-hat soft shoe typically associated with it, tap-­dancing — like so much of American popular culture — owes its very essence to black people. Like the jazz it evolved alongside, tap blends the European and the African to a near-indissoluble degree, with origins only dimly reconstructable. Brian ­Sei­bert’s authoritative “What the Eye Hears” illuminates those beginnings — along with what happened afterward — as well as anyone ever will.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutors Will Not Retry Former Dewey Chairman
text: Prosecutors in Manhattan have decided not to retry Steven H. Davis, the former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the once-prominent New York law firm that collapsed in bankruptcy in 2012, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Inside the List
text: Elephant in the Room: “Cross Justice,” the latest thriller in James Patterson’s long-running Alex Cross series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 1. This has been, as usual, a very good year for Patterson: “Cross Justice” is his ninth novel to hit the adult hardcover list in 2015 (seven of them written with other people, but still), and since January he has appeared on that list, or the extended version, for all but four weeks. Patterson was at the National Book Awards ceremony last month, at Cipriani Wall Street, to accept the Literarian Award for his efforts to promote reading. “I feel uncomfortable,” he told the crowd, “because, well, I am the elephant in the room, the bull in the china shop, the stranger in a strange land, the Big Mac at Cipriani.” He went on to discuss his early love of fiction — he’s partial to the terrific novels “Mr. Bridge” and “Mrs. Bridge,” by Evan S. Connell — and to praise school libraries and independent bookstores, encouraging his listeners to help those institutions if they could: “Let’s all be literarians, whatever the hell that means.” He also revealed that his debut mystery, “The Thomas Berryman Number,” had been rejected 31 times before finding a home. “I keep a list of all the editors who turned down my first novel,” he said. “Sometimes they send me books and ask for blurbs. Mostly, though, they’re dead.”

headline: Barry Bonds’s Return to Baseball Will Be Compelling to Watch
text: The hitting coach is the busiest person on a baseball team. If you see him in the pregame hours, he is almost always scurrying somewhere — bouncing over to the video room to study swings on a laptop, ducking into a conference room to share scouting reports, wheeling a cart of baseballs into a batting tunnel under the stands. Pitchers, with their delicate arms, cannot throw constantly to shake a slump. But hitters can swing as often as they like.

But an eighth-floor apartment in the building closed at its full $35,000,000 asking price and yielded a hefty profit. The two transactions were the priciest of the week.

headline: Landlord Lets Reporters Into San Bernardino Suspects’ Home

And upstairs, in one of the bedrooms, a white crib had been piled high with pillows, blankets and toys for a baby.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The 10 Best Books of 2015
text: This week, editors at the Book Review discuss the year’s best books; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Matthew Schneier discusses facial hair and a treatise on men’s style; Bee Wilson talks about “First Bite”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Mortgage Approval Entirely Online
text: Progress toward moving the entire mortgage approval process online made an apparent leap forward last month with the introduction of Quicken Loans’ Rocket Mortgage.

headline: Resistance Is Futile
text: There’s no data on this, but I’d guess that most self-help books are purchased in the depths of a bad mood. When we’re happy, we idle and play. When we’re not, we buy books that promise a fix. And when those books fail to deliver, we feel wronged. The market has responded accordingly, with a crop of new books seemingly aimed at people who have grown cynical about self-help. These books have profane titles, saucy premises and, in one case, a cover photo of the author posing nearly nude and oiled and aiming a weapon. Their tone is belligerent. Much like their intended readers, these books could be credibly described as having an attitude problem.

headline: A Neurotic’s Guide to Small Talk
text: As a lifelong neurotic, I sympathize with the daily struggle to conquer human-to-human small talk. Parties, weddings, bars, offices, public transportation: Small talk is all around us. Holiday party season makes it worse.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Suffocation Described as Likely Cause of Death in Freddie Gray Case
text: BALTIMORE — Freddie Gray’s spinal cord was so severely injured that he most likely lost his ability to breathe and suffocated, a state medical examiner testified here Friday on a tense day of testimony and video evidence that evoked an issue and a phrase — “I can’t breathe” — intimately associated with another contentious case of a black man’s death after a rough encounter with the police.

headline: Thinking Chowder? Try an Iberian-Inspired Soup
text: Publishing a new recipe for chowder seems like asking for trouble, since everyone has a different idea about what makes a true one.

headline: How Jamie Hodari, Workplace Entrepreneur, Spends His Sundays
text: Would you eat a fish caught in Prospect Park? Neither would Jamie Hodari. But that doesn’t stop Mr. Hodari, 34, whose business is creating shared office spaces, from getting out there with bait and rod and letting the prospect of catching a largemouth bass transport him to another place. Mr. Hodari is a founding partner of Industrious, which has been constructing its first outpost in New York. “It’s a little ironic,” he said in late October, “because my work is devoted to saying that working at home inhibits your creativity and makes it harder to be productive. But our first New York location doesn’t open for three weeks, so I do work from home relatively frequently.” Home is an apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, where Mr. Hodari lives alone.

headline: Gun Violence and Fear in America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyer’s Flagship Bistro, Is About to Set Sail
text: Like certain insects or figures from Greek mythology, New York eats its own. You know how it works: A restaurant moves into an underserved area, attracts attention, then a crowd, and then other restaurants and larger crowds. Before you know it, the original restaurant can no longer afford to remain in the very neighborhood it helped create. That’s exactly what happened to Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyer’s flagship bistro. After 30 years, the restaurant is relocating from its perch on East 16th Street to the other side of Union Square. In celebration of the move, Mr. Meyer created the 12 Nights of Union Square Cafe, a three-course menu for $85 available through Dec. 12.

headline: In Miami, a Trio of Minimalist Paintings
text: It’s undeniable that figuration stands tall in today’s art market — bodies of all shapes and sizes are in evidence throughout the Miami art fairs and are the subject of one of the most buzzed-about pop-up exhibitions in town, “Unrealism,” at the Design District’s Moore Building, curated by the heavyweight double bill of Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. However, as soon as a trend hits a saturation point, the window opens wide for a counterpoint. Throughout Art Basel Miami Beach, there are a number of strikingly spare paintings whose minimal, monochromatic brushstrokes bear uncanny superficial resemblances, despite originating from very different times and places. The 78-year-old Swiss painter Niele Toroni is known for applying short, squarish acrylic streaks of a prescribed size in strict patterns; he has new works on offer at a number of booths, including Alfonso Artiaco. On offer at Greene Naftali is a historical work by the recently deceased German painter Gunther Forg — who, though prolific like Toroni, is known for constant variation rather than repetition. Finally, the Paris-based South Korean artist Lee Ufan’s canvas of two blocky gray smears at Galerie Nächst St. Stephan Rosemarie Schwarzwälder is discreetly rooted in the natural origin of its materials, which combine oil with pigments of stone.

headline: Greg Abbott’s Stern Commandments
text: HOUSTON — IF I’ve learned anything living in Texas, lo, these many years, it is that actions that seem nuts or cruel on the surface usually have some rational basis down below. But I’m struggling to see this one.

headline: ‘The Wiz Live!’ Scores Strong Ratings
text: “The Wiz Live!,” NBC’s latest live musical, scored strong ratings on Thursday night, easily beating last year’s live rendition of “Peter Pan.” The broadcast brought network television’s highest Thursday-night ratings in the key 18- to 49-year-old demographic, for a nonsporting event, in more than a year.

headline: The Green Lady of Brooklyn
text: Elizabeth Sweetheart, 74, is known in her area of Brooklyn as the Green Lady of Carroll Gardens for her evergreen approach to life.

text: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 13 games, including Monday’s matchup between the Dallas Cowboys and the Washington Redskins. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 13 player rankings.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Limp as a Baby Solved
text: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the real-life case of a 28-year-old woman who had a long history of abdominal pain and constipation who suddenly started seizing and having hallucinations. It was a pretty classic presentation of a rare disease, and lots of you figured it out.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Debt Relief to Get Supreme Court Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide whether Puerto Rico, which is in the midst of a financial crisis, may allow public utilities there to restructure $20 billion in debt.

headline: Russian Truckers, Irate Over New Tolls, Block Roads Near Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Hundreds of long-distance truckers blocked a lengthy section of the ring road circling the capital on Friday to protest a new national toll, in the first sign that Russia’s economic woes might be eroding the broad support for President Vladimir V. Putin’s government.

headline: The End of Social Security Loopholes: What Now?
text: For years, retirees have been able to squeeze tens of thousands of extra dollars from Social Security using two special tactics. Though they went by gimmicky names like “claim benefits now, claim more later,” these strategies were perfectly legal.

headline: Inside a Redecorated 17th-Century Palace
text: What to do when inheriting a family castle filled with battle weapons, dusty heirlooms and family portraits? For Giovanni and Lucia Guarini, it started with paint.

headline: Shanice Williams on Her Road to Dorothy and ‘The Wiz Live!’
text: Shanice Williams had big sparkly slippers to fill when she stepped into the role of Dorothy for NBC’s broadcast of “The Wiz Live!” on Thursday night. By most accounts, she more than pulled it off, earning accolades from many critics, fans and celebrities following along on Twitter. They were all the more impressed because she’s making her professional debut at only 19, and she had to hold her own with a cast that included Mary J. Blige, Queen Latifah, and Ne-Yo. (“Your world is about to ‘change its face’ but I know where you’re going…as far and as high as you want,” Audra McDonald tweeted to her.)

headline: The Vibrant Makeover of a 17th-Century Palace
text: Giovanni and Lucia Guarini inherited a castle filled with battle weapons, dusty heirlooms and family portraits. And then they got some paint.

headline: Yahoo’s Spinoff Plan Could Be Risky Business
text: The Yahoo board is reconsidering ways to increase its languishing stock price, including a possible sale of the core platform and advertising business. Most of the value of Yahoo’s stock is locked up in its $32 billion stake in Alibaba, and for almost a year, the board has focused on trying to dispose of those shares without paying taxes.

headline: Avon Opts for New Playbook in Fight With Activist Investor
text: Avon’s fading beauty is in the eyes of two different financial beholders.

headline: Is Gollum Good or Evil? Jail Term in Turkey Hinges on Answer

headline: ‘Now I Am With the Protesters’: Readers on a Police Shooting in Chicago
text: The videotaped shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald by a Chicago police officer prompted readers to call for systemic change to restore public trust in law enforcement in Chicago and around the country.

headline: When a New Mother Is Accused in a Shooting
text: The reported accounts of Tashfeen Malik’s life sound so ordinary. She met her husband, Syed Rizwan Farook, online, through a dating site. She moved to the United States from Pakistan on a K-1 visa as his fiancée, and they married two years ago. After she became pregnant, the couple registered at Target, inviting friends and family to give them familiar things, a car seat, diapers, safety swabs.

headline: What’s Hot in Miami This Week — Outside the Basel Tent
text: Prioritizing is key for the collectors, artists and onlookers who descend upon Miami Art Week. Alongside the fairs — Art Basel, plus 22 satellites — there’s an international influx of events and exhibitions in the realms of design, fashion, art and everything in between scattered across diverse venues in the city. While some ambitious participants touched down over the weekend, Monday night offered the first round of previews, beginning at the Shelborne Wyndham Grand, where the artist Bosco Sodi has installed six gold, site-specific sculptures with an almost extraterrestrial shine. Across the water in the up-and-coming neighborhood of Little Haiti, the recently moved Gallery Diet opened its doors for Ann Craven’s new painting show — giving visitors the opportunity to get better acquainted with the local talent.

headline: Bookshelf: Holiday Tales
text: New picture books include “When Santa Was a Baby” and “Miracle on 133rd Street.”

headline: From Jordan to Hummus, Looking Back at Ben Carson’s Tough Week
text: Ben Carson is taking a break from the campaign trail on Friday, which he may need after a particularly rough week that saw him stumbling in polls amid questions about his command of foreign policy.

headline: Popcast: Sophie and Grimes
text: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss their approaches to music.

headline: A Meal-Delivery App Claims Turf in Seamless’s Own Backyard
text: When Seamless and GrubHub merged in May 2013, they formed a meal delivery juggernaut that seemed certain to dominate in New York City. But two years later, a new player has begun to compete, even outpacing Seamless, a New York native, in some of the city’s neighborhoods.

headline: Delhi to Limit Use of Cars in an Effort to Control Pollution
text: NEW DELHI — The notoriously polluted air in the Indian capital has become so bad that the local government is planning to limit the use of private cars to alternate days, among other measures.

headline: Lyric Opera Seeks to Reassure Patrons Over a Work that Mirrors the Terror Out There
text: It is not just television networks that have had to grapple since the Paris attacks with when and how to present scenes of terrorism, but the Lyric Opera of Chicago as well. “Bel Canto,” a much-anticipated opera that will have its world premiere there on Monday, opens with an unexpectedly resonant scene: a musical performance interrupted by gun-toting terrorists.

headline: M. Roland Nachman, Lawyer in Times v. Sullivan Libel Case, Dies at 91
text: M. Roland Nachman, an Alabama lawyer who opposed The New York Times in a libel case that resulted in a landmark Supreme Court decision establishing greater leeway for newspapers and individuals to criticize government officials and other public figures, died on Nov. 24 at his home in Montgomery, Ala. He was 91.

headline: Sara Hylton’s Images Depict Little Pakistan’s Quiet Conflicts
text: Last summer, Sara Hylton, a Canadian photojournalist who splits her time between New York and New Delhi, came to Brooklyn in search of a way to tell the story of the borough’s Muslims, religious profiling and police surveillance.

headline: Caregivers Sometimes Must Sacrifice Their Careers

headline: La Bonne Bière, Cafe Hit in Paris Attacks, Is Back in Business
text: PARIS — Jacqueline Bouley used to go regularly to La Bonne Bière, a sprawling cafe in Paris’s 10th Arrondissement, to linger over a drink on the long terrace. Her routine came to an abrupt halt after the night of Nov. 13, when Islamic State gunmen drove up and massacred five people in a hail of gunfire before continuing their deadly assault around town.

headline: University Negotiates to Return Pissarro to Jewish Family
text: After fighting for years, the University of Oklahoma is now negotiating the terms under which it will return a Pissarro painting to a Jewish family whose relatives had their artworks looted by the Nazis.

headline: China Creates a World Bank of Its Own, and the U.S. Balks
text: BEIJING — As top leaders met at a lush Bali resort in October 2013, President Xi Jinping of China described his vision for a new multinational, multibillion-dollar bank to finance roads, rails and power grids across Asia. Under Chinese stewardship, the bank would tackle the slow development in poor countries that was holding the region back from becoming the wealth center of the world.

headline: Learning From Ebola: Was Quarantine Too Extreme a Response?
text: Sometimes journalists take a hard look at questions that survive after an immediate crisis has passed. In that spirit, my most recent article for The Times was about Ebola — yes, Ebola, last year’s frightful threat.

The next in the series is Michael Pollan, author of many titles including “The Omnivore’s Dilemma” and “In Defense of Food.” He shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Worlds Converge in Deadly Crash on New Jersey Highway
text: In one vehicle there were 13 immigrant workers, men and women commuting home in a van after a long Saturday shift at a Chinese restaurant. In another was a young data analyst heading home after mentoring a teenager. And in another, two farmers hauling a truckload of Kentucky cattle back to Maine.

headline: Restoring a Connecticut Farmhouse
text: For 22 years, Suni Munshani, a technology entrepreneur who lives in Easton, Conn., with his wife, Tina, and daughter, Saira, dreamed of owning a country home. He had in mind a particular place, set on 10 rolling acres with farm buildings, paddocks and a pair of Asian katsura trees that gave off the odor of caramelized sugar in the fall.

text: Suni Munshani, a technology entrepreneur, restores a farm and renovates a 1935 house.

headline: Inquiry Into Paris Terror Attacks Widens to Eastern Europe
text: BRUSSELS — The investigation into the Paris terrorist attacks, previously focused on jihadist networks in France and Belgium, has widened to Eastern Europe, with a Belgian federal prosecutor announcing Friday that one of the people suspected of terrorism traveled in September by car to Hungary, where he picked up two men now believed to have links to the carnage of Nov. 13.

headline: The Arithmetic of Compassion
text: WE all can relate to the saying “One death is a tragedy; a million deaths is a statistic.” Our sympathy for suffering and loss declines precipitously when we are presented with increasing numbers of victims. In the 1950s, the psychiatrist Robert Jay Lifton studied survivors of the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki and discovered that a condition he labeled “psychic numbing” enabled them to withstand the psychological trauma of this experience.

headline: Review: Stars Pay Tribute to Frank Sinatra
text: Everything that was good and bad about Lincoln Center’s underwhelming fund-raising gala timed to Frank Sinatra’s centennial, “Sinatra: Voice for a Century” at David Geffen Hall on Thursday, converged late in the evening in a moment of disturbing clarity. As the mighty New York Philharmonic orchestra, conducted by Alan Gilbert, played the funereal opening chords from Nelson Riddle’s original arrangement of “What’s New?” from the 1958 album, “Frank Sinatra Sings for Only the Lonely,” an emotional chasm opened up.

headline: Smooth Visa Process for Woman in Attack Is Focus of Inquiry
text: The woman involved in the shootings in San Bernardino, Calif., on Wednesday passed through two rounds of criminal and national security background checks as she obtained a “fiancé visa” and later a resident green card to live in the United States, federal officials said.

headline: Gad Elmaleh: Talking Funny in French and English
text: As stand-up comedy becomes an increasingly global phenomenon, international stars are starting to emerge, like the South African Trevor Noah, who played to huge audiences in Africa before taking over “The Daily Show.” Now Gad Elmaleh, a Moroccan-born stand-up comedian often called the Jerry Seinfeld of France, is hoping for crossover success here as well. He’s embarking on his first significant run of shows in English beginning Sunday at Joe’s Pub, part of a national tour and later New York residency.

headline: Review: The Paris Opera Ballet, Under New Management
text: PARIS — The new triple bill of ballets at the Paris Opera — named, after its choreographic auteurs, “Christopher Wheeldon, Wayne McGregor, Pina Bausch” — demands three thoroughly unalike styles from its dancers. Yet the company’s dancing in each is a tremendous pleasure: three-dimensional in texture, keen in dynamics and, most welcome of all, proceeding through long, multifaceted phrases.

headline: Evening Hours | Bright Nights
text: A festive benefit, a street festival and more.

headline: Launch of Cargo Rocket to Space Station Is Postponed
text: A rocket packed with 7,700 pounds of cargo destined for the International Space Station remained on the ground Friday after bad weather again halted the countdown.

headline: It’s Turner Time, When British Artists Win Cash and a Skewering
text: GLASGOW — The voices of three singers dressed in black slide from impossibly high notes down to gruff growls. Nearby is a reading room stocked with books, papers, magazines and television monitors broadcasting interviews with people discussing alien abduction and conspiracy theories. In yet another room, fur coats are stitched into the backs of chairs. Elsewhere, a small house has been assembled and filled with furniture, doorknobs, sinks and lampshades, all for sale.

headline: Samsung to Pay Apple $548 Million in Patent Dispute
text: Samsung agreed to pay Apple $548 million to settle a smartphone patent dispute, but the payment won’t put an end to the long-running legal battles between the two companies.

headline: Review: Kissin and Friends at Carnegie Hall
text: Carnegie Hall’s “Perspectives” series give major artists the chance to show audiences the breadth of their musical lives. This season, the pianist Evgeny Kissin’s series is happily varied — most interesting, an evening of Yiddish poetry and piano works by Jewish composers, coming later this month. A few weeks ago, he again proved his solo credentials with a rare repeated recital, and there’s Rachmaninoff to come with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in the spring.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: No More Thoughts and Prayers
text: We never had enough time to rationalize, in the uniquely American way, why that middle-aged white man killed a cop, a mother of two and an Iraq war veteran in Colorado Springs, when the latest slaughter of human life intruded. He was — what, pro-life? Screaming something about “baby parts” while he unloaded in a Planned Parenthood clinic?

headline: Review: ‘Gigantic’ Takes On a Ton of Teenage Angst
text: There are no fat suits in “Gigantic,” the new musical set at a weight-loss camp for bulky teenagers. For its characters, the end of the summer will bring no magical transformation from round to svelte.

headline: Review: Riverside Symphony Offers Nostalgia and Tibetan Tones
text: The Riverside Symphony, founded in 1981 by George Rothman and Anthony Korf, has built a solid reputation for varied, sometimes challenging programs. So “Time Travel,” its season-opening concert on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, proved something of a disappointment from the start.

headline: Draghi Says No Limits on European Stimulus Measures
text: In a speech to Wall Street investors, the president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, reinforced his promise to do all in his power to push Europe’s stagnating economy toward a full recovery.

headline: Review: Pavel Zustiak’s ‘Custodians of Beauty’
text: The door to the theater at New York Live Arts was within arm’s reach, but we were taken on a detour, directed to walk down a staircase, which veered into a pitch-black corridor. In an instant, the quotidian was washed away, replaced by a strange, uncomfortable feeling: displacement.

headline: Review: In Badolo’s ‘Yimbégré,’ Men Jesting and Ranting
text: In the program note to his new dance, “Yimbégré,” the choreographer Souleymane Badolo tells a story about taking French friends to a funeral in his native country, Burkina Faso. When they think they see dancing, he tells them it is “not the dancing they know” but instead “a codified language of movement that must be known to appreciate the messages within.”

headline: Lawmakers Near Deal on Billions in Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Republican and Democratic negotiators closed in Friday on a major package of tax cuts for businesses and individuals that could exceed $700 billion in forgone revenues over a decade, and planned to work through the weekend in hopes that Congress can approve it before quitting for the year.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Biker Jacket
text: The biker jacket has now replaced the tailored sports jacket. It seems to reflect — in its most rugged, sinister black — the mood of the world today. Even if the fashion world tries to lighten it up with a rainbow of colors, the black jacket remains the most popular, and the statement of autumn. Below, veterans in club-insignia-covered jackets.

headline: U.S. Presses for U.N. Resolution to Fight ISIS’ Financing
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Russia are negotiating a new resolution at the United Nations Security Council intended to strengthen international efforts to cut off revenues that  the Islamic State raises to govern territory and spread its ideology.

headline: New Name for Roosevelt Hospital
text: The Mount Sinai Health System renamed the Manhattan hospital in November.

headline: Mount Sinai Sheds Roosevelt Name as Hospital Moves On
text: Roosevelt. Love it or hate it, the name resonates in American history.

headline: Facing Resistance in Texas, Syrian Refugees Find Temporary Sanctuary in New York
text: Though Texas has sued to keep Syrian refugees out, a dozen of them found temporary respite on Friday in New York City, where Mayor Bill de Blasio said he welcomed them “with open arms to the city of immigrants.”

headline: Yahoo Board Is Quiet on Any Shake-Up Plans
text: SAN FRANCISCO — With a crucial deadline looming next week, Yahoo shareholders still do not know how — or if — the board plans to restructure the technology giant.

headline: Giants Dealing With New Injuries
text: The Giants’ offensive lineup appears to be getting healthier, but defensively, the Giants lost two more starters to injury this week.

headline: Melvin Williams, an Inspiration for ‘The Wire,’ Dies at 73
text: Melvin Williams, whose exploits as a drug kingpin in Baltimore informed the plot and character details of the HBO series “The Wire,” and who, after emerging from prison, played a role on the show, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 73.

headline: Justin Trudeau Outlines Sweeping Agenda for Canada
text: OTTAWA — Getting down to work after a whirlwind global tour, Justin Trudeau, Canada’s new Liberal prime minister, presented Parliament with a sweeping legislative agenda on Friday.

headline: A Victory for Women at War
text: THE announcement this week by Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter that all combat roles in the United States military would officially be open to women is, without question, a victory. News of the decision was a thrill for me and thousands of other women who have served and continue to serve over the past 14 years in “support” roles in Iraq and Afghanistan, many of whom enthusiastically volunteered, as I did, for positions that put us in the middle of conflict.

headline: Chipotle Stock Tumbles After E. Coli Outbreak
text: Chipotle Mexican Grill’s stock took a hit on Friday, falling about 8 percent in after-hours trading, when the company rescinded its 2016 forecast after an E. coli outbreak that has sickened dozens of people across the United States.
