headline: Donald Trump Widens Lead in New Hampshire, Poll Shows
text: Donald J. Trump has widened his lead in New Hampshire, according to a poll released on Tuesday that showed him beating his closest rivals for the Republican presidential nomination by a margin of more than 2-to-1.

headline: A Conversation With Martin L. Nussbaum
text: Mr. Nussbaum, 39, is a founding partner of the Slate Property Group, a development company that was started in 2012 and focuses on multifamily and mixed-use properties in emerging markets in Manhattan and Brooklyn. He was a founder of Silverstone Property Group, which also specialized in multifamily property.

headline: Lessons of the Past Hint at Hurdles in Fight to Stop ISIS
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Nine years ago, after the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah captured two Israeli soldiers in a risky cross-border raid, Israel declared it would crush the organization once and for all.

headline: Jeb Bush Takes Voter Questions, but Has No Answer for Donald Trump
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Jeb Bush on Tuesday outlined his plan to overhaul Social Security at a forum here hosted by AARP. He gave a stump speech focused on protecting the nation from the threat of Islamic terrorism. He answered voter questions on topics including the Iran nuclear deal and immigration.

headline: Trump’s Plan to Bar Muslims Is Widely Condemned Abroad
text: LONDON — A day after Donald J. Trump called for a ban on the entry of Muslims into the United States, much of the rest of the world on Tuesday looked at the American presidential election with a mix of befuddlement and despair.

headline: Obama Making Calls to Negotiate Climate Deal, Kerry Says
text: LE BOURGET, France — Despite a domestic agenda consumed by his response to last week’s terrorist attack in California, President Obama is closely tracking the United Nations climate change negotiations outside Paris, Secretary of State John Kerry said in an interview on Tuesday.

headline: Law Professors Ask Congress to Delay Changes in Debt Law
text: Eighteen law professors sent a letter to leaders on Capitol Hill on Tuesday urging them to postpone proposed changes to a Depression-era law that they say could have “broad negative unintended consequences in the securities markets.”

headline: New York Court Dismisses Challenge to Nail Salon Wage Protections
text: A New York State judge last week dismissed a lawsuit challenging a new state regulation designed to protect nail salon workers.

headline: Jordan Is Asked to Admit Thousands of Stranded Syrians
text: AMMAN, Jordan — The United Nations and human rights groups on Tuesday called on Jordan to allow the entry of thousands of Syrian refugees stuck in a northeast desert holding area adjoining the Syrian border.

headline: Remembering Lennon, Amid a Debate About Gun Violence
text: As they do every Dec. 8, admirers of John Lennon assembled at the Strawberry Fields memorial in Central Park to sing familiar Beatles songs and imagine a world that lives as one.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: RECENT SALE

headline: Douglas Tompkins, 72, North Face Founder, Dies in Kayaking Accident
text: Douglas Tompkins, a noted conservationist and the founder of the North Face and Esprit clothing brands, died on Tuesday after a kayaking accident in the Patagonia region of southern Chile. He was 72.

headline: Trump’s Anti-Muslim Plan Is Awful. And Constitutional.
text: Philadelphia — DONALD J. TRUMP’S reprehensible call to bar Muslim immigrants from entering the United States tracks an exam question I’ve been giving my immigration law students since Sept. 11. Would such a proposal be constitutional? The answer is not what you might think — but it also raises the issue of what, exactly, we mean when we say something is “constitutional” in the first place.

headline: Chipotle’s Safety Woes Worsen as Scores of Students Fall Ill in Boston
text: Things are going from bad to worse at Chipotle Mexican Grill.

headline: Anxiety Grows in Texas With Syrians Due to Arrive Soon
text: HOUSTON — Republican leaders in Texas want to expand the legal authority of the states to bar Syrian refugees, as the expected arrival of 21 of the refugees in Texas this week has intensified concerns and fears about accepting Syrians in the wake of the Paris attacks last month.

headline: Opposition in Venezuela Now Has to Fix the Ills That Led to Its Victory
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Now comes the hard part. The political opposition here rode discontent over a failing economy to an overwhelming majority in legislative elections on Sunday, but after years of sniping from the sidelines, members have to get down to the difficult task of delivering on promises to fix the country’s many ills.

headline: Spotify Is Said to Have Reconsidered Its Free Access Policy for Big Acts’ New Albums
text: Since it started in 2008, the streaming service Spotify has clung fiercely to its so-called freemium model, arguing that the best way to get people to buy a subscription for unlimited music online is to make the same catalog of songs also available free to listeners, but with ads.

headline: North Korea: U.S. Adds Penalties
text: The United States expanded sanctions targeting North Korea on Tuesday, imposing economic penalties on six of its international banking representatives and three of its shipping companies for what the Treasury Department called ties to illicit arms proliferation and financing. The sanctions, announced by the Office of Foreign Assets Control, bars them from dealings with the United States and impounds any assets in American jurisdiction. It was the second time in four weeks that the Treasury had imposed sanctions on North Korea, reflecting concerns about its efforts to improve its nuclear weapons and missile capabilities despite United Nations prohibitions.

headline: Roger Federer Drops Stefan Edberg From Coaching Staff
text: Roger Federer plays on at age 34, and he will play on in 2016 without Stefan Edberg, his boyhood idol and assistant coach.

headline: This Time, Cubs Beat Mets by Signing Zobrist, a Top Free Agent
text: NASHVILLE — As the Mets waited for an answer from Ben Zobrist, their top free-agent target, Manager Terry Collins exchanged text messages with him Tuesday, trying to sell him on joining the Mets. They imagined him as their second baseman, as another clubhouse leader, as the addition that would keep their momentum going after they won a National League pennant.

headline: U.S. Cautious on Iran Missile Test Claim
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is facing another difficult choice with Iran: As Tehran takes apart much of its nuclear infrastructure to win sanctions relief, how vocally should the White House condemn Iranian violations of United Nations resolutions on other issues?

headline: Diane Rehm Announces Retirement From Long-Running Talk Show
text: Diane Rehm, who has interviewed prominent newsmakers as an NPR radio host since 1979, announced on Tuesday that she planned to retire next year from her two-hour current affairs show.

headline: Hundreds of Volkswagen Suits Will Be Heard in California
text: Hundreds of civil lawsuits against Volkswagen over its use of deceptive software to evade emissions tests will be heard by a federal judge in California, despite a push from the automaker and the federal government to send the cases to Detroit. The United States Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation decided on Tuesday to send the cases to District Judge Charles R. Breyer in San Francisco, where the first VW case in the nation was filed.

headline: Honoring Broadcasters, No Audio Required
text: A sportscaster is defined by how he calls a game and tells a story. For baseball announcers, a home run call or exclamations like “Holy cow!” are signature phrases. And many live in the memory of fans for how they handled a moment in time: “I don’t believe what I just saw!” Jack Buck said when an injured Kirk Gibson hit a pinch-hit home run to win Game 1 of the 1988 World Series.

headline: Chinese Glacier’s Retreat Signals Trouble for Asian Water Supply
text: MENGKE GLACIER, China — Over the years, Qin Xiang and his fellow scientists at a high and lonely research station in the Qilian Mountains of northwest China have tracked the inexorable effects of rising temperatures on one of China’s most important water sources.

headline: Plan to Bar Foreign Muslims by Donald Trump Might Survive a Lawsuit
text: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump called on Monday for “a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States,” many legal scholars were aghast and said that such a ban would certainly be struck down by courts as blatantly unconstitutional.

headline: Yasiel Puig Will Join Cuba Trip
text: Yasiel Puig, a Dodgers outfielder who defected from Cuba in 2012, will join a good-will tour of Cuba next week. The trip, sponsored by Major League Baseball and the players’ union, will include Puig, Jose Abreu, Alexei Ramirez and Brayan Pena, all originally from Cuba.

headline: New York Looks Into ‘Speculative’ Ticket Resellers
text: Tickets for Bruce Springsteen’s 2016 tour will not go on sale until Friday, but hundreds of seats have already been listed for up to $5,000 or more on StubHub and other resale sites — listings that have drawn the attention of the New York attorney general in the latest volley over the $8 billion ticket scalping business.

headline: Tibor Rubin Is Dead at 86; Medal of Honor Was Delayed by Anti-Semitism
text: “When Corporal Rubin’s battalion found itself ambushed by thousands of Chinese troops,” the president said at a White House ceremony, “the Americans’ firepower soon dwindled to a single machine gun. The weapon was in an exposed position and three soldiers had already died manning it. That was when Corporal Rubin stepped forward. He fought until his ammunition was gone. He was badly wounded, captured and sent to a P.O.W. camp.”

headline: Yankees, Seeking to Get Younger, Acquire Starlin Castro From the Cubs
text: NASHVILLE — The Yankees’ challenge is to recast an aging team with a bloated payroll after years of lavish spending. Like all teams, they crave young, athletic players with reasonable contracts. But those players can rarely be bought.

headline: Dean Skelos’s Son Kept a Hand Out, and Never Took ‘No’ for an Answer
text: In a season when two of the three most powerful political figures in New York State have been hauled into court on corruption charges, you might expect at least some gaudy spoils of the alleged plunder to be on display.

headline: Enrique Marquez, Buyer of Guns Used in San Bernardino Attack, Is Studied
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — As federal officials scour the backgrounds of the couple who went on a terrorist rampage here last week, they are looking carefully at Enrique Marquez, a childhood friend and relation by marriage of the husband, Syed Rizwan Farook. It was Mr. Marquez, 24, who bought the two assault rifles that Mr. Farook and his wife, Tashfeen Malik, used to carry out the attack, which killed 14 people and wounded 21 others.

headline: Obama’s Plans to Stop ISIS Leave Many Democrats Wanting More
text: WASHINGTON — Many of President Obama’s Democratic allies in Congress say they do not believe he is being aggressive enough in confronting the terrorist threat of the Islamic State after last week’s attacks in California, undermining Americans’ sense of safety, especially among voters who will decide the party’s fate in elections next year.

headline: After Losing His Mom, He Finds the Will to Move On
text: When Lamont Foxhall needs to hear his mother’s voice, he plays a recording he made on his cellphone of one of their last conversations.

headline: Judge Acquits Guard in Assault That Maimed New York State Prisoner
text: A judge in Ulster County on Tuesday acquitted a New York State corrections officer of charges that he kicked an inmate so hard in the groin that part of his testicle had to be removed.

headline: Joe Biden Disparages Donald Trump’s Muslim Ban and Presidential Chances
text: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday added his voice to the chorus of condemnation of Donald J. Trump’s vow to temporarily bar Muslims from entering the country, calling it a “very, very dangerous brew for America” and predicting that if Mr. Trump wins the Republican nomination, Hillary Clinton would beat him “in a walk.”

headline: Robert E. Macdonald Wins 3rd Term as Mayor of Lewiston, Maine
text: Robert E. Macdonald, the two-term mayor of Lewiston, Me., beat back an aggressive challenge Tuesday from Ben Chin, a political neophyte, keeping the city, where registered Democrats far outnumber registered Republicans, in Republican hands for another two years.

headline: Diamond Nine
text: Administrivial “Set Your DVRs” Alert! On the Friday, December 18, 2015 episode of “Jeopardy!”, Will Shortz will be reading clues drawn from each of next week’s puzzles as part of a ‘New York Times Crossword’ category. Tune in and play along!

headline: Abandoned Yahoo Spinoff a Sign That Tax Is Fading as a Deal Driver
text: Yahoo has reportedly abandoned its plan to spin off its stake in Alibaba.

headline: The Living Room to Close at the End of December
text: The Living Room, a no-frills nightclub that gave an early start to Norah Jones and the Lumineers, and for almost 18 years has hosted countless singer-songwriters in three locations in Manhattan and Brooklyn, will close at the end of December, its owners, Steve Rosenthal and Jennifer Gilson, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Draws Criticism for Plan to Pay for Security in Private Schools
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday that he would sign a bill that would allow private and parochial schools to hire security guards at a cost of nearly $20 million annually to New York City, drawing criticism from some of his usual allies, who called it a giveaway to religious schools.

headline: Americans Attracted to ISIS Find an ‘Echo Chamber’ on Social Media
text: WASHINGTON — When a lonely Virginia teenager named Ali Amin got curious about the Islamic State last year and went online to learn more, he found a virtual community awaiting. It had its own peculiar language, stirring imagery and just the warm camaraderie, sense of adventure and devotion to a cause that were missing from his dull suburban life.

headline: Dow Chemical and DuPont Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
text: Dow Chemical and DuPont, two of the biggest and oldest companies in the American chemical industry, are in talks to merge in what would be one of the largest transactions in a year full of huge deals, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Ties Other Republicans to Trump’s Plan to Bar Muslims From U.S.
text: SALEM, N.H. – Hours after a new poll gave Donald J. Trump a strong lead in the New Hampshire primary, Hillary Clinton arrived here to blast his proposed prohibition on Muslims entering the country and accuse other Republican presidential candidates of maligning Muslims in their own ways.

headline: ‘Scream Queens’ Season 1 Finale: And the Killers Are
text: The identities of the killers in “Scream Queens” haven’t really mattered since about the third episode, when it became clear that the show was mostly interested in milking caricatures and seeing how many pop-culture references it could cram into every hour. But for the record: Hester did it. And Boone. And Pete. Yet Chanels 1, 3 and 5 (Emma Roberts, Billie Lourd and Abigail Breslin) took the rap.

headline: 2 in New York Police Dept. Are Accused of Taking Bribes From Bar Owners
text: A New York City police lieutenant and a detective took bribes from the owners of karaoke bars in Queens in exchange for advance warning of police inspections and raids, according to criminal complaints made public on Tuesday.

headline: Walmart’s Imports From China Displaced 400,000 Jobs, a Study Says
text: Imports from China by Walmart, the nation’s largest retailer and biggest importer, eliminated or displaced over 400,000 jobs in the United States between 2001 and 2013, according to an estimate by the Economic Policy Institute, a progressive research group that has long targeted Walmart’s policies.

headline: U.S. Reports a New Low in Deaths of Infants
text: WASHINGTON — Infant mortality in the United States fell to its lowest level ever in 2014, according to new federal data, as one of the biggest risk factors for infant deaths — preterm births — continued to fall.

headline: For Bernie Sanders, Policy and Levity on ‘Tonight Show’
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont appeared on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” on Tuesday to talk about climate change and income inequality and to leave no question that he thinks Donald J. Trump is a rabble-rouser.

headline: Disappointing Addition to UConn’s Long History at Madison Square Garden
text: Connecticut’s first N.C.A.A. tournament appearance came in 1951, and it sent the Huskies on their maiden voyage from Storrs, Conn., to Madison Square Garden.

headline: Greenpeace Subterfuge Tests Climate Research
text: A sting operation by the environmental group Greenpeace suggests that some researchers who dispute mainstream scientific conclusions on climate change are willing to conceal the sources of payment for their research, even if the money is purported to come from overseas corporations producing oil, gas and coal.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I have to watch my son because there is no kindergarten today. What bothers me the most is that my son may have a very negative view of nature.”

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
text: Baby, it’s cold outside — somewhere — but not when Taraji P. Henson and Terrence Howard steam up the stage. Meanwhile, the Pritchetts and a couple of polar explorers deal with unseasonably warm weather. And South Park arms itself.

headline: Americans Who Don’t Buy Health Coverage Face Heftier Fine in ’16, Analysis Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Americans who remain uninsured in 2016 despite having the option of buying health coverage through an Affordable Care Act marketplace will owe an average tax penalty of $969 per household, a new analysis has found.

headline: Drop in Diabetes Cases: Encouraging, but Not Enough

headline: #You Ain’t No American, Bro
text: Two weeks ago, I was in Kuwait participating in an I.M.F. seminar for Arab educators. For 30 minutes, we discussed the impact of technology trends on education in the Middle East. And then an Egyptian education official raised his hand and asked if he could ask me a personal question: “I heard Donald Trump say we need to close mosques in the United States,” he said with great sorrow. “Is that what we want our kids to learn?”

headline: No Reason to Exclude Transgender Medical Care
text: A decade ago, when she was starting to transition genders, the artist known as Our Lady J steeled herself as she called endocrinologists, seeking one who would prescribe hormones. “I couldn’t find a doctor,” said the classical pianist and singer, who is currently a writer for the television series “Transparent.” “I was treated like a freak.”

headline: An Opening for States to Restrict Guns
text: To listen to the insistent harangues of many gun-rights advocates, one might imagine that the Second Amendment prohibits almost any regulation of firearms.

headline: On Corrupt Politicians
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Toughness
text: When voters look at equally experienced male and female politicians, “the man will still be seen as more capable on issues of national security and defense,” Meredith Conroy, a professor of political science at California State University, San Bernardino, wrote me in response to my inquiry about the current election. But “Hillary is able to overcome this and other gender stereotypes. She turns much of the scholarship on voter perceptions of Democratic candidates, and furthermore female politicians, on its head.”

headline: Diversity Makes You Brighter
text: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION is back before the Supreme Court today. The court has agreed to hear, for the second time, the case of Abigail Fisher, a white applicant who claims that she was rejected by the University of Texas at Austin because of her race. Ms. Fisher invokes the promise of equal protection contained in the 14th Amendment, reminding us that judging people by their ancestry, rather than by their merits, risks demeaning their dignity.

headline: The Muslim Drill
text: AFTER the terrorist attacks in Paris last month, a real estate mogul and television host with nature-defying hair used the moment to publicly muse about registration databases and even special identification cards for American Muslims. For the sake of efficiency, I created a card myself, listing my skin tone as “Caramel Mocha,” my ethnicity as “Bollywood” and my religion as “Sunny-Side Sunni.”

headline: Australian Police Raid Home of Man Said to Be Likely Creator of Bitcoin
text: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian authorities on Wednesday raided the home of a computer expert and entrepreneur in suburban Sydney, just hours after two news outlets identified the man as a likely creator of the digital currency Bitcoin.

headline: Myanmar Political Shift Revives Debate on Sanctions
text: YANGON, Myanmar — The Burmese tycoon Zaw Zaw, who has been subject to American economic sanctions for nearly seven years, thinks it is time for them to end. At least in his case.

headline: Imagine a Medicare ‘Part Q’ for Quality at the End of Life
text: I spent the last Sunday of my father’s life sitting by his bed on the hospice unit in a small Connecticut hospital. He was dying of pneumonia, once called “the old man’s friend.” There was a nondenominational chapel down the hall, and a sheet cake in the kitchen. His hand was warm. Reassured by the quiet presence of the hospice nurses and feeling the mysterious quickening of life through his veins, I gave over to being his daughter and letting him be my father one last time.

headline: Schooling Children in Manners, Thank You Very Much
text: Middle schoolers are not generally known for their good manners. But Cord Ivanyi, a teacher in Chandler, Ariz., said that he was fed up after seeing “the sheer rudeness and carelessness the boys showed” during his classes, especially during parties when they would shove their way to the front of food lines.

headline: Marco Rubio Quietly Undermines Affordable Care Act
text: WASHINGTON — A little-noticed health care provision slipped into a giant spending law last year has tangled up the Obama administration, sent tremors through health insurance markets and rattled confidence in the durability of President Obama’s signature health law.

headline: Supreme Court Justices’ Comments Don’t Bode Well for Affirmative Action
text: WASHINGTON — An affirmative action plan at the University of Texas seemed to be in trouble at the Supreme Court on Wednesday. By the end of an unusually long and tense argument, a majority of the justices appeared unpersuaded that the plan was constitutional.

headline: Re-Examining Race and College Admissions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday returns to the question of the role race may place in admissions decisions at public colleges and universities. Here is a look at how the case twice made its way to the court and how changes in the court’s personnel may affect its outcome.

headline: At Muji, Design Intelligence Meets Dried Squid
text: A bin of cream-colored fluff sat on a table near the store’s front entrance. My friend Teddy picked up a tuft, examined it and laughed.

headline: They Helped Erase Ebola in Liberia. Now Liberia Is Erasing Them.
text: MARSHALL, Liberia — It was around 3 in the afternoon when Sherdrick Koffa spotted, in neatly written script, the name on the body bag that he was preparing to set ablaze.

headline: Living In Rego Park, Queens
text: The classic immigrant neighborhood has recently also attracted people from other parts of the metropolitan area looking for home values.

headline: Rego Park, Queens: Finding Value in a Melting Pot
text: Much of Rego Park retains the character of a classic New York immigrant neighborhood. Imported goods from Russia and other countries line shelves at the NetCost Market on Queens Boulevard, and Uzbeki fare like chebureki, meat-filled turnovers, and shish kebab is on the menu at Cheburechnaya on 63rd Drive.

headline: Street Style Favorites of 2015
text: A countdown of the Top 25 most “liked” street style photos on our @nytimesfashion Instagram account in 2015.

headline: As Beijing Shuts Down Over Smog Alert, Worse-Off Neighbors Carry On
text: BEIJING — The Chinese capital endured another day under an air quality “red alert” on Wednesday, with schools still closed, half of all cars kept off the roads and factories shut. But in other cities across northern China, tens of millions of people went about their daily routines in toxic air that was far worse than Beijing’s.

headline: Does Your School Offer Enough Opportunities to Learn Computer Programming?
text: This is Computer Science Education Week, and schools around the world are participating in Hour of Code events.

headline: Third Assailant in Bataclan Paris Attack Was a Frenchman
text: PARIS — The third attacker at the Bataclan concert hall, where 90 people were killed in the terrorist attacks here last month, was a 23-year-old native of northeastern France who had gone to fight in Syria, a lawyer for his family said Wednesday.

headline: Gunfight at Taliban Hostage Siege in Kandahar Kills Dozens
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — A hostage siege by Taliban attackers near the Kandahar Airfield military base stretched into a second day on Wednesday, leaving dozens dead. And in neighboring Helmand Province, the insurgents were reported to have overrun a major district.

headline: ‘The Japanese Lover,’ by Isabel Allende
text: Isabel Allende has built her reputation on romantic love. But her new fairy tale of a novel, “The Japanese Lover,” doesn’t allow love to get in the way of comfort. As in all of Allende’s fiction, we find a large, colorful cast of characters, this time swirling around the octogenarian Alma Belasco, happily if peculiarly ensconced in Lark House, a retirement home in San Francisco. Foremost is Irina Bazili, the young Moldovan immigrant whose repressed “terrors” of adolescence form a drumbeat of foreshadowing through the three years of her service to Alma. But as the story lurches back to the late 1930s and then to the highlights between, we also meet Alma’s Jewish family in pre-World War II Europe; the San Francisco relatives who adopt her; the entire family of her Japanese lover, Ichimei Fukuda; and a host of other lovers, care givers, evildoers and saints. No character is so minor as to lack a back story. At the same time, no character, including Alma and Irina, manages to fill in his or her outlines and command our undivided attention.

headline: Antony Beevor’s ‘Ardennes 1944’
text: On Christmas Eve 1944, some 30 soldiers in gray SS uniforms entered the village of Bande in Belgium, following in the wake of the German units that had punched a huge hole in Allied lines. They were, in a way, the first “European” security force — French, Belgian and Dutch fascists led by a Swiss, all in the service of the Sicherheitsdienst (SD), the secret service of the SS. They gathered all of the Belgian males of military age and, with the exception of one who escaped, beat them and shot each one in the back of the head. The SD troopers were not alone: Particularly (but not exclusively) in the elite Waffen-SS units, it was common to plunder, rape and murder the hapless villagers of the Ardennes, who had thought themselves liberated, their war over.

headline: ‘Hubris: The Tragedy of War in the Twentieth Century,’ by Alistair Horne
text: In 1984, the eminent American historian Barbara W. Tuchman, known for narrative masterpieces like “The Guns of August” and “The Proud Tower,” published a disjointed volume called “The March of Folly.” In it, she attempted to generalize about various mistakes made over the centuries, beginning with the Trojans opening their city walls to a wooden Greek horse, continuing on to the Renaissance popes who failed to stem the abuses leading to the Reformation and the British leaders who failed to prevent or stop an American revolt, before concluding with the mishandling of the Vietnam War — which for obvious reasons of proximity clearly was the mistake closest to her heart.

headline: Does Exercise Help Keep Our Brains Young?
text: Physical fitness may be critical for maintaining a relatively youthful and nimble brain as we age, according to a new study of brain activation patterns in older people.

headline: Charlie Parker Opera Will Go On

When Gotham Chamber Opera closed this fall, it looked like one of the casualties would be the New York premiere of “Charlie Parker’s Yardbird,” the ambitious new work it had co-commissioned with Opera Philadelphia and which it had planned to perform at the Apollo Theater, where Charlie Parker himself played.

text: LONDON — The French luxury goods group Kering said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to sell the Italian shoemaker Sergio Rossi to the private equity firm Investindustrial, concluding months of negotiations.

text: With all the buzz and headlines on campaigns’ “going digital,” an old political standby is feeling left out: local television networks.

text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Afghan political leaders publicly warned President Ashraf Ghani not to smile when he came to Pakistan for a global conference on Wednesday, but he soon found that to be hard going.

headline: Chinese-Language Readers Speak Out on the Emissions Challenge
text: As negotiators from nearly 200 countries meet in Paris to work on an accord to address climate change, we asked readers of The New York Times’s Chinese-language website how pollution affected their lives, what they believed caused the problem and what could be done.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Kids Demanding Pets
text: Brooke writes: We recently had to put down our dog. I got him before I had children; now I have three. We weren’t sure we’d get another dog, but seeing my kids react to life without a pet has changed my mind. My husband disagrees.

headline: A Life on the Move Molds a U.C.L.A. Basketball Star
text: LOS ANGELES — Home for Nirra Fields these days is a room in a five-bedroom suite on the U.C.L.A. campus. It is not luxurious: Fields has decorated it with basketball and family pictures, and she shares a common space and a single bathroom with four other students. But the space is clean, and it is organized, and — this is most important — it is all hers.

headline: Serious Play
text: Stephen Shore was 24 in 1972 when he took his first photographic road trip across the United States. Using color film and a 35-millimeter Rollei, he shot a bewildering variety of subjects: roads, homes, gas stations, fluorescent bulbs, pay phones, hotel beds, cars and televisions. He took pictures of friends and strangers, meals and toilets, framed paintings on walls, fridges left open, shop fronts after hours: anything, it seemed, at which the camera could be pointed. The body of work he made over the next two years, eventually exhibited and published as ‘‘American Surfaces,’’ feels oddly familiar now. With its flatness and indiscriminate subject matter, it looks just like the stuff people put on Instagram. But for all their casual affect, Shore’s images are sophisticated, supported by an instinct for pictorial structure. Along with William Eggleston, he was a pioneer of an American visual demotic, long before anyone could have dreamed of social media.

headline: What Should I Have Done After an I.V.F. Mix-Up?
text: I continue to struggle with decisions I made many years ago following an in vitro mix-up. The technology was then relatively new. I became pregnant with another couple’s child because of the negligence of the medical staff during the transfer of embryos from the petri dish to my womb. The mistake was discovered when the nurse called me by the wrong name as I was wheeled out of the operating room. I asked my husband to make sure our embryos were not at that moment being transferred into another woman. Thankfully, that had not happened.

headline: Consider (Cooking) the Clam
text: ‘‘To catch a clam,’’ begins a book I find profound on many subjects, ‘‘you must first find it.’’ Mr. Curtis Badger, the author, is aware that with his pleonasm, he risks sounding obvious. But he has his reasons. To him, finding a clam entails thinking like one. Clams are so different from humans that good interspecies relations demand sometimes considering just what a clam is after: a shallow, sandy substrate of the ocean floor, in a salt marsh, amid Spartina grasses, surrounded by other clams and a steady tidal flow.

headline: In New ‘Star Wars,’ Daisy Ridley and John Boyega Brace for Galactic Fame
text: When “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” opens on Dec. 18 and, for the first time in nearly a decade, moviegoers can return to that galaxy of long ago and far, far away, they will find that it contains two new stars. The film, which is directed by J. J. Abrams and continues the interstellar saga of Luke Skywalker, Princess Leia and Han Solo some 30 years after the events of “Return of the Jedi” (1983), is also a launching pad for two young actors who are barely half as old as the “Star Wars” franchise itself.

headline: The Deported
text: Kelvin Villanueva was almost home one night last June when a policeman stopped him for a broken taillight. From his truck, he could see his longtime girlfriend, Suelen Bueno, waiting for him behind the glass door of their apartment. She often did that when he worked late. Villanueva supervised a small team of Hondurans — like him, undocumented migrants — who did finish carpentry on construction projects throughout Kansas City. It was normal for them to put in 12-to-14-hour days. During his 15 years in the United States, he had never been pulled over. Still, Bueno worried. The threat of deportation did not subside with time. You just had more to lose.

headline: Campaign to Lower Voting Age to 16 in Local Races Ignites a Debate
text: Turning 16, for many teenagers, means finally driving a car without supervision or starting the college search. Now, a new campaign is hoping to add the ability to vote in local elections to the milestones of that age.

headline: Yahoo to Keep Alibaba Stake but Spin Off Core Businesses
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Even after the Internal Revenue Service refused in September to grant its blessing to Yahoo’s proposed tax-free spinoff of its $32 billion stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, Marissa Mayer was determined to go forward with the deal. In late October, Ms. Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, told shareholders that the plan was on track, and the preparations were still continuing last month.

headline: Thai Police Investigate U.S. Ambassador on Suspicion of Insulting King
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Thailand’s aggressive campaign to protect its ailing king from criticism escalated into a diplomatic feud on Wednesday when the Thai police said they were investigating the United States ambassador to the country in connection with a royal insult.

headline: Condemnation of Trump Plan Can’t Bridge Divide Among Republicans
text: Condemnations of Donald J. Trump’s call for a temporary ban on Muslim immigrants reverberated across the political spectrum and the globe on Tuesday. Mr. Trump drew fire from the leaders of both parties in Washington and from his Democratic opponents.

headline: Cameron Scoggins Brings the ‘Bro’ to a Very Strange Family in ‘Hir’
text: Cameron Scoggins was catnapping, his long frame filling a couch before an interview at Playwrights Horizons. If he’s a bit tired these days, it’s not surprising. Isaac, the character he plays in Taylor Mac’s play “Hir,” is a tightly wound former Marine who returns home after a dishonorable discharge and finds his family utterly transformed: His younger sister, Maxine, is now his brother, Max (Tom Phelan), and his abusive father (Daniel Oreskes) has become a meek puppet of his wife (Kristine Nielsen).

headline: Officer Takes Stand in Freddie Gray Case
text: BALTIMORE — A cool and composed Officer William G. Porter took the witness stand in his own defense Wednesday, telling a jury he thought Freddie Gray was faking his injuries and had no idea the young man’s life was in danger until a police transport van arrived at the Western District police station and he opened the door to find Mr. Gray, shackled and unresponsive, slumped against a bench inside.

headline: Fortress Resort in Alberta Slowly Catching Its Breath
text: Unlike its competitors in Banff National Park, Fortress Mountain Resort is little known as a skiing destination outside of Alberta. But despite that, it is still familiar to much of the world, for a quite a different reason.

headline: Climate Negotiators Face Hurdles on Key Issues as Deadline Looms
text: LE BOURGET, France — Less than two days before their deadline to conclude a sweeping new climate accord, negotiators from nearly 200 countries have yet to resolve major issues, such as how and when pledged cuts to carbon emissions would be verified.

headline: Angela Merkel’s War for Europe
text: HAMBURG — FOR the 10 years that she has occupied the German chancellor’s office, Angela Merkel has kept her country out of any meaningful military engagement, most recently in Libya, even if this meant leaving her European partners in the lurch. Now, with her decision to commit fighting forces in Syria, the chancellor is not only entering her first war, she is entering a new kind of world war.

headline: Afghanistan Hopes W.T.O. Membership Can Reboot Its Battered Economy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Its chief export is opium and its main “import” is international aid. But Afghanistan is about to join the World Trade Organization, in what officials hope is a sign of better things to come for this impoverished, war-ravaged country.

headline: The Original Nike Windbreaker Gets a High-Fashion Update
text: Sneakerheads, stand down — Nike will spend 2016, an Olympics year, celebrating the jacket that put it on the apparel map at the 1980 U.S. Olympic trials. Both the Japanese label Sacai and the Italian sportswear brand Stone Island updated the Windrunner in honor of the occasion: Sacai’s creative director, and frequent Nike collaborator, Chitose Abe rendered the hood and body in an irreverent faux-fur; Stone Island brought its material and dyeing expertise to the silhouette with water- and wind-resistant Mussola Gommata and Nylon Metal fabrics. The two resulting styles “couldn’t be more different,” says NikeLab senior design director Jarrett Reynolds. The sportswear staple “continues to inspire, not only those who wear it, but those who use it as a canvas for their own creation.”

headline: Netanyahu Says He’ll Still Meet With Donald Trump, Despite His Remarks on Muslims

headline: At Least 9,115 Killed in Ukraine Conflict, U.N. Says
text: GENEVA — At least 9,115 people have been killed in the 21 months since the outbreak of hostilities in eastern Ukraine in April 2014, United Nations monitors in Ukraine reported on Wednesday, an increase of more than a thousand since the United Nations’ last estimate, in September. An estimated 20,797 have been injured.

headline: The Top 100 New York Times Stories of 2015, by Total Time Spent

headline: 1890: Nihilists on Trial in Russia
text: ST. PETERSBURG — The trial of Nihilists, which is at present proceeding before a special section of the Senate, sitting as a District Court of St. Petersburg, will probably last until the end of the year, for the prisoners are numerous, having been arrested on different grounds at different times since the early part of the current year. They are being tried in parties of five. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 10, 1890

headline: British Petition to Keep Donald Trump Out of Country
text: LONDON — More than 360,000 people, angered by Donald J. Trump’s call to ban the entry of Muslims into the United States, have signed a petition accusing him of hate speech and asking the British government to bar him from the country.

headline: 1940: Murillo Canvas Is Sent to Spain
text: VICHY — The famous seventeenth century painting ‘‘The Immaculate Conception,’’ by Murillo, which used to attract the immediate attention of all who visited the Grand Gallery of the Louvre Museum at Paris by the angelic expression on the face of the central figure and the delicate blue tint of the draperies, has been handed over to Spain by the Pétain government. It will henceforth adorn the walls of the Prado Museum in Madrid. The loss of this celebrated masterpiece was first communicated to the French people today [Dec. 9] in the form of a Madrid dispatch of two paragraphs published at the bottom of a page in ‘‘Le Temps.’’ It stated merely that Francois Pietri, the French Ambassador at Madrid, had gone to the station there to meet the train bringing the picture to its new home. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 10, 1940

What happened during the post-Civil War period, and how we understand what happened, matters.

headline: A Different World
text: With its irreverent title and minimalist yet bouncy visual style, “Dare to Disappoint,” Ozge Samanci’s graphic coming-of-age memoir, seems at a quick glance as though it might be subtitled something like “Growing Up in Marin County.” But this is a book about growing up in Turkey — worlds away in its cultural apparatus from comfy American suburban life, yet still a place where teenagers of a certain social class believe they must compete fiercely to have any shot at a respectable future.

headline: Where Katharine Hepburn Got Her Chocolates

headline: First Dengue Fever Vaccine Approved by Mexico

headline: The Internet’s Loop of Action and Reaction Is Worsening

Trump and Hillary Clinton said this week that we should think about shutting down parts of the Internet to stop terrorist groups from inspiring and recruiting followers in distant lands. Mr. Trump even suggested an expert who’d be perfect for the job: “We have to go see Bill Gates and a lot of different people that really understand what’s happening, and we have to talk to them — maybe, in certain areas, closing that Internet up in some way,” he said on Monday in South Carolina.

Taylor, a former corporate wunderkind who became president of CBS at 37, unloaded an underperforming network-owned property, the New York Yankees, and then, as a sometimes nettlesome overachiever, was fired by William S. Paley, the imperious CBS chairman and founder, died on Dec. 3 in Salisbury Township, Pa. He was 80.

headline: C. Gerald Fraser, Longtime Reporter for The Times, Dies at 90

headline: In Southwest Germany, Charming Day Trips From a Charming Town

Especially if said latrine (and the museum it’s a part of) is in Rottenburg, already recommended to me as a storybook medieval town. And if Rottenburg was just a pleasant seven-mile bike ride down the Neckar River from Tübingen, itself a storybook town.

headline: New Policy Strands Thousands of Migrants in Greece

headline: Thousands of Migrants Stranded in Greece as Route North Is Narrowed
text: IDOMENI, Greece — There has been a rough triage taking place the last few weeks along the barbed-wire and chain-link fence separating Greece from Macedonia.

headline: Jeb Bush Jumps In at a ‘Life of the ‘Party’ Event
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Jeb Bush … party animal?

headline: What Do Campus Protesters Really Want?
text: A wave of campus protests against racial discrimination has drawn intense media attention. But how well did the media capture what students were actually saying? Not too well, according to the students themselves — and our own analysis.

headline: Tech Toys to Inspire a Child’s Imagination
text: Still looking for the perfect holiday gift for that little someone on your list? A lot of today’s technology is geared toward adults, but there are exciting new tech toys for children, too. Here are some good options to help a child on your list create, learn, explore and have fun.

headline: Mets Acquire Neil Walker and Asdrubal Cabrera, Reshaping Middle of Infield
text: NASHVILLE — A day after losing out on Ben Zobrist, their top free-agent target, the Mets refashioned their infield on Wednesday. They traded their fifth starter, Jon Niese, to the Pittsburgh Pirates for second baseman Neil Walker and acquired the free-agent shortstop Asdrubal Cabrera, a two-time All-Star with the Cleveland Indians who played for Tampa Bay last season.

headline: Chinese Justice System Relies on Torture, U.N. Panel Says
text: GENEVA — Torture remains deeply entrenched in China’s criminal justice system, United Nations experts said Wednesday, calling for an end to the widespread use of secret detention in “black prisons” and to the punishment of lawyers for representing clients.

headline: Wrap Skirts to Build a Holiday Look Around
text: Plus: Ferragamo’s new shoes, in time for the holidays; a new collection of fashion-focused workout clothes and the winner of the British emerging accessory designer award riffs on his popular heart-shaped ring.

headline: Israel Holds 5 Arab Israelis Suspected of Supporting ISIS
text: JERUSALEM — Five Palestinian citizens of Israel have been arrested in recent weeks on suspicion of supporting the Islamic State, acquiring rifles and practicing shooting in a forest, according to Israeli officials.

headline: Good News: Mets Lose Out on Ben Zobrist
text: Ben Zobrist, the apple of the Mets’ eye this off-season, decided to spurn the family Wilpon and sign with the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Sam Mendes Leaves ‘Chocolate Factory’ on Its Way to Broadway
text: Sam Mendes is withdrawing as the director of the Broadway-bound musical “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,” allowing the producing team free rein to rework the commercially successful but critically divisive show before it opens in New York.

headline: Studios Blamed in Directors Guild Study on Hiring of Women and Minority Filmmakers
text: The long established paucity of women directors in Hollywood has not only led to a federal investigation into gender discrimination, at the behest of the A.C.L.U., it has also spurred one of the industry’s most important groups to take aim at the discrepancy – and take studios to task for failing to effect change.

headline: ‘Happy Birthday’ Copyright Case Reaches a Settlement
text: After more than two years of litigation, “Happy Birthday to You” — often called the most popular song in the world, but one that has long been under copyright — is one step closer to joining the public domain.

headline: In Beijing, a Day Off School for Smog Is No Fun for Anyone
text: BEIJING — Wu Yiling, a 15-year-old student with a love of hamburgers and Hello Kitty, celebrated when she heard that her school was canceling classes for three days because of air pollution. Finally, she would be able to stay up late watching her favorite Korean soap operas, she imagined, and playing computer games with friends.

headline: When Seeking Better C.D. Yields Can Be Costly
text: If the Federal Reserve acts as expected next week to raise interest rates, savers will be on the lookout for certificates of deposit offering better yields.

headline: Apple Names Periscope the Top iPhone App of 2015
text: The live-streaming video app Periscope was named the iPhone app of the year, according to the Apple editors who discover, select and promote the apps and entertainment in the App Store and on iTunes.

headline: Tylenol Is Ineffective Against Flu Symptoms
text: Tylenol is a popular remedy for treating the symptoms of flu. But a randomized trial has found that the drug is no more effective than a placebo, with no discernible effect at all on reducing fever or other flu symptoms.

headline: Study Finds Director Pay Rising Sharply
text: It pays to sit on the board of an oil, mining or energy company.

headline: Suspect in Colorado Planned Parenthood Rampage Declares ‘I’m Guilty’ in Court
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — “I’m guilty. There’s no trial,” Robert L. Dear Jr. told a startled courtroom here on Wednesday. “I’m a warrior for the babies.”

headline: Review: Samuel Blaser Quartet’s ‘Spring Rain’ Recalls a Ghost
text: “Spring Rain”

headline: Defense Lawyers Point Out ‘Holes’ in Case Against Dean Skelos and Son
text: Defense lawyers for State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son told jurors at their federal corruption trial on Wednesday that the case against the two men amounted to little more than distractions, snippets of conversations taken out of context, and self-serving lies from two of the prosecution’s central witnesses.

headline: Tiny Homes You Can Collect
text: Inside the rain-battered tents of last week’s Art Basel Miami Beach art and design fairs, there were bears made from feathers, a painting made from shoes and shoelaces, and a stabbing incident involving an X-Acto knife that was not a performance piece. Among these and other, expected curiosities were two architectural prototypes: an aluminum and steel dining pavilion designed by Zaha Hadid with Patrik Schumacher, which sprouted like a kind of Martian flower over a molded timber table and chairs, and a 350-square-foot white box sheathed in laminated plywood designed by Gluckman Tang as an art pavilion. (It would certainly make an appropriate container to house one’s art fair purchases once home.)

headline: For Indians, Smog and Poverty Are Higher Priorities Than Talks in Paris
text: MUMBAI — Under a fingernail moon at Sassoon Docks, Parumati Mangela, a fisherwoman, sat on her haunches, grimacing. Something strange is happening over the Arabian Sea, she said: “The sky is getting hot more and more,” perhaps because something has angered the goddess Lakshmi.

headline: Review: R. Kelly’s New Album, ‘The Buffet,’ Offers Sex and Sentiment
text: You don’t need to know that R. Kelly wrote, by his own count, 462 songs in preparation for “The Buffet,” his 13th album, to understand that he is a protean character. (It’s nice to know it, though: 462 is a comical number.) The spirit of not getting stuck is an integral part of Mr. Kelly’s work, even more than his specialization in super-sexed subject matter.

headline: Derek Jeter on His Second Act, as a Sports Media Mogul
text: “Now he’s the competition,” said Efraim Grinberg, the chief executive of Movado watches, chiding a reporter in his company’s West 39th Street showroom on Tuesday, waiting for Derek Jeter to arrive.

headline: Review: Larry Keigwin Gives Young Choreographers a Break at the Joyce
text: Mr.Keigwin — whose own work will be performed by Paul Taylor’s company in March — has invited young up-and-comers to create pieces for Keigwin & Company.

headline: Christmas Trees, Good and Bad
text: A survey of holiday greenery in New York City.

headline: Review: Matthew Welch Offers Ethereal Chamber Music at the Stone
text: The music of Matthew Welch, who began a weeklong residency at the Stone on Tuesday, draws on a world of influences. His opening set, performed by the ensemble Cantata Profana, packed in references to Highland bagpipes, Balinese funerary rites, Minimalism, Borges, Beckett and Buddha. Yet much of the resulting chamber music is exquisitely ethereal, made up of delicate, transparent textures that hum with expressive tension. If Mr. Welch were a chef, he’d be the kind who pushes the boundaries of molecular gastronomy, transforming earthy ingredients into translucent beads of pure flavor.

headline: Review: Handel’s ‘Messiah,’ With Heightened Drama
text: It’s kind of like the lighting of the Christmas tree at nearby Rockefeller Center: For many New Yorkers of a classical bent, the holiday season officially begins with the two performances of Handel’s “Messiah” at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, featuring the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys and the period-instrument band Concert Royal.

headline: Manhattan as Tinsel Town: Holiday Decorations Traditional and Weird
text: For large segments of the resident Grinch population, holiday time can be a period of ambivalence, malaise, Bing Crosby overload and eggnog-induced regret. It is tough enough inducing jollity when looming at month’s end is what amounts to a calendar blackout — consecutive days of holy observance when little or nothing gets done — followed by the New Year and lots of credit-card debt.

headline: Debbie Harry and Keira Knightley Honor Valentino Designers
text: At what was billed as “an evening honoring Valentino” at Lincoln Center on Monday, it should not come as a surprise that many guests wore Valentino.

headline: Blendle, a Journalism Payments Start-Up, Targets a U.S. Start Date
text: Blendle, a publishing start-up that aims to simplify the way that people pay for journalism online, will be introduced in beta form in America in early 2016, the company said Wednesday.

headline: Deborah Kass: “No Kidding”
text: The artist’s new exhibition at Paul Kasmin Gallery offers social critique by way of references to pop culture.

headline: Art as Social Critique — With a Little Help From the Rolling Stones and Katy Perry
text: When you walk into “No Kidding,” the artist Deborah Kass’s exhibition opening tonight at Paul Kasmin Gallery, be prepared for a strange sensation: you can almost hear Kass’s new mixed-media paintings in addition to seeing them. “The thing about music is that it’s so democratic, and art isn’t,” Kass said when T visited her studio last month. Throughout the show, the artist alludes to popular song lyrics from a wide swath of eras, from the 1895 waltz “The Band Played On” to Fats Waller’s 1929 “(What Did I Do to Be So) Black and Blue” to Katy Perry’s 2010 “Teenage Dream.” The references are diverse, but taken as a whole, their message is clear: a deep-seated, and deeply droll, cynicism about the present political and artistic climate, and about our capacity to fiddle while Rome burns. Other pieces in the show ironically deploy phrases like “GOOD TIMES” and, in several three-panel works, “WHO BLUE WHO,” to much the same effect.

headline: Christmas Shows Are TV’s December Comfort Food
text: At the very least, the War on Christmas is not being waged on television.

headline: With ‘Meet the Composer,’ Nadia Sirota Illuminates New Music
text: The violist Nadia Sirota, the daughter of a composer, was born into the world of contemporary music. At Juilliard, she set aside Bach’s sonatas in favor of commissioning pieces from classmates like Nico Muhly. And now she has made an entire career — a sustainable one, at that — of championing new work.

headline: Obama Calls for End to Bigotry, in Implicit Rebuke of Donald Trump
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday called for Americans to reject “bigotry in all its forms” and keep pressing for equality “no matter what ugliness might bubble up,” appearing to use the 150th anniversary of the constitutional amendment abolishing slavery to challenge the incendiary anti-Muslim politics espoused by Donald J. Trump.

headline: How to Value Yahoo’s Core Business
text: With Yahoo exploring a separation of its core business, the world may soon know what the company — minus its lucrative stake in Alibaba — is worth.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 14: Vikings at Cardinals
text: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday night’s game between the Minnesota Vikings and the Arizona Cardinals. Check back Friday for analysis on Sunday’s games and Monday’s matchup between the Giants and the Miami Dolphins. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Senate Republicans Introduce Bill for Puerto Rico Relief
text: Under pressure to help Puerto Rico avoid a bond default on Jan. 1, Senate Republicans introduced a bill on Wednesday to extend several forms of assistance to the island.

headline: Vincent Gray, Former Washington Mayor, Won’t Be Charged in Federal Inquiry
text: Vincent C. Gray, the former mayor of Washington whose tenure was frequently overshadowed by a federal investigation into his 2010 campaign, will not be charged in connection with the inquiry, prosecutors said Wednesday.

headline: House Republicans Denounce Obama’s Handling of Prisoner Exchange
text: WASHINGTON — After months of secret talks in early 2014 on a potential deal to swap five Taliban detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for a captive American soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, an agreement seemed near that May. But the chief American negotiator sent an email to the Pentagon warning that any leak could scuttle it.

headline: Review: ‘The Verdict’ Speaks in a Grisham-esque Tongue With a British Accent
text: Readers who enjoy having curveballs pitched at them are sure to appreciate Nick Stone’s hyperactive throwing arm. Mr. Stone, an award-winning mystery writer who is much better known in his native Britain than he is here, has come up with a legal thriller called “The Verdict.” It may well find an American audience without a helping hand, but comparisons to John Grisham will ease its way. They’re valid, and not just because of the blunt title. The Grisham feeling persists, even though this book’s courtroom scenes are set in the Old Bailey and feature white horsehair wigs.

headline: 1926 | Draw, She Said
text: Don’t tell Erick Erickson — the blogger who objected graphically to our front-page editorial, “The Gun Epidemic” — but guns had a place in the corporate culture of The New York Times long before his parents were born.

headline: ESPN and College Football Playoff Agree Not to Air Daily Fantasy Ads
text: ESPN and College Football Playoff officials have agreed that there will be no advertising for daily fantasy games during the telecasts of the national semifinals or the national championship game this season, the latest move by college athletics to distance itself from an increasingly controversial business that critics say constitutes gambling.

text: The campaign finance lawyer for the outside groups supporting Jeb Bush has accused Donald J. Trump of improperly mingling his corporate business with his campaign work and has asked the Federal Election Commission to investigate.

headline: Race and College Admissions at the Supreme Court
text: Racial diversity is essential in carrying out the missions of institutions like universities, corporations and the United States military. Affirmative action is one tool that’s useful in achieving that diversity. Some Supreme Court justices, however, seem unable to accept this fact, despite decades of experience and evidence showing its value.

headline: Competing Authorizations for Military Force
text: President Obama challenged Congress on Sunday to pass new legislation authorizing the use of military force in the fight against the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL. The following documents include four different proposed versions of that legislation.

text: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress have criticized President Obama’s response to the Islamic State — also known as the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, ISIL, or ISIS — but have been slow to authorize the use of force against the group.

headline: Happiness Doesn’t Bring Good Health, Study Finds
text: Go ahead and sulk. Unhappiness won’t kill you.

headline: Wool Baseball Caps for the Chilly Off-Season
text: Sporty, warm looks are a winner.

headline: Chicago’s Mayor Demands Sweeping Police Reform
text: CHICAGO — Facing sharply escalating criticism of him and his Police Department, Mayor Rahm Emanuel used an unusually emotional address on Wednesday to call for sweeping changes in the ways the police use force, treat black residents and discipline abusive officers.

headline: Kenneth Griffin, Richest Man in Illinois, Endorses Marco Rubio
text: The billionaire hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin is endorsing Senator Marco Rubio of Florida for president, adding another major Republican donor to Mr. Rubio’s roster.

headline: New York State Attorney General Takes Control of Inquiry Into Fatal Police Shooting
text: The New York State attorney general’s office has taken control of an inquiry into the fatal shooting on Tuesday of an unarmed man in a wooded area in Westchester County by a New York City police officer.

headline: Canada: Cabdrivers Stage Uber Protest
text: Cabdrivers seeking a legal crackdown against Uber, the ride-sharing service, snarled traffic on expressways and downtown streets in Toronto on Wednesday. The disruption began during the morning rush hour with slow-moving convoys of taxis. Later, cabdrivers blocked a major downtown intersection. A police officer on a bicycle suffered minor injuries when he was clipped by a taxi. A television crew also recorded a taxi driver pounding on a small sedan carrying an Uber passenger. John Tory, the city’s mayor, said that the city was enforcing current laws against Uber while developing additional regulations. But Mr. Tory condemned the protest. “Dangerous and divisive tactics do nothing to address these issues,” he said.

headline: West Bank: Attackers Wound 4 Israelis
text: Gunmen presumed to be Palestinians fired more than 20 bullets at an Israeli car in a drive-by shooting in the occupied West Bank on Wednesday, wounding an Israeli couple, according to the Israeli military and news media. The Israelis were identified as Shaul and Rachel Nir. Mr. Nir was a leader of the so-called Jewish Underground that carried out attacks against Palestinians in the 1980s. He was sentenced to life in prison for his role in a gun and grenade attack on the Islamic College in Hebron, in which three Palestinian students were killed, but his sentence was commuted and he was released after about seven years. Earlier on Wednesday, a Palestinian stabbed and wounded two Israelis in the West Bank city of Hebron, the Israeli authorities said. An Israeli security guard fatally shot the assailant at the scene.

text: 8:25 p.m. Eastern, NFL Network

headline: New Jersey Officials See Hope for Jobs in Seton Hall’s Medical School Plan
text: New Jersey was once so chock-full of thriving pharmaceutical companies that it was known as America’s medicine chest. But that dominance eroded as one major drug company after another abandoned corporate campuses that had provided thousands of high-paying jobs.

headline: Donald Trump Loses Luster When Words Reach the Middle East
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — At Lifestyle, an inexpensive home furnishings store tucked inside the Mall of the Emirates here, shoppers on Wednesday examined lamps and picked up picture frames.

headline: Chief of Sprout Is Leaving the Company
text: Cindy Whitehead, who oversaw a long, but ultimately successful, effort to bring to market the first prescription drug to enhance women’s sexual drive, is leaving her post as chief executive of Sprout Pharmaceuticals.

text: Food pantries supply Vivian Green and her 88-year-old mother, Helen Taylor, with most of their meals these days. Ms. Green does not let any of it go to waste.

headline: Gucci Opens at Brookfield Place and Other Shopping Events
text: Ready to kick-start your holiday shopping? This week there’s a spate of holiday bazaars and pop-ups and a few major retail openings. You’ll find the Gucci designer Alessandro Michele’s hit accessories, like a floral print leather shoulder bag ($2,700), at the label’s new Brookfield Place store. At 200 Vesey Street.

headline: Regulator Is Said to Fine Fiat Chrysler $70 Million
text: Fiat Chrysler is expected to pay the federal government as much as $70 million in penalties for significantly underreporting the number of death and injury claims tied to potential defects in its cars, according to a person briefed on the fine.

headline: Senators Condemn Big Price Increases for Drugs
text: Senators from both parties on Wednesday denounced huge overnight price increases for decades-old drugs that have been made by some pharmaceutical companies lately, calling them unconscionable and detrimental to patients.

headline: Suit Claims Weeknd Song Infringes on Copyright of Film Soundtrack
text: The Weeknd’s song “The Hills” became one of the biggest hits of the year with a slithery electronic bass line. But according to a copyright infringement lawsuit filed on Wednesday, that bass line was taken without permission from the soundtrack of a little-noticed science-fiction thriller.

headline: Report Traces Ebola’s Spread in Liberia
text: Ebola viruses that sickened many people during the height of the epidemic in Liberia can be traced back to a single case of the disease probably introduced from Sierra Leone, according to a report published Wednesday in the journal Cell Host and Microbe. “The data are consistent with the vast majority of cases in Liberia coming from a single event,” said Jason T. Ladner of the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute for Infectious Diseases. The virus then spread from Liberia back into Guinea, where the current epidemic was first identified. Scientists analyzed genomic sequences from 140 blood samples, nearly 2 percent of all reported cases in Liberia, collected over 11 months, after a smaller outbreak had been controlled. Liberia had no new Ebola cases last week, and a recent cluster was most likely linked to a rare case of transmission from a survivor, officials said Wednesday.

headline: CVC Capital Plans São Paulo Office
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — The private equity firm CVC Capital Partners plans to open an office in São Paulo and take on a prominent Brazilian investment banker to run it.

headline: Kerry in Familiar Spot: Trying to Coax Deal in Meeting’s Closing Days
text: PARIS — For the second time this year, Secretary of State John Kerry has settled into a grand capital of Europe for talks that could shape the globe, not to mention his own reputation, for decades to come.

headline: Mike Rice, Disgraced Rutgers Coach, Returns to the Sideline
text: METUCHEN, N.J. — For more than two and a half years, Mike Rice had receded into the shadows after Rutgers fired him because of a scandal that wrecked his coaching career and turned him into a pariah.

headline: John Trudell, Outspoken Advocate for American Indians, Is Dead at 69
text: John Trudell, whose outspokenness and charisma made him a leading advocate of Native American rights, and who channeled his message of righteous defiance into poetry and songwriting, died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Clara County, Calif. He was 69.

headline: In Pursuit of Victory, the Diamondbacks Show No Sensitivity to Costs
text: NASHVILLE — Dave Stewart let the question hang there on Wednesday, like a poorly thrown split-finger fastball, the kind he rarely delivered during his heyday as a pitcher.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Says Texas Gunman Used Encryption to Text Overseas Terrorist
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said Wednesday that investigators could not read more than 100 text messages exchanged by one of the attackers in a shooting this year in Garland, Tex., because they were encrypted, adding fuel to law enforcement agencies’ contention that they need a way to circumvent commercially available encryption technology.

headline: Fatema Mernissi, a Founder of Islamic Feminism, Dies at 75
text: Fatema Mernissi, a Moroccan sociologist who was one of the founders of Islamic feminism, whose work included studies of the sexual politics of Islamic Scripture and a book based on her childhood in a domestic harem, died on Nov. 30 in Rabat. She was 75.

headline: Fan Injuries Spur M.L.B. to Call for Netting at Stadiums
text: After several gruesome incidents in which fans were struck by balls and shattered bats at games last season, Major League Baseball on Wednesday issued a recommendation for all 30 clubs to erect protective netting in front of the most exposed field-level seats from one dugout to the other.

headline: Hate Crime Inquiry Opened Into Vandalism of Sikh Temple in California
text: The police in Buena Park, Calif., said on Wednesday that they had opened a hate crimes investigation into the vandalism of a Sikh house of worship after its members found expletive-laced graffiti referencing Islam and the Islamic State just days after the San Bernardino terrorist attack.

headline: Lawmakers Rush to Cram Pet Projects Into Spending Deal Ahead of New Deadline
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional negotiators are lurching toward a year-end deal that could combine a $1.1 trillion omnibus spending bill with a slate of more than $750 billion in tax breaks for businesses and low-income workers, setting off a frenzied push by lawmakers, lobbyists and interest groups to attach pet provisions to the catchall legislative package.

headline: Finding Voice Again, Joe Biden Sees Time Left to Make a Difference
text: KIEV, Ukraine — As he stood next to Ukraine’s fresh-faced prime minister one day this week, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. looked like a stern uncle admonishing a recalcitrant youth.

headline: Review: Andrea McArdle and Kip Gilman Puzzle Out Love in ‘2 Across’
text: Catch a subway home from the San Francisco airport at 4 a.m., and you’d think you could have a quiet ride, just you and your crossword puzzle, duking it out. That’s not the way it goes, though, in “2 Across,” a meet-cute, sitcom-style two-hander starring Andrea McArdle as Janet, a puzzle aficionado in need of cheering up — but maybe not right this second, O.K.?

headline: Review: ‘The Golden Bride’ Walks Down the Aisle Again
text: The Russian shtetl in the long-lost, newly reconstructed Yiddish operetta “The Golden Bride” has a dreamy look about it, all latticework and whitewash, like the setting for a garden party. The people here may dream of riches — who doesn’t? — but they’re doing all right. If they leave this place for America, it’s only because an even better life awaits.

headline: Obstacles
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Hands up if you remember the Mazola margarine television commercial with the First Nations (I hope) actress who said, “You call it corn, but we call it maize …”

headline: A Congress That Doesn’t Want to Weigh In on War
text: WASHINGTON — Shortly after Paul D. Ryan became speaker, the chairmen of the House Armed Services and Intelligence Committees went to him with a difficult request: to help them put a bill on the House floor to authorize a war against the Islamic State extremist group.

headline: Arab-Israeli Parliament Member Sees Prospect for Peace
text: A prominent Arab-Israeli member of Israel’s Parliament whose party alliance made strong gains in the last election expressed optimism on Wednesday about the future of a more inclusive Israeli democracy and the creation of a Palestinian state.

headline: Yankees Trade Reliever Justin Wilson for Luis Cessa and Chad Green
text: NASHVILLE — Because of their bullpen depth and the value he might bring in return, the Yankees have explored trade possibilities involving their closer, Andrew Miller, this off-season. On Wednesday, though, they traded a different left-handed reliever.

headline: Australian Police Charge Five After Counterterrorism Raids
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Five people, including a 15-year-old boy, have been charged with terrorism-related offenses after arrests in Sydney on Thursday.

headline: Six Possible Deal Breakers in Spending Agreement
text: As the risk of a government shutdown looms, lawmakers are racing to attach pet provisions to a sweeping catchall legislative package, including numerous policy prescriptions by Republicans.

headline: Texas Fails to Block Entry of Syrian Refugees
text: HOUSTON — Texas officials escalated their effort on Wednesday to bar Syrian refugees from resettling in the state, asking a federal judge to stop the scheduled arrival of a group of refugees on Thursday.

headline: Trucker Cited for Running Light in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Path
text: Call it failure to yield to a mayor.

headline: Assertions of Hate Crime in Seattle After a Somali-American Teenager Falls to His Death
text: SEATTLE — The Seattle Police Department said Wednesday it was investigating the death of a 16-year-old Somali-American boy who died Saturday after a fall from a balcony near Seattle Central College, where he had been taking classes.

headline: G.M. Compensated Some Pre-Bankruptcy Crash Victims
text: WASHINGTON — As General Motors publicly expressed remorse over its decade-long failure to disclose defective ignition switches, it successfully fought to retain its protection from any lawsuits for crashes that occurred before its 2009 bankruptcy.

headline: Walmart Prepares to Enter Mobile Payments Business
text: Walmart is jumping into the crowded mobile payments business with a service called Walmart Pay, the retailer’s bid to gain the upper hand from the tech giants Apple, Samsung and Google in the next generation of consumer convenience.

headline: Carmelo Anthony and the Knicks Have No Shot in Utah
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Carmelo Anthony reclined on a padded seat Wednesday morning, speaking of his shooting touch as an impermanent entity, a feeling that comes and goes without much warning.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: We’re still just kids at heart when Tom Hanks, Tim Allen and company celebrate the 20th anniversary of “Toy Story.” Michael Bublé croons in the holidays in Tinseltown. And Dolly Parton remembers her Tennessee childhood and a gift that changed everything.

headline: Corrections: December 10, 2015
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Most of the black scientists in this country don’t come from schools like the University of Texas. They come from lesser schools where they do not feel that they’re being pushed ahead in classes that are too fast for them.”

headline: South Korean Labor Leader Leaves Temple to Surrender to Authorities
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A fugitive labor leader who had taken refuge in a well-known Buddhist temple surrendered to the authorities on Thursday, ending a 24-day standoff that had set off a rare police raid within the temple complex.

headline: Photographing the Refugee Trail by Drone
text: Immigration is a deeply personal matter for Rocco Rorandelli: He was born in Florence to a mother from the Bronx and a father from Italy, married an Indian woman and now lives in Rome raising twin boys who are part American. Yet when it came time to photograph the current refugee crisis in Europe, he took a decidedly impersonal approach: Rather than be wedged in among desperate migrants, he used a drone hovering over them.

headline: Why the New Education Law Is Good for Children Left Behind
text: THE No Child Left Behind law will soon be consigned to the dustbin of history. With a rare display of bipartisanship, Congress has overhauled federal education policy. The law’s successor, the Every Student Succeeds Act, is headed for the president’s desk, and he has signaled his intention to sign it.

headline: In Venezuela, a Triumph for the Opposition
text: On Sunday, voters in Venezuela delivered a stinging rebuke to Nicolás Maduro and his ruling party by electing a coalition of opposition lawmakers to Parliament that is large enough to challenge his socialist policies and could conceivably cut short his term in office.

headline: Guns and Thunder on the Supreme Court’s Right
text: The Supreme Court turns down new cases at the rate of 150 a week, and only rarely does one of those denials break through the fog to become news. It happened this week with the court’s refusal to hear an appeal challenging a Chicago suburb’s ban on the sale and ownership of assault weapons. Over the dissenting votes of Justices Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia, the court let stand a lower court’s ruling that the ban, adopted in 2013 by the city of Highland Park, was consistent with the right to gun ownership under the Second Amendment, as interpreted by the Supreme Court.

headline: The Trump Effect, and How It Spreads
text: Go ahead, deplore Donald Trump. Despise his message. Reject his appeals to exclusion and hatred. But do not make the mistake of treating him as a solitary phenomenon, a singular celebrity narcissist who has somehow, all alone, brought his party and its politics to the brink of fascism.

headline: Pentagon Seeks to Knit Foreign Bases Into ISIS-Foiling Network
text: WASHINGTON — As American intelligence agencies grapple with the expansion of the Islamic State beyond its headquarters in Syria, the Pentagon has proposed a new plan to the White House to build up a string of military bases in Africa, Southwest Asia and the Middle East.

headline: As Heisman Trophy Finalists Experience a Milestone, So Do Gamblers
text: The race for the Heisman Trophy is one of college football’s most engaging contests. Take a large pool of contestants, throw them into the rollicking up-and-down of the three-month regular season and then hang the finalists out to dry, sitting uncomfortably in suits in an oak-panel room in New York, until one of them lifts the hefty bronze statue.

headline: Delegates at Climate Talks Focus on Saving the World’s Forests
text: LE BOURGET, France — The climate deal being negotiated here is meant to begin a transformation of the world’s energy systems, but it has another goal that has received far less attention: a sweeping effort to save the world’s forests.

headline: What is Your Reaction to Donald Trump’s Proposal to Bar Muslims From Entering the Country?
text: Donald J. Trump called this week for the United States to bar all Muslims from entering the country until the nation’s leaders can “figure out what is going on” after the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline: VW Says Emissions Cheating Was Not a One-Time Error
text: WOLFSBURG, Germany — The chairman of Volkswagen said on Thursday that the decision by employees to cheat on emissions tests was made more than a decade ago, after they realized they could not meet United States clean air standards legally.

headline: ‘The Mark and the Void,’ by Paul Murray
text: Paul Murray’s satirical novel of the Irish banking crisis, “The Mark and the Void,” takes place primarily at the International Financial Services Center, a section of Dublin that functions as a tax haven for multinational corporations, a place where billions in assets hide behind brass nameplates in the Transaction House and shadow banks operate hidden from the prying eyes of regulators. It’s anonymous by design. As one of Murray’s characters explains: “We’re in the middle of Dublin, where Joyce set ‘Ulysses.’ But it doesn’t look like Dublin. We could be in London or Frankfurt or Kuala Lumpur.”

headline: ‘The White Road,’ by Edmund de Waal
text: A friend of mine inherited a ­Bavarian coffee set from her maternal great-­grandmother, a woman who fled Europe in the late 1930s, carrying little more than the purpose-built, velvet-lined case that still holds it. That family is scattered across the globe and the way of life the coffee set embodied has vanished, but the dainty china pot and matching cups remain flawless. Porcelain is like that. We all know that the sweep of a careless elbow can shatter it into unmendable bits. But take some basic precautions and in a hundred years it will look as good as new — its colors undimmed, its whites snowy — after you and your children are dead and gone. It is fragile, and it is strong.

headline: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, From Captivity to Courtroom

Within a day, he was captured by the Taliban and held prisoner for five years, setting off a furious search and high-level diplomatic negotiations, and ending with his exit on May 31, 2014, aboard a helicopter flown by American commandos.
