headline: Great Performers Above It All
text: The year’s best actors — as chosen by A. O. Scott — in a series of photographic tributes to classic flight scenes from the movies.

headline: Behind the Scenes of ‘Take Flight’
text: Some might imagine that all the magic happens in postproduction these days, but so much of it is actually done on the set. For several of our short films, special-effects technicians strapped the actors into harnesses and worked these rigs in three-person teams, pulling them to and fro, almost like marionettes. Even from that perch, the actors had to do an incredible amount of work to complete the illusion: to convincingly look weightless or airborne, even when they were strung up somewhere in Los Angeles. I had no idea just how physically demanding the work is. It’s not easy to fly.

headline: Congress Gives Itself 5 More Days to Reach Spending Deal
text: Congressional leaders officially threw in the towel on Wednesday on trying to meet a Friday deadline to pass a funding deal to keep the government open.

headline: Editor’s Letter: Take Flight With Virtual Reality
text: Movies are one of the few forms of illusion to which we regularly submit ourselves without skepticism or scorn. They transport us with visual effects, and we are happy to enjoy the journey without scrutinizing too hard how it was accomplished. Never is this more true than when the illusion is one of flight, which may be Hollywood’s most enduring and iconic form of movie magic. When Superman blazes through the sky or Mary Poppins floats away, few moviegoers stop to ask how they achieved liftoff.

headline: The Art of Flying in the Movies
text: At 10:35 on the morning of Dec. 17, 1903, on the sand dunes of Kitty Hawk, N.C. ... Do I need to finish the sentence?

headline: Chinese Rights Lawyer’s Trial Over Online Comments to Begin Soon
text: BEIJING — One of China’s feistiest and most prominent civil rights lawyers, Pu Zhiqiang, will stand trial on Monday over charges related to his combative online comments, his lawyers said on Thursday, after months of uncertainty about when the contentious case would be heard in court.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: SmartWool Socks
text: In recent years, I have taken note of a creeping subversive streak in sock culture, from the outrageously patterned stockings peeking from beneath the cuffs of straphanging bankers to the pot-­leaf-­printed numbers worn by skateboarders. Like a paper bag around a can of Coors Banquet, the lowly sock seems to have become a vehicle for safe transgression. Even those of us hemmed in by dress code can still challenge society’s strictures, from ankle ­height. And although my home office makes no particular demands on my wardrobe, I, too, have been protesting quietly with my feet.

headline: 5 Things Skiers May Not Know About the Trail Map
text: Skiers know that the trail map is an essential part of coming up with a game plan for a day on the mountain. It’s the best way to make sure that an advanced beginner, say, doesn’t get stuck at the top of a double-black-diamond mogul run that looks for all the world like the side of an elevator shaft with bumpy walls. Or that an expert doesn’t inadvertently wind up on a side of the mountain that she could ski backward in her sleep.

headline: 1940: Britain Bars Food Relief Plan
text: The British government, through its Ambassador to Washington, the Marquess of Lothian, rejected yesterday [Dec. 10] former President Herbert Hoover’s plan for feeding the 37,000,000 inhabitants of occupied Finland, Norway, the Netherlands, Belgium and central Poland this winter. The British Ambassador, however, expressed his government’s willingness to arrange for passage through Britain’s blockade, covering virtually the whole of continental Europe, of ‘‘medical supplies destined for distribution in territories occupied by Germany and in unoccupied France by approved bodies.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 11, 1940

headline: Polluted Skies Heighten Challenge for Chinese Government
text: BEIJING — Red has been considered the color of prosperity and good fortune in China for centuries, and it is also the color of the Communist Party. But this week, it took on a darker meaning here, as it began to symbolize the failure of the party to rein in toxic smog that regularly endangers the health of hundreds of millions of people in the country’s north.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: TV Snubs and Surprises
text: You can count on the Golden Globes to throw a few curveballs when it comes to television, and this year’s nominations were no exception. An Amazon comedy came out of nowhere, while a PBS war horse and previous Globes favorite was ignored as it approaches its final season. And a two-time Emmy nominee who was considered a lock in the supporting-actress category wasn’t nominated, proving that even Cersei Lannister doesn’t frighten the nominators.

headline: A Men’s Wear Staple Expands its Offerings
text: For the past five years, Sweetu Patel has been hunkered down in his sub-level shop on Bond Street, quietly selling some of the best men's wear in New York City. C.H.C.M. has become widely respected for its unique mix of brands — a tight edit that somehow always has something you need, without overwhelming you with options. It’s a philosophy as much as it is a sales strategy.

headline: Let Israel Fight ISIS
text: TEL AVIV — In 1990, when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, he provided President George H. W. Bush his finest hour as a leader, a diplomat and a commander in chief. Among Mr. Bush’s accomplishments was bringing together more than 30 countries to oppose Iraq’s aggression. But the United States president knew what he’d have to do to build the kind of broad international coalition that he wanted: Keep Israel out of it.

headline: Harvard Poll of Millennials Finds Integrity Means More Than Experience
text: The millennial voting bloc is coalescing around the candidates running outsider, insurgent campaigns, according to a new poll released by Harvard University.

headline: Rijksmuseum Removing Racially Charged Terms From Artworks’ Titles and Descriptions
text: AMSTERDAM — The Rijksmuseum is in the process of removing language that could be considered offensive from digitized titles and descriptions of some 220,000 artworks in its collection. Words that Europeans once routinely used to describe other cultures or peoples, like “negro,” “Indian” or “dwarf” will be replaced with less racially charged terminology.

headline: Muhammad Ali Defends Islam After Trump’s Proposal to Bar Foreign Muslims

headline: 2016 Ojai Festival to Feature Kaija Saariaho Premieres
text: The Ojai Music Festival in California has an unusual model. It hands the reins to a new music director each year. For 2016 the task has fallen to Peter Sellars, the opera and theater director, who announced Wednesday that the 70th festival this June would include works by Kaija Saariaho, Caroline Shaw and Tania León, among others.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Film Surprises and Snubs
text: You guys, Lily Tomlin — 76 years old and wickedly funny in “Grandma” — was nominated for two Golden Globes! One for movies, one for TV! She hasn’t been nominated since 1985, when she was up for “All of Me.” (We’re not counting the best ensemble cast Golden Globe she and dozens of others won for “Short Cuts” 21 years ago.)

headline: 1965: Gemini-7 Stresses Medical Side
text: HOUSTON, Tex. — On Gemini-7, the medical doctors are figuratively sitting in the astronauts’ laps. Short of going along for the ride, they are attempting to monitor by radio the two men’s vital functions in great detail for 14 days. More than any other manned flight in the American program, Gemini-7 is focusing on the human reaction to prolonged exposure to weightlessness, confinement and the psychological pressure of flying in orbit. ‘‘We don’t think someone will come down with jellied bones,’’ Dr. Charles Berry, the chief flight surgeon, said before the flight. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 11, 1965

headline: Trade an End to Sanctions for Putin's Help Against ISIS?

headline: From the Editor
text: A Russian friend recently shared a witty observation about his country: “In two years, everything changes; in 200 years, nothing changes.” That is certainly true for Russia, a nation whose every lurch forward seems to leave it farther behind. Is it also true for what we call progress? Are all the dazzling technological inventions and social transformations of our time nothing more than superficial variations on an unchanging template?

headline: Death and Sandwiches

headline: Still in a Crib, Yet Being Given Antipsychotics

At 18 months, when an epilepsy medication resulted in violent behavior, he was prescribed the antipsychotic Risperdal, a drug typically used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder in adults, and rarely used for children as young as 5 years.

headline: N.F.L. Playoff Scenarios: Watch Week 14 Like an Expert

headline: When the Car Reviewer Buys a Car

headline: Planning a Ski Trip? Where to Go to Find Snow
text: What are warm and welcome conditions for stringing up holiday lights to some are anxiety-producing for travelers with ski plans, as temperatures have remained mild in much of the country this month. While resorts in the eastern half of the country are counting on snow-making, some in the West say conditions are fine, including Beaver Creek Resort in Colorado, which has reported over six feet of snowfall this year to date, the most this early since 1992. Michael Berry, the president of the National Ski Areas Association, answered a few questions about this year’s snowfall or seeming lack thereof.

headline: Mauricio Macri, Argentina’s New President, Is Sworn In Amid Feud With Predecessor
text: BUENOS AIRES — Mauricio Macri was sworn in as president of Argentina on Thursday in a ceremony that was boycotted by his predecessor, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, after a bitter argument over how and where to hold it.

headline: Madonna Performs Impromptu Acoustic Set in Paris to Honor Terror Victims
text: Following a sold-out show at a Paris arena on Wednesday night, Madonna took to the streets to play some more. “Im singing some songs in place de la republique,” the pop star wrote on Twitter after her concert. “Meet me there now.”

headline: U.F.C. Says Holly Holm’s Next Fight Will Be Ronda Rousey Rematch
text: Holly Holm will apparently not be able to defend her Ultimate Fighting Championship title until Ronda Rousey recovers from the beating she gave her.

headline: Salman Khan, Bollywood Star, Wins Appeal in Hit-and-Run Case
text: NEW DELHI — A court in Mumbai acquitted the Bollywood superstar Salman Khan in a hit-and-run case from 2002 that left one person dead and four injured.

headline: Luis Miguel Returns to Madison Square Garden
text: Luis Miguel is celebrated across several continents as an irresistibly suave balladeer — an expert delivery system for imploring boleros and rancheras románticas, strong of voice and single-minded in purpose. Born of Mexican heritage in Puerto Rico, he has been an arena headliner for long enough that his devoted fans have come to expect clockwork efficiency from him: tailored suits, soaring entreaties, a slick and potent performance.

headline: ‘Luther,’ With Idris Elba, Returns to BBC America
text: His beard is flecked with gray now, his soul bedeviled by the ghost of Alice Morgan (who, alas, has run off with Noah Solloway in “The Affair”). And you can’t help wondering what’s lurking in his pretty head as he gazes into the beyond from the White Cliffs of Dover, where he has alighted during a self-imposed exile.

headline: Tracing Diane Simpson’s Structural Evolution in Boston Exhibition
text: In 2013, the New York art world was reintroduced to the impeccably structural, richly referential sculptures of Diane Simpson by JTT, a tiny gallery on the Lower East Side, in her first solo show here since 1980. Ms. Simpson’s work, best known in and around her hometown, Chicago, is distinctive for the way it elegantly parses the components of garments like aprons, samurai armor, Amish bonnets, muffs and evening attire to create strange yet recognizable wonders of articulated form. Her materials of cardboard, fabric, metal and wood enhance the familiar formality of the work as well as the evocations of buildings and bodies and of the human mind at work.

headline: Handel’s ‘Messiah’? It’s Complicated
text: Handel’s “Messiah” gets pigeonholed as a cozy holiday staple, capped by the rousing “Hallelujah” chorus. But it is also a seething, disturbingly deep reflection on faith and suffering, one that disorients with its perpetual, sudden shifts of tone.

headline: The Unknowable Trump Vote
text: My Campaign Stops column this week tries to explain how the current intersection of national security and immigration in the headlines (including in today’s Times) has left the Republican establishment particularly defenseless against Donald Trump’s demagoguery, because the combination of Bush-era foreign policy failures and the party elite’s consistent dissembling on immigration policy (against amnesty in even-numbered years, otherwise for it) has eroded voter trust to a point where a normal partisan pitch on this issues falls on quite a few deaf ears.

headline: Jury Begins Deliberations in Trial of Dean Skelos and His Son
text: The jury in the political corruption case against Dean G. Skelos, the former State Senate majority leader, and his son began its deliberations on Thursday, after a nearly four-week trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: ‘The Savage Eye’ Wanders Through Los Angeles at the Museum of the Moving Image
text: Apparently the National Legion of Decency didn’t much care for “The Savage Eye” when it came out in 1960. The film “has been given a ‘Class C,’ or ‘condemned,’ rating” by the group, The New York Times reported that June, because it “involves blatant violations of Judeo-Christian decency.” The legion found the film “morally unacceptable in a mass medium of entertainment.”

headline: How Deal Between Dow and DuPont Could Create Value
text: Combining two chemical giants, Dow Chemical and DuPont, which are each worth nearly $60 billion, would be complicated. A three-way split thereafter might not unlock much value, either.

headline: Lois Smith Returns to the Stage With ‘Marjorie Prime’
text: Though crowns have never been part of her professional headgear, Lois Smith is indisputably royalty in the American theater. Ms. Smith, who improbably turned 85 last month, has been one of our most adventurous and prolific actresses since she made her Broadway debut in 1952. Her very presence evokes a host of tantalizing memories of fabled productions, from Tennessee Williams’s “Orpheus Descending” (in which she played the fey, phantasmal Carol Cutrere) to the Steppenwolf Theater’s “The Grapes of Wrath” (as the indomitable Ma Joad).

headline: Marissa Mayer of Yahoo Announces Birth of Twin Daughters

headline: California and Germany, Opposites With a Common Energy Goal
text: PARIS — One is a European country known as “the powerhouse of Europe” that struggles against soggy winters and seemingly endless gray skies. The other is a digitally driven American state, known as “the Golden State,” for its abundant sunshine and year-round growing season.

headline: An Old Alsatian Museum’s Modern Makeover
text: Every December, the streets of Colmar, one of the prettiest towns in Alsace, are scented by cloves, cinnamon and nutmeg — the aroma of the vin chaud (spiced wine) ladled out to the cheerful crowds who visit its five Christmas markets. Within pine bough-draped chalets, everything from wooden toys and hand-blown glass ornaments to gingerbread houses and farmhouse jams are on offer. And this season, the little French town will also celebrate the newly renovated and expanded Musée Unterlinden when it opens on Saturday. Located in a cloistered 13th-century Dominican convent, the museum is one of the most visited small museums in France and is best known for its Isenheim Altarpiece, which was sculpted and painted by the German artists Niclaus of Haugenau and Matthias Grünewald respectively between 1512 and 1516.

headline: Alice Cazenave’s “Honesty Pictures”
text: The photographer uses leaves that have been stripped of pigment as photographic negatives to create delicate, ghostly pictures of plants’ inner workings.

headline: Connecticut to Ban Gun Sales to Those on Federal Terrorism Lists

headline: Delicate, Magical Portraits of Plants’ Inner Lives
text: Do plants have souls? With her “Honesty Pictures” series, the artist Alice Cazenave aims to find out, by capturing the delicate inner workings of leaves and stems. Inspired by her background in molecular science as well as her family history of craftspeople (her relatives have included cabinetmakers and draftswomen), Cazenave employs experimental, camera-free techniques to get at the essence of plants. She strips the leaves of pigment by washing them in chemical solutions that transform them into translucent, glassy structures, then uses them directly as negatives, placing them onto photosensitive paper and then exposing them to light. She doesn’t use lenses or screens, in an effort to create images as a “direct consequence of an interaction between light and object,” she says. This series is intended to capture a sense of “shadows peeled off the real” — and to restore a sense of wonder and mystery to a medium that has become almost universally accessible. “Much of my work comments on the growing disengagement with the natural world, and aims to re-establish a sense of magic and alchemy to photography, which I feel in recent times has been lost.”

headline: When a Gift Goes Unmatched
text: My husband and I were childless for many years. During that time, we gave overly generous gifts to my brother-in-law’s three children for the holidays. Now that we have a 5-year-old, I am amazed at how little reciprocation there is. They spend about $35 per gift for our child, while we spend from $50 to $100 on each of theirs. I don’t want to buy gifts for them like I used to because my spending is never matched. How can I politely convey that they should be spending as much as we do?

headline: The Top Books of 2015

Mr. Hitchens has a valid point, yet the year’s end is a time for summing up, in books as in other things. Hence the lists that follow.

headline: Dolph Schayes, a Bridge to Modern Basketball, Is Dead at 87
text: Dolph Schayes, the New York University basketball star out of the Bronx who went on to gain acclaim as a Hall of Fame forward and one of the greatest players of his time with the old Syracuse Nationals, died on Thursday in Syracuse. He was 87.

headline: Shades of Dolph Schayes in Today’s ‘Stretch Four’ Forwards
text: When Kristaps Porzingis, a mammoth young forward for the Knicks, sets up outside for a deep shot instead of pounding the ball inside, people have a tendency to compare him to Dirk Nowitzki, another player who mastered a position called the “stretch four.” But Porzingis, Nowitzki and all the other big men who aspire to be outside gunners owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to the man who perfected the position long ago: Dolph Schayes.

But the show’s first season finale is down-to-earth and true to the series’s bleak, but cautiously optimistic ideas about heroism and guilt.

headline: Review: ‘Boy and the World,’ a Colorful and Stirring Animated Journey
text: Alê Abreu’s “Boy and the World” unleashes the exuberance of a child on the harsh realities of Brazil today. It’s both the best children’s animated film this year since “Inside Out” — you might call it “Outside In” — and, unexpectedly, a more stirring depiction of the deadening modern megalopolis than most heal-the-world documentaries.

text: Photos from Syria, Israel, England and the United States.

headline: Geffen Hall Redesign Team Is Chosen
text: They didn’t choose a starchitect.

headline: Review: In ‘The Tainted Veil,’ the Hijab Is Debated
text: “The Tainted Veil” explores the history and the contradictions of the hijab, the head and neck covering that many Muslim women wear. This documentary’s subjects variously describe the garment as an expression of, and a denial of, femininity; a source of beauty and a concealment of it; a backward-looking symbol and a modern fashion accessory.

headline: Review: ‘Sunday Ball’ Visits a Soccer Championship in Rio’s Slums
text: A happy marriage of rudimentary conditions and highly sophisticated filmmaking, Eryk Rocha’s passionate documentary “Sunday Ball” dives into an amateur soccer game in the Brazilian slums and barely comes up for air.

headline: Review: In ‘Dixieland,’ an Ex-Convict Is Sorely Tempted
text: Hank Bedford’s “Dixieland” has nothing to do with music, but it certainly has intriguing musical connections. Steve Earle, the country rocker, turns up in a secondary role and acquits himself well. So does Faith Hill, the country star. And one of the leads is played by Riley Keough, granddaughter of Elvis Presley.

headline: Review: In ‘Body,’ a Mansion Turns Into a House of Horror
text: There’s an approximately five-minute section of “Body,” a relatively brief horror movie written and directed by the young filmmakers Dan Berk and Robert Olsen, that accomplishes something rare in the genre. For a little bit, while the film’s twists are coming fast enough to keep the viewer’s mind off the story’s implausibilities, “Body” manages to turn a pitiable, helpless victim of criminal negligence into an object of fear and terror. It suggests Mr. Berk and Mr. Olsen have some viable inspiration to go with their above-average talent.

headline: Review: ‘American Hero,’ a Deadbeat Superhero, Forever Backsliding
text: “American Hero” starts off seeming as if it is going to be a fresh take on superheroes, but Nick Love, who wrote and directed, turns out to have nowhere to go with his intriguing premise.

headline: Review: In ‘The Girl in the Book,’ a Young Editor Is Unsettled by Her Past With a Novelist
text: As Marya Cohn’s romantic drama “The Girl in the Book” begins, Alice (Emily VanCamp, formerly of “Revenge” on ABC), an editorial assistant at a Manhattan publishing house, lacks self-esteem. She flounders at writing fiction; she is tiring of one-night stands; her supercilious boss (Jordan Lage) ignores her discovery of a promising novelist; and her dominating father, an old-school hotshot literary agent (Michael Cristofer), refuses to believe she can make her own decisions. Clearly, Alice has problems with men, especially male authority figures.

text: A group of Irish women who have traveled abroad to have abortions posted images of their faces online on Thursday as part of a new social media campaign to destigmatize the procedure and build support to change the law that makes it nearly impossible to legally terminate a pregnancy in Ireland.

headline: After Heisman Snub, Navy Passer Focuses on What He Can Control
text: PHILADELPHIA — Keenan Reynolds never campaigned for the Heisman Trophy. He never struck a Heisman pose after scoring one of his many touchdowns. He never boasted of his achievements. And Reynolds will not win the trophy on Saturday night, having been left off the list of finalists despite an online campaign on his behalf.

headline: Review: ‘How to Get Into Buildings’ Finds Love Amid a Crash, a Duel and Soups of the Day
text: In Trish Harnetiaux’s “How to Get Into Buildings,” a young woman hands the man she’s just met a book. “It’s like time travel and true love and shootouts,” she enthuses, promising she won’t give anything else away. “It’s really important to just keep reading it,” she adds.

headline: Review: ‘Don Verdean,’ a Sendup of Ambitious Pastors and the Lure of Religious Relics
text: With his shaggy haircut, ill-trimmed beard, safari vest and plastic-framed glasses, Don Verdean will never be mistaken for Indiana Jones. But to his admirers, Don, played with hoot-owl deadpan by Sam Rockwell, is every bit as charismatic as his fellow archaeologist. Don’s specialty is biblical artifacts — actual stuff mentioned in the Old and New Testament — and he captivates church audiences with tales of his discoveries. He claims to possess the very scissors used by Delilah to clip poor Samson’s locks.

headline: A Japanese Chef in Harlem
text: Before Chef Shinichi Inoue starts cutting the fish that is flown in to his Harlem restaurant from Japan, he performs a personal ritual: He blesses it, expressing thanks and honoring what he will later serve to his customers. He has done this twice a week since July, when Sushi Inoue opened.

headline: A Japanese Chef in Harlem
text: New York City chefs make the pilgrimage up to 130th Street for chef Shinichi Inoue’s distinct sushi style.

headline: Israel Hails ‘Successful’ Test of Antiballistic Missile System
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system intercepted a target on Thursday in a region of space just outside the earth’s atmosphere in the first successful test of its kind, according to Defense Ministry officials.

headline: San Francisco Police Chief Faces Calls for Resignation After Fatal Shooting
text: San Francisco has become the latest city where protesters are demanding the resignation of the police chief after the death of a young black man at the hands of the police.

headline: Review: ‘In the Heart of the Sea,’ It’s Man vs. Leviathan
text: As the ice caps melt, the trickle of movies about nature’s revenge may turn into a deluge. There are oceans already sloshing through “In the Heart of the Sea,” the latest from the director Ron Howard, about the shipwreck that was an inspiration for Herman Melville’s “Moby-Dick.” Epic in ambition, it spans decades and miles as it moves from Nantucket to a Pacific whale hunt that pits man (Chris Hemsworth) against Leviathan. It’s at once a biopic and an adventure yarn that, with harpoons and ploddingly good intentions, turns a story of survival into an ecological cautionary tale.

headline: Review: In ‘The Big Short,’ Economic Collapse for Fun and Profit
text: A true crime story and a madcap comedy, a heist movie and a scalding polemic, “The Big Short” will affirm your deepest cynicism about Wall Street while simultaneously restoring your faith in Hollywood.

headline: Review: The Pacifica Quartet Interprets Composers’ ‘Last Words’
text: Schubert knew he was dying when, in 1828, he wrote his final three piano sonatas. Beethoven was deaf and ill in 1826, the year before he died, when he composed his String Quartet No. 16. But Elliott Carter was still going strong when he finished his String Quartet No. 5 in 1995, at 87. He composed  dozens more pieces before he died in 2012, completing his last work just a few months before his death at 103.

headline: Vatican Says Catholics Should Not Try to Convert Jews
text: ROME — Catholics should not try to convert Jews, but should work together with them to fight anti-Semitism, the Vatican said on Thursday in a far-reaching document meant to solidify its increasingly positive relations with Jews.

headline: Four Rewarding Shows in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — Rarely is it a better time than now for a trip to Philadelphia, where four of the city’s major art institutions are presenting exceptionally rewarding shows, each distinctively its own thing. The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts offers a comprehensive retrospective of the career of Norman Lewis, the first such exhibition to be devoted to this African-American Modernist painter and one that invites viewers to consider Mr. Lewis’s place in the history of the country’s art. Dazzling the eyes and intriguing the mind, the Philadelphia Museum of Art presents two centuries’ worth of American still-life paintings and sculptures, from John James Audubon’s images of birds and mammals to Andy Warhol’s Brillo boxes. The Barnes Foundation has an astounding presentation of extravagantly ornamental antique works of wrought iron from a French museum, including door knockers with demonic faces and coffee grinders that look as if dreamed up by a steampunk artist. And the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania has a solo show of delightfully offbeat works by the self-taught New York artist Christopher Knowles.

headline: Risk to Aircraft From Drones Being Debated
text: When the pilot of an Alitalia jetliner reported seeing a drone while approaching Kennedy Airport in New York in March 2013, the likelihood of a collision between a drone and a commercial jet seemed pretty remote.

headline: Review: John Jahnke’s ‘Alas, the Nymphs . . .’ Goes Back to the Beginning
text: Part 1 of Mr. Jahnke’s trilogy, arriving via Hotel Savant almost five years after Part 3, brings fairy-tale Greek drama to BAM Fisher.

headline: Movie Listings for Dec. 11-17
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: ‘The Dangerous Liaisons,’ Lush Music of Malice
text: Among its many gifts to New York’s cultural life, the Manhattan School of Music has provided valuable opportunities to revisit modern American operas that never quite became standards. The school’s opera program, under the artistic leadership of Dona D. Vaughn, has offered revivals of works like Virgil Thomson’s “The Mother of Us All,” Thomas Pasatieri’s “The Seagull” and Lee Hoiby’s “A Month in the Country” and “Summer and Smoke.”

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on Terrorism and the 2016 Race
text: Americans are more fearful about another terrorist attack than at any time since the weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, and the gnawing sense of dread is lifting Donald J. Trump to a new high among Republican voters who are most focused on nominating a strong leader, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 4 through 8 with 1,275 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,053 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Fear of Terrorism Lifts Donald Trump in New York Times/CBS Poll
text: Americans are more fearful about the likelihood of another terrorist attack than at any other time since the weeks after Sept. 11, 2001, a gnawing sense of dread that has helped lift Donald J. Trump to a new high among Republican primary voters, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Best Classical Music Recordings of 2015
text: The classical music team of The New York Times shares its favorite albums of the year below. Also read our list of the best classical performances.

headline: Citadel Investigating Images of Cadets in White Hoods
text: The Citadel said on Thursday that it was investigating the events behind images on Facebook that showed seven cadets at the Charleston, S.C., military college with white pillowcases on their heads, evoking a likeness to the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Review: ‘World Ballet Stars’ Puts a Spotlight on Bucharest From a Global Cast
text: At the end of the World Ballet Stars gala-style event on Wednesday at the Rose Theater, the ballerina Alina Cojocaru, who had danced in four of the 15 items on the program, made a speech that epitomized the endearing spell she casts. She scarcely spoke about herself; she was all gratitude and admiration for others. Her voice (like her dancing) expressed youthfulness, fragility, radiance, courage. It is easy to care for her, easy to want to cry because of her, easy to admire her.

headline: Dance Listings for Dec. 11-17
text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: Ailey Company Begins Dancing a Prison Tale
text: Before Tuesday’s performance began at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Robert Battle, the company’s artistic director, appeared onstage with four suited gentlemen. “These are my lawyers,” Mr. Battle said jovially, before adding quickly, “The times are strange.”

headline: Theater Listings for Dec. 11-17
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: In ‘Robert Ryman,’ One Color With the Power of Many
text: For nearly 60 years, the Minimalist painter Robert Ryman has had few equals when it comes to doing more with less. White has been his primary, if not quite his only, color, the square his typical format. And yet within these seeming limitations a remarkably fecund and resonant body of work has evolved, as demonstrated by a small but comprehensive exhibition at Dia:Chelsea on West 22nd Street.

headline: ‘Quiet Clubbing’ and Revisiting Tracy & the Plastics
text: Brookfield Place, the former World Financial Center, has in the past year become a food-lover’s paradise, a pop-up art space and a shopping mall. (For the holiday season, it even has its own Santa Claus accepting Christmas wish lists.) Now Brookfield is also a nightclub of sorts.

headline: Handel’s ‘Messiah,’ Sung Across the City
text: A sampling of performances of Handel’s “Messiah” and other oratorios (soloists are featured in most performances) in New York. Want more? Click here for holiday presentations at local churches and here for other seasonal celebrations.

headline: Vaginal Davis’s Feminist Wall Reliefs Pledge ‘Open Revolt’
text: It’s hard to know where to begin with the self-described intersex artist Vaginal Davis, because there’s so much there. Born in Los Angeles in the 1960s, she’s a performer, writer, editor, composer and painter, and her solo show at Invisible-Exports adds sculptor to the résumé. The exhibition’s 16 wall reliefs, while modest in size, give the term multimedia a serious stretch, each piece having being made from — and I quote the exhibition’s checklist — “clay, stucco fragments, wet n wild brickhouse nail varnish, neon nail lacquer, Rival de Loop nylon nail enamel, hydrogen peroxide, glycerin, witch hazel, Pam, Aqua Net extra-strength hair spray and Jean Naté perfume.”

headline: The Season of Joyful Noises
text: Looking to A sampling of musical presentations this holiday season at churches in New York. Want more? Click here for a guide to performances of Handel’s “Messiah,” and here for other seasonal celebrations.

headline: Seth, Poet of the Ordinary, in ‘Nothing Lasts’
text: The acclaimed comic-book artist Seth (real name, Gregory Gallant) is a poet of the ordinary and the downbeat, a nostalgic chronicler of regret, disappointment, confusion and occasional moments of happiness. This enchanting exhibition features 80 original drawings for two chapters from the autobiographical story “Nothing Lasts.” The first 40-page section appeared in the 22nd issue of “Palookaville,” a series begun by Seth in 1991 and published by Drawn & Quarterly. The second will soon appear in “Palookaville 23.”

headline: Jean Tinguely’s Kinetic Sculptures at Gladstone Gallery
text: This exhibition provides a rare look at the discombobulated kinetic sculptures of the Swiss artist Jean Tinguely (1925-1991), a prominent member of the postwar European avant-garde. Tinguely’s found-object assemblages contributed vocally to his generation’s turn away from figurative sculpture. He is probably best remembered in the United States for his Dadaist “Homage to New York,” a self-destructing junk sculpture cobbled together from scrap metal and mechanical elements that he activated in the Museum of Modern Art’s sculpture garden in March 1960. Since its demise was halted by the fire department, a surviving fragment is in the museum’s collection.

headline: Hilary Harnischfeger and a Host of Forms at Rachel Uffner
text: Hilary Harnischfeger’s mongrel objects continue to strengthen, looking more alien than ever. Elaborately handmade, they sidestep traditional painting and sculpture to conjure (and sometimes use) a host of applied art forms: ceramics, mosaics, textiles, jewelry and architectural decoration. The usual notions of skill and finish are deferred; scale is confusing, as these things are too dense for their size.

headline: More Holiday Events and Music for Making Merry
text: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including concerts, screenings and processions. Want more? Click here for a guide to performances of Handel’s “Messiah,” and here for musical presentations at local churches.

headline: Showcasing Jewish Antiques and Their Stories
text: Moriah Galleries, one of Manhattan’s oldest purveyors of Jewish ritual objects and art, has closed after six decades and sold its inventory to one of the newest Judaica stores in New York, Menorah Galleries. In three basement rooms at the Manhattan Art & Antiques Center on Second Avenue, Menorah Galleries has set up Jewish antiques — many of them salvaged from destroyed synagogues and decimated communities — that are rarely the subject of exhibitions and sales.

headline: To Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump Is No Longer a Laughing Matter
text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Until Monday, when Donald J. Trump proposed a ban on Muslims entering the United States, Hillary Clinton could hardly keep herself from laughing at the mention of his name. “I’m sorry, I can’t help it,” she told ABC News on Sunday, letting out a giggle that made advisers squirm.

headline: Career Surveys for David Hammons and Adrian Piper
text: Just about every gallery and museum would like to have a David Hammons show.

headline: Japanese-Americans Imprisoned, but Unbowed, During World War II
text: A photojournalist’s discovery that his father was among the Japanese-Americans confined to internment camps in World War II led him to seek out survivors photographed by Dorothea Lange.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $225 Million Settlement Over Mortgage Securities
text: Morgan Stanley will pay $225 million to settle lawsuits related to its sale of faulty mortgage-backed securities to five now-defunct corporate credit unions.

headline: Movie Review: ‘In the Heart of the Sea’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “In the Heart of the Sea.”

headline: Death Toll From Hajj Stampede Reaches 2,411 in New Estimate
text: The estimated death toll from a stampede at the hajj three months ago surpassed 2,400 on Thursday, widening the gap with Saudi Arabia’s publicly announced figure and raising new concerns about why the kingdom has not yet reported its own inquest into the disaster.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Don Verdean
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Don Verdean.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Big Short’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “The Big Short.”

headline: Faraday Future, Electric Car Maker, Plans a Nevada Factory
text: Faraday Future, an electric car company backed by a Chinese entrepreneur, said on Thursday it would invest $1 billion to build a 900-acre factory in a suburb of Las Vegas.

headline: Experts Testify to Defend Baltimore Police Officer
text: BALTIMORE — Lawyers for Officer William G. Porter sought Thursday to bolster his defense with testimony from a pair of experts: a police chief who said the officer behaved reasonably in not calling a medic for Freddie Gray, and a neurosurgeon who said Mr. Gray suffered a “catastrophic spinal cord injury” that paralyzed him “within milliseconds.”

headline: Twitter Aims to Show Advertising to Much Wider Audience
text: Twitter has long argued that its reach and influence extends far beyond the 320 million people who log into its social media service at least once a month. Tweets are embedded on thousands of other websites and apps, emailed, displayed on television and published in newspapers.

headline: Republicans Make Presence Felt at Climate Talks by Ignoring Them
text: LE BOURGET, France — More than 40,000 people are attending the climate talks, including scientists, activists, people living on the front lines of global warming and the negotiators for the 195 nations represented. One group is noticeably missing, however: Republicans.

headline: Gloria Contreras, Choreographer Mentored by Balanchine, Dies at 81
text: Gloria Contreras, a leading Mexican choreographer who chronicled her development as a dance maker under George Balanchine’s mentoring, and who created more than 260 ballets for companies she directed in New York and Mexico, died on Nov. 25 at her home in Mexico City. She was 81.

headline: President Obama Signs Into Law a Rewrite of No Child Left Behind
text: WASHINGTON — Putting an end to more than a decade of strict federal control of public education, President Obama on Thursday signed a sweeping rewrite of the No Child Left Behind act that returns power to states and local districts to determine how to improve troubled schools.

headline: Port Authority to Pay Part of Murdoch Companies’ Rent to Lure Them Downtown
text: What’s good for Rupert Murdoch and his companies could be even better for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Review: Dan Auerbach Leads the Arcs at Terminal 5
text: It was throwback Wednesday when the Arcs, led by Dan Auerbach, played a packed Terminal 5. Mr. Auerbach, who has been the guitarist and singer of the Black Keys since 2001, situates the Arcs somewhere near the end of the 1960s, as a kind of rock and soul revue that can knock out Motown beats, fuzz-toned boogies or slow-grooving R&B. The time frame is similar to the one Mr. Auerbach visits with the Black Keys, but the spirit is different: simultaneously, and paradoxically, more communal and more desolate.

headline: End of Crude Oil Export Ban Is Possible
text: WASHINGTON — For months, Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, and Senator Heidi Heitkamp, Democrat of North Dakota, formed a quiet, persistent alliance as they sought to convince their colleagues that it was time to end a more than 40-year ban on crude oil exports.

headline: Corporate Victims Said to Be Shocked (Shocked!) at Dean Skelos’s Request for Money
text: The sideshow stole the spotlight.

headline: Compromise Bill Would Give President More Muscle Against Unfair Trade Practices
text: WASHINGTON — The House is expected to approve bipartisan trade and customs legislation on Friday that would empower the administration to more forcefully counter unfair trading practices, though the measure’s provisions against suspected currency manipulation by other countries fell short of demands from critics in both parties.

headline: Key to Success of Climate Pact Will Be Its Signals to Global Markets
text: LE BOURGET, France — As diplomats here work through the final points of a sweeping new climate change accord, experts said the ultimate measure of success of the agreement will be whether it sends a clear signal to global financial investors that they should move money away from fossil fuels and toward clean-energy sources such as wind and solar power.

headline: From Stanley Cup Finals to a High School Coach
text: HIGHLANDS RANCH, Colo. — In June, George Gwozdecky stood behind the bench during the Stanley Cup finals as an assistant for the Tampa Bay Lightning.

headline: The Court Takes Up One Person, One Vote
text: On its face, the constitutional doctrine of “one person one vote” seems about as clear as they come: no one’s vote should count more than anyone else’s.

headline: For Yankees and Mets, Key Word Is Caution
text: NASHVILLE — When teams make major moves, they usually feel some pain. They include an extra prospect in a trade, add another year to a contract, extend themselves for a player with untapped potential. High-impact deals inspire both elation and dread.

headline: With Remarks in Affirmative Action Case, Scalia Steps Into ‘Mismatch’ Debate
text: In an awkward exchange in Wednesday’s potentially game-changing Supreme Court arguments on affirmative action, Justice Antonin Scalia hesitantly asked whether it might be better for black students to go to “a slower-track school where they do well” than to go to a highly selective college, like the University of Texas, through some form of racial preference.

headline: Syrian Rebels Form Bloc for New Round of Peace Talks
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — An array of Syrian opposition groups agreed here on Thursday to form a new and more inclusive body to guide the diverse and divided opponents of President Bashar al-Assad in a new round of planned talks aimed at ending the Syrian civil war.

headline: Donald Trump’s Words Have Added Sting for 2 Muslims in Congress
text: WASHINGTON — When Representative André Carson was first introduced to Islam, he was a young man watching as his Muslim neighbors escorted older women to the grocery store and scared drug dealers off their streets in Indianapolis.

headline: Divers Search for Electronics of San Bernardino Attackers
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Divers searched a lake here Thursday for electronic devices, including a computer hard drive, that investigators suspect were dumped in the murky water by the husband and wife who carried out a massacre last week.

headline: Tossed Glass of Wine Hits Nerve in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil is dealing with a severe economic crisis, reports of a surge in birth defects caused by a mosquito-borne virus and efforts to impeach President Dilma Rousseff.

headline: Review: Urban Bush Women Channel John Coltrane at BAM
text: “Trying to describe Coltrane’s music is like trying to describe God.” So says a member of Urban Bush Women during the troupe’s new work, “Walking With ’Trane,” which opened at the BAM Harvey Theater on Wednesday. That kind of talk is standard for the practically beatified jazz saxophonist John Coltrane, one of the only musicians in history to have a church consecrated in his name. But these dancers don’t have to describe Coltrane’s music, only dance to it.

headline: Mattiwilda Dobbs, Soprano and Principal at Met, Dies at 90
text: Mattiwilda Dobbs, a coloratura soprano who was the third African-American to appear as a principal singer with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Tuesday at her home in Atlanta. She was 90.

headline: Mayor Bill de Blasio to Undergo Hernia Operation
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York will undergo surgery on Friday for a hernia that he recently developed.

headline: In Boston, a Runaway Ride on the Rails in the Dark
text: BOSTON — For the beleaguered riders of Boston’s beleaguered subway system, add a new worry: a runaway train, carrying 50 terrified passengers, hurtling down the tracks without a driver.

headline: Verbatim: Donald Trump Promises Death Penalty in Killings of Police Officers
text: — Donald J. Trump, speaking on Thursday night in Portsmouth, N.H., where he was endorsed by the New England Police Benevolent Association. (Check out our fact check.)

headline: Elite Rodeo Circuit? Whoa
text: LAS VEGAS — As the 10-night National Finals Rodeo concludes here on Saturday, when world champions are crowned in events like saddle-bronc riding, calf roping and steer wrestling, professional rodeo will straddle a telling and potentially historic moment. The next big competition is scheduled for a Texas courtroom.

headline: Dec. 10 Draft Agreement for Paris Climate Negotiators
text: The latest version of the international agreement that negotiators at the Paris climate conference have been haggling over.

headline: Review: In ‘Oh Hello,’ Sour and Crotchety Old Men at Their Best
text: Far be it from me to suggest that the great David Mamet was looking over the shoulders of the great Gil Faizon and George St. Geegland when they composed their latest chef-d’oeuvre. Or that the respectable Messrs. Faizon and St. Geegland might have been eavesdropping on Mr. Mamet in rehearsal.

headline: Some Tropicana and Other PepsiCo Products to Carry Non-GMO Project Seal
text: Labels on Tropicana Pure Premium orange juice and four of its brand siblings will begin carrying early next year an increasingly familiar certification — the butterfly seal conferred by the Non-GMO Project, a nonprofit group that verifies products as being free of genetically engineered ingredients.

headline: Round Numbers
text: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If I was going to try to spot a minitheme for Barry Silk’s crossword puzzle, it would have to be a combination of “Ancient Greece” and “The Internet.”

headline: Review: ‘The Color Purple’ on Broadway, Stripped to Its Essence
text: Give thanks this morning, children of Broadway, and throw in a hearty hallelujah. “The Color Purple” has been born again, and its conversion is a glory to behold.

headline: Former Oklahoma City Police Officer Found Guilty of Rapes
text: Daniel Holtzclaw, a former Oklahoma City police officer accused of raping women while on duty, was found guilty on Thursday.

headline: Bonnie Lou, Country and Rockabilly Star of the 1950s, Dies at 91
text: Bonnie Lou, a singer who achieved national stardom in the 1950s by recording country and rockabilly hits and performing on television and radio, but whose career declined after she turned down a major-label deal, died on Tuesday in Cheviot, Ohio. She was 91.

headline: Development Money, in Cuomo Era, Is Disbursed With Dazzle
text: ALBANY — Fawning M.C.s. Beaming winners. And tons of cold, hard cash.

headline: Council Bills Seek to Make Construction Less Perilous in New York City
text: Alarmed by a surge in recent deaths and injuries in construction accidents, members of the New York City Council on Thursday urged swift passage of legislation intended to penalize contractors who break the rules.

headline: The Life of a Stadium
text: Chicago’s Soldier Field, which opened in 1924, was built to host a wide variety of events, and in the decades since it has not disappointed.

headline: A Pitch, a Swing and a Family’s Medical Nightmare
text: The Matos family’s long health scare began with a softball pitch.

headline: Jets’ Darrelle Revis Hopes to Return From Concussion to Face Titans
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis said Thursday that he expected to return Sunday against the Tennessee Titans after missing the last two games with a concussion.

headline: Antibiotic Sales for Food Rise
text: Despite a major effort by the Obama administration to reduce the use of antibiotics, the amount of those drugs sold for use in animals grown for food rose again last year. Sales to farmers and ranchers rose by 3 percent from 2013, the Food and Drug Administration said, and sales are up by 23 percent since 2009, when the agency began reporting the figures. Indiscriminate antibiotic use, in people and animals, is leading to the rise of superbugs resistant to many critical drugs. Critics say the use of antibiotics to prevent sickness in animals is too sweeping. Lance Price, a researcher at the Milken Institute School of Public Health, noted that cephalosporins, a class of drug often used to treat ear and urinary tract infections, rose 12 percent last year, which he said doctors would find troubling.

headline: Drug and Bribery Investigation Brings New Scrutiny to Queens Karaoke Clubs
text: Karaoke clubs light up the streets of Flushing every night of the week, drawing young and old revelers alike for singing, drinking and good times, often behind closed doors in a warren of luxurious private rooms.

headline: Religious Colleges Obtain Waivers to Law That Protects Transgender Students
text: More than two dozen religiously affiliated colleges and universities across the United States have received exemptions from the federal civil rights protections provided under Title IX since 2014, documents show, waivers that activists said allow them to discriminate against students and employees on the basis of categories like sexual orientation and gender identity.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | gist
text: gist • \ˈjist\ • noun

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Dec. 11-17
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Dec. 11-17
text: Information on events for possible inclusion in Spare Times should be sent to weekend@nytimes.com by Friday at 5 p.m. for publication that week. Longer versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 11-17
text: The Museum of Modern Art is offering children a new way to play: Instead of pretending to be, say, Batman or Katniss Everdeen, how about imagining yourself as Ellsworth Kelly or Louise Nevelson?

headline: What to Watch Friday
text: “Transparent” begins a second glorious season with bigger issues than ever; Miley Cyrus acts like a baby in her latest video; and Emma Stone and Bradley Cooper face off in “Aloha,” a Cameron Crowe flick that may be more enjoyable than it is good.

headline: Corrections: December 11, 2015
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “America represents wilderness and freedom, and also a big house.”

headline: North and South Korea Meet in Latest Bid to Improve Relations
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Officials from North and South Korea met Friday in the latest effort to improve relations on the divided Korean Peninsula, where military tension along the world’s most heavily militarized border has often alternated with short-lived attempts at reconciliation.

headline: Japanese-Americans Imprisoned, but Unbowed, During World War II
text: Paul Kitagaki Jr. had just started out as a photographer in the late 1970s when an uncle mentioned to him that Dorothea Lange had once photographed his father and extended family waiting to board a bus in Oakland, Calif. Their destination? A temporary detention facility, one of 15 assembly centers along the West Coast, before they were sent to one of 10 permanent internment camps where 120,000 Japanese-Americans were confined after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

headline: The Tarnished Trump Brand
text: Real estate companies, furniture makers and other businesses that have emblazoned the Trump name on their properties and products ought to think hard about whether they want to be associated with the outrageous things coming out of Donald Trump’s mouth as he campaigns for the Republican nomination for president.

headline: Empowering the Ugliness
text: We live in an era of political news that is, all too often, shocking but not surprising. The rise of Donald Trump definitely falls into that category. And so does the electoral earthquake that struck France in Sunday’s regional elections, with the right-wing National Front winning more votes than either of the major mainstream parties.

headline: The Ted Cruz Establishment
text: There are two types of Machiavellians in politics, Selfish Machiavellians and Kind Machiavellians. The Selfish ones are the ones we usually think of — the nakedly ambitious people who are always strategizing, sometimes ruthlessly, for their own personal advantage. The Kind Machiavellians realize that it’s smart to get along with people, so they pick their friendships strategically, feigning affection toward those who might be useful.

headline: Goose-Steppers in the G.O.P.
text: Well, he’s got the Hitler vote. The neo-Nazi website, Daily Stormer, was out and proud earlier this week: “Heil Donald Trump — the Ultimate Savior.” After endorsing the Republican presidential front-runner earlier this year for his call to deport 11 million Mexican immigrants, the fomenters of American fascism have now added an apt twist to his slogan, one not far from the truth of the campaign: “Make America White Again.”

headline: Gunmakers’ War Profiteering on the Home Front
text: As each new mass shooting leaves dead and wounded Americans strewn like casualties on a battlefield — a butcher’s toll that has now intersected with the international terrorist threat — the gun industry’s culpability amounts to war profiteering through the reckless sale of military weapons tailored for the civilian homefront.

headline: The Return of History
text: AN Islamic philosopher in Karachi, an ideologue who provides violent ideas to some of Pakistan’s fiercest extremist groups, once told me that there are two kinds of history: dead and living. “Dead history is something on a shelf or in a museum,” he said. “Living history is part of your consciousness, something in your blood that inspires you.”

headline: No Whistle, and No Win, for Carmelo Anthony and Knicks
text: SACRAMENTO — With four and a half seconds left in the fourth quarter on Thursday night, Carmelo Anthony caught an inbounds pass near midcourt, rumbled like a N.F.L. running back to the 3-point line, and heaved a potential game-winning shot that clanged off the rim.

headline: A Wordless Elegy for China’s War Dead
text: BEIJING — When the composer Wang Xilin’s haunting requiem for the souls of China’s millions of World War II dead rings out in Beijing on Sunday, half a century will have passed since he first conceived of it.

headline: China’s Coastal Cities, Underwater
text: Some cities in China will be dramatically affected by rising seas as the atmosphere warms.

headline: News Q’s | ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Fans Are Already Lining Up
text: Before Reading ‘ “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” Fans Are Already Lining Up’:

headline: Where Republican Presidential Candidates Traveled in November
text: The November itineraries for Republican presidential candidates reflect robust travel schedules that reveal campaign strategy.

headline: Chris Christie Rises and Donald Trump Endures in New Hampshire, Poll Says
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has surged to second place in New Hampshire, according to a new poll that shows his persistence there starting to pay off. But Donald J. Trump remains firmly in the lead in the state, despite his provocative policies on Muslims.

headline: Taking a Break to Travel Without Breaking Your Professional Ties
text: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Soundproofing for New York Noise
text: Pietro Cicognani, an architect, made a risky promise when he undertook the $3.5 million renovation of a Fifth Avenue penthouse with wraparound terrace views. When finished, he said, the apartment would be silent.

headline: U.S. Police Leaders, Visiting Scotland, Get Lessons on Avoiding Deadly Force
text: TULLIALLAN, Scotland — The United States and Britain are bound by a common language and a shared history, and their law enforcement agencies have been close partners for generations.

headline: Putting the Presidential Candidates (and America) on a Diet
text: At the wooden kitchen table in his rambling home in the horse country of Waccabuc, N.Y., Mike Berland, a crisis manager, public-opinion researcher and veteran political pollster, assessed the so-far lackluster campaign performance of Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Carol Leifer Proves You Don’t Have to Be Unhappy to Be Funny
text: The expectations were zero.

headline: An Enduring and Erudite Court Jester in Britain
text: LONDON — IAN HISLOP looks mild and soft, rather like a pudding. He is polite, soft-spoken and was, appropriately enough, born in the district of Swansea, Wales, called Mumbles.

headline: High Polls for Low-Energy Campaigners (Like Donald Trump)
text: Donald J. Trump mocks his opponents as “low energy,” but his own campaign travel schedule is relatively sleepy: He left his home base of New York for only 17 public events during a 30-day stretch.

headline: Do Screens Get in the Way of the Rest of Your Life?
text: Have you found you don’t spend enough time doing the other things you enjoy in life because you’re always on a screen? Instead of playing sports, hanging out with friends, reading a book or doing something creative, you’re online, texting, watching videos or playing video games.

headline: Where We Partied in 2015
text: The top parties of the year included the Met Gala, the Vanity Fair Oscar party, and too many events to count during New York Fashion Week. See the photos.

headline: Where We Partied in 2015

headline: How to Prepare for an Earthquake
text: ‘‘Bolt heavy objects to the wall,’’ says Ross S. Stein, a geophysicist who teaches at Stanford University. Loose things cause many earthquake injuries; broken bottles cut feet, falling armoires and flying televisions break bones. So fix your bookshelves in place and hang framed art with quake-­proof mountings. Latch cupboards containing breakables like glassware. Keep a headlamp by your bed, because there will probably be a power failure. ‘‘These are the easy, cheap fixes,’’ says Stein, who studied earthquakes and their aftershocks for more than 30 years as a senior scientist with the United States Geological Survey. Last year, he introduced temblor.net, a website and app that enables users to calculate their seismic exposure.

headline: 1915: A Funereal Error
text: BERLIN — A widow lady named Wachterhausen, residing at Potsdam, recently had the misfortune to lose her only daughter, Amalia, who was staying at Nice for the benefit of her health. The mother telegraphed to an undertaker in that town ordering an elaborate coffin, and requesting that the remains should be sent home for burial. Just before the funeral on Sunday the mother had the coffin opened, and found that it contained, not her child, but the body of an old officer in Russian uniform. On making inquiries she learned by telegram from Nice that the bodies had been accidentally exchanged. Her daughter’s body had been forwarded to Smolensk in Russia instead of that of the officer. On telegraphing to the Russian authorities Madame Wachterhausen was informed that the body of her daughter had just been buried with great ceremony and military honors. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 12, 1915

headline: 1940: A Woman’s Patriotic Duty
text: LONDON — The ‘‘bombores’’ — those persons who pour into one’s ears their real or imagined experience with a high-explosive that has obeyed the law of gravity — are to have sympathetic female audiences. The Marchioness of Reading, chairman of the Women’s Voluntary Service, which has 50,000 or more members, announced today [Dec. 11] at Preston, Lancashire, that W. V. S. would provide ‘‘listeners’’ for bombed-out persons who wanted to talk about it. And up at Birmingham those with hard-luck stories to retell are reported to have formed a ‘‘Birmingham District Bombees Association.’’ ‘‘We must realize,’’ said Lady Reading, ‘‘that people who have come from a bombed area are in a highly nervous state and that one of the things that helps them is to be allowed to talk about it.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 12, 1940

headline: Readers Make Their Presents Known

headline: ‘A Field Philosopher’s Guide to Fracking,’ by Adam Briggle
text: Because he wanted to see the workings of an actual frack site, Adam Briggle rode his bicycle up to Interstate 35, in Denton, Tex., ran across one side of the highway and lost his shoe in the mud in the median, between cars zooming north and south. Briggle had never even heard of fracking when he was hired as a professor of philosophy at the University of North Texas, in 2009. But with around 250 gas wells drilled within Denton’s city limits, the subject was thrust upon his consciousness. A member of the City Council asked him to form a citizens’ advisory group for gas-well regulations, and Briggle became a field philosopher, running across highways, helping collect air samples from backyards, consulting not only Mary Shelley and the theologian Duns Scotus to help guide him along “the arduous trail that is thinking” but also scientists, engineers, mayors, neighbors and his daughter, Lulu, a 2-year-old rogue impervious to propaganda.

headline: Inside the List
text: Let It Go: Desmond Tutu, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984 for his opposition to South African apartheid, turns up on the monthly relationships list on Page 24 this week: “The Book of Forgiving,” written with his daughter Mpho Tutu, is at No. 9. “It doesn’t matter whether you are having trouble moving forward from the wrongs that were done to you, or whether you need the courage to admit the wrongs you have done,” he writes in the introduction. “Forgiveness is nothing less than the way we heal the world. We heal the world by healing each and every one of our hearts.” If that kind of talk triggers flashbacks to your last cardiologist visit — the best way to heal our hearts is probably to eat less bacon — it remains true that Tutu writes with undeniable moral force. And given his experiences leading the Truth and Reconciliation Commission after apartheid’s fall, his prescription is not just simple but consistent and radical. “In South Africa, we chose to seek forgiveness rather than revenge,” he writes. “That choice averted a blood bath. For every injustice, there is a choice. . . . You can choose forgiveness or revenge, but revenge is always costly. Choosing forgiveness rather than retaliation ultimately serves to make you a stronger and freer person.” As it happens, your cardiologist might agree. According to the Johns Hopkins Medicine website, “Studies have found that the act of forgiveness can reap huge rewards for your health, lowering the risk of heart attack; improving cholesterol levels and sleep; and reducing pain, blood pressure and levels of anxiety, depression and stress.”

headline: If Colleges Can’t Pay Athletes, Maybe Fans Can, Group Says

headline: John Sedgwick’s ‘War of Two: Alexander Hamilton, Aaron Burr, and the Duel That Stunned the Nation’
text: On July 11, 1804, on a rocky ledge above the Hudson River in New Jersey, Aaron Burr, the vice president of the United States, and Alexander Hamilton, the former secretary of the Treasury, met to engage in a lethal game of honor. A single shot from Burr’s pistol ended Hamilton’s life. It was the “duel that stunned the nation,” as the novelist and biographer John Sedgwick calls it in his lively, wide-­ranging and immensely readable book. The world of “War of Two” is often more personal than political, an intimate portrait of Hamilton and Burr as they plunged toward their fatal collision.

headline: ‘The Relic Master,’ by Christopher Buckley
text: What a moment of joy Christopher Buckley must have experienced when he lit on the idea for his latest novel. As a veteran of political and cultural satire (“Thank You for Smoking” and many others), he surely surveyed the dismal — hold on to that word — landscape of American politics in the run-up to the next election and realized the whole thing was now so self-satirizing that no novel could do it justice. Instead he’s done a back flip into a moment in history similarly rich in hypocrisy, corruption, avarice, self-­delusion and mendacity.

headline: ‘Grateful Doe’ Is Identified 20 Years After Road Trip Death

headline: William H. Gass’s ‘Eyes’ and John Barth’s ‘Collected Stories’
text: Every so often a magazine with curatorial or prophetic aspirations — say, Granta or The New Yorker — produces a list of the best writers under 40 from a particular nation state. The underlying principle isn’t much more than the logic of the marketplace — the search for the new commodity, explicitly applied to literature. But these lists are haunted by a cluster of unspoken questions about writing’s relationship to longevity. Are writers so short of material that they need to be anointed before midlife? Is novelistic craft not perfected over time? If the answers to these questions aren’t obvious, why not imagine a shadow list that gathers the best American fiction by writers over 80? William H. Gass — 91 years old at the time of writing — would certainly benefit from such a list, since his work typically gestates across decades. He labored on his central achievement, “The Tunnel” (1995), for longer than some acclaimed young novelists have been alive, while his latest volume, “Eyes,” has similarly been in the pipeline at least since the turn of the millennium.

headline: New Harvard Hub Melds Work on Human and Planetary Health

headline: A Caretaker of Turtles
text: Lorri Cramer’s Upper West Side apartment has the feel of an aquarium, with turtles in glass tanks cluttering the living room, surrounding the upright piano and edging up to the furniture.

headline: ‘Fox Tooth Heart,’ by John McManus
text: The opening paragraph of “Betsy From Pike,” one of the arresting but tender stories in John McManus’s collection “Fox Tooth Heart,” features a three-legged dog, a trailer park in Kentucky, “teenage Satanist rest-area murderers” and a potty-mouthed mom who sleeps all day rather than confront the squalor of her life. Like many of the opening paragraphs of this book, it will have members of Concerned Women for America and other professional worrywarts atwitter. Oh, who am I kidding? They wouldn’t touch this book unless each of its pages was scrubbed with a fresh bar of lye soap.

headline: ‘The New and Improved Romie Futch,’ by Julia Elliott
text: With last year’s genre-bending collection “The Wilds,” Julia Elliott introduced herself as a Flannery O’Connor for the data-mining age: a dark poet of the grotesque and absurd in a world that feels ever more science fictional. “The New and Improved Romie Futch,” her first novel, follows in the same hoof prints, weaving a Southern Gothic fable out of near-future neuroscience and Frankenfood beasts.

headline: ‘The Horse,’ by Wendy Williams
text: In June 1976, a friend of mine and I, passing through Virginia on our way back to Brown, went for a hike in the Smokies, where black bears live. Although my friend would soon become a distinguished science writer, one of the pleasures of our friendship was scaring each other silly. We kept joking about those bears. Halfway up Mount Rogers, we got caught in a thunderstorm and took shelter under a rock face that leaned into canopy. It was a fine hide-out, but it was not ours alone. Under our feet we saw the scat of a large animal, copious and dark — and fresh. Never mind the lightning; we ran.

headline: The King and I
text: The novel was coming along quite well, until I got to the ­foreskins.

headline: ‘The Mountain Shadow,’ by Gregory David Roberts
text: Gregory David Roberts’s “Shantaram” was an unlikely publishing sensation. Literary purists scoffed at its purple prose; Indian (and many other) readers bristled at its stereotypes and cultural simplifications. The book nonetheless possessed a grittiness and vividness that helped Roberts sell four million copies around the world. Hollywood rights were scooped up (though a film has yet to be made). The book has gone on to occupy a distinctive — and deserving — place in an emerging genre of Bombay noir.

headline: ‘The Death of Cancer,’ by Vincent T. DeVita Jr. and Elizabeth DeVita-Raeburn
text: When I was doing my medical training nearly 20 years ago, there were two kinds of residents: those who were planning on specializing in oncology and those who couldn’t tolerate the subject for even a month. One night when I was on call, I worked with someone in the second camp. He told me about a patient of his, an elderly woman with pancreatic cancer that had grown into her bile duct and metastasized through her intestinal tract. She had been through several rounds of ­chemotherapy without success and was ready to quit treatment, but was afraid to tell her oncologist. “She told me, ‘I don’t want him to think I’m giving up,’ ” my colleague said, obviously disgusted that she didn’t feel comfortable speaking freely about her goals.

text: WASHINGTON — With negotiators certain to blow a midnight deadline for a $1.1 trillion spending bill for 2016, Congress on Friday approved a stopgap measure to forestall a government shutdown and provide an additional five days to reach a deal.

headline: Timpano
text: A streamlined dinner-party centerpiece that is just as delectable as more authentic versions, but faster, easier and a bit lighter.

headline: A Timpano That’s Easier to Make and Just as Spectacular
text: Ages ago, after the movie “Big Night” was released, a friend served a timpano at a dinner party.

headline: In Greece, Brewer’s Woes Reflect Struggle of Business Owners
text: ATHENS — Demetri Politopoulos, the founder of a midsize beer producer in northern Greece, says he nearly fainted when he heard the news late one night in October.

headline: Full-Floor Greenwich Village Penthouse for $20.14 Million
text: A loftlike, full-floor penthouse with ample outdoor space at the Greenwich Lane, a nearly blocklong condominium complex being built on the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus in Greenwich Village, sold for $20,137,750.47 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

text: Project runaway

headline: China to Track Renminbi Based on Basket of Currencies
text: HONG KONG — China’s central bank said Friday night that it would start tracking the value of the country’s currency against a basket of many other currencies and not just the dollar. The move is likely to reignite speculation about the possibility of another devaluation by Beijing and could fan trade tensions.

headline: The Murky Meaning of the Killer Selfie
text: Earlier this fall, a friend of yours, or perhaps a robot, may have dropped this bit of clickbait into one of your feeds: You Are Now More at Risk of Dying While Taking a Selfie Than Being Killed by a Shark. According to the authors of this widely circulated story, selfie-caused fatalities have become a phenomenon of significant proportions. What used to be seen as unconnected, accidental deaths are now examples of a supposedly distinct global pandemic.

headline: Discrimination by Airbnb Hosts Is Widespread, Report Says
text: Airbnb likes to refer to itself as less a company than a “community.” To that end, it has made trust between real people a cornerstone of its business strategy in short-term home rentals.

headline: Gwyneth’s Gift Guide
text: HELLO, all! Gwynnie here! Welcome to another issue of Goop, my newsletter for people who enjoy the finer things in life. I’m proud to present our annual gift guide. Just because I’m Gwyneth Paltrow, it doesn’t mean I can’t kick back and enjoy the holidays. I put my winter-capris on one cashmere leg at a time, just like you!

headline: Iraqi Forces Advance in Campaign to Retake Ramadi From ISIS
text: BAGHDAD — More than six months after falling to the Islamic State, the city center of Ramadi is under siege by Iraqi security forces and tribal fighters backed by American air power. Commanders say that as few as 300 militants remain holed up inside, behind a defense of elaborate tunnels, booby-trapped buildings and roads laced with hidden bombs.

headline: What Inspired an Album Based on Art History
text: Walter Martin’s old band, The Walkmen, was responsible for what is still one of indie rock’s great humblebrags: “When I used to go out, I would know everyone that I saw,” go the lyrics to “The Rat.” “Now I go out alone, if I go out at all.” That appeared on the second of the band’s seven albums, but there was already a world-weariness to their music: These guys were pushing 30; they’d seen it all. Almost 12 years later, The Walkmen have disbanded and Martin, who played bass and organ and contributed lyrics, has two young children. He goes out even less these days, and when he does, it’s more likely to a museum than a bar.

headline: Dolly Parton Movie Draws Almost 13 Million Viewers
text: NBC’s television movie “Coat of Many Colors” drew 12.8 million viewers on Thursday night, lifting NBC to the highest viewership of any network for the night.

headline: ‘A Severe Case of Modern Life’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paleontologists Discover a Poor Cousin to Triceratops
text: Paleontologists have discovered a distant relative of Triceratops in western China that lived 160 million years ago. Named Hualianceratops wucaiwanensis, the plant-eater stood on its hind legs and was about the size of a spaniel. Hualianceratops and another dinosaur from the region, named Yinlong downsi, are the two oldest known ceratopsians, so-called horned dinosaurs, although neither the Hualianceratops nor Yinlong had horns. There were dozens of species of ceratopsians, but Triceratops, which lived in North America about 65 million years ago, is the best known. “These small dinosaurs were related to Triceratops, but very distantly,” said Catherine A. Forster, a paleontologist at George Washington University and one of the team who discovered Hualianceratops. She and her colleagues recovered a partial skull and hind leg, and described their findings in the journal PLOS One.

headline: Review: ‘Young Charles Dickens’ Musically Mixes Fact and Fiction
text: It’s hard to imagine Ebenezer Scrooge, Miss Havisham and the Artful Dodger all occupying the same stage, but that’s the effect of “Young Charles Dickens,” a new musical from New York City Children’s Theater. These characters, though, don’t appear in their fictional guises. Barbara Zinn Krieger, the company’s founder and author of the show’s book and lyrics, has conceived them as real people in Dickens’s life — a cruel boss, a madwoman on the street, a cunning pickpocket — with whom he later populated his novels. Audience members who are old enough can amuse themselves by guessing who’s who. (Bonus points to those recognizing the character from “Bleak House.”)

headline: China’s Emissions Pledges Are Undercut by Boom in Coal Projects Abroad
text: TAM HUNG COMMUNE, Vietnam — The puddle under the slide at the Tam Hung Kindergarten is inky black. A security guard says the staff has to sweep coal dust off the playground every morning. Parents whose children have developed persistent coughs blame the school’s new neighbor: a huge coal-fueled power plant built by Chinese engineers with Chinese aid.
