headline: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Has World Premiere, No Expense Spared
text: LOS ANGELES — A veritable army of security guards, publicists and event staffers. Quadruple the typical number of invited guests. A lavish after-party, replete with Stormtroopers and a roaming Chewbacca, stretching for four city blocks.

headline: Modi Rival Denounces Raid at Delhi State Government Headquarters
text: NEW DELHI — A longtime political rivalry in India heated up on Tuesday when federal officials raided the offices of the Delhi State government and the state’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, reacted with fury, calling Prime Minister Narendra Modi a coward and a psychopath.

headline: European Drug Makers Sanofi and Boehringer Ingelheim in Talks
text: LONDON — The French pharmaceutical company Sanofi and the German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim said on Tuesday that they were in “exclusive negotiations” on a potential asset swap that would make Sanofi one of the world’s largest manufacturers of nonprescription medicines.

headline: General Electric to Sell Commercial Lending Business in Japan
text: HONG KONG — General Electric agreed on Tuesday to sell its commercial lending business in Japan to Sumitomo Mitsui Finance and Leasing, one of Japan’s largest leasing companies, for 575 billion yen, or about $4.8 billion.

headline: All Things Being Unequal
text: President Obama calls economic inequality “the defining challenge of our time.” Pope Francis tells us that “today we also have to say ‘thou shall not’ to an economy of exclusion and inequality.” The French economist Thomas Piketty writes a nearly 700-page book for Harvard University Press about long-term trends in inequality and, in the wake of the Occupy movement, is rewarded with a surprise best seller. Mitt Romney, of all people, now complains that “income inequality has gotten worse.” Economic inequality is bad. Everybody thinks so.

text: The language of food is changing at breakneck speed to reflect new menus, new mash-ups, new diets, new hashtags.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Unveil Counterterrorism Strategy
text: In the weeks since the Dec. 2 attack in San Bernardino, Calif., Hillary Clinton has urged tolerance toward Muslims and reiterated her calls for increased gun control measures. What she has not done is speak extensively about what she would do to stop a terrorist attack in the United States.

headline: New York Today: Our Person of the Year
text: Updated 11:23 a.m.

headline: Yemen Agrees to Cease-Fire With Rebels as Peace Talks Begin
text: GENEVA — The Yemeni government and Houthi rebels called an immediate halt to hostilities on Tuesday as they started peace talks mediated by a United Nations special envoy at an undisclosed location in Switzerland, a United Nations spokesman confirmed.

headline: Morning Agenda: Diagnosing Yahoo’s Ills
text: DIAGNOSING YAHOO’S ILLS  | Over the weekend, Eric Jackson, who runs a small hedge fund called SpringOwl Asset Management and has long railed against the Yahoo’s missteps, sent a presentation to the board. The figures in it listed the billions spent on acquisitions of unknown companies, stock buybacks, compensation, free food and parties.

headline: Ben Carson’s Threat to Leave G.O.P. Packs Less Punch Than Donald Trump’s
text: Republicans are gathering to debate on Tuesday with an unpleasant question lingering in the background: whether, in the long run, they will all remain Republicans.

headline: PR Newswire Sold to Cision for $841 Million
text: LONDON — UBM, the British business-events organizer, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell the news-release distribution service PR Newswire to Cision, the owner of Gorkana Group, for $841 million.

headline: House Armed Services Committee to Ban Cameras From Witnesses’ Feet
text: It’s an iconic moment at any big congressional hearing — witnesses take their seats to testify and the whir from the cameras of photographers seated on the floor between the witness table and the committee dais confirms that the moment has been captured for posterity.

headline: Aveva and Schneider Electric Terminate Plans for Complex Deal
text: LONDON — The British engineering company Aveva Group said on Tuesday that it had walked away from a complex deal with Schneider Electric that would have seen the French industrial group take a majority stake in the company.

headline: AMC Entertainment Names Adam Aron Chief Executive
text: LOS ANGELES — AMC Entertainment Holdings, which operates the AMC Theaters movie theater chain, named Adam M. Aron president and chief executive on Tuesday, filling a post vacated by Gerardo I. Lopez in July.

headline: Rebuilding the Middle Class the Army Way
text: A few weeks ago, I was sitting in a classroom at the United States Army War College in Carlisle, Pa. There were 16 students, all in their early 40s and most of them lieutenant colonels, who had been selected to spend a year in this rural, peaceful place learning how to think strategically about war. In modern business, ‘‘thinking strategically’’ has become a cliché entirely devoid of meaning. But in the military, its meaning remains quite precise. As one person in the class told me, as a lieutenant colonel in a tank battalion, he was engaged in tactics: making sure that his tankers and their tanks were ready to fight. As a colonel, he would be concerned with strategy: advising on which enemies those tanks should engage and how.

headline: Who’s Really ‘Radical’?
text: For the last couple of centuries, the word ‘‘radical’’ referred to people who try to pull things up from the root. After the Civil War, Radical Republicans, as they were called, pushed Reconstruction policies through Congress on behalf of freed slaves, trying to tear down the plantation-based power structure of the antebellum South. Eugene Debs, the most prominent socialist of the early 20th century (and a hero to Bernie Sanders), ran for president five times on what was seen as a radical platform of condemning capitalist oppression.

headline: There’s ‘Joy’ in Working Together Again
text: Anticipation is understandably high for David O. Russell’s new film, “Joy,” about the late-blooming brainiac inventor of the dazzlingly successful Miracle Mop, and later those skinny velvet hangers. Once again, Mr. Russell rounded up his team of A-list players. Jennifer Lawrence plays the titular Joy Mangano, Robert De Niro portrays her father, and Bradley Cooper is an executive at QVC, the television-shopping network where Joy peddled her wares. The film, which opens on Christmas, traces Joy’s decades-long journey, from a precocious girl in the 1960s to a disgruntled housewife in the 1970s to a steely entrepreneur in the 1990s, surmounting financial woes, con artists and her meddlesome Greek chorus of a family.

headline: Has Europe Reached the Breaking Point?
text: A few weeks ago, I visited the fence that made Hungary a symbol of European anxiety. Chain-link and razor wire, it slices through pastures as it traces Hungary’s southern border. More than 100 miles long, it was constructed quickly this summer as refugees streamed into the country, heading toward Austria and Germany. Police officers and soldiers were stationed every few hundred yards, and they examined my passport at almost every checkpoint. They seemed bored, perhaps because the flood of refugees and migrants had mostly abated. The fence had sealed Hungary off, and that made Laszlo Toroczkai — the 37-year-old mayor of Asotthalom, a Hungarian farming town on the Serbian border, and a rising ultranationalist star of far-right European politics — very happy.

headline: Poll Watch: Donald Trump’s Supporters Are Not a Happy Bunch
text: Supporters of Donald J. Trump expressed two clear sentiments in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll: anger about the way things are going in Washington, and excitement about what Mr. Trump would do as president.

headline: In Crucial Republican Bout, 2 Names Will Take the Middle of the Ring
text: Tonight is the last Republican presidential debate of 2015, and possibly the most consequential.

headline: Cartoon: Saudi Arabian Roadblock
text: A snail’s pace on women’s rights.

headline: Qualcomm Concludes a Split Would Be Detrimental
text: Qualcomm has a message for its shareholders: Breaking up is hard to do. And in the opinion of the company’s top management, it is less profitable than staying together.

headline: 1940: Bermuda Defense Bastion
text: American military authorities are losing no time in pushing ahead the development of the new United States base at Bermuda. Already United States Army engineers are in the field, making a thorough survey so that construction may start within three months. Bermuda, long recognized as a paradise for American tourists, a blissful haven for wedding trips and a peaceful place never touched by actual warfare, suddenly has become one of the most important links in a chain of military bases reaching from Newfoundland to South America. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 16, 1940

headline: The Weekly News Quiz Is on a Short Break, but We Have a Challenge for You Instead
text: Our Weekly News Quiz is on hiatus until Jan. 5, and we’re running a special Farewell, 2015 Quiz in its place.

headline: U.S. Navy Commander Implies China Has Eroded Safety of South China Sea
text: BEIJING — A senior American naval commander has implicitly accused China of creating “so-called military zones” close to artificial islands it has built in the South China Sea, declaring that such actions are eroding the security of one of the world’s busiest waterways.

headline: ‘Big Short’ Gains Awards Momentum but a Big Test Nears
text: The Oscar-aspiring “The Big Short,” a star-studded mortgage crisis comedic thriller (you probably won’t ever see those words together again), opened gangbusters this weekend, averaging $90,000 per screen. Mind you, as Variety has noted, the film was only on eight screens, and “Steve Jobs” opened auspiciously, too, taking in $130,000 per screen in four theaters before tanking.

headline: How an M.L.B. Tour of Cuba Went From a Dream to Reality
text: After Yoenis Cespedes won the Home Run Derby at the 2013 All-Star Game, he was given the opportunity to direct a charitable donation to an organization of his choosing. Cespedes immediately thought of Cuba, the country he fled in 2011, but he was not sure how to proceed. So he asked Leonor Colon, an official with the players’ union, for guidance.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Announces 2016 Season
text: Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, Derick K. Grant and Jason Samuels Smith will explore the legacy of tap dance. Wendy Whelan will team up again with Brian Brooks for an evening of new solos and duets to music played by Brooklyn Rider. And troupes from around the world — including the Bereishit Dance Company of South Korea, Che Malambo of Argentina and Compagnie Hervé Koubi of France — will come to the Berkshires to dance.

headline: Tangled Passages
text: Long, complicated sentences can be off-putting to hurried readers, especially those reading on small screens. Of course we want to convey complex ideas, with layers of nuance, background and qualification — but we don’t have to do it all in a single sentence. What’s more, overstuffed sentences are far more likely to run off the grammatical rails.

headline: A New Emphasis on Fact-Checking in Real Time
text: Here’s what makes readers justifiably crazy: false statements in news articles that are allowed to go unchallenged.

headline: Obama Counters Anti-Muslim Talk by Welcoming New Citizens
text: WASHINGTON — Standing in a room with the original Constitution, Declaration of Independence and Bill of Rights, President Obama on Tuesday declared that the United States should never give in to fear but should continue to welcome immigrants and refugees because “that’s who we are.”

headline: A Solution for Awful N.F.L. Officiating? Simplify the Rules
text: Officiating gaffes continue to be a story line of the 2015 N.F.L. season, and the problem is not just human error.

headline: Who Is a Muslim?
text: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump’s scandalous proposal that the United States bar entry to all Muslims — though he later clarified his view that American citizens and a few others might be allowed in — raises two fundamental but largely unaddressed questions: Who and what is a “Muslim”?

headline: Brazil’s Students Occupy Their Schools to Save Them
text: São Paulo, Brazil — Brazil’s economy, a huge corruption scandal at a state-owned oil company and, more recently, impeachment proceedings against President Dilma Rousseff have dominated the news about this country recently. But it’s another crisis in the state of São Paulo that has the potential to shape democracy in the country for years to come. That’s because this crisis — a huge protest in response to the state’s plan to close 94 public schools — involves some of the country’s youngest citizens: elementary, middle and high school students.

headline: The Traveling Old-Fashioned Glasses
text: Dear Diary:

headline: In North Carolina, a Town to Lift a Fork or Turn a Page
text: On the surface, there’s not much to suggest there would be anything special about the central North Carolina town of Hillsborough, population around 6,000, northwest of the Research Triangle, as the area encompassing Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill is called. Its downtown business district, a handful of low-slung brick buildings, peters out after a block or two in any direction. After that, the space between homes quickly grows, and rural surroundings take over.

headline: Airports: The Unlikely New Scene of Pop-Ups and Parties
text: For Allison Reeves, a 34-year-old actor based in Hollywood, Calif., a trip to the airport is something she dreads. “I hate, hate, hate flying,” she said. So she was surprised when she actually had fun at Kennedy International Airport after Thanksgiving.

headline: Germany Arrests Islamic Extremist Suspected of Aiding Terrorist Groups
text: The German authorities on Tuesday detained one of the country’s most active Islamic extremists, who once tried to open a school supported by a network called “Invitation to Paradise,” on four counts of supporting a terrorist organization, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Basketball’s Birth, in James Naismith’s Own Spoken Words
text: James Naismith, basketball’s inventor, arrived in New York City in early 1939 with three items on his agenda.

headline: Howard Stern and SiriusXM Sign New Deal for 5 Years
text: A decade ago, Howard Stern surprised the media world by leaving terrestrial radio — where he had a huge audience but faced constant headaches over censorship issues — for the relatively new and unproven world of satellite radio.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: Linda Ellerbee, who explained the birds and the bees and everything in between to a generation of children, bids farewell. The finalists on “The Voice” sing their hearts out. And a South Korean homicide detective has a very bad day.

headline: Trading Sags 36% at Jefferies Group
text: Jefferies Group said on Tuesday that its sales and trading revenue fell 36 in the fourth quarter, dealing a blow to its results.

headline: Mass Shootings Add Anxiety to Movie Theater Visits
text: As she sat down with her 8-year-old daughter recently in an Oakland, Calif., theater for a matinee of “The Peanuts Movie,” Denise Simard, 44, was surprised by her own paranoia.

headline: NATO Nations No Longer Question Need for Alliance
text: LONDON — NATO is the alliance that keeps finding reasons to exist, to the surprise of some and the annoyance of Moscow.

headline: Daily Report: Rules for Registering Your Drone
text: The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday laid out new registration requirements for owners of recreational drones, just in time for Christmas. The rules apply to Americans with a drone weighing between half a pound and 55 pounds — which means nearly all recreational drones.

headline: Dividing the Screen in Mac OS X
text: Q. How do you turn on the split-screen mode in the new Mac system?

headline: Related Companies Raises $1 Billion for Real Estate Fund
text: A few years after the recession, Related Companies — the real estate firm behind New York landmarks like Time Warner Center and Hudson Yards — started a fund to invest in distressed properties and refurbish them to sell at a higher price.

headline: Britain Prunes Silly Laws on Salmon Handling and Armor Wearing
text: LONDON — It is not a great idea to carry a plank of wood down a busy sidewalk. Nor should you ride a horse while drunk, or handle a salmon under suspicious circumstances.

headline: A Conservative Islam For a Liberal Society
text: My Sunday column, on Islam’s future in the West, tried to imagine how Western debates about faith in a pluralist society look to a devout Muslim trying to imagine how his religion might modernize and moderate without dissolving its essentials in a relativizing/secularizing sea. At the end, I tentatively suggested that American evangelicalism and Mormonism offer interesting models for a conservative Islam’s future in the liberal order: The analogy in both cases is necessarily theologically inapt, but the distinctive balances that American evangelicals and Mormons have struck between assimilation and self-segregation, between ecumenism and proselytization, between adapting to egalitarian norms and maintaining forms of hierarchy and patriarchy, all have relevance to what lies ahead for Islam in the West.

headline: E.U. Pushes to Take Over Border Security at Migrant Crossings
text: BRUSSELS — European Union authorities on Tuesday proposed taking control of border and coastal security at entry points for migrants in countries like Greece and Italy, to get a grip on a crisis that has divided the bloc and fed the rise of populist political movements.

headline: The Best Songs of 2015
text: The music critics of The New York Times share their picks for the best songs of the year.

headline: 1965: Peking A-Missile Peril to World
text: PARIS — Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today [Dec. 15] that Communist China will probably be able to hit cities such as San Francisco and Berlin with nuclear missiles within ten years. Mr. McNamara, in a speech to the semi-annual NATO Council meeting, said Peking would have enough fissionable material by 1967 to start producing and test-firing medium-range nuclear missiles. By 1975, he said, they would probably have operable long-range missiles. He suggested, however, implicitly, that NATO should enlarge itself into a world-wide police force to withstand Chinese aggression. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 16, 1965

headline: ‘Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them’ Trailer is Released
text: “Lumos maxima.” With the words from that incantation, a trailer, and potentially a new franchise, begins. The first look at “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” the spinoff film from the “Harry Potter” series, was released on Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Washington Mayor Avoids Charges, but Bitterness Lingers
text: WASHINGTON — In this city of poorly kept secrets and sometimes stranger-than-fiction schemes, the identity of mayoral “Candidate A,” as he was formally known in a far-reaching political corruption investigation, was not even briefly a mystery. Candidate A was Mayor Vincent C. Gray.

headline: Life on ‘Mars’ by Way of Hawaii: Q. and A.
text: On a rocky, sloping terrain near the Mauna Loa volcano in Hawaii, Christiane Heinicke, a 30-year-old German physicist and engineer, is one of six researchers conducting a yearlong simulation of life on Mars.

headline: Los Angeles and New York Differ in Their Responses to a Terrorism Threat
text: LOS ANGELES — The nation’s two largest school systems confronted threats of a terrorist attack on Tuesday and reacted in sharply different ways: New York City reviewed the warning and dismissed it as a hoax, but officials here abruptly shut down all public schools, upending the lives of parents, students and teachers.

headline: 2 Dead Children Found in Storage Unit in Northern California
text: Police officers in Northern California who were investigating a case of torture and abuse of a child this week found the bodies of two children inside a storage unit.

headline: Giants Brush Themselves Off, Still Looking to Contend
text: Chasing after a sideline pass in Monday night’s game with the Miami Dolphins, Giants cornerback Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie could not hold up as the play ended and his momentum carried him full speed into his team’s bench area. In an instant, the fully-padded Rodgers-Cromartie crashed into Tom Coughlin, propelling the 69-year-old Giants coach in a violent backward tumble.

headline: Holidays, Uncertainty and the Extended Foster Family
text: “Auntie Meghan?”

headline: What Happens When Mother Earth Gets Angry
text: The momentous climate accord reached last weekend in Paris recognizes three powerful and unyielding economic and ecological trends. These were prompted by the collision of the resource-abundant development approach of the 20th century with the increasingly dire environmental conditions of the 21st.

headline: Prison Diversion Programs in New York Face New Scrutiny After Police Officer’s Killing
text: On May 6, 2013, Darrell Wright was caught with a handgun in Brooklyn, his first arrest. He was 16, and prosecutors diverted him from jail into a program intended to provide young people with a pathway out of gang life.

headline: Focusing on Leadership as Marine Corps Mandate to Integrate Women in Combat Units Nears
text: Fourteen years ago, when I was a midshipman at Marine Corps Officer Candidates School, our female sergeant instructor lined us up at attention. “If you’re a woman in the Marine Corps,” she said, “you’re either a bitch, a dyke, or a ho.” Shocking? Perhaps. But with a purpose: she was trying to prepare us to interact with men who wouldn’t always be supportive of our presence. So this fall, before Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter announced that women would be allowed into all military occupations, I looked to the Marine Corps’ yearlong experiment to integrate women into ground combat jobs to see if attitudes had changed.

headline: For Ben Simmons, Lifting L.S.U. May Be Too Tall a Task
text: College basketball has often been enlivened by stars who turn average teams into world-beaters. Larry Bird took Indiana State to the national finals in 1979. David Robinson and Navy made it to the round of 8 in 1986. Elena Delle Donne led Delaware to the round of 16 in 2013.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 8: Christmas Time
text: Christmas is the perfect setting for a “Jane the Virgin” episode. It’s a holiday that, especially on television, emphasizes happiness, togetherness, family and tradition. The midseason finale is no exception, though it does contain a few wonderful (and dark) twists.

headline: In New Ad, Marco Rubio Appeals to Supporters of Trump and Cruz
text: Senator Marco Rubio has gone on the attack recently against Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz, who are leading in the polls nationally and in Iowa. But with this commercial, which began running on Tuesday, he instead appeals directly to their core supporters: people who feel disaffected from American politics.

headline: What to Wear for Free Nights at MoMA
text: Visitors to the Museum of Modern Art’s free Friday nights were worldly with their outfits.

headline: What to Wear for Free Nights at MoMA
text: On a recent Friday, the Museum of Modern Art quietly welcomed the millionth visitor to its Uniqlo Free Friday nights, when admission is free from 4 to 8 p.m. There was a parade of students, tourists and bargain-seeking New Yorkers (many on date nights) who braved a chilly night waiting in line.

headline: Montserrat Caballé, Former Star Soprano, Is Fined in Tax Case
text: A Spanish court on Tuesday ordered the soprano Montserrat Caballé to pay a fine of 254,000 euros, about $278,000, for avoiding taxes by falsely claiming residency in Andorra.

headline: Heilemann and Halperin to Join a Political Program on Showtime
text: One week after striking a deal with MSNBC, John Heilemann and Mark Halperin have signed a deal for a weekly show for Showtime, the premium cable channel announced on Tuesday.

headline: Ben Carson Says Muslim Civil Rights Group Has Ties to Terrorists
text: Ben Carson, the Republican presidential candidate who has been fading in the polls, accused a leading Muslim-American civil rights group of having ties to terrorists on Tuesday as he laid out a new national security plan.

headline: ‘Never Again? Don’t Be So Sure’: Readers on Donald Trump and Fascism
text: European readers offered warnings, conservatives offered defenses, and others condemned what they described as bigotry in parts of the Republican party, in response to recent articles about Donald Trump’s anti-Muslim statements.

headline: Best New York Restaurants 2015
text: Pete Wells’s picks for the top dining in the city this year.

headline: Top New York Restaurants of 2015
text: The new restaurants I reviewed this year gave me a very deep bench from which to pick this year-end list. Ruthlessly, this ranking of my favorites was capped at 10, but I could have stretched it to 15 without any noticeable drop-off in quality.

headline: Valeant Makes Distribution Deal With Walgreens
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International has agreed to distribute many of its drugs through Walgreens stores in a new way and, in some cases, for lower prices, the companies announced on Tuesday.

headline: Immigrants in America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Police Say Threat Made to New York Schools Was a Hoax
text: An email that threatened attacks against the New York City school system on Tuesday, nearly identical to one that prompted officials in Los Angeles to close schools there, was a hoax, New York officials said.

headline: ‘Transparent’ Season 2, Episodes 4 and 5: Raffles and Mee-Maw
text: When Ali and Syd are in the stacks of the Malibu library, Ali stumbles upon the concept of “epigenetics,” the idea that trauma can actually get baked into a family gene pool and pass down from generation to generation. If this theory is true, then there is something buried deep in the Pfefferman’s past that might be able to explain — or at least partly account for — the current mixed-up nature of the family, with no one quite able to chart a path toward happiness.

headline: Chris Christie’s Rubio Dilemma
text: The official Big Story of tonight’s Republican debate is Donald Trump versus Ted Cruz, but since Trump tends to back off in debates and save his barbs for his rallies and Twitter the smart money is on Ted Cruz versus Marco Rubio offering the more interesting fireworks. But the even smarter money (I know, I know, how smart can you get?) might tell you to watch out for a Chris Christie assault on Rubio, since how that attack turns out could shape the primary campaign more than whatever slings and arrows Cruz and Trump and Rubio exchange with one another.

headline: Putin Gambit Over Syria Proves to Be Dual-Edged Sword
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Eleven weeks after Moscow launched its first airstrikes in Syria, the scream of Russian warplanes has become so familiar in rebel-held areas that even children recognize it. But the military map of the conflict has changed little, and the Kremlin’s forces have become another set of players in a civil war that seems to defy solution.

headline: The Tax Acrobatics in the Dow-DuPont Deal
text: Investors cheering the planned merger of Dow Chemical and DuPont should raise a glass to the lawyers. Last week’s deal might never have come together without rarely exploited fine print in the United States tax code that should allow the companies to avoid any tax on capital gains.

headline: House Reaches Accord on Spending and Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Republican and Democratic negotiators in the House clinched a deal late Tuesday on a $1.1 trillion spending bill and a huge package of tax breaks.

headline: Fenway Park’s Neighborhood Changes, but Keeps Its Character
text: BOSTON — The Fenway neighborhood is most closely associated with Fenway Park, the Red Sox and baseball-themed taverns.

headline: How To | Wrap a Gift
text: The beauty guru and stylist Linda Rodin quickly shares how to package a present — without paper.

headline: Leslie Uggams Drops Out of Off-Broadway’s ‘Dot’
text: Leslie Uggams has dropped out of the Off Broadway play “Dot,” which opens at the Vineyard Theater on Feb. 23, in favor of a recurring role on Fox’s “Empire.”

headline: First Draft Focus: Welcome to America
text: President Obama delivered remarks on Tuesday at a naturalization ceremony at the National Archives in Washington. The event featured 31 candidates for citizenship from 25 countries.

headline: French Court Acquits Marine Le Pen of Hate Speech
text: PARIS — A French court on Tuesday acquitted the far-right leader Marine Le Pen of charges that she incited religious hatred against Muslims with comments made in 2010.

text: Check out how we analyzed the fifth Republican debate by Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport, and as well as our fact checks.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Rangers Look to Right the Ship
text: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players.

headline: Afghans See Taliban as a Key to U.S. Aid Projects, Study Finds
text: WASHINGTON — The United States spent $64,597 to build a wall around a school in Qala Nazir Baba, a village in Logar Province in Afghanistan. It spent an additional $41,792 to rehabilitate an irrigation system in Zoya, a village in Wardak Province.

headline: Review: In ‘Yours in Haste and Adoration,’ Terry Southern’s Thoughts Spill Out
text: It must have been a gas, to borrow one of his favorite terms, to get a letter from Terry Southern. Each was its own little acid trip, streaked with innuendo and poached in a satirical kind of intellectual flop sweat. He used thin, expensive paper and sealed some of his letters with wax. People were said to read them aloud to whoever was in the room.

headline: World Powers Relax the Process for Picking a U.N. Leader, Slightly
text: UNITED NATIONS — For decades, the secretary general of the United Nations has been chosen by the world’s five most powerful countries — and always behind closed doors. The only clear qualification for the job was that the permanent members of the Security Council agreed on him — and, yes, it has always been a him.

headline: Crispy Winter Squash Pastries for a Holiday Party
text: I try to get ahead not only with sweet holiday baking in December, but also with savory hors d’oeuvres that I can freeze until I need them for a party. Baked Greek phyllo triangles — tiropites — are my favorite in this department. The crispy filled pastries are always impressive, and while they take some time to make, they are not at all difficult.

headline: Thaw in China-Russia Relations Hasn’t Trickled Down
text: BLAGOVESHCHENSK, Russia — Lured by warming relations between the two countries, Li Lihua, a Chinese entrepreneur, has invested all of her money in this frigid Russian outpost on the border with her country. She has opened Chinese restaurants, purchased factories and started a $120 million housing project to build affordable apartments aimed at young, upwardly mobile Russians.

headline: Ebola Stigma in Liberia
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Guide to Delaware County’s Thriving Craft Culture
text: With candles and cheese, ceramics and coffee, a new generation of artisans is making a name for the once sleepy area of New York.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘F Is for Family,’ Netflix’s Ribald Portrayal of a ’70s Household
text: There have been several 1970s in TV’s imagination. We’ve seen the brightly plumed ’70s of the last season of “Mad Men,” the innocent mood ring of “That ’70s Show,” the consciousness-raising 1979 of “Fargo,” whose characters grasp at U.F.O.s and self-help programs to levitate them out of malaise.

headline: Russell Wilson Has Seahawks Back in the Playoff Picture
text: The Seattle Seahawks lost to the Arizona Cardinals on Nov. 15, and fell to 4-5. The offense was struggling, and the star running back Marshawn Lynch was dealing with an abdominal injury.

headline: Gilbert Taylor, New York City Homelessness Chief, Quits Post
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio, still struggling to manage near-record levels of homelessness, announced on Tuesday that his homeless-services chief was stepping down in another shake-up of the administration’s antipoverty efforts.

headline: Spoiler-Free Reviews of ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’
text: No one wants to see a spoiler.

headline: Preparing to Raise Rates, Fed Underestimates Benefits of More Inflation
text: This is going to sound like anathema to all those economists who lived through the inflation of the 1970s, but there’s a good case for trying to double the inflation rate.

headline: Mysterious Website Aims to Shed Light on Soccer Dealings
text: The press officer for F.C. Twente, a professional soccer club in the Netherlands, received a telephone call one morning last month while driving to work. A colleague had just seen a strange post on Twitter.

headline: Under Fire, Debt Restructuring Amendment Is Pulled
text: The spending bill on Capitol Hill no longer includes an amendment that had hedge funds and other investors in Caesar’s Entertainment at loggerheads.

headline: Man Arrested in VTech Breach of Children’s Data
text: Police in England said they arrested a 21-year-old man on Tuesday in connection with last month’s breach of VTech, a Hong Kong electronic toy maker, which exposed personal data for 12 million people, including 6.4 million minors.

headline: Retailers Feel the Heat of Lost Winter Clothing Sales
text: High above the pedestrians milling about Herald Square in light coats and jackets, Stuart Greenberg, a seller of luxury furs, fondly recalled chilly Decembers past.

headline: The Search Is On for Missing Public Art in England
text: LONDON — A two-ton bronze. Four, seven-foot fiberglass bulls. A 300-foot metal tube. A spiky, rusted metal pineapple-shaped fountain. These are some of the unlikely artworks that have disappeared from public places since 1945, says Historic England, a government service that protects English heritage. On Tuesday Duncan Wilson, chief executive of Historic England, issued “a call to arms” to the public to help search for some 40 missing works of public art, some by major figures like Henry Moore and Barbara Hepworth.

headline: Tyler Perry to Host Live Musical About Jesus on Fox
text: Fox is to broadcast a live musical in March about Jesus Christ, titled “The Passion,” the latest live music special to appear on network television. “The Passion” will be hosted and narrated by Tyler Perry, and broadcast live from New Orleans on Palm Sunday.

headline: Fed Rate Move May Not Hurt Eurozone, but It Won’t Help Much, Either
text: FRANKFURT — Cheap oil. A weak euro. Money printing by the central bank.

headline: Jue Lan Club’s High-End Chinese in the Flatiron District
text: Jue Lan Club Upstairs and down, indoors and out, this elaborate collection of dining areas is the showcase for the high-end modern Chinese food from Oscar Toro, who was at Buddakan. “Some of my food, like the crystal shrimp dumplings and hot and numbing crispy beef, are traditional, but I’ve interpreted other dishes,” he said. So his bao buns are filled with “sloppy” oxtail, and he’s come up with a bone marrow and prawn dumpling, and filet mignon with green Sichuan peppers, black bean aioli and taro fries. There is a raw bar, which will be expanded in the garden in the spring. Stratis Morfogen, the managing partner, has created one dining area as a homage to Limelight, the church building and former nightclub that houses the restaurant. (Opens Thursday): 49 West 20th Street, 646-524-7409, juelanclub.com.

headline: Hopes Dashed Again in Hunt for Fabled Nazi Gold Train in Poland
text: WALBRZYCH, Poland — Experts from the Krakow University of Science and Technology said on Tuesday that, contrary to 70 years of local folklore, there is no trace of any armored Nazi train filled with looted treasure buried near Walbrzych in southwestern Poland.

headline: The Latest Wave of New York’s Food Districts
text: Food neighborhoods emerge in mysterious waves. Here, we track some of New York City’s more interesting developments in 2015.

headline: A Tantalizing, Mysterious Art Book (or Is it Book Art?)
text: The artist’s book, a medium that originated in France at the turn of the last century, gets a digitally inspired reboot with “RadioPaper,” a project launching today at Studio Leigh in Hoxton, East London.Taking its title from the electronic paper that replicates the physical page in Kindles and other e-readers, the exhibition provides a showcase for the debut book work by the British artist Mary Ramsden, which will also be available to buy in an edition of 30. Framed in fluorescent-edged Perspex boxes, each of the copies of “RadioPaper” contains a series of abstract artworks by Ramsden, and perhaps more surprisingly, submerged within their French folds, five specially composed super-short stories by the Granta award-winning novelist Adam Thirlwell.

headline: Vote at Atomic Agency Officially Ends Inquiry Into Iran’s Nuclear Past
text: WASHINGTON — The nations controlling the world’s nuclear inspection agency voted on Tuesday to close its decade-long investigation into the work it suspected Iran of conducting to design a nuclear weapon, and instead to move ahead with fulfilling the deal signed in July to limit Iran’s production of atomic material for at least 15 years.

headline: Curing Hepatitis C, in an Experiment the Size of Egypt
text: SHABAS EL SHUHADA, Egypt — Abdel Gawad Ellabbad knows exactly how he was infected with hepatitis C.

headline: Donald Trump to Meet G.O.P. Megadonor Sheldon Adelson Before Debate
text: Donald J. Trump was scheduled to meet with the casino magnate and megadonor Sheldon Adelson at the Venetian Hotel in Las Vegas, the site of Tuesday night’s Republican debate, according to people briefed on the meeting.

headline: A New Education Law, and the One Left Behind
text: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Held in Connection With Paris Attacks in January and November
text: PARIS — Three people are being questioned by French investigators in connection with terrorist attacks in the Paris area this year, including two suspected of supplying the guns used in the deadly siege of a kosher supermarket in January, the Paris prosecutor’s office said Tuesday.

headline: Should Schools Err on the Side of Caution When It Comes to Bomb Threats?
text: Schools across Los Angeles were shut down and arriving students sent home on Tuesday after the police received what officials described as a credible bomb threat against “many schools, not specifically identified” and their students. Some 640,000 students enrolled in over a thousand schools were affected, along with their parents, by the sudden morning shutdown. Many parents were already on the way to school with their children, or had already put them onto buses, which were instructed to turn back. Students already at schools were sent home and arriving families turned away.

headline: Mets Re-sign Reliever Jerry Blevins
text: The Mets announced Tuesday that they had re-signed reliever Jerry Blevins, whose 2015 season was cut short by injuries, to a one-year deal. He is likely to enter next season as the team’s left-handed specialist, a position they lacked this year.

headline: Ski Issue: On the Right Path
text: A selection of photography shot for this year’s ski issue, including stunning views from Aspen, Telluride and more.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Greece and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Dec. 15, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, Indonesia, Kazakhstan and India.

headline: Remaking Dow and DuPont for the Activist Shareholders
text: The proposed combination of Dow Chemical and DuPont shows that in today’s markets, financial engineering prevails and that only activist shareholders matter. Whether that is good for the rest of us remains to be seen.

headline: Argentine Prosecutor Seeks to Reopen Case Against Ex-President
text: BUENOS AIRES — A federal prosecutor is trying to revive a criminal complaint filed by Alberto Nisman, a prosecutor who died in mysterious circumstances earlier this year.

headline: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Top 10 Lists
text: December means a flood of Top 10 and Top 100 lists, year-in-review essays and special issues dedicated to summations of one kind or another. Blake Wilson, a senior editor in Culture, talks about his department’s contributions to the torrent.

headline: Shiite Muslim Sect Alleges Massacre by Nigeria’s Military
text: KADUNA, Nigeria — Representatives of a Shiite Muslim sect in northwestern Nigeria said on Tuesday that hundreds of its members were killed by the military in a massacre over the weekend.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Jeb Bush Begins ‘The New Hampshire Project’ to Try to Resurrect His Chances in the State
text: Jeb Bush will next hit the campaign trail for a packed day of town-hall-style events in New Hampshire at 8 a.m. Saturday in Contoocook, and finish up nearly 12 hours later in Nashua. Then he will return to the state, again and again.

headline: Facts & Figures: Ted Cruz, Proud Partisan
text: Ted Cruz is near the bottom of the “Bipartisan Index,” a ranking based on how often lawmakers sponsor or co-sponsor bills introduced by members of the other party. Of those in the Senate for at least 10 months between 1993 and 2014, he ranked 224th out of 227. And if you look at current senators, he’s third from the bottom.

headline: Quentin Tarantino, Jennifer Jason Leigh and Channing Tatum at ‘The Hateful Eight’ Premiere
text: Stars of Mr. Tarantino’s new 190-minute-long film attend the screening and after-party at the Rainbow Room.

text: Is there a director in Hollywood besides Quentin Tarantino whom actors are dying to work for, in scenes too violent to be described in a newspaper?

headline: The Operatic Tenor Juan Diego Flórez Shifts His Tone, and His Persona
text: BARCELONA, Spain — The boyish pluck is still there, but middle age seems to have sneaked up on Juan Diego Flórez.

headline: What Donald Trump Has Built
text: As the 2016 electoral contest slouches toward actual voting, I wonder whether Donald Trump is happy with the results of a campaign that he has built almost entirely on hatred, fear and personal invective. Does he have any remorse over what he’s created, or is it all just part of the show for him?

headline: Pete Rose Just Doesn’t Get It, So the Hall Won’t Get Rose
text: With two outs and the bases empty in the bottom of the eighth inning on Aug. 17, 1986, Pete Rose inserted himself into the Cincinnati Reds’ game at Riverfront Stadium. Rose, who was the last active player to be his team’s manager, struck out against Goose Gossage of the San Diego Padres. He never played again.

headline: How Unpopular Is Trump’s Muslim Ban? Depends How You Ask
text: Donald J. Trump’s proposal to bar Muslim noncitizens from entering the United States, at least temporarily, does not appear to be broadly popular with Americans. But exactly how unpopular it is depends on what question a pollster asked, and possibly on whether a human or a machine asked it.

headline: Donald Trump Makes Megyn Kelly a Target Again
text: Most presidential candidates spend debate days brushing up on their policy points, getting in a bit of exercise or trying to relax before stepping into the spotlight.

headline: Health Insurance Enrollment Deadline Is Extended to Thursday
text: Hours away from a deadline, the government announced on Tuesday that it was extending an enrollment period for full-year health insurance in 2016 under the Affordable Care Act.

text: Taraji P. Henson, Caitlyn Jenner and Adele, among others, made waves this year with elegant looks and bold experiments.

text: On social media, Néstor Reverol, the head of Venezuela’s National Guard, has bragged about seizing large shipments of cocaine in raids against drug cartels.

headline: MoMA to Organize Collections That Cross Artistic Boundaries
text: Within the Museum of Modern Art’s announcement on Tuesday of coming exhibitions were signs of a seismic shift underway in how it collects and displays modern and contemporary art — changes that are expected to have a powerful impact on the museum’s renovation.

headline: Chinese Adoptees at Home in America
text: A chance encounter with several Chinese girls being raised in Montana led Meng Han to explore the world of Chinese adoptees in the United States.

headline: Jurors in Freddie Gray Trial Tell Judge They Are Deadlocked
text: After roughly 10 hours of deliberations, jurors in the trial of Officer William G. Porter, on trial for manslaughter in the death of Mr. Gray, announced that they were deadlocked. But the judge told them to continue deliberating.

headline: Review: In ‘The First Noel,’ a Forlorn Girl Longing for Holiday Gaiety
text: The little girl is called Noel, and you can tell she’s a doodler from her shoes, decorated with tiny drawings and snatches of words. “Noel the 2nd,” she’s spelled out along one side, and there it is: the wound she’s been carrying through her childhood.

headline: Holiday Lights Around New York City
text: The photographer Natan Dvir captures some of the best holiday displays from Fifth Avenue to Dyker Heights (dubbed “Dyker Lights”).

headline: ‘Luther’ Returns, With Idris Elba Reprising His Role as Tortured Detective
text: After a recent screening of the very compact new “season” of “Luther” (two hourlong episodes, being shown back to back on Thursday on BBC America), a fan’s question knocked Idris Elba off his stride for a moment: “Why are you such a badass?” She wasn’t talking about John Luther, rogue detective, or Stringer Bell, the drug dealer Mr. Elba played on “The Wire,” or James Bond, the secret agent much of the world wants him to play. She was going to the source. Badassery follows Mr. Elba around, and in the age of the incredible shrinking movie star, he’s the rare performer who sells a production based on his own considerable charisma.

headline: A Sumptuous Surrealist Moment in Manhattan
text: The Carlyle Hotel is having a Surrealist moment. Two art galleries on the premises have mounted sumptuous shows on the subject, and they play off each other beautifully.

headline: Goldman Sachs Names a Third M.&.A. Co-Chairman
text: At the close of a year filled with merger deals, Goldman Sachs has named John Vaske a third co-chairman of global mergers and acquisitions, alongside Tim Ingrassia and Paul G. Parker.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Colorado Springs Deals With Mass Killing as Nation Moves On
text: COLORADO SPRINGS — It had been just five days since a visit to a Planned Parenthood clinic put Kentanya Craion in the middle of a massacre that left her cowering in a back room and her boyfriend among the three dead.

headline: Essay Contest to Determine New Ownership of Maine Movie Theater
text: Tired of commuting 150 miles each way, the owner of a movie theater in Maine is holding an essay contest to give away his restored, nearly 100-year-old cinema.

text: RECENT SALE

headline: Baltimore Mood in 12 Tweets
text: Many Baltimoreans were disappointed yet unsurprised at the outcome of Officer William G. Porter’s trial – though some are urging those fighting for change not to give up.

headline: A ‘Dreamer’ Activist Becomes a Citizen, but Her Fight Is Not Over
text: WASHINGTON — Lorella Praeli has not always been happy with President Obama.

headline: Review: ‘The Emperor’s New Clothes,’ a Documentary About Income Inequality
text: Free-market fundamentalism — the belief that the economy, if left to its own devices, will self-correct in times of stress — is the source of all evil in Russell Brand and Michael Winterbottom’s inflammatory documentary, “The Emperor’s New Clothes.” And the economist Milton Friedman, whose laissez-faire economic theories were embraced by Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, is portrayed as a kind of Antichrist foreshadowing the global meltdown of 2008.

headline: A Conversation With Klara Madlin
text: Ms. Madlin, 68, is the president of Klara Madlin Real Estate, a boutique residential brokerage firm that she founded in 1984. The single-office firm specializes in properties on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Review: Generations of Music by the Carter Family, Documented
text: American royalty gets a well-deserved encomium in Beth Harrington’s fond documentary, “The Winding Stream: The Carters, the Cashes and the Course of Country Music.”

headline: Review: ‘Dreams Rewired,’ a Futuristic Look at the Past
text: “Dreams Rewired,” a montage of clips from nearly 200 vintage films, is a lively, visually enthralling attempt to gaze into the future by remembering the past. The snippets — mostly obscure excerpts from dramas, cartoons and scientific and educational films — are seamlessly fused into a whoosh of images, many of them zany, all from the 1880s to the 1930s. The later ones have sound.

headline: Global Payments to Buy Heartland Payment for $4.3 Billion
text: Global Payments said on Tuesday that it planned to buy Heartland Payment Systems, a fellow payment processor focused on small to midsize businesses, for about $4.3 billion in cash and stock.

headline: Physicists in Europe Find Tantalizing Hints of a Mysterious New Particle
text: Does the Higgs boson have a cousin?

headline: Hillary Clinton Asks Tech Companies to Help Thwart ISIS Online
text: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton on Tuesday accelerated her call for technology companies to cooperate with the government and develop a “unified national strategy in cyberspace” to stop the Islamic State from using the Internet to recruit members in the United States and around the world.

headline: A Park to Sop Up Pollutants Before They Flow Into the Gowanus Canal
text: At the foot of Second Street in Brooklyn, hard by the Gowanus Canal, is a tiny green space with a very big job.

headline: Group Calls Israelis ‘Foreign Agents’ for Work on Behalf of Palestinians
text: An ultranationalist Israeli group was accused of incitement on Tuesday for labeling the leaders of four of Israel’s most prominent human rights organizations “foreign agents” in a widely viewed video that equates their work on behalf of Palestinians with support for terrorism.

headline: Undertaker’s Discovery Turns a Brooklyn Death Into a Murder Case
text: On a morning in November, the New York police officers who had been called to check on an 82-year-old woman found her lying on her kitchen floor, her body partly under a table. She was dead, the authorities said, and had probably been there for days.

headline: San Diego Vows to Move Entirely to Renewable Energy in 20 Years
text: Last weekend, representatives of 195 countries reached a landmark accord in Paris to lower planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions. On Tuesday, local leaders in San Diego committed to making a city-size dent in the problem.

headline: School Segregation Persists in Gentrifying Neighborhoods, Maps Suggest
text: The segregation in New York City elementary schools is often assumed to be a simple consequence of where people live: If neighborhoods are racially divided, so too will be their neighborhood schools.

headline: Plaintiff and Lawyer Ordered to Reimburse New York in False-Arrest Suit
text: Nearly three years ago, a woman reported being abused by her husband. He was arrested, only to have the charge dropped after the wife recanted. The man, Patricio Jimenez, then sued New York City last year for false arrest.

headline: Judge to Appoint Monitor for Mold Repairs in New York Public Housing
text: A federal judge, frustrated by the slow pace of New York’s efforts to curb mold in public housing, will appoint a special master to ensure the city complies with an agreement to address the problem faster and more aggressively.

headline: What You’ve Missed So Far in the Debate
text: Check out how we analyzed the fifth Republican debate in real time, as well as our fact checks.

headline: Glen Sonmor, 86, a Brawling N.H.L. Coach
text: Glen Sonmor, an explosive hockey coach who guided the Minnesota North Stars to their first Stanley Cup finals in 1981, died on Monday in Brantford, Ontario. He was 86.

headline: Battered, Apologetic and Still Pitching Their Hedge Funds
text: It has been a bruising year for hedge funds. Not even billionaire managers with sterling records were able to escape heavy losses, and several among them have made the industry’s list of worst performers. Some lost so much of their investors’ money this year that they have written apology letters.

headline: Army Names Woman to High Post
text: Weeks after the military opened all combat roles to women, the Army on Tuesday named Brig. Gen. Diana Holland as the first female commandant of cadets at West Point, the service academy that has produced some of the country’s most famous officers. General Holland, who is currently the deputy commander for support of the Army’s 10th Mountain Division, graduated from West Point in 1990. The commandant oversees the cadets at West Point, while the dean, also a one-star general, is in charge of academics. Both report to the academy’s superintendent, who is a three-star general. General Holland joined the Army Corps of Engineers after leaving West Point, and she deployed to Iraq in 2004 and later did two stints in Afghanistan.

headline: Graduation Rates Reach a High
text: The graduation rate for American public school students is at its highest ever, according to data released Tuesday by the United States Department of Education. In the 2013-14 school year, 82 percent of students who started ninth grade completed high school within four years. The increase held true across all demographic categories, including low-income students and students with disabilities or limited English proficiency. The largest gains were among black students, for whom the rate rose 5.6 percentage points since 2010-11, when states began using a uniform measurement, to 72.5 percent in 2013-14, and among students learning English, among whom the rate increased 5.6 percentage points in the same period, to 62.6 percent.

headline: Hague Court Orders Retrial for 2 Aides to Milosevic
text: PARIS — United Nations appeals judges on Tuesday ordered a new trial for two top aides of former President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, saying that they had been wrongfully acquitted in 2013.

headline: California: 2 Children Found Dead
text: Police officers in Northern California who were investigating a case of torture and abuse of a child this week found the bodies of two children inside a storage unit. The Plumas County sheriff’s office said in a statement on Tuesday that it was asked by the county child protective services agency on Friday to conduct a welfare check on a 9-year-old girl living in an apartment in Quincy. It said that two people, Gonzalo Curiel, 17, and Tami Joy Huntsman, 39, were arrested after the girl was found with “numerous injuries.” They were being held on torture, mayhem and child abuse charges with bail set at $1 million. The case turned into a homicide investigation when the bodies of two children were found in a storage unit in Redding, about 100 miles away.

headline: Tennessee Woman Tried Coat-Hanger Abortion, Police Say
text: A Tennessee woman has been charged with attempted murder after she reportedly tried to abort a 24-week-old fetus with a coat hanger, a case that has raised passions about abortion and women’s autonomy.

headline: Report Finds Less Misuse of Painkillers by Teenagers
text: A new federal report suggests that misuse of prescription painkillers among teenagers is decreasing, news that heartened officials who remained concerned at the steady numbers regarding marijuana and e-cigarette use.

headline: In Lower-Tier Debate, Republicans Warn About Choice for President
text: Remember us?

headline: The Republican Debate in Las Vegas
text: Republican presidential candidates gathered for their final debate of 2015 on Tuesday night in Las Vegas.

headline: Slack Aims to Become a Control Panel for Your Job
text: What if you could run your whole job from a messaging app? Imagine doing your expenses or requesting human resources forms through a simple chat interface, or using an instant message to respond to customer complaints or to start a conference call with your colleagues.

headline: A Bad Call on the Bergdahl Court-Martial
text: The decision by Gen. Robert Abrams, the head of Army Forces Command in North Carolina, to refer Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, a soldier who was held hostage by the Taliban for five years, to a general court-martial was an odd call. Lt. Col. Mark Visger, the military officer who oversaw Sergeant Bergdahl’s preliminary hearing, recommended that the soldier not face jail time or a punitive discharge, and found that a different process called a special court-martial would be appropriate. General Abrams did not explain his thinking.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief Ashton Carter Prods Gulf States to Take Larger Role in ISIS Fight
text: INCIRLIK AIR BASE, Turkey — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter flew to this strategically positioned air base in southern Turkey on Tuesday carrying an appeal for allied nations to do more to combat the Islamic State.

headline: Don’t Blame Mental Illness for Gun Violence
text: Those who oppose expanded gun-control legislation frequently argue that instead of limiting access to guns, the country should focus on mental health problems.

headline: Dance This Week: Misia Sert, Meredith Monk and Anne Waldman
text: While New York dance this week is dominated by the continuing and annual seasons of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” (New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater) and Alvin Ailey Dance Theater (at City Center, where the Balanchine “Nutcracker” had its premiere in 1954), two other events occur this week only. Though not primarily dance events, they connect music, theater and dance in various ways.

headline: Transcript: Republican Presidential Debate
text: Following is a transcript of the “undercard” Republican debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Fifth Republican Debate: Analysis
text: We analyzed in real time the fifth Republican debate, in Las Vegas.

headline: Review: In ‘These Paper Bullets!,’ a Chance to Twist and Shout
text: Try to forget Shakespeare, and it’s easy enough to have a goofy good time at “These Paper Bullets!,” a lively if labored update of “Much Ado About Nothing” that the Atlantic Theater Company opened on Tuesday.

headline: Cul-de-Sac
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Paula Gamache, she was reminding us to keep our ears clean, but today she offers us a puzzle that shows us that the DEAD can pop up just about anywhere, so please make sure that you are prepared for the zombie apocalypse, which is apparently upcoming.

headline: Muslim Parents on How They Talk to Their Children About Hatred and Extremism
text: A Muslim parent in Tokyo tells her children to “work 100 times harder” and “be 100 times kinder.” A father in Ontario advises his teenagers to be wary of anyone reaching out to them over the Internet and claiming to be Muslim. “ISIL is trying to recruit you,” he tells them, referring to the Islamic State.

headline: Faith Is Sustaining Family Through Mother’s Tumor
text: There is no doubt in Victoria Gonzalez’s mind that her Christian faith is responsible for her very survival. And she hopes her children will benefit from it in equal measure.

headline: Rookies Fill Void on Defense and Give Rangers a Boost Against the Streaking Oilers
text: Just 23 seconds after serving a slashing penalty, Rangers defenseman Marc Staal skated right back to the box for clobbering Edmonton Oilers forward Leon Draisaitl in the face with his stick. The Rangers were squatting on a one-goal third-period lead, a rarity lately.

headline: John Kerry Visits Moscow to Prepare for Talks on Syria
text: MOSCOW — Secretary of State John Kerry pressed ahead on Tuesday in the effort to organize a new round of talks aimed at ending the Syrian civil war that could also align the United States and Russia more closely in strategies for fighting the Islamic State.

headline: Luigi Creatore, Songwriter and Producer for Presley and Sam Cooke, Dies at 93
text: Luigi Creatore, a songwriter and record producer who teamed with his cousin Hugo Peretti to create hits for Elvis Presley, Sam Cooke, Perry Como and others, died on Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 93.

headline: In Republican Debate, Donald Trump and Marco Rubio Become Targets

headline: Who Won the Republican Debate? Commentators Weigh In
text: The final Republican presidential debate of 2015 was marked by sharp exchanges between Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, and it featured a feistier Jeb Bush and a Donald J. Trump who seemed as if he was trying not to slip up. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky also sought to seize the spotlight in an event that saw all the candidates trying to make a strong impression on Republican voters less than two months before the first nominating contest.

headline: Success Academy Network to Shorten Its School Day Next Year
text: Success Academy, the high-achieving charter school network, told employees this week that it would shorten its school day next year, altering a feature that has distinguished the network from New York City’s regular public schools but has also made it hard to retain teachers.

headline: Case Against Civil Rights Lawyer Tests Free Speech in China
text: BEIJING — Many Chinese Internet users are watching with great concern the case of the civil rights lawyer Pu Zhiqiang, in which prosecutors brought charges against Mr. Pu based on seven short posts he wrote from 2011 to 2014 on Weibo, a Twitter-like platform.

headline: 2 Brooklyn Men Are Charged in Firing of Pistol at Waldorf Astoria Wedding
text: Two brothers who were arrested this summer after one of them inadvertently fired a pistol during a wedding at the Waldorf Astoria were indicted on felony weapons charges on Tuesday, according to court filings.

headline: ‘Ghostbusters’ Joins Library of Congress National Film Registry
text: Are you troubled by strange noises in the middle of the night? Do you experience feelings of dread in your basement or attic? Well, perhaps the Library of Congress can help alleviate those sensations when it adds “Ghostbusters” and 24 other classic movies to its National Film Registry.

headline: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Delivers the Thrills, With a Touch of Humanity
text: The big news about “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” is — spoiler alert — that it’s good! Despite the prerelease hype, it won’t save the world, not even Hollywood, but it seamlessly balances cozy favorites — Harrison Ford, ladies and gentlemen — and new kinetic wows, along with some of the niceties that went missing as the series grew into a phenomenon, most crucially a scale and a sensibility that are rooted in the human. It has the usual toy-store-ready gizmos and critters, but it also has appealingly imperfect men and women whose blunders and victories, decency and goofiness remind you that a pop mythology like “Star Wars” needs more than old gods to sustain it.

headline: What Israel Tells Us About Affirmative Action and Race
text: THE Supreme Court heard oral arguments last week in Fisher v. University of Texas, a case that could decide the future of affirmative action in American higher education. When the court first heard the case, in 2013, the justices ruled that universities may take race and ethnicity into account in admissions only if race-neutral solutions have proved to be unworkable. Many legal scholars predict that this session’s decision is likely to pressure schools to find race-neutral ways of achieving student diversity.

headline: Paris Climate Accord Is a Big, Big Deal
text: PARIS — I had low expectations for the U.N. climate meeting here and it met all of them — beautifully. I say that without cynicism.

headline: Can This Really Be Donald Trump’s Republican Party?

headline: Thinking Against Violence
text: This is an interview with Brad Evans, a senior lecturer in international relations at the University of Bristol in England. He is the founder and director of the Histories of Violence project, a global research initiative on the meaning of mass violence in the 21st century. His most recent books include “Disposable Futures: The Seduction of Violence in the Age of Spectacle” (with Henry Giroux), “Resilient Life: The Art of Living Dangerously” (with Julian Reid) and “Liberal Terror.” — Natasha Lennard

headline: Japan’s Top Court Upholds Law Requiring Spouses to Share Surname
text: TOKYO — Japan’s highest court on Wednesday upheld a law dating back more than a century that requires married couples to share the same surname, rejecting a claim that it discriminates against women by effectively forcing them to give up their names in favor of their husbands’.

headline: How Exercise May Help Us Fight Off Colds
text: Working out could help us fight off colds and other infections, according to a timely new study. The study, which found that regular exercise strengthens the body’s immune system in part by repeatedly stressing it, was conducted in animals. But the results most likely apply to people, the researchers say, and could offer further incentive for us to remain physically active this winter.

headline: 1915: Austria Denies U.S. Allegations
text: LONDON — The Austrian government’s Note in reply to the ‘‘final word’’ of the United States regarding the sinking of the Italian steamship Ancona, among whose murdered passengers were several Americans, is described by all evening papers here as of a most offensive tone. Aimed as direct defiance to the United States, the callous refusal of Vienna to be governed by the precedent established by Berlin after the sinking of the Lusitania — when Germany promised not to sink passenger ships without warning — is regarded as indicative that submarines of the Dual Monarchy will continue their piratical policy. — The New York Herald, European Edition, December 17, 1915

headline: Must I Pretend to Like My Artist Friend’s Work?
text: A good friend of ours is an aspiring painter. Recently she held an exhibition at her studio of her latest efforts. We love her, but we’re not fans of her art, which is definitely a work in progress. She invited us to her ‘‘party,’’ but we knew that if we attended, we’d be expected to buy one of her paintings, which cost a few hundred dollars each. She’s struggling and could use the money, but here’s our question: Are we obliged, out of friendship or sympathy, to buy art from her even if we have no interest in it? Name Withheld

headline: A New Winter Roast
text: We were eating dinner at Houseman, a restaurant opened by the chef Ned Baldwin on the once-quiet far-western side of SoHo, now called Hudson Square. It is a spare, welcoming room, with walls of white brick, warm lighting, smooth wooden tables the color of Bridgehampton sand — a neighborhood restaurant for those who live amid art and commerce, who travel widely, who want to eat simply and well.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Helicoptering Your Parents’ Babysitting
text: Dan writes: My partner thinks we should leave our 15-month-old son alone with my parents overnight. But I have witnessed some alarming behavior when they have taken care of my nephew. Once, rather than use the formula powder my sister-in-law had left them, my mom went into a random cabinet and used pancake mix instead.

headline: Understanding El Niño
text: Rain in California. Fires in the tropics. Floods in the southern United States. Unseasonably warm weather on the Eastern Seaboard. All have followed El Niño events in past years.

headline: A Training Ground for Untrained Artists
text: The artists arrived at the Creative Growth Art Center shortly after 9 a.m. Most come on East Bay Paratransit buses, which bring them from Alameda, Castro Valley and San Francisco, but a few travel independently. William Tyler takes the orange line BART from his group home in Union City. In 37 years, he has almost never been late. Terri Bowden takes the BART from Fremont, accompanied by a life-size matboard Fred Flintstone. It is a familiar sight to commuters in Oakland’s 19th Street BART station: the legally blind woman with a mohawk and her inanimate sidekick. Bowden periodically replaces the doll’s face; before Fred Flintstone, it was Abraham Lincoln, Michael Jackson, Robert Plant and, at some point, nearly every Creative Growth staff member. John Martin, who lives with his aunt 20 blocks away, walks to work, but not in a straight line. He stops at coffee shops, which fill his empty Gatorade bottles with coffee; at churches, which hand him donated cans of food; and at trash bins, where he rummages for plastic toys, sunglasses and flip phones.

headline: Republican Debate Offered Several Standouts and More Substance Than Fireworks

headline: U.S. Calls for Investigation of Shiite Deaths in Nigeria

headline: Bo Ryan’s Retirement Ends an Era in Wisconsin Basketball
text: At his postgame news conference on Tuesday night after Wisconsin’s 64-49 win over Texas A&M-Corpus Christi, Coach Bo Ryan checked the night’s stat sheet. He spoke for a minute about the game. Then Ryan, who has the most coaching wins in Wisconsin basketball history, announced his immediate retirement.

headline: Michael Fassbender and the Robes of Royalty
text: In “Macbeth,” high medieval fashion gets a makeover befitting the rugged landscape of 11th-century Scotland. “We avoided all decoration — the brocades and braids — anything you’d associate with medieval style,” Jacqueline Durran, the film’s costume designer, said. “We wanted it to be almost primitive.” Instead she relied on materials like bone, hemp and nettle to dress the mad and murderous characters of one of Shakespeare’s darkest stories.

headline: Christmas Fiction: A Gift for Marian
text: STANDING in the kitchen, I was finishing the washing up when I noticed it had begun to snow. Not properly, just a few flakes. The lights were on over the way, they’ve got their tree in the window: nicely decorated, all red and gold. I could see her — Marian — her face lit momentarily by the blinking Christmas lights, and she clocked me too, gave me a little wave.

headline: Stick to Sanctions on Russia
text: LONDON — Ukraine and Russia are still at war. Since the Minsk II peace agreement came into effect on Feb. 15, nearly 400 Ukrainian soldiers and more than 200 civilians have been killed. Many more may die yet. As European Union leaders gather for a summit meeting this week, with the issue of whether to renew sanctions against Russia far from resolved, they cannot afford to ignore the continued violations of the cease-fire.

headline: The West’s Best Ally Against ISIS
text: KIRKUK, Iraq — Whenever it can, the Islamic State strikes at the West through the attacks by terrorists inspired by its hateful ideology. The recent attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., are an all too painful reminder of the dangers of this despicable group.

headline: A Three-Day Trek in the Highlands of Myanmar
text: We’d been walking for hours on a dirt path with no shade when we came to the rice field. In a clearing, half a dozen farmers had set slanting wooden boards on the ground, arranged in a circle. They were hitting bundles of harvested rice plants against the panels so that the kernels broke away and slid down onto a tarp. Oxen waited nearby, hitched to heavy wooden carts.

headline: Neu West Berlin
text: The newly opened restaurant, exhibition space and club is a hangout for the city’s art crowd.

headline: A New All-Purpose Hangout for Berlin’s Creative Types
text: On one recent evening at Neu West Berlin, a new artist-run restaurant, exhibition space, club, studio and chef’s residency in the heart of the city’s Kreuzberg creative scene, red and green lasers dashed across the walls as the noise-music group SFX tinkered with cassette players, pedals and mixers, filling the space with a moody soundscape. One musician, Cem Oral, stood on a chair and duct-taped an audio recorder to a wartime fuel tank hanging from the ceiling. “This is a jam,” said co-founder Patrice Lux, seated in candlelight. “It’s a different kind of music night.”

headline: India, Choking on Pollution, Restricts Vehicle Use in New Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — The Supreme Court of India ordered several transportation restrictions in the nation’s capital on Wednesday to help curb pollution, issuing a temporary ban on the registration of some diesel cars and setting a time frame for all taxis in the region to switch to compressed natural gas.

headline: These ‘Star Wars’ Stormtroopers Aim for the Heart
text: At the Los Angeles premiere of “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” on Monday, fans, celebrities and droids mingled in celebration of all things intergalactic. But only one fan group was invited to send over 50 costumed fans to the event.

headline: ‘Transparent’ Season 2 Episodes 6 and 7: Motherhood and Making Amends
text: Here’s everything you need to know about Pfefferman parenting: when Josh confronts his mother about hiding his child, Shelly is not the least bit contrite. Instead, she immediately justifies her actions, saying they were just trying to protect him and let him move on with his life, consequence-free. She says they didn’t beat him and that they gave him a credit card — what else could a good Jewish boy want?
