headline: New York State Agrees to Overhaul Solitary Confinement in Prisons
text: New York has agreed to a major overhaul in the way solitary confinement is administered in the state’s prisons, with the goal of significantly reducing the number of inmates held in isolation, cutting the maximum length of stay and improving their living conditions.

headline: After Shingles, Higher Risk of Heart Attack or Stroke
text: Shingles infections are very painful. They may also increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes in the weeks after an outbreak, a new study reports.

headline: ‘Artistic Furniture of the Gilded Age’ Recalls Rockefeller and Worsham
text: In 1881, Arabella Worsham, mistress and later wife of the railroad tycoon Collis P. Huntington, commissioned the cabinetmaker and interior designer George A. Schastey to decorate her home at 4 West 54th Street. A product of Schastey’s work was a private dressing room for Worsham done in the fashionable style of the Aesthetic movement. It was a fully integrated chamber featuring a built-in wardrobe, full-length mirrors, delicate tables and chairs, and intricate marquetry rendered in satinwood and purpleheart with mother-of-pearl inlays. In 1884, Worsham sold the house and its furnishings to John D. Rockefeller, who left it to the Museum of the City of New York after his death in 1937.

headline: 2015 in Men’s Fashion
text: Instagram peacocks and upscale underwear were but two phenomena from 2015, as guys seemed to be paying special attention to how they looked.

headline: The Obsessions of Douglas Sirk
text: Few Hollywood directors have undergone the kind of renovation of reputation experienced by Douglas Sirk (1897-1987), whose career is surveyed in a far-reaching retrospective presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, Wednesday, Dec. 23, through Jan. 6 at the Walter Reade Theater. The titles alone — “Magnificent Obsession,” “All That Heaven Allows,” “Written on the Wind,” “All I Desire,” “Imitation of Life” — evoke a hyperemotional soap-opera climate. If this German-born director is best known for his churning domestic melodramas, his output also includes musical comedy (“Slightly French”), war films (“Battle Hymn”) and westerns (“Taza, Son of Cochise”).

headline: Parents of Teenagers, Stuck Taking Out the Emotional Trash
text: Psychologists have long observed that teenagers sometimes manage uncomfortable feelings by passing them off to their parents. Remember how your toddler wordlessly handed you her wrappers and empty juice boxes, and you reflexively accepted them, even when both of you stood right next to a wastebasket? In the adolescent equivalent, the trash is emotional, not actual, but the effect is the same: Our teenagers sometimes lighten their loads by passing their problems to us.

headline: Great Midweek Recipes
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Lise de la Salle and Emanuel Ax: Affordable Elegance
text: Music lovers in the New York area have long counted on the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts for excellent, affordable programs. The series continues on the afternoon of Sunday, Dec. 20, when the elegant French-born pianist Lise de la Salle is joined by four instrumentalists from the Knights, the dynamic player-run chamber orchestra, in an enticing program of works by Mozart, Martinu, Takemitsu, Ravel and Judd Greenstein. Her colleagues for the occasion include the violinist Colin Jacobsen and the cellist Eric Jacobsen, the brothers who founded the Knights, along with the violinist Guillaume Pirard and the violist Kyle Armbrust. (2 p.m., Town Hall, pscny.org.)

headline: Christmas Events, Traditional and Not
text: Feeling the holiday spirit? This is a good time to catch up to the always impressive Rockettes, high-kicking away in “The Radio City Christmas Spectacular.” (Through Jan. 3; radiocitychristmas.com.) Or, for something sillier, try “Elf the Musical,” adapted from the 2003 Will Ferrell comedy. (Through Dec. 27; elftour.com.) Irish Repertory Theater’s “A Child’s Christmas in Wales,” based on the prose poem by Dylan Thomas and featuring John Cullum, is a more intimate option. (Through Jan. 3; irishrep.org.)

headline: American Dance Machine for the 21st Century Keeps Classic Moves Alive
text: When a Broadway show closes, what happens to the choreography? Dance, not as easily documented as music or dialogue, is at a higher risk of eroding as the production sits in storage. Such is the driving concern behind American Dance Machine for the 21st Century, which keeps musical-theater dances alive and untarnished through exacting reconstructions. Founded in 2012 by Nikki Feirt Atkins, the current incarnation picks up where the 1970s original, established by the dancer and director Lee Becker Theodore, left off a few decades ago.

headline: Republican Debate Has Candidates Seeing Red
text: The nine Republicans running for their party’s presidential nomination didn’t agree on much during Tuesday’s main debate (other than the fact that any of them would be a better leader than Hillary Clinton), but on one thing, there was surprising near unanimity: seven of the nine came armed for battle in red.

headline: ‘Santas in the Barn,’ on TruTV, Will Pick a Winner
text: Television is at its most mindless during the last two weeks of the year, but at least TruTV is performing a public service with its mindlessness. On Thursday night, after a grueling month of competitions, its “Santas in the Barn” will identify the best Santa in the United States.

headline: Los Lobos Returns to City Winery
text: A Mexican-American band, a jam band, a roots-rock band, a blues band, a folk-rock band, a band with an arty streak and a band that could easily play a 1950s sock hop or a backyard barbecue in East Los Angeles — Los Lobos is all of those, coherent in its versatility. Now in its fifth decade, Los Lobos has become as much an American band as the Grateful Dead was: still in touch with its heritage but never confined by it. The band returns to City Winery, the club where it recorded its 2013 album, “Disconnected in New York City,” for its annual Christmastime stint. (Sunday, Dec. 20, with Connor Kennedy opening, and Monday, Dec. 21, with the Jamie McLean Band opening; citywinery.com.)

headline: Choosing Antibiotics Over Surgery for Appendicitis
text: Once, appendicitis in a child always meant immediate surgery. But a new study has found that antibiotics may work just as well for children with uncomplicated appendicitis. (That means no ruptured appendix, a relatively low white blood count and no impacted feces.)

headline: In a Self-Serve World, Start-Ups Find Value in Human Helpers
text: It’s unfashionable to admit this in the age of Expedia, Priceline and other do-it-yourself online tools, but here it is: I miss travel agents.

headline: A Houston Marriage Proposal Stops Highway Traffic
text: Since the dawn of time — or at least the dawn of social media — men have been maneuvering themselves and their loved ones into foolish situations to set the stage for jaw-dropping marriage proposals.

headline: Video House Tours
text: Surprising and delightful interiors, belonging to the most interesting people in fashion, art, architecture, society and design.

headline: Jazz Intuition, American Roots and Double Hybrids
text: LOTUS

headline: You Asked, Martin O’Malley Answered
text: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

headline: Rolls-Royce to Restructure Management in Cost-Cutting Drive
text: Rolls-Royce, the British engineering group, announced a major management restructuring on Wednesday that the company said was aimed at simplifying a byzantine hierarchy and lowering operating costs after a string of profit warnings.

headline: At Republican Debate, Straying Into Mideast, and Getting Lost
text: WASHINGTON — In a surprisingly substantive debate on foreign policy Tuesday night, Republican presidential candidates had a chance to present their alternative to what was portrayed as President Obama’s failed approach to the upheaval in the Middle East. But in their effort to demonstrate their skills at analysis and leadership, the politics and history of the region often eluded them.

headline: Larry Wilmore to Host White House Correspondents’ Dinner
text: In its search for a topical satirist to fling timely zingers and pierce overinflated egos at its annual dinner, the White House Correspondents’ Association is keeping it 100: Larry Wilmore, the host of “The Nightly Show” on Comedy Central, will be the principal entertainer at this annual Washington event on April 30, the association said Wednesday.

headline: Judge Leaves Northern Ireland’s Abortion Laws to Lawmakers
text: DUBLIN — A Belfast judge declined to modify Northern Ireland’s strict abortion laws on Wednesday, saying that only lawmakers had the authority to bring the current legislation in line with European human rights laws.

headline: Jeb Bush Campaign Promotes His Performance in a Call With Donors
text: In the week before Tuesday’s debate in Las Vegas, when reporters asked Jeb Bush how he planned to regain control of the narrative in the presidential race, Mr. Bush quipped, “Not answer any more questions about Donald Trump.”

headline: Trifonov Joins Prokofiev Marathon in Brooklyn
text: The marathon concert of all five Prokofiev piano concertos that Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra are bringing to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in February will include some youthful star power: Daniil Trifonov and George Li will join the lineup of soloists, the academy announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Red Caboose, a Midtown Hobbyist Shop
text: Since 1970, the hobbyist store has been a paradise for collectors of model trains, cars and buses.

headline: 1965: U.S. Launches Sun Satellite
text: CAPE KENNEDY — A drum-shaped interplanetary explorer named Pioneer-6 rocketed into orbit about the sun today [Dec. 16] and radioed back ‘‘good quality’’ information which may help unlock mysteries of the solar system.

headline: Republican Candidates’ Sparring Resumes Mere Hours After Their Debate
text: Senator Ted Cruz, facing the most aggressive effort yet to sully his reputation with conservatives, absorbed a flood of attacks Wednesday from Senator Marco Rubio over immigration policy and national security, an offensive aimed at halting Mr. Cruz’s rise among Tea Party and evangelical voters.

headline: A Little Something for Nearly Everyone
text: After much discussion and many delays, White House and congressional negotiators reached an agreement to make permanent more than 50 temporary tax breaks, or “tax extenders,” that had been repeatedly extended for only short periods to understate their long-term costs. Below are some highlights.

headline: At a Midtown Shop, Trains, Planes, Buses. And More Trains.
text: “You’re either a bus guy or a train guy,” Arnold Hochberg said the other day. He has a collection of more than 500 model buses. He is a bus guy.

headline: That ‘Brooklyn Look’: A Family Business
text: The brothers Robert and Eric Taffera, contractors who specialize in Brooklyn brownstone renovations, have become the de facto caretakers of a neighborhood.

headline: The Curators of a Home’s ‘Brooklyn Look’
text: The stoops and sidewalks of Brooklyn Heights on this November afternoon were napped with gold — drifts of maple, oak and willow leaves — appropriate dressing for the gold coast neighborhood that was the city’s first historic district. Its de facto caretaker, Robert Taffera, a mild-mannered contractor from Washington State, walked the fog-slick streets and pointed out his handiwork: nearly 40 houses that have been renovated by his company.

headline: The Novel’s Evil Tongue
text: When the world was just new, Story came into being, and it came with the beguilements of gossip, and talebearing, and rumor.

headline: Gingerbread Dream Team
text: When an architect, a pastry chef and a kid decide to build a gingerbread house, who knows what will happen?

headline: The Secret of Trump’s Success
text: My sense of things, last night and in the cold light of morning, is that yesterday evening’s Republican debate mostly maintained the primary race’s status quo — Trump on top, Rubio and Cruz jockeying beneath, and room for maybe one more candidate to work their way into the not-Trump mix. It was an evening when Rubio and Cruz fought one another to a draw on national security and immigration, when Ben Carson continued his slow recessional, when Chris Christie stuck to selling himself as a tough-guy leader (how tough? World War III tough, Wolf) instead of mixing it up with the candidate he needs to eventually fight, when Kasich and Fiorina and Rand Paul were afterthoughts, and when nobody save Paul and Jeb Bush even tried to lay a glove on Donald Trump.

headline: Gossip and Scandal Lead Google’s Top Searches in 2015
text: Google released the top search terms of the year Wednesday morning, accompanied by a video stitched together from inspiring clips: France’s response to the Paris attacks, refugees navigating their way to safe haven and an adult lion bathing its cub, all of it narrated by Caitlyn Jenner’s speech at the ESPY Awards calling for harmony and acceptance of one another’s differences.

headline: Riverton Housing Complex Is Sold in a Deal Preserving Affordable Units
text: Riverton, a residential complex that has long been a home for Harlem’s middle class, was one of the first properties to fall victim to speculators during the heady days of the last real estate boom a decade ago.

headline: Star Wars Fans, Awakened by ‘The Force,’ Turn Out in Droves
text: LONDON — In Manila, a 27-year-old ballet dancer named Mika Fabella began weeping as John Williams’s orchestral score filled the cinema. In Bangkok, Winyou Sukhumwat, 40, who had made a video of himself posing with a lightsaber, declared, “I feel alive again.” In Paris, Jérémy Forges, a 32-year-old security guard, took a day off from work so he could stand in line for five hours to catch the 10 a.m. screening at the sumptuous Grand Rex theater.

headline: BATS Exchange to Try Again at an I.P.O.
text: BATS Global Markets is making a second attempt at a public stock offering three years after a technology problem forced it to stay private.

headline: Teenager Who Used ‘Affluenza’ Defense in Fatal Crash Is Missing
text: Two years ago, a Texas teenager who killed four people in a drunken-driving crash was given probation after a defense witness suggested he suffered from “affluenza,” a term used to describe psychological problems that can afflict children from wealthy families.

headline: Chris Christie Reminds Voters, Again and Again, of His Prosecutor Days
text: Most governors who seek the presidency promote executive experience as their chief credential, regaling voters with tales of big decisions they have made and budgets they have balanced.

headline: Group Backing John Kasich Likens Donald Trump to Hippo in New Ad
text: New Day for America, a “super PAC” supporting Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, is aggressively attacking Donald J. Trump, now with a mocking commercial titled “Hippo-Crit” that suggests Mr. Trump belongs in the White House about as much as he belongs in a zoo.

headline: You Asked, Martin O’Malley Answered
text: On Monday, we asked you to submit questions for Martin O’Malley. During his visit to the editorial board, which was otherwise off the record, he drew one of your questions to answer on camera. Watch his response below:

headline: Why Handmade Ceramics Are White Hot
text: Bowls and platters are joining earlier trends like terrariums, Edison light bulbs and artisanal chocolate as accessories of the moment.

headline: Streaming Comedies Worth a Look
text: The best original streaming series so far are comedies like “BoJack Horseman,” “Catastrophe” and “Casual.”

headline: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Diverge in Approach to Their Hispanic Identity
text: MIAMI — One candidate, Marco Rubio, nurtured by the sprawling Cuban-American community here, bounces effortlessly between two cultures — fritas and hamburgers, Spanish and English — in a city so comfortably bilingual that news conferences pivot between the languages.

headline: Duets That Reflect the World Offstage
text: Ballet exudes tradition, is surrounded by conservatism and still depends on a small core repertory of 19th-century classics. This century, though, it’s been showing multiple signs of changing its character. Some reforms remain too few: Misty Copeland’s historic ascent to become American Ballet Theater’s first African-American female principal, for example, will dwindle into mere tokenism unless other black ballerinas soon start to make an equal impact. Still, there have been important dances reflecting the racial diversity of the Western world. More generally, ballet has begun to reflect an altered society.

headline: Peter Schickele Brings P.D.Q. Bach Back to the Stage
text: Avid P. D. Q. Bach followers, and there were many, knew the routine cold. The stage was set, the orchestra was ready, the announced time for the concert had arrived. But the star of the evening — its perpetrator and host, Peter Schickele — was nowhere to be found.

headline: Wheaton College Professor Is Put on Leave After Remarks Supporting Muslims
text: Wheaton College, an evangelical Christian institution, has disciplined a professor who put on a head scarf in solidarity with Muslims and said they worship the “same God” as Christians.

headline: Expected Repeal of Oil Export Ban Unlikely to Have Immediate Impact
text: HOUSTON — Ever since the 1970s, when international oil boycotts threatened the American economy and produced around-the-block waiting lines at gasoline stations, a ban on oil exports has been at the heart of national energy policy.

headline: Facebook and Uber Follow Asian Rivals in Plan to Enhance Messenger App
text: For years, Asia’s technology giants have been one step ahead of Western companies in how they treat messaging apps.

headline: Fed Raises Key Interest Rate for First Time in Almost a Decade
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would raise short-term interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis, a decision it described as a vote of confidence in the American economy even as much of the rest of the world struggles.

headline: CNN Says G.O.P. Event Was Third-Highest in Ratings for a Primary Debate
text: More than 18 million people tuned in to CNN to watch the Republican candidates for president on Tuesday, the third-highest viewership in history for a nominating debate, according to Nielsen data provided by the cable network.

headline: Ferguson Nears Deal With Justice Dept. to Overhaul Police Force
text: WASHINGTON — Officials in Ferguson, Mo., have reached the outlines of a deal with the Justice Department that would force changes to the city’s Police Department and head off a civil rights lawsuit alleging years of unconstitutional policing, local and federal officials said.

headline: Streaming TV Isn’t Just a New Way to Watch. It’s a New Genre.
text: At some point during Netflix’s “Sense8” — a gorgeous, ridiculous series about eight strangers scattered across the world who use a psychic connection to aid one another in fights and at one point have a virtual orgy — I had to ask myself: What am I watching?

headline: Los Angeles Schools Reopen With Many Parents on Edge
text: LOS ANGELES — As wary parents dropped their children off at schools here on Wednesday — the day after the entire school system was shuttered by a terrorism threat that turned out to be a hoax — school officials from around the country expressed a good measure of support and very little criticism for the decision by the Los Angeles Unified School District to close all the schools as a precaution.

headline: ‘Memory Theater,’ by Simon Critchley
text: If my dog finds a dead rat in the park, he remembers where he found it for months, if not years. I have no trouble remembering the spot either, perhaps because evolution shaped both my dog’s brain and mine to facilitate hunting, and hunters need to be able to recall the lay of the land and salient objects within it.

headline: Pakistan Surprised to Be Included in Saudi-Led Alliance It Never Heard Of
text: Officials in Pakistan said Wednesday that they had not been consulted by anyone in Saudi Arabia before their nation was described as a founding member of a new, 34-country “Islamic military alliance” to fight terrorism announced late Monday night by the Saudi defense minister.

headline: Europe’s Justice Commissioner Prepares for a Difficult 2016
text: By any standard, Vera Jourova has had a busy year.

headline: The Mutual Fund Equivalent of Bankruptcy
text: The recent decision by the managers of a fund invested mainly in high-yield, or junk, bonds to put their fund into the mutual fund equivalent of bankruptcy reminds us that mutual funds are like banks in an important way. Namely, both banks and mutual funds invest in long-term assets, yet promise short-term liquidity.

headline: Budget Deal Raises Spending, and the Deficit, Through Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional negotiators introduced a sweeping year-end spending and tax-break package Wednesday that bursts through previously agreed budget limits with $66 billion in new spending for 2016. It also makes permanent an array of tax benefits at a cost of adding more than a half-trillion dollars to the deficit.

headline: Ethiopians on Edge as Infrastructure Plan Stirs Protests
text: BURAYU, Ethiopia — There are creeping signs of tension in this small town on the outskirts of Addis Ababa, the capital. Small groups of federal police officers prowl the streets, eyeing taxi stands and coffee shops. On a side road near the town center, a rectangle of black soot and a single burst tire mark the site where a bus recently went up in flames.

headline: Pope Francis, Reminding That Salvation Is Free, Warns Against Fraudsters
text: An estimated 10 million Roman Catholics are expected to pass through the Holy Door, a symbol of the threshold to salvation, during a yearlong celebration dedicated to the theme of mercy.

headline: Qatari Safari Members, Including Royalty, Are Abducted in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Militants in the southern Iraq desert ambushed and abducted at least 26 hunters from a Qatari safari early Wednesday, officials of both countries reported. The kidnapping victims were said to include some members of senior Qatari royalty.

headline: San Bernardino Attackers Discussed Jihad in Private Messages, F.B.I. Says
text: The husband and wife who shot and killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif., this month used private online messages to express their commitment to jihad and to martyrdom in the years before the attack, but they did not make those communications on social media, the director of the F.B.I. said Wednesday.

headline: When it Comes to Terrorism Threat, Republicans and Democrats Go Separate Ways
text: The all-terrorism, all-the-time focus of the Republican debate on Tuesday was not an accident. Democratic and Republican voters give unequal weight to the issue after the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., as revealed in polling this week.

headline: A Machine to Explain Monetary Policy. Why Not?
text: This year, we knew that big Fed news was on the horizon. The economy was going strong and the Fed was hinting that this was the year it was going to raise rates. If it did, it would be a momentous occasion for American monetary policy. The Fed hadn’t raised rates in almost 10 years, and this would signal the beginning of the end of an era of easy money.

headline: Advice for Volkswagen: Being Green Is Profitable
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yoga Teachers Behaving Badly
text: The opening scene of the fictional web series “Namaste, Bitches” starts with some very un-yogic behavior. Sabine, a yoga teacher and recent transplant to Los Angeles, is driving on the freeway and is cursing repeatedly at her GPS while smoking a cigarette — hardly a model of Zen healthy living.

headline: How to Track Data Use, and Choose the Right Smartphone Plan
text: EVERY week, Matt Spaccarelli, the owner of a heating and air-conditioning business in Savannah, Ga., follows a precise routine with his iPhone: He goes into the device settings to check how much cellular data he has used.

headline: For a Shakespeare Anniversary, an Online Re-Creation of a 1796 Show
text: The coming year promises to bring global Shakespeare mania, as the 400th anniversary of his death prompts a cavalcade of performances and exhibitions around the world.

headline: A Critique of Saudi Arabia
text: To the Editor:

headline: Syrian Child Refugees
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Fed’s Interest Rate Move, a Test of the Stock Markets
text: The extraordinarily low interest rates of the last seven years have stoked a bull market in stocks, fueled a global boom in commodities, prompted a wave of corporate mergers and led companies to borrow trillions of dollars in the markets.

headline: Malala Yousafzai, Nobel Winner, Calls Donald Trump’s Remarks on Muslims ‘Full of Hatred’
text: Donald J. Trump’s contentious proposals on Muslims are reverberating around the world. The latest to denounce them is Malala Yousafzai, the youngest winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Classical Playlist: John Scott, Mozart and Ryan Wigglesworth
text: ‘DANCING DAY': Music for ChristmasSt. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys; John Scott, conductor(Resonus Classics)Reminders of the choirmaster and organist John Scott, who died suddenly in August, are all around during the holiday season, a time he and the choir of St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue did so much to enrich for New Yorkers. This year’s annual performances of Handel’s “Messiah” went by, alas, without him. He would have led Benjamin Britten’s “A Ceremony of Carols” and John Rutter’s “Dancing Day” in a concert on Thursday, Dec. 17. (Stephen Buzard, the choir’s acting music director, will conduct instead.) And now comes an album of the Britten and Rutter works and a few other carols, the last of Mr. Scott’s many recordings, bringing tidings of melancholy and joy. The choir sings wonderfully, whether accompanied by Mr. Buzard or Benjamin Sheen on organ, or Sara Cutler on harp. Several of the boy trebles — some of whom by now, as such things go, may well be baritones — have lovely solo moments. Yet another worthy memorial to a beloved figure on the New York music scene. (James R. Oestreich)

headline: Curing Migraines
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Carpet-Bombing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mistrial Declared in Case of Officer Charged in Freddie Gray’s Death
text: BALTIMORE — The trial of the first Baltimore police officer in the death of Freddie Gray ended in a hung jury on Wednesday, an unexpected twist that complicates the cases against five other officers facing charges in a fatal police encounter that prompted violent unrest here last spring.

headline: Raoul’s, a Discreet Celebrity Hangout in SoHo, Turns 40
text: “That was Robert De Niro’s booth, Al Pacino would sit here, Johnny Depp and Kate Moss sat there.”

headline: Women Who Play Games Shun ‘Gamer’ Label
text: Like men, about half of all women play video games. But men are far more likely to call themselves “gamers.”

headline: Yemeni Sides Agree to Prisoner Swap, as Peace Talks Begin in Switzerland
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Warring parties in Yemen agreed on Wednesday to release hundreds of prisoners as the Yemeni government and Houthi rebels sat down for peace talks in Switzerland aimed at ending the country’s nine-month conflict.

headline: App Smart | The Year’s Standouts
text: After checking out thousands of apps, Kit Eaton describes three that he has kept on his home screen: Prune, Pause and Enlight.

headline: Video Feature: Some Favorite Apps of 2015
text: WRITING this feature once a week means I get to experiment with thousands of apps every year. I’ve tested around 3,000 apps in the last 12 months, including apps in new categories like video webcasting and Apple Watch apps, and I’ve seen a surge in short-term vacation rental apps, plus increasingly minimalist graphics across all categories.

headline: A Trio of Art Shows that Inspire Double Takes
text: From quadratura to hyperrealism, artistic movements from the Italian Renaissance onward have recreated reality using trompe l’oeil (literally “deceive the eye”) painting techniques. This winter, a trio of European exhibitions make a strong case for a return to the uncanny valley — this time through sculpture and other three-dimensional forms.

headline: Warren Buffett Endorses Hillary Clinton and Calls for Higher Taxes on Wealthy
text: Hillary Clinton on Wednesday picked up the endorsement of the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, who gave his backing to her while calling for increased taxes on the country’s highest wage earners.

headline: Janet Yellen’s New Hat: Risk Manager
text: Janet Yellen is many things: an economist, a regulator, the chief administrator of a sprawling government agency. Her decision to raise interest rates Wednesday, however, shows her wearing a different hat: risk manager.

headline: A Party Reagan Wouldn’t Recognize
text: During Tuesday night’s Republican debate, a.k.a. DEFCON 1, Republicans portrayed the United States as a tremulous nation cowering before the threat of Islamic terrorism. In a debate about national security, the field of nine candidates used images of war, death, and enemy infiltration to profit politically from ISIS-related attacks in Paris and San Bernardino. Led by Donald Trump, Ted Cruz, and Chris Christie, the fear-mongers projected an image of a diminished America that is grotesquely at odds with the way Americans have historically viewed themselves.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Beard Triggers a Style Debate
text: In political circles, it was the equivalent of “Dylan goes electric” — or at least “Rose McGowan goes bald.”

headline: Fed Follies
text: No, I don’t mean the decision to raise rates, although nothing I’ve seen changes my view that it’s a bad idea. I mean the desperate efforts to say something new about today’s move. I understand that there are strong journalistic incentives here, but it really is trying to squeeze blood from a stone.

headline: Portuguese Migrants Struggle to Find Relief in Angola
text: When Portugal’s economy hit the skids, it sparked a return migration to Angola, its oil-rich former colony. This time, the Europeans are in the subservient role.

headline: Gigi Hadid and Tommy Hilfiger Join Forces on a Collection
text: A designer eager to be talked about can typically do one of three things. The first is to anticipate the cultural climate and hit upon something consumers want before they know they want it. The second is to manufacture a controversy. And the third is to mine the spirit and feed off it, often by aligning him or herself with a current celebrity phenomenon.

headline: Broadway Is Getting Another Theater, Its 41st
text: A British theater magnate has acquired a long-term lease to the Hudson Theater, on West 44th Street, just east of Broadway, owned by Millennium Hotels and Resorts.

headline: Huge Beer Merger’s Cast-Offs Could Attract a Private Buyer
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev has barely concluded its $106 billion deal to buy SABMiller and now is planning its next deal: a sale of Peroni and Grolsch, which it will acquire in the SAB deal. SAB’s dregs might attract a rival, but a private buyer may find those brands more to its taste.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Long Goodbye
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Last week, about an hour before the Los Angeles Lakers were to face the Timberwolves here at Target Center, Gary Vitti leaned against a wall outside the visitors’ locker room and exhaled. Vitti has been the Lakers’ athletic trainer for 32 seasons, but he has other responsibilities, too. He fields ticket requests. He helps manage the schedule.

headline: Steven Spielberg and DreamWorks Studios in Deal to Form New Company
text: LOS ANGELES — Steven Spielberg said on Wednesday that he and his DreamWorks Studios would join Participant Media, Reliance Entertainment and Entertainment One to form an entertainment company called Amblin Partners to produce movies, television shows and digital content.

headline: Review: Casey Schwartz’s ‘In the Mind Fields’ Considers the Brain, on the Couch and in the Lab
text: Neuroscience and psychoanalysis are not on particularly good speaking terms at the moment. One is glamorous and cutting edge, attracting all the pretty research grants; the other is old and unfashionable, redolent of Oriental rugs and vanquished by Lexapro. One expresses itself in numbers; the other in words. One strives for predictability and order; the other embraces ambiguities, chaos, mess.

headline: A Place to Learn
text: A friend tells the story of a great meatloaf recipe a woman gave her, passed down from the woman’s own mother. It made two small loaves, baked separately. One day this woman served it to her mother, who was visiting. The mother asked why on earth she made meatloaf in two pans. “Because that’s how you always did it!” the daughter answered. “I was following your recipe.” The mother explained that she did it that way only because the family had moved into an apartment with a smaller oven, and her old baking pan no longer fit.

headline: ‘Peace Reigns’ in Spain as Prado and a New Museum Settle Dispute
text: The Prado museum has settled a long-simmering duel with a new royal museum in Madrid over the rights to its most famous paintings, including “The Garden of Earthly Delights” by Hieronymus Bosch and the 15th-century depiction of the descent of Christ from the cross by Rogier van der Weyden.

headline: In 2015, European Union Faced Threats From Outside and Within
text: The leaders of the European Union’s 28 member states will gather on Thursday in Brussels for their eighth and final summit meeting of 2015. Issues that dominated their agenda at the start of the year have grown more urgent, threatening to undo decades of progress to foster closer ties, more open borders and tighter economic integration.

headline: A Debate Focused on National Security
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Reed Krakoff Decorates a Room
text: “It was kind of a puzzle from the beginning, just bringing all of these things together to create some interesting relationships and interesting ideas,” says the fashion designer Reed Krakoff who, along with his wife, the interior designer Delphine Krakoff, curated “Alchemy: Art x Design,” a part of Sotheby’s Important Design auction, whose items go on sale today.

headline: Love for Sale: The Shopgirl Has a Pop Cultural Moment
text: In the 1939 George Cukor classic, “The Women,” Crystal Allen is the ultimate spritzer girl. A perfume vendor by any other name, as portrayed by Joan Crawford she’s a mantrap in a black sheath and pearls, as fetching a commodity as the amber-tinted potions that she sells.

headline: How Many Scripted TV Shows in 2015? A Precise Number, and a Record
text: There is finally a definitive answer for the number of shows on television, in a year in which television executives have debated whether the industry has reached “Peak TV.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Paraguay and Elsewhere
text: Paraguay and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Girl, 16, Attacked by Man With Box Cutter in Queens
text: An assailant wearing medical garb and wielding a box cutter attacked a 16-year-old girl who was walking to school in Queens on Wednesday morning, the police said.

headline: Trade War Escalates Between Russia and Ukraine
text: MOSCOW — Ukraine and Russia on Wednesday escalated their trade war after a series of energy and air travel disruptions.

headline: Bartolo Colon and Mets Said to Agree on One-Year Deal
text: Bartolo Colon, who has become a favorite of Mets fans’ for his astonishing success on the mound and at the plate, will return next year.

headline: At U.N., China Tries to Influence Fight Over Internet Control
text: Over the last six months, United Nations diplomats have negotiated over the text of a document set to define the policies and frameworks of how the Internet is governed in the future, and who has a role in the process.

headline: Dec. 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Paraguay, Kenya, Greece and Belgium.

headline: Military Operation With Mouse Ears: Inside the ‘Star Wars’ Premiere
text: I was fortunate enough to attend the world premiere of this little film you may have heard of — “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”

headline: Ted Cruz’s Call to ‘Carpet-Bomb’ the Islamic State Draws Scrutiny
text: Earlier this season in the hit Showtime series “Homeland,” Peter Quinn, the elite black-ops C.I.A. agent, briefed a room full of top spies and military officials on what could be done to make a difference in the fight against the Islamic State.

headline: Jerusalem Attacks Subside, but Not Palestinian Ire, as Israel Clamps Down
text: JERUSALEM — When the latest Palestinian uprising erupted in early October, set off by increasing fears that Israel was seeking to take over Al Aqsa Mosque compound, its locus was Jerusalem. The city was also home to the young men and women who carried out the attacks, stabbing, shooting and trying to hit Israelis with their cars.

headline: Teen Marijuana Use Holds Steady Despite Legalization
text: People who oppose the legalization of marijuana argue that changing the law will encourage more teenagers to try the drug and will lead them to more dangerous substances like heroin, ecstasy and amphetamines. But a new study provides fresh evidence that contradicts both of those assertions.

headline: Making Porcelain Replicas of Sticks
text: The forager-artist Katie Ridley Murphy shares her process.

headline: Italian Men’s Tailoring That Screams ‘Sexy’
text: Now that what was once a radical movement is just simple marketing, it’s safe to admit that #menswear — the early-2010s Tumblr-driven spread of male sartorial aspiration — was always a boy’s game.

headline: The Chicest Sticks
text: Long before the forager-artist Katie Ridley Murphy began sculpting sticks from porcelain, she sketched them from her own Atlanta backyard — and sold the resultant works as original drawings and prints. And each piece, regardless of the medium, was modeled after a real stick she found in nature.

headline: Nicki Minaj Concert in Angola Draws Human Rights Complaint
text: The Human Rights Foundation is asking Nicki Minaj to reconsider her scheduled performance in Angola on Saturday, citing a list of abuses committed by the president of the oil-rich African nation.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell Hands Out Book Blurbs Like Santa Does Presents
text: When Malcolm Gladwell was asked to write a blurb for the 2005 book “Freakonomics, ” he did not explain that it explored the dynamics of the Ku Klux Klan or the impact of naming a child “Loser.” Instead, the New Yorker writer and best-selling author of “The Tipping Point” and “Blink” simply wrote, “Prepare to be dazzled.”

headline: 3 Men Imprisoned in 1980 Brooklyn Arson Case Are Exonerated
text: Three men were cleared on Wednesday of setting a 1980 fire in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that caused the death of a mother and her five children, after the sole eyewitness was deemed unreliable and new understanding of the evidence fires leave behind was applied.

headline: Scent Without a Sex
text: For a new generation of consumers, the traditional notion of gendered fragrances is starting to go a little stale. The days when floral notes were exclusively for women and musks were solely for men are all but gone, and mass-market brands that peddle colognes and perfumes are starting to catch on.

headline: California D.M.V. Stops Short of Fully Embracing Driverless Cars
text: SAN FRANCISCO — California is not quite ready to let self-driving cars hit the road on their own.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Doesn’t Want Jeb Bush’s Endorsement Anyway
text: Donald J. Trump responded with a familiar refrain to reports that Jeb Bush’s aides had researched the legal implications of saying that Mr. Bush wouldn’t support the real estate developer should he become the Republican nominee.

headline: Review: Jane Glover Conducts the New York Philharmonic in ‘Messiah’
text: Some conductors, determined to bring a jolt of freshness to Handel’s “Messiah,” opt for bracing tempos and extra incisive execution. Not Jane Glover, the respected British conductor, in a long-overdue debut with the New York Philharmonic on Tuesday night at David Geffen Hall. Using no conductor’s stand, no score and no baton, Ms. Glover led a flowing, elegant and subtle “Messiah.”

headline: Lovers Rock, a Reggae Bar in Bedford-Stuyvesant
text: A great new neighborhood bar slides in seamlessly, filling a hole without unraveling the local fabric. Lovers Rock, a mellow reggae-themed bar that opened in Bedford-Stuyvesant over the summer, is this rare kind of place.

headline: Review: ‘Making a Murderer,’ True Crime on Netflix
text: “Making a Murderer” fairly bursts at the seams. You get the feeling that the filmmakers Laura Ricciardi and Moira Demos, after spending 10 years working on it, couldn’t bear to part with a single jailhouse phone call or videotaped interrogation. Their documentary’s 10 episodes, which will be available on Netflix on Friday, often push past an hour, clocking in at 64 or 66 minutes. If you’re planning to binge, clear some extra time.

headline: Review: Cage the Elephant’s ‘Tell Me I’m Pretty’ Edges Toward Darkness
text: “Tell Me I’m Pretty”

headline: Review: ‘Code Red’ Is Monica at a Turning Point
text: “Code Red”

headline: Holiday Pop-Ups Multiply, and Other Shopping Events
text: As many of us get set to travel, holiday pop-ups continue apace. From Thursday to Saturday, Tatiana Santo Domingo and Dana Alikhani will have a pop-up for Muzungu Sisters, their ethical luxury-fashion website that sells products sourced from local artisans around the world. A beaded coin necklace ($225) and Sicilian basket with pompoms ($413) are among the goodies available. At 402 West 13th Street.

headline: Judge Is Eager to Move the FIFA Case to Trial
text: As United States prosecutors delivered updates on Wednesday in their unfolding corruption case against global soccer officials and business executives, a federal judge expressed eagerness to move the case toward trial.

headline: Review: Willow Smith’s ‘Ardipithecus,’ Teen-Speak on Astral Planes
text: “Ardipithecus”

headline: Older Actors Are Having an Awards Season Moment
text: Most actors would yip with joy if an Oscar-winning director were to ring them up offering a starring role. But not Michael Caine, whose first thought — so he said — when he found himself in that very spot last year was that the director, Paolo Sorrentino, had gone a bit barmy.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Republicans, ‘Star Wars,’ Congress
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: In the Kitchen with Barbara Lynch
text: Barbara Lynch is a gritty Boston restaurateur whose home kitchen is the height of industrial chic.

headline: Musicians Redefine Long Play in 2015
text: This was a year of muchness.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: A Quick Look at the Fed’s Interest Rate Increase
text: The move is seen as a vote of confidence in the American economy’s recovery since the financial crisis. What does it mean for consumers and the markets?

headline: Chokers, the Wrap Coat and Bold Stripes
text: Accessories with a hint of kink, a relaxed robe coat looks refined over everything and chromatic stripes.

headline: Bernie Sanders Warns of Demagogues and Division in Mosque Visit
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont joined members of three faiths – Christianity, Islam and Judaism – around a table at the Masjid Muhammad mosque in Washington on Wednesday to discuss racial and religious tensions in national politics and the national mood.

headline: Review: ‘The Creation of Meaning’ Views an Economically Torn Italy in Echoes of Earlier Days
text: Shot in the Tuscan Alps, the documentary-fiction hybrid “The Creation of Meaning” moves between suspending us in timeless nature and listening to the echoes of the past. A mountainside farmer, Pacifico Pieruccioni, clad in shorts, is one of the last men standing (for a few miles, at least) in an area wracked by Italy’s economic dysfunction and still touched by the memories of the Germans in World War II. The setting is an idyll fading before our eyes (with a bit of secret).

headline: Donald Trump Finds a Receptive Audience in Arizona
text: MESA, Ariz. — The Boeing 757-200 taxied outside a private airport hangar here on Wednesday to thunderous cheers, as well as boisterous chants of “We love you, Mr. Trump” by three men in cowboy hats. The hangar’s owners had lent the space to Donald J. Trump, the billionaire running for president, an easy in-and-out arrangement the day after the last Republican debate of the year, in Las Vegas, a short flight away.

headline: Mariano Rajoy, Spanish Prime Minister, Punched in Face by Teenager
text: A young man punched Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain in the face during a campaign event on Wednesday, leaving the stunned leader with broken glasses and bruises.

headline: Belgium Says Law Limiting Raids May Have Allowed Suspect in Paris Attacks to Escape
text: PARIS — The authorities in Belgium said on Wednesday that one of the Paris attackers may have been holed up in a house in Brussels two nights after 130 people were killed and hundreds more injured — but that he could have escaped because of a law banning police raids on private homes from 9 p.m. to 5 a.m., according to the country’s justice minister.

headline: How I Escaped Vietnam
text: The images accompanying this article are a combination of drawings from memory and the new artwork based on our recent trip back to my homeland.

headline: Fact-Checking Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio on Immigration
text: The two Hispanic senators in the Republican presidential race — Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida — battled over immigration in the debate on Tuesday, competing to show who is tougher on border security. Mr. Rubio is vulnerable with conservatives on the divisive issue because of a bill he sponsored in 2013 that would have given people in the country illegally a pathway to citizenship.

headline: The Dizzying Circular Logic of Donald Trump
text: Shortly before Tuesday night’s Republican debate, Showtime announced it would be starting a new political documentary series in January called “The Circus.” The creation of the Republican media consultant Mark McKinnon and the Bloomberg political journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, the show will chronicle the presidential campaign as it unfolds behind the scenes. It is the latest event horizon in the history of campaigns being covered as reality-show entertainment pieces — the next logical look into the fun-house mirror of our meta-driven political culture.

headline: Virginia to Replace Guardrails With Others Deemed Safer
text: Virginia has decided to begin replacing certain roadside guardrails, including some made by Trinity Industries, a company that has been accused of making a defective rail.

headline: Panthers Coach Ron Rivera Praises Giants and Odell Beckham Jr.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Carolina Panthers Coach Ron Rivera, whose team is 13-0, spent several minutes Wednesday in a conference call heaping praise on the 6-7 Giants. Most notably, Rivera compared wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. to Jerry Rice, widely considered the greatest receiver in N.F.L. history.

headline: Tampa Bay Buccaneers (6-7) at St. Louis Rams (5-8)
text: 8:25 p.m., NFL Network

headline: Argentina Set to Devalue Its Currency
text: BUENOS AIRES — Argentines were bracing themselves for a substantial devaluation of their currency, the peso, as the new president, Mauricio Macri, rushed to execute sweeping market-oriented changes intended to revive an ailing economy.

headline: Streaming Royalties Rise, but Not as High as Music Industry Wanted
text: A panel of federal judges on Wednesday increased the royalty that free Internet radio services like Pandora will pay record companies for the next five years, a decision that has been closely watched in the music industry and on Wall Street.

headline: Literary Group Asks Obama to Intercede for Condemned Writers in Saudi Arabia
text: A petition from dozens of authors was sent to President Obama on Wednesday asking him to press Saudi Arabia to pardon a prominent poet condemned to beheading and a blogger punished with prison and flogging.

headline: In Likely Spending Plan, Congress Readies Blows to Obama’s Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — In a big package of tax and spending legislation that Congress is likely to approve this week, Republicans have forced President Obama to swallow three changes that undermine his signature health care law, including a two-year delay of a tax on high-cost insurance plans provided by employers to workers.

headline: Governor of Puerto Rico Warns of Looming Default Without Bankruptcy Plan
text: The governor of Puerto Rico redoubled threats on Wednesday of a major bond default, as an effort to help the struggling commonwealth use bankruptcy to shed debt headed for defeat in Congress.

headline: Chattanooga Attack Victims to Be Awarded Purple Hearts
text: Five months after the shooting rampage last summer at two Navy facilities in Tennessee, five service members who were killed and one survivor will be awarded Purple Heart medals, the military said on Wednesday.

headline: Strike Tests Kohler, Wis., and the Company Sharing Its Name
text: KOHLER, Wis. — Highland Drive unfurls like a ribbon through this photogenic village near Lake Michigan. One side of the street is a tableau of leisure: a Tudor-style luxury resort, a spa, shops and a four-star, jackets-required restaurant that serves venison loin and foie gras.

headline: Junk Bond Fund That Barred Investors Reaches S.E.C. Deal
text: Third Avenue Management reached an agreement with its regulator on Wednesday over its abrupt move last week to bar investors in a stricken bond fund from taking their money out.

headline: Year After Cuba-U.S. Thaw, Obama Says Change Will Take Time
text: WASHINGTON — As the anniversary neared of President Obama’s announcement of a historic détente with Cuba, Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen of Florida, who was born in Havana and fled with her family to Miami decades ago, gave him a reality check. The policy change had done little to improve life for the Cuban people, she told the president at the White House last week, and had actually made their human rights situation worse.

headline: Dave Duerson’s Family Says ‘Concussion’ Film Smears Him
text: In Will Smith’s new movie, “Concussion,” the former N.F.L. player Dave Duerson confronts the film’s protagonist, the pathologist Bennet Omalu, whose findings of chronic traumatic encephalopathy in pro football players shook the league. Duerson blocks the Nigerian-born Omalu from entering a medical conference, calls him a quack, and tells him to go back to Africa and to “get away from our game.”

headline: Sheldon Adelson Said to Be Buyer of Las Vegas Review-Journal
text: The billionaire casino magnate and Republican donor Sheldon Adelson is behind the mysterious purchase of The Las Vegas Review-Journal for $140 million, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity.

headline: Transfers Could Reduce Guantánamo Detainees to 90
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration appears to be on the cusp of the largest round of transfers of Guantánamo Bay detainees in a single month since 2007, a move that could reduce the detainee population there to as low as 90 by mid- to late January, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Syrian Families Look Through Photos of the Dead for Relatives Lost in Government Custody
text: While the spotlight of international attention remains firmly fixed on the brutalities of Islamic State militants in Syria, the families of thousands of Syrians who vanished into government detention facilities after protesters first took to the streets in 2011 have been confronted with graphic evidence of what President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces are capable of.

headline: G.E. Expects Growth in Its Earnings in an Uncertain 2016
text: General Electric, the nation’s largest industrial company, expects next year to be one of economic uncertainty, geopolitical turmoil and slow growth.

headline: Metro-North Crash Inquiry Delves Into Behavior of Woman Killed on Tracks
text: As federal investigators have sought to determine what led to a fatal crash on the Metro-North Railroad this past winter, they have focused considerable attention on understanding the actions of the woman whose sport utility vehicle was struck by the train and who was killed, along with five passengers aboard the train.

headline: Defense Secretary Conducted Some Official Business on a Personal Email Account
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter relied on a personal email account to conduct a portion of his government business during his first months at the Pentagon, according to White House and Defense Department officials and copies of Mr. Carter’s emails obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Walter J. Leonard, Pioneer of Affirmative Action in Harvard Admissions, Dies at 86
text: Walter J. Leonard, the chief architect of an admissions process at Harvard that has been emulated across the United States, opening colleges and universities to more women and minorities, died on Dec. 8 in Kensington, Md. He was 86.

headline: Venezuela May Have Indirectly Aided U.S. Inquiry of Official
text: For five long years, American investigators have suspected that Néstor Reverol, the former head of Venezuela’s antidrug unit, was working as a kind of double agent.

headline: Alfred C. Snider, Who Promoted Healthy Debate as Just That, Dies at 65
text: Alfred C. Snider, a scholar, rhetorician and evangelist who sought to heal the world through debate — and who in the process turned bucolic Vermont into the argumentative center of the world — died Friday in Burlington, Vt. He was 65.

headline: Direct Flights to Cuba and Other Rule Changes Explained
text: Nearly a year after the United States announced it would be loosening travel restrictions to Cuba, the two countries have reached an agreement on regularly scheduled commercial flights to the island, the Associated Press has reported. Coupled with the previous rule changes for travelers, commercial flights to the island from the United States would make it possible for practically anyone who wishes to visit Cuba to do so. Here is what you need to know before you go:

headline: Officers May Face Discipline in Overlooked Killing of Brooklyn Woman
text: The New York Police Department said on Wednesday that officers might face discipline after they failed to realize that an 82-year-old Brooklyn woman had been killed.

headline: U.N. Council to Adopt Sanctions Against ISIS
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United States and Russia have joined forces to draft a legally binding Security Council resolution to strengthen sanctions against those who do business with terrorist groups, chiefly the Islamic State.

headline: Success Academy Schools, in Shortening Their Day, Shed a Distinction
text: Among the things that set the Success Academy charter schools apart from public schools is the length of the school day: eight hours 45 minutes for elementary students, nine hours 15 minutes for middle schoolers.

headline: California Rebukes Rural Prison for Racism
text: Guards at a rural California prison use other prisoners’ possessions to reward inmates who assault each other, discriminate against black and Latino inmates, and routinely engage in unnecessary force, according to a California inspector general report released Wednesday.

headline: First to Break the Tape
text: Administrivial Updated “Re-Set My Streak Please” Alert! If you solved the Thursday, December 17 puzzle by David Kwong and were marked incorrect as a result of the late error caught last night, please go to our main Puzzle Page on the web and finish the puzzle in order to have your streak re-set. I’m told that you must be logged into your nytimes.com account and complete the puzzle in order for our team to be able to re-set streaks.

headline: Judge Faults Firm’s Failure to Keep Notes in Christie Bridge Investigation
text: A federal judge on Wednesday harshly criticized the internal investigation that cleared Gov. Chris Christie of any wrongdoing in the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal, saying it was a “calculated strategy” of “opacity and gamesmanship” rather than the thorough and transparent inquiry that the governor promised.

headline: Deportation of Former Salvadoran Official Is Upheld
text: An immigration appeals court has upheld an immigration judge’s deportation order against a former defense minister of El Salvador, Gen. José Guillermo García, based on his role assisting in the 1980 murders of four American churchwomen and other human rights crimes in that country, according to the Center for Justice and Accountability, which helped bring the case against the general. In his 2014 order, Judge Michael C. Horn found that torture and killings of government opponents were “deliberate military policy” during three years in the early 1980s when General García, a close ally of the United States, led the military. In April another defense minister from that period, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, was deported to El Salvador on similar grounds.

headline: Repaired King Tut Mask Back on Display in Egypt
text: The gold funeral mask of King Tutankhamen has been returned to its home in the Egyptian Museum after eight weeks of delicate surgery to undo damage caused by a botched procedure last year to reattach the boy king’s blue-and-gold braided beard to his face, the country’s Ministry of Antiquities said in a statement.

headline: Officials Say Boy, 2, Who Died in March Was a Homicide Victim
text: Nearly nine months after a 2-year-old boy was found unconscious in his family’s East Harlem apartment, the police said on Wednesday that his death was now being investigated as a homicide, after a lengthy review by the medical examiner.

headline: Millions of Babies at Risk, Unicef Says
text: Nearly 16.6 million babies were born in conflict zones this year, Unicef said Wednesday. Its report said newborns and mothers faced particularly acute risks in Afghanistan, the Central African Republic, Iraq, South Sudan and Syria. “Every two seconds, a newborn takes its first breath in the midst of conflict, often in terrifying circumstances and without access to medical care,” said Anthony Lake, Unicef’s executive director.

headline: Mexico: U.S. Penalizes Newspaper Executive
text: The United States Department of the Treasury said Wednesday that the vice president of a Mexico City newspaper, Unomásuno, had used the publication to support a drug trafficking gang. The executive, Naim Libien Tella, has had a long relationship with the leader of the gang, Abigael González Valencia, who was arrested in February, according to the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control. The Treasury designated Mr. Libien Tella and several businesses connected to him, including Unomásuno, as drug traffickers, barring American citizens from doing business with them.

headline: Judge Lets Cooper Union Levy Tuition in Short Term
text: A state judge approved a settlement on Wednesday that ends a bitter legal battle over tuition at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, allowing the college to charge students in the short run while developing a plan for returning to its traditional tuition-free model.

headline: Knicks Build Big Lead Before a Tired Team Nearly Lulls Them Into a Loss
text: Hours removed from playing what Coach Sam Mitchell described as their worst game of the season, the Minnesota Timberwolves arrived in New York on Wednesday at 2:30 a.m. Mitchell thought that fatigue might be a factor in his team’s game against the Knicks that night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Harassed in Guinea, Homeless in New York and Happy to Be Together
text: When a friend of Mariama Koulibaley’s told her about a man who had just graduated from a university in their native Guinea though legally blind and deaf, she was intrigued.

headline: New York Officials Defend Affordable Housing Plan to Divided Audience
text: Officials with Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration, facing the biggest public forum yet on their affordable housing strategy, defended the plan before a packed hearing on Wednesday, saying it is a “game changer.”

headline: Wi-Fi, A.T.M.s and Turbo-Flush Toilets Highlight China’s New Public Restrooms
text: BEIJING — Li Wen had heard about the turbo-strength flush power and the lily-scented soap. He knew about the stalls equipped with personal television screens and wireless Internet access, the soothing cello soundtrack and the windows lined with aloe vera plants.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I was locked up in a cage and forgotten. You don’t hear any other voices, you speak out loud just to hear yourself. You forget what it’s like to be human.”

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: He’s back: D.C.I. John Luther pulls on his tweed coat once again, and all is right with the world. Sheldon and Amy — finally! — spend the night together. And President Obama battles the elements with Bear Grylls in Alaska.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | fecundity
text: fecundity • \fi-ˈkən-də-te, fe-\ • noun

headline: How Does Air Pollution Affect Your Daily Life?
text: The New York Times would like to hear from residents living in countries seriously affected by air pollution.

headline: 모든 계절에 어울리는 음료, 스타우트
text: 아주 오래전 술을 갓 입에 대기 시작할 때부터 저는 흑맥주, 즉 포터[와 스타우트]야말로 저를 위한 음료란 걸 느꼈습니다. 흑맥주는 흡사 제가 바라보는 저 자신과도 같은 음료로서, 투박하지만 믿음직하고, 부정할 수 없이 어둡죠.

headline: Corrections: December 17, 2015
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Selects N.W.A and Cheap Trick for Class of 2016
text: Cheap Trick, N.W.A, Chicago, Steve Miller and Deep Purple will join the pantheon of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame at its 31st induction ceremony at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on April 8.

headline: Use by Iraqi Military May Be a Boon for China-Made Drones
text: HONG KONG — After more than a decade of fighting in Iraq, the names of the American-made drones striking targets there have become familiar: Predator, Reaper, Sentinel.

headline: A New Budget for a New Year
text: The $1.1 trillion spending bill for the 2016 fiscal year, agreed to by congressional leaders on Tuesday night, is good for what it does not contain.

headline: Fear, Loathing and Republican Debaters
text: Well, the big Republican presidential debate is over and the message is clear: Be afraid. Be very afraid.

headline: An Appalling Silence on Gun Control
text: It was remarkable that the Republican presidential candidates’ debate this week, supposedly focused on keeping Americans safe, was devoid of questions and comments about the public health issue of gun violence.

headline: The G.O.P. at a Crossroads
text: A long time ago, in the era we now know as B.T. (Before Trump), it was possible to envision a Republican primary campaign that would be a real contest of ideas, a clash of genuine policy visions — and therefore different from the empty I’m-not-Obama, no I’m-not-Obama contest of 2012. My favored scenario would have pitted Marco Rubio against Rand Paul: The former representing a reform-minded conservatism in domestic policy and a hawkish internationalism abroad; the latter representing a more libertarian domestic agenda and a noninterventionist posture overseas.

headline: Toward a Stronger European Border
text: More so even than the euro crisis, the refugee crisis and the threat of terrorism have raised fundamental questions about how much sovereignty European states are prepared to cede for the sake of greater unity and security.

headline: Brazil’s Toxic Sludge
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — JUST after 4 p.m. on Nov. 5, the principal’s husband ran into the school in the village of Bento Rodrigues, in southeastern Brazil, yelling that the nearby dam had burst and everybody needed to get out of the schoolhouse. Teachers and employees herded about 50 children into buses and cars. Some followed on foot. Minutes later, as the caravan made its way uphill, they saw a 32-foot-tall wave of mud sweeping over their school.

headline: Looking for the Perfect Gift? Social Science Can Help
text: ARE you in a panic, not sure what to get that special someone this year? Fear not, because my fellow social scientists have the answer for you.

headline: Republican Insecurity
text: I watched, with disenchantment and disquiet, Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate in Las Vegas, as candidate after candidate talked about how he or she would execute a war against the Islamic State, as if such a war was inevitable, if not already underway.

headline: My ‘Nutcracker’ Recovery
text: It’s “Nutcracker” season. Not again, I think. I am a recovering ballerina. I never danced professionally, but I did dream of it. I spent a lot of my childhood and early adolescence changing in and out of tights and leotards in dusty dressing rooms at various New York studios. I carried an oversize LeSportsac bag packed with balled-up tights, stray bobby pins, pointe shoes and even a special flammable shellac for hardening their tips.

headline: The ‘Benefits’ of Black Physics Students
text: LAST week during oral arguments in Fisher v. University of Texas, a case about the constitutionality of race-conscious admissions policies, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. posed two questions: “What unique perspective does a minority student bring to a physics class?” Followed by: “I’m just wondering what the benefits of diversity are in that situation?”

headline: Full N.C.I.S. Investigative Report
text: The New York Times obtained the Naval Criminal Investigative Service report on the detainee abuse episode in Kalach through the Freedom of Information Act. The full document is 129 pages; the following 115 pages do not include photographic exhibits. The report was redacted by the United States Navy. In nearly all cases, the redactions are of the names of American service members.

headline: Soldiers Report Abuse by Navy SEALs
text: Four soldiers stationed at an isolated outpost told investigators that they had witnessed members of a Navy SEAL team mistreating Afghan detainees.

headline: Navy Witnesses Play Down Events
text: Six Navy service members gave their version of the events that led to the criminal inquiry.

headline: The Interpreter’s View
text: An interpreter for the SEAL unit expanded on his initial account, as evidenced by an interview and written statement in the Naval Criminal Investigative Service report.

headline: Local Afghan Witnesses’ Testimony
text: The Afghan Local Police brought four locals to give sworn statements to investigators.

headline: Navy SEAL Captain Closes the Case
text: A letter from the East Coast SEAL command informed investigators that the charges had been dismissed.

headline: How a Quiet Corner of Iowa Packs Such a Fierce Conservative Punch
text: ORANGE CITY, Iowa — A century of assimilation has blurred European ethnic heritage in much of the United States, but here in the far northwestern corner of Iowa, people still joke, “You’re not mutch if you’re not Dutch.”

headline: Navy SEALs, a Beating Death and Claims of a Cover-Up
text: The three Navy SEALs stomped on the bound Afghan detainees and dropped heavy stones on their chests, the witnesses recalled. They stood on the prisoners’ heads and poured bottles of water on some of their faces in what, to a pair of Army soldiers, appeared to be an improvised form of waterboarding.

headline: A Guide to the N.C.I.S. Investigative Report
text: The findings of the Naval Criminal Investigative Service inquiry into the detainee-abuse case are included in a report, which was redacted by the United States Navy. In nearly all cases, the redactions are of the names of American service members. Links to excerpts from the report appear below.

headline: Vladimir Putin Chides Turkey, Praises Trump and Talks Up Russia’s Economy
text: MOSCOW — With his customary swagger and salty language, President Vladimir V. Putin held forth on a sweeping array of topics in his traditional year-end news conference on Thursday, even throwing in a glowing assessment of Donald J. Trump.

headline: News Q’s | Fed Raises Key Interest Rate for First Time in Almost a Decade
text: Before Reading ‘Fed Raises Key Interest Rate for First Time in Almost a Decade’:

headline: AstraZeneca to Acquire Majority Stake in Acerta Pharma
text: LONDON — The British drug maker AstraZeneca said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in Acerta Pharma, a privately-held cancer drug developer with operations in the Netherlands and in California, for $4 billion.

headline: A Missed Opportunity of Ultra-Cheap Money
text: Years of ultralow interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve may have breathed life back into the economy and buoyed Wall Street. But they have not managed to solve problems like the aging Portal Bridge.

headline: The New Attack on Hispanic Voting Rights
text: In September 2000, Oscar Del Toro of Monterrey, Mexico, arrived with his wife and three children at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston to start a new life in the United States. Del Toro, then 38, had spent his whole life in Mexico. His mother and father were naturalized American citizens who lived near Houston and had wanted to bring him to the United States with them. But because he was already an adult, with a wife and a child, he was subject to a long waiting period for a green card. He went on with his life in Mexico, building a business selling laser printers and buying a comfortable four-bedroom house. He had more or less forgotten all about the prospect of moving to the United States when, around Christmas in 1999, his mother told him she had a present for him: an Immigration and Naturalization Service letter inviting him and his family to apply for permanent residency.

headline: New York Prisons Take an Unsavory Punishment Off the Table
text: ALBANY — Of all the punishments meted out upon prisoners in solitary confinement, the most unsavory may well be a misshapen one-pound brick of cuisine.

headline: Lanvin and Alber Elbaz: The Story of a Breakup
text: Even in a world inured to designer change, no one expected this.

headline: Portuguese Migrants Struggle to Find Relief in Angola
text: The Portuguese began migrating to Angola by the tens of thousands, this time around, when Portugal’s economy bottomed out in 2010, while Angola’s, fueled by oil exports, gushed tons of cash. Just two years later, the Angolan government announced it was building a detention center to hold the flood of migrants entering the country illegally. Joan Bardeletti, a French freelance photographer who focuses on documenting the changing dynamics of urban life across Africa, knew the time had come to visit the southwest coast and check out Angola’s new settlers.

headline: What Kind of Tourist Are You?
text: How do you behave when you travel?

headline: When Runners Go the Distance, but Races Don’t
text: When we hear about a road-race shortcut, many of us think of Rosie Ruiz, who notoriously cut into the final mile of the 1980 Boston Marathon to win the women’s title. But sometimes a racecourse is inadvertently shortened by human error — a misplaced traffic cone, say, or a confused but well-intentioned volunteer.

headline: Morning Agenda:  Janet Yellen’s New Risk Manager Role
text: JANET YELLEN’S NEW RISK MANAGER ROLE | The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the first time in almost a decade yesterday, a move that was both widely anticipated yet closely scrutinized, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

headline: Wines of Niagara
text: There is more to this diverse wine region than ice wine.

headline: Exploring Canada’s Fertile Niagara Wine Region
text: JORDAN, Ontario — Wine country on the Niagara Peninsula of Ontario, Canada, may sound a little incongruous. But the area about a half-hour west of Buffalo is home to a wine region of depth, diversity and distinction.

headline: Poll Watch: Americans Fear More Terrorist Attacks but Have Mixed Views on Gun Control
text: Most Americans describe themselves as very concerned about the threat of attacks from terrorists, but considerably fewer worry about a mass shooting taking place in the area where they live, according to the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll.
