headline: Court Acquits Journalist Accused of Defaming South Korean President
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A Seoul court found a Japanese reporter not guilty on Thursday of defaming President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, whose government has been accused of using legal channels to try to silence news reports unfavorable to her administration.

headline: Spending Bill to Block Limits on Outside Political Groups
text: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, has failed in his high-profile push to include a change in congressional campaign spending rules in the new budget bill that lawmakers are set to consider on Friday. But to the dismay of campaign watchdogs, the 2,000-page omnibus spending measure would block other significant efforts to force more disclosure of contributors and to limit increasing political activity by nonprofit organizations.

headline: Ask Well: Blood Pressure Over Age 70
text: Question:

headline: Ted Cruz Begins a Post-Surge, Super Tuesday Tour
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, buoyed by a steady debate performance and a slew of encouraging polls recently in Iowa and beyond, is beginning a seven-day, 12-city, general-election-style tour on Thursday of the so-called Super Tuesday states.

headline: Test Your ‘Star Wars’ Knowledge
text: Before you see “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” try your hand at this quiz about the cultural and marketing juggernaut the franchise has become.

headline: Early Detection of Ovarian Cancer May Become Possible
text: A new version of a screening test for ovarian cancer may reduce deaths from the disease, but it needs more study to determine whether the benefits hold up, researchers reported on Thursday.

headline: Jackson Galaxy Thinks Cats Saved His Life
text: Do you think that the popularity of cats online has had an effect on cats? Do they realize we’ve come back to worshiping them? I was on the scene back when cats were pariahs, and now that they’re like the Egyptian goddess once again, man, I am not looking that gift horse in the mouth. It’s an amazing time; it’s a renaissance for cats. Lil Bub could run for president right now, and she might have a better chance than Donald Trump. I’m all for it.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Joke Dollar
text: Around 10 years ago, on an evening about town, a friend of mine made a remarkable offhand joke about a sexual encounter with a mermaid. It was too crude to reproduce here, and anyway, I’ve learned not to try. It’s never as funny as it was that night. During the collapse that followed, I summoned just enough motor control to hand her a dollar. Clearly, I figured, she had done work: She surveyed the market, applied her expertise and delivered — on deadline no less. A buck seemed like the least I could do.

headline: Review: Amy Poehler and Tina Fey Come Home in ‘Sisters’
text: “Sisters” is a movie to go out and see when you’ve run out of television to watch. Which could happen, at least theoretically. Directed by Jason Moore (“Pitch Perfect”) from a script by the longtime “Saturday Night Live” writer Paula Pell, this raunchy-huggy comedy features, in keeping with Hollywood custom, a gaggle of well-known and well-liked sitcom and sketch-comedy performers being a little less funny than you want them to be. They are allowed to swear more robustly than on network or basic-cable shows, to deliver sentimental speeches along with punch lines and to play with or against type as the mood suits.

headline: Aviation Museums Where the Imagination Can Soar
text: Exploring places where globe-trotters, backpackers in Birkenstocks and the all-around curious can rediscover the original, wide-eyed wonder of flight.

headline: 19 Coal Miners Trapped in Northeast China Are Presumed Dead
text: BEIJING — Nineteen coal miners trapped for more than 24 hours after a gas explosion and raging fire in a mine in Hegang, in northeastern China, are presumed dead, the state-run broadcaster CCTV reported on Thursday.

headline: Debate Brings the Fear of Terrorism and Immigration to Center Stage
text: In the waning days of the 2014 midterm elections, the issues of national security and immigration collided — the rise of the Islamic State and the re-emergence of Ebola created a deep sense of fear in the weeks before voters returned control of the Senate to Republicans. Thirteen months later, after the San Bernardino attacks, those issues are again intertwined.

headline: Peggy Noonan: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The Time of Our Lives” isn’t impressed with recent books by presidential contenders: “They were mostly unreal and insincere.”

headline: Adele Moves to Stop Scalpers From Reselling Concert Tickets
text: Adele has broken sales records with her new album, “25,” but little noticed outside the concert business has been her war against ticket-scalping.

headline: 1940: U.K. Dooms Woman Spy to Die
text: LONDON — The forty-two-year-old wife of one of London’s fire-fighting heroes stood up stolidly in court at Winchester, Hampshire, today [Dec. 17] and heard the judge sentence her to death as a spy. Mrs. Dorothy Pamela O’Grady, of Sandown, Isle of Wright, is the first woman spy to be condemned to death in Great Britain in this war. Mrs. O’Grady posed as a quiet and neighborly proprietress of a small boarding house in Sandown. Under this guise, it was charged, she had secretly made plans to help ‘‘the enemy,’’ had cut a military telephone wire and collected important defense documents. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 18, 1940

headline: China Protests Sale of U.S. Arms to Taiwan
text: HONG KONG — The Obama administration’s announcement that it would sell $1.83 billion worth of arms to Taiwan, including two warships and antitank missiles, has drawn a swift rebuke from China, which threatened to penalize the companies that made the armaments and summoned a United States diplomat to register an official protest.

headline: When News Gets (Too?) Personal
text: A recent article in The Times about the flawed way that experts predicted health care costs had an extra element when read online: personalized location.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘Beasts of No Nation’
text: If directing a movie in the Ghana jungle with the somber subject matter of child soldiers wasn’t already difficult work, try also acting as the cinematographer for that film as well. That’s what the filmmaker Cary Fukunaga decided to do for his harrowing West African war drama “Beasts of No Nation,” in theaters and streaming on Netflix. Why take on both roles? Since Mr. Fukunaga started out in film school at New York University shooting other directors’ projects, he had the experience with the camera.

headline: The Stage’s Best Moments This Year
text: As a certain popular musical about a certain early Treasury Secretary maintains, we all want to be in the room where it happens. That’s never more so than at the theater, where on stages lavish or bare, every performance is one of a kind. Here, writers and editors for The New York Times recall stage moments worth singing about.

headline: Standard Chartered Hires HSBC Veteran to Run Corporate Bank
text: LONDON — Standard Chartered, an Asia-focused bank based in London, announced on Thursday that it had hired Simon Cooper, a veteran banker at HSBC, to lead its corporate and institutional banking division.

headline: No Messi or Neymar, but Barcelona Predictably Wins at Club World Cup
text: The Club World Cup sounds like a big, important event, and in a way it is. Virtually every club in the world is technically eligible for the competition, from the mighty teams of Europe to the smallest of the Pacific islands.

headline: Drug C.E.O. Martin Shkreli Arrested on Fraud Charges
text: It has been a busy week for Martin Shkreli, the flamboyant businessman at the center of the drug industry’s price-gouging scandals.

headline: Naked in the East Village
text: Dear Diary:

headline: How to Navigate America’s Busiest Airports
text: Pack a portable charger, and your patience. The December holidays are among the busiest for travel across the country, making for lengthy airport security lines, fast food temptations and mass scrambles for open electrical sockets. While many airports have upgraded their concourses with shopping malls, commissioned artwork and even micro-hotels, some of the busiest remain miserable, according to a new study by J.D. Power, which listed Newark, New York’s La Guardia and Los Angeles International as the bottom three in flier satisfaction.

headline: Swiss Regulator Bars 6 Former UBS Workers in Currency Inquiry
text: LONDON — A Swiss regulator said on Thursday that it had barred six former managers and traders at UBS from the financial industry in an investigation into manipulation of the foreign currency markets.

headline: Israel Grants Approval for Development of Giant Offshore Gas Field
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday announced final government approval for a long-delayed deal that will let an American-Israeli energy partnership develop an offshore natural gas field.

headline: U.N. Rights Council Presses for Inquiry in Burundi
text: GENEVA — Responding to chilling accounts of mass killings in Burundi, the United Nations’ top human rights body on Thursday called for an international investigation of abuses as part of an effort to curb the violence and prevent a wider regional conflict.

headline: Baltimore Wrestles With the Way Forward After a Mistrial
text: BALTIMORE — Armored National Guard trucks were still rolling through the streets last spring when a tough-talking young African-American prosecutor named Marilyn Mosby marched onto the steps of Baltimore’s grand columned War Memorial, faced a bank of television cameras and vowed to “deliver justice” on behalf of Freddie Gray.

headline: Daily Report: Google’s Lousy Time at the D.M.V.
text: Some days, even Google gets frustrated by the D.M.V.

headline: Getting Gmail Verification Codes Without a Smartphone, or a Phone at All
text: Q. Is there any way to use Gmail’s two-step security system if you do not have a working cell signal — or even a mobile phone capable of getting text messages with the codes needed to log in?

headline: Avon in Deal to Split Off North American Business
text: Ever since Avon Products rebuffed a $10.7 billion unsolicited offer by Coty more than three years ago, the beauty company has been the subject of takeover speculation.

headline: Fretful Backers Push Marco Rubio to Pick a Must-Win Early Primary State
text: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — A nagging problem hovers over Senator Marco Rubio of Florida as he crisscrosses the country seeking support in the states with the first four nominating contests: With a month and a half until the voting begins, he still has not committed himself fully to trying to win any of them.

headline: Neighbor of San Bernardino Attackers Faces Terrorism Charges
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — Enrique Marquez, who supplied the assault rifles used to kill 14 people in a massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., this month, was arrested Thursday and charged with crimes including conspiring to support terrorists. Court papers show that he and one of the attackers had steeped themselves for years in radical and violent Islamist propaganda, including the teachings of the extremist cleric Anwar al-Awlaki and bomb-making techniques from an Al Qaeda magazine.

headline: 1965: Johnson’s French Chef Quits
text: NEW YORK — The French chief hired to add some spice to White House state dinners by President and Mrs. John F. Kennedy in 1961 has submitted his resignation. The chef, René Verdon, said today [Dec. 17] he did not like what had happened to the White House cuisine since the Johnsons moved in and that he would be leaving at the end of the year. Mr. Verdon said he did not mind what the first family wanted to eat for their own meals but added: ‘‘I don’t want to lose my reputation.’’ He said it was ‘‘very lousy’’ to have frozen foods in the president’s house. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 18, 1965

headline: Greta Lee On Hollywood Stereotypes and Playing the ‘Lovable Weirdo’
text: Greta Lee is a familiar face to fans of “Girls,” where she played an entitled gallerist; “High Maintenance,” where she was Heidi; and “Inside Amy Schumer,” a gig Ms. Lee landed after she and Ms. Schumer met in an elevator after their failed auditions for a Noah Baumbach film. Next up is Ms. Lee’s scene-stealing turn in Tina Fey and Amy Poehler’s raucous new comedy, “Sisters,” where she plays Hae Won, a nail salon technician and devout partyer.

headline: Echoes of the Past as David Cameron Enters Talks on Britain’s Future in European Union
text: LONDON — The British prime minister holds high-stakes talks before a crucial referendum on whether to abandon European integration. Though distracted by other problems, the German chancellor tries to help him out. Back home, British critics snipe, hoping the negotiations will collapse.

headline: Liquor Taxes and Sexually Transmitted Infections
text: Maryland increased its liquor taxes in 2011 and a sharp decrease in the rate of new gonorrhea infections immediately followed. Researchers have determined that the two events are closely linked.

headline: Class Differences in Child-Rearing Are on the Rise
text: The lives of children from rich and poor American families look more different than they have in decades.

headline: Libya’s Rival Factions Sign Deal for Unity Government
text: CAIRO — Representatives of Libya’s dueling parliaments signed a United Nations-brokered agreement on Thursday to form a national unity government that supporters said was an important and long overdue step toward ending years of chaos and civil war.

headline: Why Giving Back Isn’t Enough
text: DURING this season of giving, I will join millions of Americans in volunteering to feed the homeless, contributing to clothing drives and donating to poverty-fighting charities. Yet I worry that through these acts of kindness, I absolve myself of asking deeper questions about injustice and inequality. We Americans are a remarkably bighearted people, but I believe the purpose of our philanthropy must not only be generosity, but justice.

headline: José Mourinho Is Fired by Chelsea
text: José Mourinho is probably the most visible coach in the world of soccer, striking on the sideline in a finely tailored suit and scarf. Admired and disparaged in equal measure, he has brought triumph and controversy to a succession of the biggest teams in Europe.

headline: Reporting in a War Zone: Inside the Navy SEALs Story
text: Rail thin and hunched over, Assadullah shuffled into the living room of The New York Times’s bureau in Kabul, Afghanistan, on a warm August morning with a story that colleagues and I had been waiting months to hear. His timing could not have been worse.

headline: Link to Paris Attack Roils Debate Over Migrants in Hungary
text: BUDAPEST — Three months after throngs of migrants turned the Keleti station in Budapest into a squalid symbol of Europe’s disarray, the grand 19th-century rail terminus has taken on a no less divisive role in a mounting debate over links between terrorism and the chaotic influx of people fleeing war and poverty in the Muslim world.

headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5, Episode 10: Bless the Child
text: What a child needs from a parent is simple enough: love, safety, comfort. But what does a parent need from a child? Equal measures of love? Forgiveness?

headline: Growing Up in a Time of Fear: Confronting Stereotypes About Muslims and Countering Xenophobia
text: Muslims in America are an incredibly diverse group, reflecting the variety inherent in a worldwide religion of over 1.6 billion followers.

headline: Vladimir Putin Praises Donald Trump, Sealing a Long-Distance Bromance
text: One is the leader of a declining superpower that is trying to reassert itself militarily. The other wants to “make America great again.” And the two have a budding bromance that transcends the tense relationship between the two nations.

headline: Brazil Restores WhatsApp Service After Brief Blockade Over Wiretap Request
text: WhatsApp, a popular instant messaging service owned by Facebook, was briefly shut down in Brazil on Thursday after the American firm refused to place wiretaps on certain WhatsApp accounts.

headline: This Time, Make It Brooklyn
text: Mick Magsino and Cara Barrese met while working at Corbis, the photo agency. Shortly after they married nearly a decade ago, they left their Jersey City rental and moved for work to Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 15: Buccaneers at Rams
text: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday night’s game between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the St. Louis Rams. Check back Friday for analysis on Sunday’s games and Monday’s matchup between the Detroit Lions and the New Orleans Saints. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Having Owned Up to Buying Newspaper, Adelsons Go Silent
text: Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate and Republican donor, and his family have formally owned The Las Vegas Review-Journal for a week.

headline: Marine Le Pen Deletes Tweet With Photo of Slain Journalist
text: LONDON — Marine Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front party in France, deleted a tweet on Thursday that contained a photo of the decapitated body of James Foley, the American journalist who was killed by the Islamic State last year, after criticism from his family.

headline: Ashton Carter Emails Sought by Senate Armed Services Committee
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter was widely criticized on Thursday for using a personal email account earlier this year to conduct government business as top Republicans on Capitol Hill said they would review his messages to determine whether they had compromised sensitive national security information.

headline: Down From the Trees, Humans Finally Got a Decent Night’s Sleep
text: Over the past few million years, the ancestors of modern humans became dramatically different from other primates. Our forebears began walking upright, and they lost much of their body hair; they gained precision-grip fingers and developed gigantic brains.

headline: Indictment Charges Shkreli With Security Fraud
text: The investigation is related to Martin Shkreli's time as a hedge fund manager and running the biopharmaceutical company Retrophin.

headline: British Teeth Aren’t So Bad, Study Says
text: It would seem that the British public, long the butt of dentistry jokes told by Americans, has now been issued bragging rights by the scientific community.

headline: How to Fix Latin America’s ‘Strongman’ Problem
text: In early December, Ecuador’s lawmakers voted to throw out presidential term limits, a divisive move that quickly spurred street demonstrations in the capital, Quito. To appease protesters, President Rafael Correa backed a law making him sit out the next election. He may still find a way to renege on the deal or return early, but regardless, the new law lets him run for office indefinitely after 2021.

headline: Introducing Gizmo
text: At The New York Times, our development teams have been adopting the Go programming language over the last three years to build better back-end services. In the past I’ve written about using Go for Elastic MapReduce streaming. I’ve also talked about using Go at GothamGo for news analysis and to improve our email and alert systems at the Golang NYC Meetup. We use Go for a wide variety of tasks, but the most common use throughout the company is for building JSON APIs.

headline: Video Review: The New Audi TT Still a Fun Dash Down the Road
text: WHEN Audi unleashed the production model TT in 2000, it was a Bauhaus sight to behold. Gloriously exposed hex screw heads and aluminum accents were crafted into an instrument that celebrated the raw beauty of machinery. Its design attitude was in stark contrast to Audi’s modern minimalist approach.

headline: Oklahoma Highway Shootings Leave 2 Dead
text: Two people in separate cars were fatally shot by a man who drove along an Interstate highway in Oklahoma while randomly firing at vehicles, an official said on Thursday. The suspected gunman was arrested after a short pursuit.

headline: The Jeb Scenario
text: My Campaign Stops column today, looking at the genuinely ideologically-significant choice that G.O.P. voters are likely to face next year, assumes that we’re headed for a three-man race: Rubio, Cruz and Trump. That assumption is reasonable, but it’s hardly airtight, which is why earlier this week I considered one alternative scenario, in which Chris Christie shouldered his way into the mix as a right-of-center alternative to Rubio (and Trump). But what about Jeb Bush? He still has money and endorsements, after all; he has more support nationally than Christie (well, by a point or so); in New Hampshire he’s slipped behind him but not by much. The race is still fluid, the voting is still more than a month away: If we’re considering a Christie scenario, it still make sense to ask if there’s a Jeb scenario as well.

headline: Under Fire From G.O.P., Obama Defends Response to Terror Attacks
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking to counter pressure for a military escalation in response to terrorist attacks, told a group of news columnists this week that sending significant ground forces back to the Middle East could conceivably result in the deaths of 100 American soldiers every month.

headline: Britain Offers Licenses for Shale-Rock Exploration
text: LONDON — The British government, in an effort to stoke interest from energy companies in extracting fuels from shale rock, said on Thursday that it was offering licenses for oil and gas exploration on 159 tracts of land.

headline: Apple Makes Shifts in Senior Management
text: Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, is continuing to make over the company’s executive ranks.

headline: Jaromir Jagr Leading Panthers’ Veterans and Youngsters at 43
text: NEWARK — South Florida is associated with snowbirds — retirees who migrate from the North to spend their later years in the comfort of warm weather — and professional hockey there is full of the N.H.L.’s version: The Panthers are one of the league’s oldest teams, averaging 28.5 years.

headline: President Obama, Joining Bear Grylls, Tests Survival Skills in Alaska
text: WASHINGTON — He helped make tea from catkins, ate a salmon prechewed by a bear, and discussed why people would drink their own urine.

headline: Public Theater Casts Two Transgender Actors in ‘Southern Comfort’
text: An invitation by the Public Theater for auditions by transgender actors prompted 130 submissions, and has led to the casting of two transgender performers in a bluegrass musical being staged at the Off Broadway theater this winter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Gets Backing From Leading Union and a Liberal Group
text: Senator Bernie Sanders received the endorsement of the Communications Workers of America on Thursday, giving the Democratic presidential hopeful his biggest union nod as he heads into the homestretch before votes are cast in the nominating contests.

headline: Drone Maker Lily Announces a Product Delay and New Funding
text: People who order innovative new drones from start-ups without track records have good reason to be nervous.

headline: Call Him Trumpevich: Vladimir Putin’s Presidential Pick
text: There is some big news in the 2016 campaign.

headline: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler: Not Exactly Party Animals
text: In “Sisters,” Tina Fey and Amy Poehler play adult siblings who decide to throw one last wild teenage-style bash in their childhood home. (Cue the dance-offs and cannonballs into the pool.) In real life, Ms. Fey and Ms. Poehler have been to decades of parties together, from wrap nights at “Saturday Night Live” to awards-show celebrations. Now that their film opens the same weekend as “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” they may be reaching for higher marketing powers  to combat the competition. In the meantime, they spoke to Melena Ryzik about their favorite blowouts and what it was like to be uncool kids. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Benjamin Genocchio of Artnet to Head Armory Show
text: Ever since Noah Horowitz announced in July that he was stepping down  as head of the Armory Show, the art world has wondered who would replace him at a time when that mammoth fair for Modern and contemporary art faces increasing competition from Frieze New York.

headline: Secret Tape, TV Hearings and a Resignation: A Watergate Moment for Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — For more than two weeks, Indonesians have been glued to their television sets as one of the biggest political scandals in the country’s history has unfolded before their eyes.

headline: The Joy of Reading in the City
text: From the subways to the steps of the public library, readers can be seen enjoying a book, sometimes for the 15th time.

headline: The Invisible Democratic Debates
text: The Republican presidential candidates have demonstrated such an appetite for debates that if I set up nine lecterns in my living room on a weeknight around 8 p.m. and chanted “carpet bomb” and “anchor baby,” they’d probably materialize en masse, even before I had time to vacuum and put out the artichoke dip.

headline: Reading Is About the Lines That Leap Off the Pages
text: I don’t mind writing year-end Top 10 lists. As William Styron’s Sophie discovered, forced choices can lead to soul-searching.

headline: Love on the Hospital Walls
text: The patient I was caring for, a woman in her 40s with leukemia, had been admitted to the hospital for the second of four monthly courses of chemotherapy. She was sitting quietly in a chair by the window of her hospital room, dressed in her street clothes and flipping through some photos on her iPad. The cancer drugs dripped from a clear bag hanging on a nearby IV pole through clear plastic tubing into the catheter in her arm.

headline: Lowly Team Turns to a Different 76er (He’s Going on 77)
text: Upon his unanticipated return to the N.B.A., Jerry Colangelo especially enjoyed one Philadelphia news media report noting how the 76ers had not-so-coincidently hired a 76-year-old to restore their credibility.

headline: Carolyn Ryan: Unpacking the 2016 Presidential Election
text: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: Disney and Other Theme Parks Add Metal Detectors for Holidays
text: As they prepare to host tens of millions of holiday visitors, three of America’s biggest theme park operators — Disney, Universal and SeaWorld — on Thursday reacted to heightened security concerns by installing metal detectors outside their gates.

headline: BRIC’s Spring Season Includes Concert Series and Brooklyn-Centric TV Shows
text: A concert series, a major contemporary art exhibition and new episodes of Brooklyn-centric television shows are the highlights of the spring season at BRIC House, a multimedia arts space in Brooklyn.

headline: Under Wire, House Passes Big Package of Tax Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan expressed annoyance on Thursday at the $1.1 trillion year-end spending bill now on the House floor. “You know I don’t like this process, right?” he told reporters. “I mean you know we inherited a process, a cake that was pretty much more than half-baked.”

headline: A Jimmy Buffett Musical to Set Sail With Broadway in Mind
text: Is Broadway ready for Margaritaville?

headline: For the Holidays, Your Folks’ or Mine?
text: Since my husband and I began dating, deciding whose family to visit for holidays has caused strife. (They live too far to visit both.) This year, our first as a married couple, we settled on Thanksgiving with his and Christmas with mine. We will alternate next year. But now my husband says he can’t miss his father’s family’s Christmas party — to be held the day after Christmas this year. He proposes spending Christmas Eve and Christmas night together, then visiting his family for the weekend, leaving me with mine. But that wasn’t our agreement, and I want us together. Ideas?

headline: What the Fed’s Rate Increase Means
text: To the Editor:

headline: HBO’s Mike Nichols Documentary to Show at Sundance
text: The HBO documentary “Becoming Mike Nichols” has been given late clearance into next month’s Sundance Film Festival, a berth that allows the film to premiere before a rival PBS project arrives on Jan. 29.

headline: Ted Cruz, Shunned in the Senate, Plays Unpopularity to His Advantage
text: WASHINGTON — It is the hate that dare not speak its name.

headline: Review: Catherine Russell Sings Still-Resonant Standards at Birdland
text: At a moment when the world can seem dangerously out of balance, it is still possible for a musician to convey a groundedness and a joy that don’t seem smiley-faced and goody-goody. A fine place to find it is Birdland, where the jazz singer Catherine Russell began a short run  with her sextet on Tuesday evening, projecting a strength, good humor and intelligence that engulfed the room in a mood of bonhomie. She reminded you that even in the most chaotic times, there are oases of calm.

headline: Gus Powell’s Word Play
text: The photographer pairs evocative images with one-liners in an homage to the cartoonist William Steig.

headline: An Inventively Designed Photo Book (That You Can Read)
text: The images in the Gus Powell book released this fall, “The Lonely Ones,” can stand alone: Powell captures orphaned landscapes and quotidian moments that hit on both the poignancy and the absurdity of everyday life. But it’s the subtle, funny one-liners Powell adds to his photos that elevate the collection of images to something that’s part poetry, part comic strip. Taking its name and inspiration from the 1942 classic by the cartoonist William Steig, “The Lonely Ones” pays homage to the “king of cartoons” with a book (and upcoming show) that delights in the interplay between language and image. “I tried to make a book that did traffic in feelings,” Powell says of the body of work, which spans a decade.

headline: Review: ‘Antigona’ Is Noche Flamenca’s Teeming Take on the Greek Tragedy
text: Settling into a six-week run at West Park Presbyterian Church, the troupe has found ways to subtly mirror and amplify the emotions of its star.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — A Puncher’s Chance
text: Pat Robertson, a Southern Baptist minister and media mogul, took part in a two-round boxing exhibition in Manchester, N.H., in February 1988 while running for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: New York City’s Flu Shot Mandate for Young Children Is Struck Down
text: A judge ruled on Thursday that the New York City health department could not require young children to be vaccinated for the flu to attend city-licensed preschools and day care centers, striking down one of the more ambitious public health initiatives of the Bloomberg administration.

headline: Report Criticizes U.N.’s Handling of Child Sex Abuse Allegations
text: UNITED NATIONS — An independent panel has concluded in a scathing report issued Thursday that United Nations officials passed allegations of child sexual abuse by peacekeepers “from desk to desk, inbox to inbox” and failed to meet the organization’s core mission to protect the rights of the most vulnerable civilians.

headline: The Logic in AstraZeneca’s Buying Spree
text: AstraZeneca is increasing risk with its merger splurge. The phamaceutical company is spending $4 billion on a stake in the cancer specialist Acerta, taking its total to more than $7 billion this quarter. But while AstraZeneca’s deals aren’t cheap, they do seem to clear the value hurdle.

headline: Security Concerns Force Ben Carson to Cancel Israel-Africa Trip
text: Ben Carson on Thursday canceled a trip to Israel and Africa, which was planned with the intention of improving his credibility on foreign policy, because of what one adviser said were “active credible” threats from the terrorist group Boko Haram.

headline: What Happened When a Teenager Joined Martin Shkreli on a Live Stream
text: About a month ago, Martin Shkreli, the pharmaceutical entrepreneur who was arrested on Thursday, began live-streaming himself on YouTube, sometimes for 10 hours or more at a time, as he worked, played video games, strummed a guitar and, occasionally, while he slept.

headline: Is ‘Black Lives Matter’ Making Police Cautious, Driving Up Crime?
text: Since the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., last year, police conduct has been under increasing scrutiny at the same time that a bipartisan call for lower rates of incarceration and arrest has gained strength.

text: Julie Rice and Elizabeth Cutler are business partners whose enduring friendship fuels the success of the fitness phenomenon SoulCycle.

headline: No Diva Drama as Jets Receivers Share the Workload
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Jets wide receiver Brandon Marshall reached into his locker on Tuesday and displayed his Christmas gift for quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick. It was “Just Give Me the Damn Ball!” — an autobiography by Keyshawn Johnson, a former Jets receiver.

headline: Iran Registers Clerics Seeking to Choose Next Supreme Leader
text: TEHRAN — Iran started a 10-day registration period on Thursday for clerical candidates who hope to be elected to a council that can choose the country’s next supreme leader.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: John Cameron Mitchell
text: For his bookshop and website One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer, actor and director John Cameron Mitchell. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Room for Debate Podcast: Police, Crime and the Ferguson Effect
text: Heather Mac Donald of the Manhattan Institute and Paul Butler of Georgetown University law school debate whether criticism of police tactics has led to less aggressive policing and higher crime rates.

headline: Sheldon Adelson Bought the Wrong Newspaper
text: The mystery of who bought The Las Vegas Review-Journal has been solved.

text: To the Editor:

headline: House Panel Faults Failure to Review Visa Applicants’ Social Media Use
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of lawmakers aggressively questioned Obama administration officials on Thursday about the government’s efforts to properly vet visitors and asylum seekers coming to the United States, raising concerns that terrorists could exploit the system to enter and carry out attacks against Americans.

headline: The Trend I Skipped This Year
text: Abbi Jacobson, John Slattery, Marcus Samuelsson and others on what big thing they chose to pass over in 2015.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Takes In $14.1 Million Abroad
text: “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” took in $14.1 million in 12 foreign markets where it rolled out on Wednesday, an opening day that was very strong but did not set many major records, perhaps because of the midweek arrival.

headline: A Solution to Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Campaigning Marco Rubio Misses a Chance to Object to a Spending Bill
text: Senator Marco Rubio says he wants to slow down and amend the $1.1 trillion spending bill that is making its way through Congress.

headline: A Culture Gap the Size of an Ocean, Bridged by Facebook
text: A few months ago, my 75-year-old technophobic father, who still works full time as a big-city mail carrier, asked me to sign him up on Facebook, leaving me nearly speechless with surprise. When he added that he was doing it to keep in touch with a 26-year-old Saudi Arabian woman he had met on his mail route, I was even more stunned.

headline: Leaders at E.U. Summit Vow to ‘Regain Control’ of Borders
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders vowed on Thursday to “regain control” of the Continent’s external frontiers at their final summit meeting of 2015, a tumultuous year bracketed by lethal terrorist attacks in Paris and convulsed by destabilizing blows to Europe’s common currency and to its faith in a common destiny without borders.

headline: A Report Peppered with Questions and Sticky Notes
text: Lorenzo Davis, a former police commander, wrote this 2014 report recommending that the officer who shot Cedric Chapman, Kevin Fry, be fired. This copy of the report shows, with handwritten notes and sticky notes, where supervisors questioned or disagreed with Mr. Davis's findings.

headline: Use of Force Was Justified
text: In this final report, the Independent Police Review Authority in Chicago found that Officer Kevin Fry followed departmental guidelines about the use of force when he fatally shot Cedric Chatman.

headline: Breaking the Code of Silence
text: In Chicago, police have shot and killed more people in recent years than in any of the 10 largest cities in America. Yet officers are rarely disciplined. A retired officer who investigated excessive force complaints explains why.

headline: Chicago Pays Millions but Punishes Few in Killings by Police
text: CHICAGO — The gunshots blasted on and on, 45 in all, until Calvin Cross lay dead in a vacant lot. Mr. Cross, 19, had run away after three Chicago police officers pulled alongside him on a South Side street near his house. Bullets hit his chest, arm, back, face and the little finger on his right hand.

headline: VW Names Kenneth Feinberg to Oversee Fund for Claims on Emissions Deception
text: Volkswagen has hired Kenneth R. Feinberg, a prominent specialist in compensation funds, to devise and administer a program to address claims related to vehicles that have been affected by the company’s admitted use of deceptive software to cheat on emissions tests.

headline: Wrestling’s Daily Struggle in Guatemala
text: Although the golden age of professional wrestling has faded in Guatemala, on weekends some hard-core devotees don masks and meet at a garage turned arena.

headline: I.M.F. Chief Faces Trial in Case Dating to Time as French Finance Minister
text: PARIS — A special French court on Thursday ordered Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to stand trial on charges of negligence that date back to when she served as France’s finance minister, the second time in five years that a top French I.M.F. official has faced legal scrutiny.

headline: Smithsonian Announces Gift of David Smith Sculpture
text: Describing it as the most important sculpture gift it has received in decades, the Smithsonian American Art Museum said it has been given an important work by the American sculptor David Smith, an artist who conjured welded iron and steel shapes from tools, metal plates and other industrial objects.

headline: Two 9/11 Artifacts, a PATH Car and an Antenna Mast, Get New Homes
text: Hangar 17 at Kennedy International Airport, which for years was as close as New York City had to a Sept. 11 memorial museum, now stands almost empty of the monumental artifacts of the attack on the World Trade Center 14 years ago.

headline: For Chicago Police, Many Complaints but Few Consequences
text: Most complaints by residents against the police do not result in discipline against officers.

headline: LifeLock Agrees to Pay $100 Million Fine in Settlement With F.T.C.
text: LifeLock, an identity protection service, agreed to a $100 million settlement with the Federal Trade Commission for failing to deliver on promises it would guard personal data and inform users when their information was breached.

headline: Conflicts Complicate Duties of Viacom’s Philippe Dauman
text: Philippe Dauman, now 61, has been the president and chief executive of Viacom since September 2006. He has received $336 million in total compensation, as of the end of the company’s 2014 fiscal year. Some of that was paid to him in the form of Viacom stock, and his stock holdings are now worth nearly $200 million.

headline: 16-Year-Old Sprints Right Into Professional Track
text: ATLANTA — When Candace Hill became the fastest teenage girl the United States has ever clocked, sprinting 100 meters in 10.98 seconds in June, she was suddenly good enough not only to qualify for next summer’s Rio Olympics, but also to potentially win a medal there. Now, at age 16, she has become the youngest track athlete in the United States to turn professional.

text: Political editor Carolyn Ryan and national political correspondent John Martin chat about the Republican field after the party’s final debate.

headline: An Old ‘Word of Rapture’ for Broadway’s New Theater
text: The old Hudson Theater is a bit hard to spot these days, sandwiched between two hotel towers on West 44th Street, still handsome but a bit of a quiet presence on a noisy block.

headline: 1920 | Why So Hard on Harding?
text: When “The Gun Epidemic” was printed Dec. 5, The Times noted that 95 years had passed since the last Page 1 editorial, which scorned the nomination of Senator Warren G. Harding of Ohio as the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Former Chief of BTG Pactual, André Esteves, Is Freed From Jail
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s Supreme Court released André Esteves, former chief executive of the Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual, from jail on Thursday, but the fallen banking star is far from a free man.

headline: Israel and Turkey Agree to Restore Diplomatic Ties
text: JERUSALEM — Israel and Turkey have reached a preliminary agreement to begin restoring full diplomatic relations after years of deep freeze, Israeli officials said on Thursday.

headline: Navigation Systems Still Show the Way, but Also Make the Route Safer
text: WHEN Gary Kaye, an editor and former television producer in Connecticut, bought his 2005 Volvo XC90, it had an in-dash navigation system. But he says the company wanted “an astonishing amount of money” to update the maps every year.

headline: Review: ‘Sancho: An Act of Remembrance,’ Recalls a British Pioneer
text: “Sancho: An Act of Remembrance,” which was originally presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has reopened at the National Black Theater, 2031-33 5th Ave, Manhattan; 866-811-4111. Here is the original review, which appeared on Dec. 18, 2015.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, Facing Homelessness Crisis, Issues Plan to Fight It
text: Vowing that he would never return New York City to the “bad old days,” Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday unveiled a newly muscular plan to monitor and combat street homelessness, seeking to retake control of a problem that has emerged as a full-bore political crisis for his administration.

headline: U.S. Airlines Preparing to Offer Flights to Cuba
text: The United States and Cuba agreed today to restore commercial flights between the two countries for the first time in more than a half century, and several United States airlines announced plans to request approval to begin flying.

headline: Podcast: A G.O.P. Debate Wrap-Up
text: The Republicans’ fifth and final presidential debate of 2015 was full of bluster and insult. And questions about fear and security and which candidate can keep the country safe from the Islamic State — and Hillary Clinton.

headline: The Junk Bond Rout That Wasn’t
text: After seven years of rock-bottom interest rates, it should come as no surprise to see excessive risk taking on Wall Street. Investors have long been trying to identify the next bubble, and last Friday Carl Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, weighed in.

headline: Review: ‘Son of Saul’ Revisits Life and Death in Auschwitz
text: The shape of the screen is unusually narrow in “Son of Saul,” the 38-year-old Hungarian filmmaker Laszlo Nemes’s debut feature. Nearly square, it evokes an earlier era, when all movies looked this way, and also emphasizes the claustrophobia of the story and the setting. We are in a Nazi death camp, and really in it, to a degree that few fictional films have had the nerve to attempt. The camera doesn’t just survey the barracks and the guard towers, the haggard prisoners and brutal guards. It takes us to the very door of the gas chambers, in the close company of Saul Auslander (Geza Rohrig), a Jewish inmate who is a member of the camp’s Sonderkommando (special commando) unit.

headline: Martin Shkreli on Skype With Teenager
text: During a live stream, Mr. Shkreli discussed rap, high school and a friend of his who is in jail.

headline: Facts & Figures: Guns Now Kill as Many as Cars
text: The death rate from car accidents has fallen since 1950, while the death rate from gunshots has risen — and in 2014, the two rates were the same, according to recently released CDC data. In 21 states and the District of Columbia, guns killed more people than cars.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Dec. 18, 2015
text: The New York Times film critics review “Sisters,” “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” and “Son of Saul.”

headline: Crimes Against Muslim Americans and Mosques Rise Sharply
text: WASHINGTON — Hate crimes against Muslim Americans and mosques across the United States have tripled in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., with dozens occurring within just a month, according to new data.

headline: New Orleans City Council Votes to Remove Confederate Monuments
text: The New Orleans City Council voted 6 to 1 to remove four Confederate monuments after a heated monthslong debate, declaring the Civil War-era statues and an obelisk to be “public nuisances.”

headline: Thursday N.F.L. Game Has Running Backs to Savor
text: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the St. Louis Rams are long shots to make the playoffs this season, but there are a pair of players having All-Pro caliber seasons worth watching Thursday night.

headline: A test for future podcats
text: this is a test for future podcast links

headline: Enrique Marquez Criminal Complaint
text: In a federal complaint released Thursday, officials charged En­rique Mar­quez with con­spir­ing to give ma­ter­i­al sup­port to a ter­ror­ist plot.

headline: Review: Variety and Risk in Trinity Wall Street’s ‘Messiah’
text: Alongside its mighty choruses, Handel’s “Messiah” features a string of solo recitatives and airs for soprano, alto, tenor and bass. As such, it is usually performed by a choir and four soloists representing each of those voice types. But Trinity Wall Street, which presented the first of its three concerts of the oratorio on Wednesday at Trinity Church, adheres to a different practice. Drawing on a deep pool of talent among its 28-member chorus, it fields a whole flock of soloists: 13 at the initial presentation.

headline: Police Officer Accused of Sexually Abusing a Family Friend’s Daughter
text: A New York police officer was arrested in Brooklyn this week and charged with sexually abusing the daughter of a family friend, the authorities said.

headline: In Handel’s ‘Messiah,’ the Trumpet as Divine Agent
text: COMING late in Handel’s “Messiah,” the glittering instrumental solo in “The Trumpet Shall Sound” is one of the most recognizable trumpet parts in music. This time of year, its rousing opening fanfare and serenely gleaming lyrical passages can be heard in concert halls and churches all over the country, part of a bass aria that becomes one of this beloved oratorio’s emotional highlights, charged with hope, mystery and awe.

headline: Once Naughty,­ Now Masterpieces
text: During the culturally repressive late-16th and 17th centuries, Spanish kings often secreted away their nude paintings in rooms known as “salas reservadas,” where they could enjoy them in private.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Spotlight’
text: Tom McCarthy narrates a sequence from “Spotlight.”

headline: Tom McCarthy Narrates a Scene From ‘Spotlight’
text: The movie “Spotlight” looks at a team of journalists at The Boston Globe who investigated a sexual abuse scandal within the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Igor Levit Discusses ‘Goldberg,’ a Project With Marina Abramovic
text: Since Dec. 7, the pianist Igor Levit has been playing Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations in “Goldberg,” a collaboration with the performance artist Marina Abramovic at the Park Avenue Armory. In her staging, audience members sit, wearing headphones, for half an hour as the pianist and piano progress slowly and silently on a moving platform down a runway into the center of a circle of deck chairs. As the work is then played, the piano makes a single revolution while the lighting steadily dims.

headline: Men’s Wear that Finds Beauty in Contrast
text: Sam Linder and Kirk Millar, the creative partners behind Linder, approach their line and their store with an opposites-attract ethos.

headline: Review: Alvin Ailey, at City Center, Maintains Polished Approach to Familiar Footwork
text: Under the leadership of Robert Battle, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has expanded and updated its repertory, mostly for the good. But as the dancers take on new challenges, how do they handle the perennial task of making old material look fresh? The All Ailey program at City Center on Wednesday night was as good a test case as any.

headline: Dennis Hastert, Former Speaker, Hospitalized Since Having Stroke
text: CHICAGO — J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House who pleaded guilty in October to trying to evade federal banking laws, has had a stroke and remains in a hospital, his lawyer said Thursday.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Sisters’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Sisters.”

headline: Lace With a Grimace: The Quirky Dresses of Rooney Mara
text: A Golden Globe nominee for “Carol,” she favors undone gowns, mostly in black and white.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Son of Saul’
text: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Son of Saul.”

headline: Review: Adding the Women’s Side to the ‘Diner’ Menu
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — Ah, remember the women of “Diner,” Barry Levinson’s priceless 1982 movie about being young and lost in Baltimore? O.K., you can be forgiven for thinking that I have asked the wrong question.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Force Awakens’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”

headline: Ted Cruz Escalates Attack on Marco Rubio Over Immigration
text: LAS VEGAS — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas ratcheted up his attack on Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Thursday by insinuating that Mr. Rubio had broken his promise to voters who elected him to fight “amnesty” for undocumented immigrants. Mr. Cruz also challenged his Republican rivals to declare their position on whether people who are in the country illegally should be granted citizenship.

headline: Review: In ‘The Great Divorce,’ Searching for Greener Pastures
text: Here are some things C. S. Lewis wanted you to know about heaven. Walking on the grass hurts your feet at first. Waterfalls talk. Murderers can be friends with their victims. Nobody is famous — or rather, everybody is. (“The glory flows into everyone,” a resident explains.)

headline: Desertions Slow Progress of Afghan Air Force Training in U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A chronic problem with desertions among airmen sent to the United States for training is adding to the woes of the Afghan Air Force, which has been stretched thin during a difficult fighting season and is struggling to build itself up to strength.

headline: Review: Ed Reed Pours Out His Feelings at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola
text: Every jazz singer who reaches a certain age is granted a turn as the voice of experience. Ed Reed, who will be 87 in February, takes that covenant more seriously than most. “I spent so many years being unhappy,” he said, confidingly, early in his first set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Wednesday night. He waited a beat. “Anybody out there read my bio?”

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Martin Shkreli, Vladimir Putin, Star Wars
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Art of Politics, in ‘Agitprop!’ at the Brooklyn Museum
text: Most art is political, whether it means to be or not. In “Agitprop!” at the Brooklyn Museum, politics is the whole point. Content is didactic; the creative part lies in how efficiently and effectively it’s delivered. Photography, prints and performance are favored media because they are, in different ways, portable, readily legible and easily reproducible. In general, monuments aside, political art isn’t made to last; it’s made to work. And it has to be ready to change as the news changes.

headline: Review: ‘The Barber of Seville,’ Truncated and Energetic
text: “Fast-paced” doesn’t do it justice. Scarcely have you eased into the familiar overture to Rossini’s “The Barber of Seville” in the Metropolitan Opera’s holiday family presentation of the work than it is over — and on to the action. That skips about, too, but the big tunes are all there, in at least some of their glory.

headline: Review: Bread and Puppet Theater Takes Up the Cause of a Puerto Rican Nationalist
text: Oscar Lopez Rivera, the imprisoned Puerto Rican nationalist, may be an unusual subject for a show deemed appropriate for all ages. But Bread and Puppet Theater, formed in 1963, is an unusual kind of troupe. Its politically oriented shows have routinely considered issues like affordable housing, rats and police conduct. (Times, it seems, haven’t changed.)

headline: Review: ‘Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip’ Features a Trip to Miami
text: Now would be an excellent time for parents of young children to invest in earplugs. A new Alvin and the Chipmunks movie has landed. This one’s called “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip,” the fourth in the series, which began in 2007 and mixes live-action and computer-generated characters.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Plaid Tidings’ Brings Back the Forever Plaid Crew
text: I hadn’t seen the Forever Plaid guys in decades, and I’d completely forgotten they were dead.

headline: Jeb Bush, Sensing Momentum After Debate, Zeroes In on Donald Trump
text: Buoyed by an aggressive performance in Tuesday’s Republican debate, Jeb Bush is intensifying his strategy of attacking Donald J. Trump’s fitness for the presidency, which his aides believe is setting him apart from the sprawling field just as voters begin to make up their minds in early voting states.

headline: The Short Life and Long Legacy of Black Mountain College
text: BOSTON — In school I had issues with structure. I wanted to study everything that involved words and images, which meant literature, art, language, philosophy, psychology and religion, among other subjects. Declaring a major was like self-censorship. The ivory tower felt tight. Street politics, travel and transcendental substances were all in my curriculum. What I was after was education as an open category, an end in itself, an adventure that “aimed at being something instead of at getting something.”

headline: Review: ‘Bajirao Mastani,’ a Bollywood Forbidden Romance
text: At the beginning of Sanjay Leela Bhansali’s “Bajirao Mastani,” a Bollywood romance set in 18th-century India, there’s much talk of planting saffron (that is, Hindu) flags in Delhi, the heart of the Mughal (that is, Muslim) empire. Is this going to be an unpleasant India-for-Hindus epic? On the other hand, the movie seems to have some feminist bona fides: Mastani (Deepika Padukone) is an impressively fierce woman warrior, who saves the life of the equally fierce Bajirao (Ranveer Singh) on the battlefield as arrows whiz by her head. “Mastani writes her own destiny,” she says. Well, O.K.

headline: Theater Listings for Dec. 18-24
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: ‘Little Dreams in Glass and Metal’ Spotlights Enameling
text: Few museums reserve gallery space and budgets for enameled objects. Bernard N. Jazzar and Harold B. Nelson, curators and collectors in Los Angeles, set out to rectify that by creating the nonprofit Enamel Arts Foundation in 2007. It owns about 1,000 of these works — from specks of jewelry to panels as tall as six feet — made of colored glass fired onto metal.

headline: Martha Wilson, Dressing Up and Poking Fun, in ‘Mona/Marcel/Marge’
text: With life, sometimes you just have to laugh, which Martha Wilson learned long ago. In the early 1970s, she dressed up for the camera and portrayed herself as several things she wasn’t — a glamour girl, a housewife, a guy, a goddess — and at least one thing that she was: a feminist, trying on for size every off-the-rack social role she could lay her hands on.

headline: Review: ‘The Genital Warriors’ Revisits Bygone Romances
text: The worst thing about “The Genital Warriors” is the title of this would-be absurdist contemplation on the lifelong need for love. The competition was pretty fierce, though.

headline: Fernando Bryce Explores Midcentury Cultural Ideas
text: The Peruvian-born artist’s work uses images and text printed in Unesco’s Courier magazine between 1948 and 1954.

headline: Saloua Raouda Choucair, a Modernist Explored
text: This sparkling exhibition gives New York its first in-depth look at the wide-ranging activities of Saloua Raouda Choucair, a pioneer of Lebanese modernism who spent four years in Paris after World War II, has worked most of her life in Beirut, and will turn 100 in 2016. It reminds us that modernism proceeds at different speeds not only around the globe but also within the efforts of individual artists.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Dec. 18-24
Review: In ‘He Never Died,’ Mastering Longevity if Not Social Skills
text: Performances don’t come more deadpan than the one Henry Rollins gives in “He Never Died,” an enjoyably strange horror film directed by Jason Krawczyk. Though perhaps “deadpan” is a poor choice of words, given that Mr. Rollins’s character, Jack, seems unable to die.

headline: Friday File: An Early Admirer of ‘Star Wars’
text: “The story of ‘Star Wars’ could be written on the head of a pin and still leave room for the Bible.”

headline: Cary Smith’s Paintings Riff on Modernist Conventions
text: This solo exhibition at the Fredericks & Freiser gallery features infectiously buoyant works devoted to variations on formal templates of geometric abstraction.

headline: Holiday Outings (That Don’t Include ‘Star Wars’)
text: This weekend two very different groups of people will be walking the streets of New York City: Those planning to watch “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” and those hoping to steer clear of theaters during its opening weekend. For the second group, the Miser has some options with a holiday vibe.

headline: ‘Graphic Passion: Matisse and the Book Arts’ at the Morgan Library
text: In Paris during 1946, Henri Matisse made a series of portrait drawings of a notoriously splenetic theater critic named Paul Léautaud. One of the images was to be made into a lithograph for the frontispiece in a book of Léautaud’s writings. Over a number of days that August — a dozen, in Léautaud’s probably exaggerated estimate — the critic sat for the artist, and the two chatted amiably during the sessions.

headline: Review: ‘Mojin: The Lost Legend,’ in Search of a Burial Ground
text: Chinese cinema has become so reliably engaging that it’s a genuine surprise when a clunker shows up on American screens. “Mojin: The Lost Legend” seeks adventure blockbuster status like “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” “Lara Croft: Tomb Raider,” “The Mummy” or other action flicks that spend a lot of time underground. But it gets no traction whatsoever.

headline: Review: Inside the Chef René Redzepi’s World in ‘Noma: My Perfect Storm’
text: In the combat sport of haute cuisine, few recent careers have intrigued as much as that of René Redzepi, the head chef of Noma, in Copenhagen, which has topped a list of the world’s best restaurants four of the last six years. Mr. Redzepi co-founded Noma first on the principle of resurrecting Nordic cuisine, and then on the idea of “time and place” — intricately preparing dishes using only local and seasonally appropriate ingredients.

headline: Humbug as a Holiday Enhancer
text: HOLIDAY cheer can have its limits — by late December, you might be looking for a night out with entertainment that’s a little less wholesome. Luckily, some of New York’s finest comedians are putting a twist on the classic wintertime fare with a mix of stand-up, sketch, storytelling, improv, music and other nonsense to tickle the Grinch in all of us.

headline: Review: ‘Polyfaces,’ a Documentary About Sustainable Agriculture
text: Granted, you don’t watch a documentary about sustainable agriculture for “Star Wars”-type thrills. Yet you may still find yourself quietly cheering for the low-key rebels of “Polyfaces.”

headline: Mars Rover Finds Changing Rocks, Surprising Scientists
text: As NASA’s Curiosity rover treks up a three-mile-high mountain on Mars, the rocks are changing. That says something about how the planet’s climate and environment changed more than three billion years ago — but scientists are not sure what.

headline: Review: ‘Those Who Feel the Fire Burning,’ a Documentary About the Refugee Experience
text: “Those Who Feel the Fire Burning,” a nervily abstract vision of refugee life in Europe from Morgan Knibbe, a first-time feature filmmaker, arrives at a moment when Syrian refugees are a major topic in the news.

headline: F.D.A. Allows Maker of Just Mayo to Keep Product’s Name
text: Sometimes, semantics can make a difference.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Supporting Jeb Bush Attacks Donald Trump in New Ad
text: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush’s campaign, moved quickly to capitalize on Mr. Bush’s well-received exchange with Donald J. Trump in Tuesday’s debate with this ad, titled “Tough Enough.”

headline: Proposed Extension of Tax Credits for Renewable Energy Would Have Uneven Effect
text: After months of taking a beating in the markets, renewable energy companies suddenly seemed to be on firmer footing this week, as lawmakers proposed extending important tax credits in exchange for lifting the decades-old ban on exporting American crude oil.

headline: Calm Acceptance as Fed Enacts Its First Interest Increase in Seven Years
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s much-anticipated “liftoff,” its first interest rate increase since the financial crisis, unfolded as quietly and smoothly as Fed officials could possibly have wished.

headline: United Nations: Sanctions Against ISIS Adopted
text: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday unanimously adopted a legally binding resolution aimed at preventing banned terrorist groups from making money and using the international banking system, with an emphasis on the Islamic State group. The resolution builds on previous Council measures, also legally binding, that make it illegal to donate money to terrorist groups, trade in oil and antiquities or make ransom payments. Those prohibitions are sometimes ignored, and the new resolution, drafted by Russia and the United States, is intended to strengthen it. The resolution calls on countries to describe what steps they are taking to prevent terrorist organizations from making money, including interdicting oil sales. The effects may be limited: The Islamic State group draws a large share of its revenues from “taxes” imposed on the people who live in its territories. Perhaps the most incongruous element of the resolution is that one of its sponsors is the government of Syria.

headline: ISIS Carries Out First ‘Serious’ Attack in Northern Iraq in Months, U.S. Says
text: ERBIL, Iraq — Islamic State fighters conducted their most significant military operation in northern Iraq in more than five months when they mounted a three-pronged attack on Wednesday night north and east of Mosul, American officials said Thursday.

headline: Obama Reaches Out to New Audience for News
text: Over the course of seven years in office, President Obama has periodically invited columnists and other opinion leaders to the White House for off-the-record discussions that sometimes do not stay all that off the record.

headline: Anthony Marshall, Brooke Astor’s Son, Experienced ‘Atrocious’ Treatment at Rikers, His Family Says
text: Anthony D. Marshall spent only a few days at Rikers Island in 2013 before being transferred to an upstate prison to serve his sentence for stealing tens of millions of dollars from his mother, the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor.

headline: Freddie Gray and the Meaning of Justice
text: On Wednesday, a judge in Baltimore declared a mistrial in the case of the first of six officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old man who died of a spinal cord injury sustained in police custody.

headline: Shkreli Indictment Portrays Small-Time Fraud
text: Martin Shkreli told investors that his hedge fund had an auditor, that it had posted a 36 percent return since its inception and that it had $35 million in assets under management.

headline: Canada: Monument Re-evaluated
text: The new Liberal government said Thursday that a monument to the victims of Communism proposed by a private group would not be built next to the Supreme Court. Mélanie Joly, the minister of Canadian heritage, also announced that a national competition would be held to pick a design to replace the current plan, which includes concrete structures dotted with pixels that, in renderings, form an image of a mass grave. Many architects, Ottawa’s mayor and the chief justice of the Supreme Court were among the opponents of the original plan. The design and site were selected largely without public review. The new government said that it would provide only a fraction of the money promised by the Conservatives for the project.

headline: Integrity Takes a Toll at the Port Authority
text: Two years ago this month, Patrick J. Foye, a middle-aged, white-bearded, bespectacled government official little known beyond his workplace and family, arrived at a legislative hearing in Trenton. Under oath, he told a story that provided the first clear view of near-gangsterism at the top levels of one of the region’s most powerful agencies, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Cam Newton and Eli Manning Love to Lead, Though Only One Can Really Dance
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning made a rare departure from his script with reporters Wednesday when asked about Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton’s post-touchdown dance called the dab.

headline: House Approves Bill to End Tax-Free Real Estate Spinoffs
text: Wall Street may have to come up with a new strategy to replace a type of deal that has been popular among activist investors and companies.

headline: Martin Shkreli’s Arrest Gives Drug Makers Cover
text: During his three months as a household name, Martin Shkreli has been a walking, talking (incessantly) personification of one of the pharmaceutical industry’s worst nightmares — the greedy drug company executive.

headline: M.L.B.’s Good-Will Tour of Cuba Is Hardly the Last Word
text: HAVANA — Clayton Kershaw stood on the lawn outside the Hotel Nacional, his profile set against a pink sky as the sun set over the Florida Straits behind him. Kershaw stretched; first his arm, then his back. Baseball in hand, he called to Jose Cruz Jr., a former big leaguer who now works for Major League Baseball’s players’ union, that he was ready to throw. A throng of Cubans watched Kershaw’s every move.

headline: Britain Considers Deflating Power of House of Lords
text: LONDON — Few dispute the need for changes to the House of Lords, Britain’s unelected and scandal-hit upper parliamentary chamber, which is the world’s largest legislative assembly outside China. Most critics complain about the chamber’s increase in number in the past 15 years, now with close to 800 voting members.

headline: Kaiser Permanente Plans to Open a Medical School
text: WASHINGTON — Kaiser Permanente, the health system based in California that combines a nonprofit insurance plan with its own hospitals and clinics, announced Thursday that it would open its own medical school in the state in 2019.

headline: Police Seek Murder Charges After 2 Dead Children Are Found in California
text: A woman and her teenage companion will face charges of first-degree murder and torture in California after the bodies of two children entrusted to their care were discovered stuffed inside a storage locker over the weekend, law enforcement officials said on Thursday.

headline: Baltimore Is Quiet, but Residents Are Pensive
text: BALTIMORE — The Rev. C. D. Witherspoon, minister at the Judah Worship Center, paced a West Baltimore street corner late Wednesday night, imploring a small group gathered around him to stave off a feeling he believed city leaders wanted residents to have: apathy.

headline: New York City to Pay $2.75 Million in Wrongful-Conviction Settlement
text: New York City has agreed to pay $2.75 million to settle a wrongful-conviction lawsuit, the city’s Law Department said on Thursday, in a case that prompted philosophical questions about the meaning of a guilty plea.

headline: Tag Line
text: Administrivial Will Shortz Sighting Alert! Tune in to tonight’s episode of “Jeopardy!” to watch Will Shortz read clues in a special “New York Times Crossword” category. All of the clues are drawn from puzzles you’ve solved this week, so if you were ever going to put money on your ability to answer the questions, this would be a good time to do it.

headline: Apple Pay Is Set to Arrive in China
text: Apple is introducing its mobile payments platform, Apple Pay, in China early next year, a move that will significantly broaden the service’s audience.

headline: Peter Dickinson, Author, Dies at 88; Master Plotter Relished a Good Puzzle
text: Peter Dickinson, an award-winning British mystery writer whose books for adults and children often crossed the boundaries separating the genres of crime, adventure, science fiction, fantasy and suspense, died on Wednesday, his 88th birthday, in Winchester, Hampshire, England.

headline: Voters Could Decide Next Year on Allowing Casinos in North Jersey
text: Voters in New Jersey may get to decide next year whether to allow two casinos to open in the northern part of the state, 40 years after legalized gambling was limited to Atlantic City.

headline: At Prestigious Rhode Island School, an Investigation Into Sexual Abuse
text: BOSTON — The prestigious St. George’s School in Rhode Island has been investigating what it says are “multiple credible reports” of sexual abuse of students in the 1970s and ’80s by three former employees, and said in a statement that its investigation was nearing an end.

headline: F.C.C. Asks Comcast, AT&T and T-Mobile About ‘Zero-Rating’ Services
text: The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday it was exploring whether new services from Comcast, T-Mobile USA and and AT&T violate net neutrality rules.

headline: Nancy Spector Joins Brooklyn Museum as Chief Curator
text: The Brooklyn Museum’s new director, Anne Pasternak — who has been rapidly shaking up its galleries and programming in the four months since she took over — announced on Thursday that Nancy Spector, the longtime chief curator at the Guggenheim Museum and a highly respected voice in contemporary art, would become her new chief curator.

headline: Beijing Issues a Second ‘Red Alert’ on Pollution
text: BEIJING — The Chinese capital issued a “red alert” for air pollution on Friday morning, saying it was enacting for the second time the highest-level emergency pollution plan in advance of a prolonged spell of smog that is predicted to smother Beijing and elsewhere in northern China this weekend. The crisis measures were expected to start Saturday and last for four days.

text: A suspect escaped from police custody in Lower Manhattan on Thursday and ran into a subway station, prompting the authorities to temporarily halt train service as they searched for him, officials said.

headline: Putting Her Son's Well-Being First
text: Many people feel the tug between family and work. Tawana Gilbert left her job as an accounting supervisor and spent her retirement savings to help keep her teenage son from slipping into drug addiction.

text: The comedian Bill Burr remembers when nothing could come between a man and his TV in Netflix’s new animated comedy. Lady Gaga is named Billboard’s woman of the year. And Thackery bucks the system on “The Knick.”

headline: Editors’ Note: December 18, 2015
text: A front-page article on Sunday, based on accounts from law-enforcement officials, reported that before entering the United States, Tashfeen Malik, one of the San Bernardino attackers, had “talked openly on social media” about her support for violent jihad.

text: “For us, she’s a Halley’s comet of sport, a teenager who’s tremendously gifted in both mind and body. With that talent and drive, we’re betting that she can be the fastest woman in the world someday.”

headline: A Theater in China That Brings Art, and Dwarfs, Out of the Shadows

headline: Democrats and Bernie Sanders Clash Over Data Breach
text: The dispute came after members of Senator Bernie Sanders’s data team were found to have gotten access to proprietary information from Hillary Clinton’s team during a software glitch with an important voter file.

headline: A Pause to Weigh Risks of Gene Editing
text: The technology for altering defects in the human genome has progressed so rapidly in the last three years that it has outstripped the ability of scientists and ethicists to understand and cope with the consequences. An international panel of experts has wisely called for a pause in using the technique to produce genetic changes that could be inherited by future generations. That would allow time to assess risks and benefits, they said, and develop a “broad societal consensus” on the work.

headline: The 2015 Sidney Awards
text: It is time once again for the Sidney Awards, when I pick out some of the best long-form essays that you might download for your holiday reading pleasure. This year there were so many fine pieces it’s impossible to read them all without totally ignoring your family.

headline: What Went Wrong With Navy SEALs
text: The mission of the American military in Afghanistan was always devilishly complex: a combination of guerrilla warfare, social outreach, military training and institution-building in a forbidding and often hostile land. But it was criminal and inexcusable that Navy SEALs assigned to train Afghan police officers in the village of Kalach joined the police in viciously beating detainees who had been taken into custody after a bomb blast killed a policeman. One was assaulted so badly that he died.

headline: Haunted by Waters
text: You stand in the mist and roar of Snoqualmie Falls, more than 100 feet higher than Niagara, and feel the liquid power of the Cascade Mountains crashing down. It’s been raining, seemingly nonstop, for at least a month in the Pacific Northwest, and this is the payoff. Hope is 4,000 cubic feet of water per second, going off a cliff.

headline: ‘The Big Short,’ Housing Bubbles and Retold Lies
text: In May 2009 Congress created a special commission to examine the causes of the financial crisis. The idea was to emulate the celebrated Pecora Commission of the 1930s, which used careful historical analysis to help craft regulations that gave America two generations of financial stability.

headline: The Problem With Focusing on Childhood Obesity
text: THERE is good news in the fight against obesity: Rates are finally falling in young children. The bad news? They’re continuing to rise to new heights in adults.

headline: Horror Stories From New York State Prisons
text: The Justice Department hauled New York City into court last year when it failed to curb the wanton brutality that has long been a hallmark among guards at the Rikers Island jail complex. The same culture of violence infests the sprawling state prison system, where guards batter inmates for sport knowing that their union will protect their jobs and that district attorneys in small towns dominated by prisons will not prosecute them. Sustained and vigorous federal pressure will be needed to change this deplorable system, and even then, it won’t be enough without leadership and commitment from New York’s top political figures.

headline: After Years of War in Syria, U.N. Passes Resolution on Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — For the first time since the nearly five-year-old Syrian civil war began, world powers agreed on Friday at the United Nations Security Council to embrace a plan for a cease-fire and a peace process that holds the distant prospect of ending the conflict.

headline: Zurich Insurance to Pay Up to $1.05 Billion for Crop Insurer
text: LONDON — Zurich Insurance Group said on Friday that it had agreed to pay as much as $1.05 billion to buy the United States agricultural insurer known as Rural Community Insurance Services from Wells Fargo.

Carter said Friday.

headline: In New York, the Fireplace Flickers
text: In New York, an apartment fireplace evokes an escape from the bustling streets, the comforting after-work notion of settling into a high-back chair with a snifter of brandy — even if the chimney was sealed long ago.

headline: Wrestling’s Daily Struggle in Guatemala
text: Everyone loves a winner. But as everyone knows, somebody has to lose. Indeed, for Guatemala City’s wrestlers, life itself is a daily struggle against defeat on all of life’s fronts. That realization came to Jorge Luis Chavarría when he started photographing the masked luchadores who grappled more for love than for money. If anything, he found himself wondering about the losers right at the moment of defeat.

headline: Fashion’s Gaze Turned to Joan Didion in 2015

headline: How to Eulogize Someone You’ve Never Met
text: ‘‘All people have a story,’’ Chris Ponnet says. ‘‘It’s your job to find it.’’ For more than a decade, Ponnet, the director of spiritual care at the Los Angeles County­-U.S.C. Medical Center, one of the largest public hospitals in the country, has been leading the annual memorial service for many hundreds of people who die in Los Angeles County whose remains go unclaimed. He eulogizes immigrants, homeless people, AIDS patients, young men killed in gang shootouts, sometimes babies who die before being named.

headline: Preserving David Ireland’s Home in All Its Marred Glory

headline: The Identity Thief
text: When my best friend and I go to our favorite cafe in the Cihangir neighborhood near Taksim Square, in Istanbul, I usually get tavsan kanı. Known as ‘‘rabbit’s blood,’’ it’s just watered-down Turkish tea, served in a small tulip glass. I quit coffee and cigarettes a year ago, and generally I don’t feel the need for them anymore. But then one beautiful day this summer, we came across a certain family of beggars in the square.
