headline: As Oil Money Melts, Alaska Mulls First Income Tax in 35 Years
text: ANCHORAGE — Oil money no longer pays the bills here.

headline: In Betsy Podlach’s Sensual Portraits, an Undercurrent of Love
text: In his poem “As I Walked Out One Evening,” W. H. Auden wrote: “And down by the brimming river/ I heard a lover sing/ Under an arch of the railway:/ ‘Love has no ending … .’”

headline: An Artist of Bears, Caterpillars and Friends
text: In Eric Carle’s 2013 picture book “Friends,” the illustrator takes a little boy on a solo journey across a river, over a mountain, through a meadow, above the clouds and into forests to reconnect with a friend who moved away.

headline: Final Note for Crossroads Music, a Local Hangout in Amagansett
text: On a recent Sunday afternoon in Amagansett, Roddy Thompson, a musician from Tupelo, Miss., strolled into Crossroads Music, an instrument store, school, and general music-lover’s hangout. He sat on a bench in the sunny room, picked up a guitar and started to strum an original tune.

headline: Soaking Up the Christmas Warmth
text: Short sleeves and ice cream cones were among the peculiar sights around New York City as springlike weather lingered on Christmas Day.

headline: Warhol and Mapplethorpe: Exploring Gender as Disguise and Identity
text: On a small wall in “Warhol & Mapplethorpe: Guise & Dolls,” at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, a photographic portrait of Andy Warhol by Robert Mapplethorpe hangs beside a silk-screened portrait of Robert Mapplethorpe by Andy Warhol. Both are head shots; both men gaze directly at the viewer. Mapplethorpe placed Warhol’s face in the center of a cruciform frame and encircled his head with a saintly glow, while Warhol saturated Mapplethorpe’s image in a deep, devilish red.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Ad Offers Conservatives Red Meat on God and Guns
text: Increasing his presence on television screens in Iowa, Senator Ted Cruz released a new ad, titled “Victories,” portraying him as a successful fighter for conservative causes.

headline: Kobe Bryant, Despite Struggles, Has Big Lead in All-Star Voting
text: Kobe Bryant, who plans to retire after the season, is the leading All-Star vote-getter by far, the N.B.A. said Friday in announcing the first returns.

headline: Turkish President Erdogan Dissuades Man From Jumping Off Bridge
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s president has often been described as a rhetorical tactician and “man of the people” who excels at rebuttals and rejoinders when challenged by critics on almost any issue. But on Friday, the president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, used his skills of verbal persuasion to save a despondent man as he sought to jump off the Bosporus Bridge here.

headline: Political Dark Money Just Got Darker
text: As untold millions of dollars pour into the shadowy campaign troughs of the presidential candidates, voters need to be reminded of the rosy assumptions of the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision that legitimized the new spending frenzy.

headline: Put Reforms Into State Prison Guards’ Contract
text: In New York State, some prison guards may well feel free to beat prisoners nearly to death because their union contract, which expires at the end of March, protects even the worst of them from being fired, disciplined or moved into jobs where they could do less harm.

headline: Candidates’ Children in the Peanut Gallery
text: Presidential candidates’ children and grandchildren are turning up once again. Ted Cruz’s decision to cast his daughters in an attack ad and Hillary Clinton’s “just like your abuela” misfire make one wonder anew, Why do candidates seek advantage by shoving the next generations center stage while insisting that they remain politically off limits?

headline: The 2-Year Law Education Fails to Take Off
text: A quicker, cheaper law degree — which got a major vote of confidence when President Obama, a lawyer and former law professor, unexpectedly endorsed it in August 2013 — has been widely promoted  as an ideal way to slash growing student debt and give beginning lawyers a leg up in a difficult job market.

headline: Protégé of Clintons Targets U.S. Congressional Seat
text: A cluster of political donors gathered in the downtown Little Rock, Ark., office of Wesley K. Clark earlier this month, listening closely as the retired general praised a Democratic candidate for Congress in effusive terms.

headline: Iran: Relatives Visit a Jailed Reporter
text: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been incarcerated in Iran since July 2014, was permitted an extended visit with his wife and mother on Friday in what appeared to be a Christmas gesture by the Iranian authorities. Mr. Rezaian, 39, a California native, has been accused of espionage and other hostile acts, charges that he and his supporters say are unfounded. His mother, Mary Rezaian, and his wife, Yeganeh Salehi, shared a home-cooked meal with him at Evin Prison in Tehran, according to an account Mrs. Rezaian relayed to her other son, Ali Rezaian, in the United States. “It was the longest meeting with him since she arrived last December,” Ali Rezaian said in an email. Martin Baron, The Post’s executive editor, said in a statement that he welcomed the gesture but said Iran should release Mr. Rezaian “and allow him a return to life as a free man who can spend time with his family where and whenever he pleases.”

headline: Iraq: Leading Cleric Urges Release of Kidnapped Qatari Hunters
text: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq’s most important Shiite cleric, on Friday called for the immediate release of a group of at least 26 Qatari hunters who were abducted while on a government-approved safari in southern Iraq more than a week ago. Ayatollah Sistani’s statement, released through his representative, Ahmed al-Safi, in the holy city of Karbala, said that “the central government must help to free all the abducted hunters” and called the kidnapping wrong and bound to “harm the country’s reputation.” No group has claimed responsibility for the seizure of the Qataris, who included some members of Qatar’s royal family. The ayatollah, whose proclamations are influential among Iraq’s Shiite majority, spoke a day after Arab League foreign ministers also called for the release of the captives. There has been speculation that Shiite militias in southern Iraq are responsible.

headline: With Added Distance, Extra Points Become Less Than Automatic
text: When Jacksonville Jaguars kicker Jason Myers blasted a kickoff through the uprights, moments after missing his seventh extra-point attempt of the season in a Week 14 win over the Indianapolis Colts, the home crowd gave him a sarcastic ovation, prompting him to slam his helmet into an equipment bag.

headline: 192 Days Later, Cavaliers Again Fall to Warriors
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — David Blatt, the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, was on the team bus heading to Oracle Arena on Friday morning when he had the strange sensation that he had just left this place. How long had it actually been since the Golden State Warriors ousted the Cavaliers in the N.B.A. finals? To Blatt, it felt like yesterday.

headline: FedEx Is Hit With Delays After Storms Across South
text: Heavy demand and bad storms delayed some holiday deliveries at FedEx, forcing the carrier to add extra staffing on Christmas Day.

headline: A Festival of Language for the Good of Yiddish
text: On a stretch of the East Village, New York City’s Christmas hush was interrupted by a peculiar melody. It was not a Bing Crosby croon or Mariah Carey’s melismatic whistle, but the faint hum of a clarinet playing along to “Undzer Nigndl.”

headline: A Sailing Event Down Under Suddenly Gains a Global Reach
text: Before sailing in Australia’s great race, which started on Saturday in Sydney and will end in Hobart, the competitors and their yachts had to get to Sydney.

headline: 11 Wins May Not Be Enough for a Playoff Spot, but 7 May Be

Such a question led us to build our N.F.L. simulator, which can be found at nytimes.com/sports, allowing you to explore which games matter the most for your team’s playoff chances.

headline: City Hall, a Restaurant Hangout for Officials in TriBeCa, Is Closing
text: City Hall is closing — the restaurant at 131 Duane Street in TriBeCa in Manhattan, not City Hall, the seat of government a couple of blocks away.

headline: Robert D. Douglas Jr., Eagle Scout Elder and Adventurer, Dies at 103
text: Robert Dick Douglas Jr., who joined the Boy Scouts on his 12th birthday in 1924 and by 17 had shot a lion on safari in Africa, hunted whales and grizzly bears in Alaska and written two books on his adventures, died on Wednesday in Greensboro, N.C. He was 103 and one of the nation’s oldest Eagle Scouts.

headline: Alabama Declares State of Emergency as Flooding From Storms Continues
text: ATLANTA — Gov. Robert Bentley of Alabama declared a state of emergency on Friday as heavy rain and flooding paralyzed areas in the central and northern parts of the state.

headline: Kiss of the Dragon
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Maybe it’s because it’s the holiday season, maybe I’m just getting better at these Saturdays, but this one fell pretty quickly for me. I’m betting that it’s because there was just enough pop culture in it to give me a leg up and make this puzzle by James Mulhern fun to solve.

headline: Woman Draws From Her Own Struggles to Help Others Find Work
text: Boredom was a powerful motivator for Chanelle Williams.

headline: Returning to His Bronx Neighborhood on Christmas Eve, a Teenager Is Fatally Shot
text: The young couple spent much of the evening on a porch, enjoying the warmth of a tropical December night, as the first hours of Christmas approached in the Bronx.

headline: Meant as Homage, Bar’s Naming for Downtown Squatter Is Perceived as a Slight

headline: The Times Square Ball Drop, in Times Past
text: New York Times photographers documented the tension and release of the annual gathering.

headline: New Year’s Eve, Times Square, Through the Years
text: What’s so special about New Year’s Eve? Plenty. For starters, photographs of the event rarely show happy families gathered together to celebrate. It’s not that kind of occasion. Alone among American holidays, New Year’s is a time for family members to run to their separate corners: grown-ups to do stuff that might charitably be called childish, and children to try on the rituals of adults.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: On this Boxing Day, you may still be at the house of friends or family. You may not be able to figure out how to use their remote control. So stream new additions to Netflix and use the last days of the year to watch “Almost Famous” and “Zoolander” before they are taken down on New Year’s Day.

headline: Patricia Field Hangs Up Her Retail Wig
text: “Do you mind if I have a cigarette?” Patricia Field asked, though the deep gravel of her voice indicated that the question was rhetorical. She was sitting in the basement office of her eponymous boutique at 306 Bowery, wearing a black tank-top, dark capri pants and heavy blue mascara that complemented her trademark vermilion hair: a punk knockout at 73.

headline: Breaking Up? Let an App Do It for You
text: Checklist for the holidays: Buy bejeweled 2016 eyeglasses and noisemakers from street vendor. Stock Champagne. Regift perfume and sweaters. Turn Christmas tree into mulch. And, oh yes, break up with significant other.

headline: Going Cashless in Sweden
text: Few countries are tilting toward a cashless future as quickly as Sweden, where parishioners text tithes to their churches and street vendors carry card readers.

headline: In Sweden, a Cash-Free Future Nears
text: STOCKHOLM — Parishioners text tithes to their churches. Homeless street vendors carry mobile credit-card readers. Even the Abba Museum, despite being a shrine to the 1970s pop group that wrote “Money, Money, Money,” considers cash so last-century that it does not accept bills and coins.

headline: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman

headline: Variety: A Determined Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — For most people, the old tradition of making New Year’s resolutions is not filled with FESTIVITY. Who wants to think about having to be a better person than you already are, and then project that out over the course of an entire year at that? It’s overwhelming.

headline: Christie Spins His Version of Security Record on Trail
text: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Chris Christie has sought to differentiate himself by spotlighting his tenure as the United States attorney for New Jersey, framing it as a time when he spent his “life protecting our country” against terrorism. The message has begun to resonate: Mr. Christie, long an underdog in the Republican presidential field, has recently risen in the polls.

headline: Man Kills Family and Then Shoots Himself in New Jersey

headline: A Janitor, Once an Addict, Cleans Up His Life
text: When Eric Gonzalez started working as a custodian on East 125th Street in Harlem for a local merchant’s association earlier this year, the hardest part was not hauling trash or sweeping gutters. It was dealing with the K2 addicts.

headline: An Entrepreneur Juggles Six Companies and One Worker: Herself

headline: After a Difficult Start, a Jets Receiver Prepares, Stays Alert and Rises

When he enters the locker room, none of his teammates are inside, not even his fellow receiver Brandon Marshall, who was astounded to discover that someone could beat him there.

headline: Don’t Abandon Puerto Rico
text: The leaders of Puerto Rico could soon have to choose between cutting essential services like the police, hospitals and education, and paying bondholders. To avoid this catastrophe, Congress needs to help the island, which is home to 3.5 million American citizens, by giving it the ability to restructure its debts in an orderly way.

headline: The Real Victims of Victimhood
text: BACK in 1993, the misanthropic art critic Robert Hughes published a grumpy, entertaining book called “Culture of Complaint,” in which he predicted that America was doomed to become increasingly an “infantilized culture” of victimhood. It was a rant against what he saw as a grievance industry appearing all across the political spectrum.

headline: A Fearful Congress Sits Out the War Against ISIS
text: The  omnibus spending bill Congress passed this month includes several explicit mentions of the military campaign against the Islamic State and a $58.7 billion budget line that will allow the Pentagon to continue fighting the terrorist group in Iraq and Syria with bombs and, increasingly, troops on the ground.

headline: Cracks in the Liberal Order
text: IN the twenty-five years since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the architecture of liberal modernity has looked relatively stable. Not flawless or wonderful or ideal, to be sure; not free of discontents and decadence. But it’s been hard to imagine the basic liberal democratic capitalist order cracking up, let alone envision what might take its place.

headline: New Minimum Wages in the New Year
text: In five states and nine cities — including California, New York, Oregon and Washington, D.C. — voters and lawmakers will consider proposals in 2016 to gradually raise minimum wages to $15 an hour.

headline: Doubling Down On W
text: As I’ve said, it’s hard these days for liberals to look at the state of the Republican primary without feeling a lot of Trumpenfreude. But one downside of The Donald’s turn in the spotlight is that the policy positions of the tonsorially conventional candidates are going largely unscrutinized, which is bad. For the fact is that the whole field has taken a hard right turn into fantasyland.

headline: Kentucky Survives Close Call Against Louisville
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — At one point in the second half, Kentucky Coach John Calipari was so animated after a failed offensive sequence that he tripped and fell backward into his bench.

headline: Binary Code
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It seems like the year just flew by, doesn’t it? Yet here we are, at the final Sunday crossword puzzle for 2015. We’ve played with a lot of words this year, but today we get to break that down even further and play with some of the letters that make up those words.

headline: Noboru Ando, 89, Mobster and Film Star in Japan, Dies
text: Noboru Ando, a yakuza, or mobster, who made a seamless transition from gang leader to movie star in dozens of Japanese crime films of the 1960s and ’70s, died on Dec. 16 in Tokyo. He was 89.

headline: Lewis M. Dabney, Who Devoted Life’s Work to Edmund Wilson, Dies at 83
text: Lewis M. Dabney, a literary scholar whose doctoral dissertation at Columbia steered his path to becoming perhaps the pre-eminent expert on the life and work of Edmund Wilson, died on Tuesday at his home in Easton, Md. He was 83.

headline: South Carolina Faces the High Cost of Curating History’s Dustbin
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — After decades of debate in South Carolina over the Confederate battle flag, it seemed the matter had been settled in July, when state officials stopped flying the flag on State House grounds and relegated it to a museum for “appropriate display.”

headline: Chicago Police Fatally Shoot 2, Raising New Questions for a Force Under Scrutiny
text: CHICAGO — The police fatally shot a man and a woman on Chicago’s West Side early Saturday, setting off a new flurry of questions about a department already under intense scrutiny.

headline: ISIS, Facing Losses, Releases Recording Said to Be of Leader
text: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State on Saturday released an audio recording of a speech purportedly made by the organization’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, in which he implored more Muslims to fight on behalf of his increasingly besieged group.

headline: Robert Spitzer, 83, Dies; Psychiatrist Set Rigorous Standards for Diagnosis
text: Dr. Robert L. Spitzer, who gave psychiatry its first set of rigorous standards to describe mental disorders, providing a framework for diagnosis, research and legal judgments — as well as a lingua franca for the endless social debate over where to draw the line between normal and abnormal behavior — died on Friday in Seattle. He was 83.

headline: Duke Wins at Yankee Stadium (Attendance Isn’t Exactly Out of the Park)
text: Duke outlasted Indiana in overtime, 44-41, under leaden skies at Yankee Stadium on Saturday to win the sixth Pinstripe Bowl, but an eagerly awaited number of higher importance, at least to the baseball team that runs the show, was announced in the second quarter: 37,218.

headline: Eight Dead as Tornadoes Strike the Dallas Area
text: At least eight people were killed in the Dallas area Saturday night when as many as 11 tornadoes swept North Texas, officials said.

headline: Severe Weather Across the U.S.
text: Severe weather across the United States over the holiday weekend.

headline: Drought Deepens South Africa’s Malaise
text: SETLAGOLE, South Africa — Under a midmorning sun that augured punishing heat later in the day, a handful of cows stood still inside a small pen, their ribs protruding. Too weak to reach the nearest grassy field some miles away, some munched on tall grass that their owner had cut from a strip of land along the highway, in a desperate attempt to save his cattle from the drought afflicting the land.

headline: Schools Evaluate Threats, Questioning When to Shut Down
text: Mark Conrad, the superintendent of schools in Nashua, N.H., got the chilling news last Sunday morning. An email sent to a school board member threatened a lethal attack on multiple schools, naming the sites, how students would be harmed and the date, Dec. 21 — the next day.

headline: Veteran International Prosecutor Foresees War Crimes Trials for ISIS
text: THE HAGUE — Stephen J. Rapp, a veteran American lawyer and a familiar figure in international courts, was doing what he most favors — talking about war crimes. Not just citing conflicts that demand the world’s attention, but also discussing how to pursue top offenders.

headline: David Hopmann, James Taul Jr.
text: David Edward Hopmann and James Wiley Taul Jr. were married Dec. 21 in the rotunda of San Francisco’s City Hall by the Rev. Richard Wilmington, an Episcopal priest.

headline: Shera Fingerman and Raimy Amasha: Prescribing Love for a Doctor

headline: Lauren Levy, Simon Bangiyev

Kouris and Petros S. Kouris of Fresh Meadows, Queens. The Rev. Chrysostomos Gilbert is to perform the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in Manhattan.

headline: Riddhima Gandhi, Neil Mehta

Mehta and Dinesh C. Mehta of Great Falls, Va. O. P. Bunkar, the marriage officer and additional district magistrate of Udaipur, officiated at the Leela Palace, a hotel there. Pandit Rajunikant Vyas led the Hindu religious ceremony that day, also at the Leela Palace, which is on Lake Pichola.

headline: Anxiety Aside, New York Sees Drop in Crime
text: Homeless encampments proliferated. Two officers, confronting armed men, were shot and killed. And many New Yorkers said they felt less safe.

headline: India Offers Atypical Video Challenges
text: MUMBAI — As the morning rain dripped in the garden outside, the yoga teacher Aparajita Jamwal got down on one knee, stretching the other leg behind her in a lunge known as the equestrian pose.

headline: ISIS Influence on Web Prompts Second Thoughts on First Amendment
text: It is one of the most hallowed precepts in modern constitutional law: Freedom of speech may not be curbed unless it poses a “clear and present danger” — an actual, imminent threat, not the mere advocacy of harmful acts or ideas. But in response to the Islamic State’s success in grooming jihadists over the Internet, some legal scholars are asking whether it is time to reconsider that constitutional line.

headline: Common Stock Ownership Spreads Among Start-Up Investors
text: When institutional investors put money into companies backed by venture capital, they typically end up owning a type of stock called preferred shares. Now, institutional investors are also becoming owners of a different class of start-up stock: common shares.

text: On the weekend after Thanksgiving, my daughter met her: my former husband’s new girlfriend.

headline: State-Level Brawls Over Medicaid Reflect Divide in G.O.P.
text: WASHINGTON — John Thune of South Dakota, the No. 3 Republican in the Senate, voted earlier this month to repeal major provisions of the Affordable Care Act and to end its expansion of Medicaid, arguing that the health law was “unpopular and unaffordable.”

headline: How Hillary Clinton Went Undercover to Examine Race in Education
text: DOTHAN, Ala. — On a humid summer day in 1972, Hillary Rodham walked into this town’s new private academy, a couple of cinder-block classrooms erected hurriedly amid fields of farmland, and pretended to be someone else.

headline: 1940: England Seeks U.S. Accord on Orient Defense
text: LONDON — While defending these islands from German air attacks, hunting submarines in the Atlantic and hammering Italy in the Mediterranean, the British are not abandoning hope that the United States will be able to take effective but nonmilitary action in the Pacific, which the British could reinforce for the defense of Anglo-American interests against Japanese encroachments.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Teaching Young People in the South Bronx to Heal One Another
text: Half a lifetime ago, Dr. Edward Eismann walked down Fox Street in the South Bronx and found a world that was unraveling. Buildings burned and crumbled, their residents sent into exile or oblivion. Those left behind had to confront the wave of poverty, gangs and drugs that swept through.

headline: Tornadoes Leave Paths of Rubble and 11 Dead in the Dallas Area
text: GARLAND, Tex. — Travis Koscheski said he was alone in his apartment here when he was first alerted to the approaching danger by “the classic train sound.”

headline: 1965: Egypt Feels the Economic Pinch
text: CAIRO — Unheard of things are happening in Egypt. For the first time in 13 years since the revolution, there is no talk of pie in the sky and a glorious socialistic future just around the corner. Instead, the masses are being told to tighten their belts today and that tomorrow may be grimmer, not better.

headline: Peyton Manning Rejects Report Linking Him to Doping
text: Mounting an aggressive campaign against a report that linked him to performance-enhancing drugs, Denver Broncos quarterback Peyton Manning said Saturday night that he was treated at an anti-aging clinic in Indianapolis in 2011 while recovering from a neck injury but that the treatment was prescribed by his physician and did not involve any banned substances.

headline: Rahm Emanuel, Under Siege in Chicago, Shows Contrite Side
text: CHICAGO — GQ, the men’s magazine, just named Mayor Rahm Emanuel to its list of “The Worst People of 2015.” In Springfield, the Illinois capital, a fellow Democrat is pressing for a measure to permit Mr. Emanuel’s recall from office. And here, demonstrators bearing thousands of signatures last week demanded Mr. Emanuel’s resignation, then blocked traffic on Christmas Eve along the city’s glittering North Michigan Avenue shopping district, chanting, “Rahm’s got to go in 2016!”

headline: British Army Is Deployed as Flooding Submerges Northern England
text: LONDON — The British Army stepped in on Sunday to help evacuate hundreds of people from waterlogged homes across the country, as swollen rivers and heavy rainfall brought misery to parts of the north and unleashed a spate of political recriminations.

headline: A Manhattan Theft Rooted in a Tale of Songwriting, Sinatra and Cigars
text: The story of the thief who walked out of an expensive Manhattan cigar store with four boxes of medium-blend Dominicans last month actually begins decades earlier, before he was born. It starts in the 1960s, with an encounter between two men that would change both their lives. One of those men was Avo Uvezian, an Armenian jazz musician living in New York City. The other was also a musician, from New Jersey, named Frank Sinatra.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Tilt Kids Festival Announces Lineup of Arts Events for Children
text: Five premieres spread across a variety of disciplines, from theater to dance, are in store for the inaugural Tilt Kids Festival, a collaboration between the French Institute Alliance Française and Cultural Services of the French Embassy.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Should old television be forgot and never brought to mind? Not in what our critic James Poniewozik calls, if not the best, “the most TV year ever.” Enjoy the lull before New Year’s Eve by watching a few of our critics’ year-end top television picks.

headline: Vichy Yearns to Shed Heavy Yoke of Past Shame
text: VICHY, France — Perhaps this small city could be forgiven for thinking, 70 years after the end of World War II, that it might be thought of as something other than the capital of the collaborationist government of Marshal Philippe Pétain.

headline: Desperate Gaza Escape Attempt Leads to Death, and Recriminations
text: GAZA — Something drove Ishaq Khalil Hassan, 28, into the Mediterranean last week, to walk naked in the shallow surf, to attempt what has become all but impossible for Palestinians: an escape from the Gaza Strip.

headline: ‘Star Wars’ Dominates Box Office But ‘Daddy’ Shows Strength, Too
text: LOS ANGELES – Seven major movies braved wide or limited releases against “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” over the Christmas weekend, and all but one – “Point Break” – found initial success, even if several prestige films still have a lot to prove.

headline: Obama The Job-Killer
text: Given the GOP field’s collective decision to go for Bushonomics squared, it seemed like a good time to update this chart.

text: Ramin Karimloo (“Les Misérables”) and Cheyenne Jackson (“Finian’s Rainbow,” TV’s “American Horror Story: Hotel”) will play brothers looking after an orphaned Sydney Lucas (“Fun Home”) in an upcoming concert performance of the 1991 musical adaptation of “The Secret Garden.”

headline: Last Refuge From Taliban for Afghans May Prove No Refuge at All
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Fleeing the encroaching front line in the embattled southern Helmand Province, Haji Abdul Qudus has moved his family many times this year, ending up at a rented home in Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital.

headline: With Flip of Fortune, Jets Top Patriots and Inject Life Into Playoff Hopes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets’ captains strode to midfield, listened to the rules of overtime and waited for the vagaries of a flipped coin to determine their season.

headline: Panthers, Leading League in Wins and Dances, Have Their First Misstep
text: ATLANTA — It was a long way down for the Carolina Panthers on Sunday. Carolina, a team that routinely, some say excessively, prances about the sidelines in celebration, finally felt the sting of a loss after 14 straight wins this season. Losses are not taken easily around the N.F.L., but the Panthers’ locker room was unusually subdued, as if the music were accidentally halted at the height of a party.

headline: Presidential Primaries May Hold Key in Senate Races
text: In 2014, Democrats, the majority party in the Senate, had to defend most of the seats up for election, more than a few in unfriendly territory. That year, Republicans took back control of the chamber, picking up nine seats.

headline: Haskell Wexler, Oscar-Winning Cinematographer, Dies at 93
text: Haskell Wexler, who was renowned as one of the most inventive cinematographers in Hollywood and an outspoken political firebrand, died on Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 93.

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ With Wayne Brady as a Cross-Dresser You Could Take Home to Mother
text: Is it true that drag queens have more fun? On the evidence of Wayne Brady’s performance these days at the Al Hirschfeld Theater, the answer is “yes,” to be written in glittery capital letters and perhaps adorned with a special push-up bra for the letter E. And it’s a lesson that a mainstream American audience seems more than willing to embrace

headline: Review: New York String Orchestra Offers Youthful Energy and a Lush Sound
text: For decades now, the influence of the historically informed performance movement has left its mark not just on the tempo and style with which works are performed but on the size of the ensembles, too. When a program includes a concerto from the classical era, most modern symphony orchestras will now send a few rows of string players backstage to sit out the performance.

headline: Review: In ‘Feel the Bernhard,’ Sandra Feels Less Menacing
text: The claws have been retracted, but the attitude remains the same: a complicated mixture of sarcasm, curdled sweetness and contempt. That describes the comedian and singer Sandra Bernhard, now 60 (but looking two decades younger), who opened her annual end-of-the-year engagement on Saturday evening at Joe’s Pub with a new show, “Feel the Bernhard.”

headline: Review: ‘East of Salinas,’ on PBS, Tells a Migrant Boy’s Story
text: At the end of “East of Salinas,” Monday night’s “Independent Lens” film on PBS, a title card puts the story we have just seen about a migrant boy named José Ansaldo into statistical context.

headline: Texas Tornadoes Leave Path of Destruction
text: Eleven tornadoes struck North Texas on Saturday, and at least 11 people were killed.

headline: Jennifer Jason Leigh Appears on Two Screens With Few Similarities
text: LOS ANGELES — It’s hard to imagine two more different roles than the ones Jennifer Jason Leigh takes on in movies closing out 2015.

headline: Review: In ‘Ardennes 1944: The Battle of the Bulge,’ Antony Beevor Is on Familiar Ground
text: For Americans who lived through it or were born in its immediate wake, the Battle of the Bulge was as famous as any event of World War II. It evoked freezing and half-starving G.I.s refusing to surrender a besieged town to an atrocity-prone German army. To younger generations it evokes almost nothing. The British historian Antony Beevor’s “Ardennes 1944: The Battle of the Bulge” may return the Bulge to collective memory by democratizing it, adding the feats and sorrows of obscure men and some unseemly quarrels among famous ones.

headline: Navy Special Force
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Like most artists, crossword constructors benefit from practice. Constructing as many puzzles as possible in order to improve one’s filling and grid design skills is an important part of a constructor’s evolution.

headline: The Year in Music Videos
text: In the beginning, music videos were strictly promotional tools. Then they became the thing itself — a song lacked meaning without an accompanying visual extravaganza. That’s still partly true, especially for the few monoculture superstars and consensus cognoscenti favorites that remain. But video as a medium is now more equal opportunity than ever: Thanks to smartphones, everyone is a director or videographer, and videos can be consumed anywhere, anytime, in six-second loops or two-hour concerts. There are still innovative artist-created music videos, but in the modern age, all the musician can really control is the song — what’s done with it once it’s in the world is anyone’s guess. Here are critics’ picks of the best music videos of 2015. Jon Caramanica

headline: New Unemployment Data, Deadline for Puerto Rico and Markets Wrap 2015
text: Experts expect the number of new unemployment claims to be at a healthy level in terms of the long-term trend, and payments are due for financially challenged Puerto Rico.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Dec. 28
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on China’s Priorities
text: China’s disregard for safety standards is marring the success story of its economic growth.

headline: Using Lasers to Preserve Antiquities Threatened by ISIS
text: Only the bas-relief bull and serpent-dragon gods were present to see the two flak-jacketed German surveyors and their security guards painstakingly moving laser equipment through Iraq’s most famous archaeological site, the ruins of ancient Babylon.

headline: H.I.V. Education That Aims to Empower, Not Shame
text: Thanks to medical advances, a diagnosis of H.I.V., while still very serious, is no longer the death sentence it once was. For organizations trying to communicate information about testing and prevention, though, the devastation the virus has caused over the decades remains ever-present.

headline: F.A.A. Drone Laws Start to Clash With Stricter Local Rules
text: MIAMI — Frank Carollo, a longtime member of the City Council here, had worked for several weeks fine-tuning a proposal to limit the use of recreational drones, the increasingly popular remote-controlled flying devices. Minutes before the start of the vote on the rules this month, lawyers from the Federal Aviation Administration called him.

headline: Mattel Takes a Risk, With Barbie and Bugs
text: As Gerry Cody, a senior design manager at Mattel, cheerfully loaded a live cricket into the driver’s seat of a new toy car, the cricket probably did not have time to wonder how it had gotten to this point.

headline: Argentina’s New President Moves Swiftly to Shake Up the Economy
text: BUENOS AIRES — Mauricio Macri clinched Argentina’s presidency last month by tapping into voters’ fatigue with a leftist political movement that had governed for more than 12 years. Campaigning on a platform of change, and promising to unite feuding factions while largely dodging specific policy proposals, Mr. Macri took 51 percent of the vote.

headline: Customers Mourn Closing of Zaro’s Bakery in Changing Bronx Neighborhood
text: Neville Livan sat at a table in the window of Zaro’s Bread Basket on Sunday morning in the Parkchester neighborhood of the Bronx. Looking toward the door as customers streamed steadily in and out, he sipped a cup of coffee and savored the last minutes of a treasured ritual.

headline: In Hollywood, a Year of Mining the Past for Box-Office Gold
text: LOS ANGELES — “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” took in about $153.5 million in North America over the weekend, for an estimated $545 million total since opening in mid-December, putting Hollywood in position to set a full-year domestic box-office record.

headline: Tied Vote on Catalan Separatist Leader in Spain
text: MADRID — A year of surprising election outcomes in Spain ended on Sunday with a bizarre result: A far-left Catalan party split evenly over whether to keep Artur Mas as the leader of both Catalonia and its secessionist movement.

headline: Families of 2 Fatally Shot by Chicago Police Question Officers’ Training
text: CHICAGO — Standing outside a home where a man and a woman were shot to death by the police, grieving relatives on Sunday demanded changes to the way the police interact with black residents, more training for officers in how to de-escalate tense situations involving possible mental health issues and meaningful discipline for officers who use excessive force.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Rockets at Spurs
text: Do not write the Houston Rockets off just yet. Widely thought to be a contender after a strong showing in last season’s playoffs, Houston has had a mediocre season, struggling on both sides of the ball. The team was further destabilized by the departure of Coach Kevin McHale in November.

headline: George Clayton Johnson, Science Fiction Writer, Dies at 86
text: George Clayton Johnson, who wrote memorable episodes of “The Twilight Zone,” the first televised episode of “Star Trek” and, with William F. Nolan, the novel “Logan’s Run,” often addressing aging and mortality in his work, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Helping Fliers Avoid Change Fees (for a Modest Fee)
text: Such is the state of air travel these days that even the fees have fees.

headline: Kevin Love’s Signature Pass Is Inspired by the Past
text: CLEVELAND — Whenever Kevin Love grabs a defensive rebound, he goes through a series of calculations. First, he spins to look toward the opposite basket. Are any of his teammates with the Cleveland Cavaliers ahead of the defense? If LeBron James has his hand up, for example, that is an instant cue for Love to make one of his favorite plays: the long outlet pass.

headline: Questions on Direction of a Paper in Las Vegas
text: Until a few weeks ago, Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino mogul and Republican party benefactor, was better known for suing newspapers than owning them.

headline: Jets Fan in Patriots’ Backyard Finds Happiness Begins in the Driveway
text: WELLESLEY, Mass. — The provisions — beer, soda, water and munchies — will have been purchased and packed the day before. The folding table with the Jets insignia, the envy of his fellow tailgaters, will also be crammed into the back of Chris Harding’s 2010 silver Honda Pilot.

headline: Obama’s ‘Boots on the Ground’: U.S. Special Forces Are Sent to Tackle Global Threats
text: WASHINGTON — They are taking on a larger combat role in Afghanistan, where the war was supposed to be over. They are headed to Syria to help fight the Islamic State in its stronghold. And President Obama recently ordered nearly 300 of them to Cameroon to assist African troops in their battle against a militant group that has pledged loyalty to the Islamic State.

headline: Remembering Alan Kurdi: Syrian Family’s Tragedy Goes Beyond Image of Boy on Beach
text: ISTANBUL — Friday is the first anniversary of the death of Alan Kurdi, a 2-year-old Syrian refugee whose drowned body was discovered on a beach in Turkey. Photos of the boy shocked the world and put a human face on the refugee crisis. Since then hundreds of children have died in the fighting in Syria and on the refugee trail. Anne Barnard, The Times’ Beirut Bureau chief who leads our coverage in Syria, reported on Alan’s death and his sprawling family’s attempts to escape worn-torn Syria. This article originally ran on Dec. 27, 2015.

headline: Presidential Medal of Freedom Says Something About Presenter, Too
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama was having some fun with Barbra Streisand as he awarded her the Presidential Medal of Freedom at the White House last month.

headline: Elections Are Easy for Queens Prosecutor; Critics Call This a Problem
text: The challenger, a former state legislator threatening the party favorite, was kicked off the primary ballot in a district attorney race in Queens after a judge ruled that the signatures he had gathered were not valid. The man, seeking to beat Richard A. Brown, lost an appeal, paving the way for Mr. Brown to easily defeat a Republican in the heavily Democratic borough.

headline: Jets, Perpetual Victims of Fate, Finally Seize Control of It
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets control their destiny.

headline: In the Wake of Addiction, a Life Bright With Purpose
text: Gloria Paige’s journey toward redemption has been a long one, and the way has not always been certain.

headline: Claims of Peyton Manning H.G.H. Use Raise Nagging Questions
text: Let’s back up this garbage truck. In 2011, we had a 36-year-old quarterback who could not grip a football properly. His triceps had withered, and his right arm had turned into a frail reed. He needed spinal fusion surgery, the insertion of a titanium plate in his neck, and that came on the heels of earlier neck operations.

headline: Ellsworth Kelly, Who Shaped Geometries on a Bold Scale, Dies at 92
text: Ellsworth Kelly, one of America’s great 20th-century abstract artists, who in the years after World War II shaped a distinctive style of American painting by combining the solid shapes and brilliant colors of European abstraction with forms distilled from everyday life, died on Sunday at his home in Spencertown, N.Y. He was 92.

headline: Carson Palmer Cements Comeback in Cardinals’ Romp Over Packers
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Less than three hours before Sunday’s kickoff, Arizona Cardinals quarterback Carson Palmer streaked across the field at University of Phoenix Stadium practically in his birthday suit. Wearing an improvised hula outfit, with kneepads strung together to form a bikini top and a white towel shredded to make a skirt, Palmer made good on a bet he had lost during a weekly postpractice throwing game. The pregame sprint was a prelude to a blissful 36th birthday for Palmer, who led the Cardinals to a 38-8 defeat of the Green Bay Packers.

headline: Monday Night Matchup: Bengals (11-3) at Broncos (10-4)
text: 8:30 p.m., ESPN

headline: Celtics’ Attack Leaves Overmatched Knicks Flailing
text: BOSTON — At 5 feet 9 inches, Isaiah Thomas of the Boston Celtics has developed, when driving to the basket, a fail-safe method for scoring over bigger players — in other words, pretty much everyone else in the league.

headline: The Best of Week 16 in the N.F.L.
text: The Ravens’ Ryan Mallett threw for a career-high 274 yards in his first start for Baltimore, leading his team to a victory over the Steelers. Making his seventh career start, Mallett went 28 for 41, with a touchdown and no interceptions. Signed by the Ravens on Dec. 15, Mallett was the fourth quarterback to start for them in six weeks.

headline: With No Beckham and No Playoff Hopes, Giants Submit to a Beating
text: MINNEAPOLIS — About an hour before kickoff Sunday night, the Giants spread out across 40 yards, taking up nearly half the field to warm up. Coach Tom Coughlin, as he always does, walked briskly through his team’s broad formation, stopping to acknowledge each player individually.

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: The networks are showing classics to distract you from the interminable holiday season. There is escapism (“The Matrix”) and there are escapees (“The Shawshank Redemption”). On Netflix, the comedian Demetri Martin cracks wise.

headline: Meadowlark Lemon Dies at 83; Harlem Globetrotters’ Dazzling Court Jester
text: Meadowlark Lemon, whose halfcourt hook shots, no-look behind-the-back passes and vivid clowning were marquee features of the feel-good traveling basketball show known as the Harlem Globetrotters for nearly a quarter-century, died on Sunday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 83.

headline: As China Hungers for Coal, ‘Behemoth’ Studies the Ravages at the Source
text: BEIJING — The artist and filmmaker Zhao Liang has shed light on some of the darkest corners of Chinese society, filming in locations as obscure as a shantytown here known as the “petitioners’ village” and a military police office on the North Korean border.

headline: Japan and South Korea Settle Dispute Over Wartime ‘Comfort Women’
text: SEOUL, South Korea — More than 70 years after the end of World War II, South Korea and Japan reached a landmark agreement on Monday to resolve their dispute over Korean women who were forced to serve as sex slaves for Japan’s Imperial Army.

headline: Fighting Climate Change With One of the World’s Largest Solar Power Plants
text: In the spring of 2009, in the depths of the Great Recession, the commercial photographer Jamey Stillings was having a hard time. The work had dried up at his Santa Fe, N.M., studio, so he decided to shift gears and put his energies in a different direction.

headline: New York Faces Struggle in Curbing Flophouse Schemes That Victimize Addicts
text: The newly renovated townhouse on Ralph Avenue in Brooklyn was described as being ideal for a family. “Be the first to live in this,” a rental advertisement says.

headline: Fighting Climate Change With One of the World’s Largest Solar Power Plants
text: A detour past a bridge in Nevada led Jamey Stillings to his latest project, a sleek and sprawling solar energy plant, the kind that will be crucial in averting the effects of climate change.

headline: New Tensions Over the Iran Nuclear Deal
text: Newspapers in Tehran have been filled recently with reports of foreigners visiting Iran to discuss the opportunities that will open up once economic sanctions related to the nuclear deal are lifted, presumably early next year. There is a sense of excitement that after years of international isolation, better days await.

headline: When Dying Alone in Prison Is Too Harsh a Sentence
text: MY patient, a man in his 60s, whispered “Gracias, God bless” over and over as I moved his legs during an exam. Our palliative care team had been called in to help manage his pain after his liver cancer recurred. The cancer had already metastasized to his spine, creating pressure on his spinal cord that left him nearly paralyzed from the waist down. He seemed like a felled tree. We found him tearful and scared. But he wasn’t alone.

headline: Which Democrat in 2016?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Doubling Down on W
text: 2015 was, of course, the year of Donald Trump, whose rise has inspired horror among establishment Republicans and, let’s face it, glee — call it Trumpenfreude — among many Democrats. But Trumpism has in one way worked to the G.O.P. establishment’s advantage: it has distracted pundits and the press from the hard right turn even conventional Republican candidates have taken, a turn whose radicalism would have seemed implausible not long ago.

headline: $250,000 a Year Is Not Middle Class
text: HILLARY CLINTON has vowed not to raise taxes on the middle class.

headline: A Maid’s Peaceful Rebellion in Colombia
text: MEDELLÍN, Colombia — The rules for domestic workers were unwritten but clear to everyone back in 1996, when María Roa joined the throngs of Colombian women who fled violence in rural areas and set out to rebuild their lives in the relative safety of big cities.

headline: The Yellowstone of the Future
text: Bozeman, Mont. — PERHAPS, like me, you were among the tens of millions who visited one of our national parks this year. If you did, you most likely shared my appreciation for the foresight of previous generations to set aside treasures like Yellowstone. This legacy of conservation has long served as a point of pride for our country, and rightly so.

headline: New York City Policing, by the Numbers
text: The warnings began even before Bill de Blasio was sworn in as New York City’s mayor in January 2014. A safe New York depended on the aggressive policing tactics that began in the 1990s and flourished under Mayor Michael Bloomberg and his police commissioner, Ray Kelly. Without those tactics, the doomsayers said, the city would be swamped by a 1970s-style crime wave.

headline: Guns and Racism
text: Those of us in favor of stronger laws to abate gun violence mostly support our cause by arguing against the claims of the gun lobby (roughly, the N.R.A. and gun manufacturers). It should by now be obvious that this is a waste of time. The case for action is overwhelming, but there’s no chance of convincing the entrenched minority who are so personally (or financially) invested in gun ownership. Legislative efforts have failed because the opposition is more deeply committed — more energized, more organized, more persistent.

headline: Debates That Got Your Attention
text: Here are the 10 Room for Debate discussions that got the most readers to weigh in with their comments.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Still Trying, Fitfully, to Promote Himself
text: On his 99th day as mayor of New York, Bill de Blasio was asked how he would improve his fledgling administration. “Communicate clearly,” the mayor replied. “Remembering to communicate early and often is the thing I would tell myself to do.”

headline: T.S.A. Moves Closer to Rejecting Some State Driver’s Licenses for Travel
text: As soon as next year, a driver’s license may no longer be enough for airline passengers to clear security in some states, if the Department of Homeland Security has its way.

headline: Jane Sanders Knows Politics, and How to Soften Husband’s Image
text: Jane Sanders, the wife of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, marched with her husband this month through the Baltimore neighborhood of Freddie Gray, the man fatally injured in police custody, and took notes while they met with African-American pastors.

headline: Posture Affects Standing, and Not Just the Physical Kind
text: A distraught wife begged me to write about the importance of good posture. “My husband sits for many hours a day slouched over his computer,” she said. “I’ve told him repeatedly this is bad for his body — he should sit up straight — but he pays no attention to me. He reads you every week. Maybe he’ll listen to you.”

text: As the year ends, the Science desk at The New York Times asked its reporters to choose the stories that were the most memorable. These are the selections, with a focus on health and medicine news.

headline: How Turkey Vultures Stay Aloft to Focus on Dinner
text: Turkey vultures use small-scale air turbulence to stay aloft at forest edges, according to a new study.

headline: Seeking the Gears of Our Inner Clock
text: Throughout the day, a clock ticks inside our bodies. It rouses us in the morning and makes us sleepy at night. It raises and lowers our body temperature at the right times, and regulates the production of insulin and other hormones.

headline: Paul Ryan Highlights G.O.P. Victories in Spending Bill to Try to Curb Complaints
text: House Republicans seem a tad defensive about their year-end budget bill as evidenced by their activities over the holiday break, suggesting that they are hearing complaints about the package at home.

headline: Iraqi Victory Over ISIS in Ramadi Could Prove Pivotal
text: BAGHDAD — Breaking a seven-month occupation by the Islamic State, Iraqi troops on Monday retook most of Ramadi, the most populous city in western Iraq, overrunning a government compound held by the terrorist group at the city center and dealing a setback to its deadly grip on large parts of the country.

headline: China Detains 12 People Over Shenzhen Landslide, Police Say
text: BEIJING — Twelve people have been detained over a debris dumpsite collapse in southern China that left dozens missing, the police there said on Monday. They also said that a former district official whose office approved and oversaw the huge site had committed suicide by jumping from a building.

headline: Why Preventing Cancer Is Not the Priority in Drug Development
text: Most people would agree that it would be better to prevent cancer, if we could, than to treat it once it developed. Yet economic incentives encourage researchers to focus on treatment rather than prevention.

text: Bengals (11-3) at Broncos (10-4)

text: In the final days of the year and the first days of the next one, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas will battle for voters in Iowa in the lead-up to the caucuses.

headline: Brooklyn Apartment Fire Kills 2
text: A man and a woman were killed in a fire that consumed a four-story, wood-frame apartment building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, early Monday, the police said.

text: For his bookshop and website One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actor and singer Neil Patrick Harris. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Valeant Pharmaceuticals Confirms C.E.O. Is on Medical Leave
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, a drug company whose business model has been under siege, announced on Monday that J. Michael Pearson, its chairman and chief executive, was on medical leave and that a team of executives would run the company while he was out.

headline: Jeb Bush Backers Asked to Write Letters to Undecided New Hampshire Voters
text: Is the art of letter writing really dead? Not if the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush has its way.

headline: Daily Report: The Financial Challenge When Free is the Norm
text: India may be the next great frontier for American technology companies.

headline: Quashing Clones on Facebook
text: Q. Someone seems to have duplicated my Facebook account and is sending out requests to my friends pretending to be me. I can still get into my page and have warned my friends, but how do I alert Facebook to this scammer?

headline: Drinking With the Candidates: Entertain Your Guests With Weird Campaign Swag
text: Why serve your friends and family with ordinary glassware when you could be enraging them by bringing politics to the party? Whether you’re hosting an intimate brunch or a New Year’s Eve party for hundreds, this year’s presidential candidates have you covered — their online stores promise to keep your beer cold, your coffee hot and your wine whatever temperature it’s supposed to be, all while sparking the kinds of tense conversations you’ll continue to regret long after Election Day.

headline: 1940: U.S. Warned on Intervention
text: ROME — Virginio Gayda, often a spokesman of Italy’s foreign policy, warned interventionists in the United States today [Dec. 28] that American violations of neutrality, no matter how disguised, might mean entry into the war. In an editorial, he asserted that very few American politicians wanted open intervention in the war on the side of Great Britain, but that numbers of ‘‘important people’’ in the United States were trying to hide real intervention behind misleading formalities. These people, Gayda said, ‘‘seek to intensify American help to England in such a form and in such dimensions as to constitute a real, even though undeclared, intervention in the war.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 29, 1940

headline: The California Ranch That Takes Jerry Brown Off the Grid
text: WILLIAMS, Calif. — Four dusty miles off State Route 20, around a curve on a dirt road once used by stagecoaches, a scattering of barns and dilapidated buildings sits hidden among rolling hills speckled with oak trees. There is no electricity or cell service. There is a compact outhouse and a redwood cabin just big enough to hold one air mattress. There is no other sign of civilization for miles.

headline: 1965: 3,000 Try to Break Up Mass
text: PRAGUE — Some 3,000 young people, some of them using ‘‘explosives,’’ tried to break up the midnight mass in the Church of St. James here on Christmas Eve, the Czechoslovak news agency CTK disclosed today [Dec. 28]. It said the crowd ‘‘tried to incite disturbances, penetrate into the church and stop the service. They even used explosives’’ (apparently firecrackers). ‘‘Thanks to the intervention of police, two women were saved from being trampled underfoot,’’ the agency said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 29, 1965

headline: Expect ‘The Hunger Games’ in Iowa After The Holiday Break
text: It is winter again in Iowa, which means it has been nearly a year since I arrived in Des Moines as part of a Times experiment to plant a full-time correspondent in the state with the first presidential nominating contest. The corn has sprouted, grown tall and fallen to the combine. The three Democrats and 13 Republicans still running have held 1,200 events in the state, and some days it feels like I have been to most of them.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
text: Christmas has come and gone, but Louis van Gaal’s torment continues unabated.

headline: Cardamom Cream Cake
text: This festive layer cake is inspired by the Indian cheese dumpling dessert ras malai.

headline: A Layer Cake Gets a Surge From Cardamom
text: Ever since we were in high school, my friend Zoe and I have had a very special birthday tradition.

headline: Review: ‘Too Much of a Good Thing’ Finds a Dilemma in Our DNA
text: We tend to think of good genes as the ones that make us thin, calm, cheerful and healthy. This logical assumption may not be completely accurate: Dr. Lee Goldman suggests that even better genes may be the ones that make us fat, anxious and candidates for the services of a cardiologist like himself.

headline: The E.U. Migrant Crisis, Told in 2 Startling Numbers
text: PARIS — The European Union’s struggle to deal with migration can be bluntly told in two numbers: More than one million people have made their way to Europe this year, according to the International Organization for Migration, and 190 have been formally relocated.

headline: The Best Roast Chickens
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Readers Respond: Seeking Silence Amid the Crowd
text: An article about the use of headphones to block out noise (and pesky co-workers) prompted many readers to share their own stories.

headline: Burundi Crackdown Puts Hutus and Tutsis, and the West, on Edge
text: BUJUMBURA, Burundi — A little more than a week ago, Benny Uwamahoro went out for a beer. He met up with some friends, listened to some music and then received a mysterious call around 8:30 p.m. asking him to go to a neighborhood shop.

headline: Amy Cuddy’s ‘Presence’ and Shonda Rhimes’s ‘Year of Yes’
text: Success doesn’t equal happiness. That’s the message coming in loud and clear in this dawning era of transparency, whether it’s embodied in enraged emails from a powerful movie producer or depressive tweets from a wealthy celebrity. But success without popularity doesn’t count, either. Slipping into the shadows in the wake of an achievement is no longer an option; you must re-enact your value in real time, on a world stage, via conferences, TED talks, panels, festivals, radio appearances and podcasts, all the while conjuring a level of poise and grace that was once the sole purview of news anchors and talk-show hosts. This is the paradox of the modern digital world: It demands broadcast-quality demonstrations of social value, even as it steadily erodes our ability to deliver them.

headline: ‘The Diet Myth,’ ‘The Good Gut’ and ‘The Hidden Half of Nature’
text: Sometime before the age of 5 or so my son misheard the term “taste buds” and imagined, instead, that his mouth was alive with “taste bugs.” This came in handy for him when under fire for rejecting the variety of new foods we put on the table. It wasn’t his fault that he didn’t like broccoli and spinach, he’d explain, it was his pesky taste bugs.

headline: Syrian Journalist Who Documented ISIS Atrocities Is Killed in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — A Syrian journalist and filmmaker who documented atrocities by the Islamic State in Syria and trained hundreds of citizen journalists has been killed in a Turkish town near the Syrian border, rights activists said Monday, calling the death an assassination.

headline: The Gift Exchange
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Henk Tijms, a Dutch mathematician and emeritus professor at the VU University Amsterdam. Dr. Tijms, the author of the acclaimed Understanding Probability, told me that he is often asked to give a light-heartened presentation on probability to a general audience. Sometimes people in the audience come up themselves with interesting probability questions.

headline: Numberplay 2015: A Year in Review
text: Here they are — the Numberplay puzzles of 2015, including this week’s Gift Exchange by the Dutch mathematician Henk Tijms. Nearly all these puzzles are original, and many were unveiled for the first time here on Numberplay. All works of art. Thank you to everyone who submitted a puzzle this year, and thank you as well to everyone who participated in the puzzle-solving discussion (where the real fun is, in case you haven’t tried it!) or shared these puzzles with friends. Math is a highly social activity, and puzzles are a great excuse for fun conversation.

headline: Shkreli, Volkswagen and Other Stars in White-Collar Crime
text: White-collar defendants seem to be emerging as the new media stars, generating publicity sometimes rivaling that of social phenomena like the Kardashians.

headline: Four Cities That Celebrate New Year’s Eve in a Big Way
text: New Year’s Eve is undoubtedly the ultimate reason to give a party, and although many cities in the United States have celebrations, a handful are favorite Dec. 31 destinations. Below are some tried-and-true — and lesser-known — fetes in four cities where ringing in the new year is a major occasion.

headline: Learning to Let Go of Financial Peer Pressure
text: Over the years, I’ve noticed that moment when each of my children started caring about what other people think of them. One by one, I’ve watched as the opinions of others become a big deal in their own decision-making.

headline: Severe Weather Aims for New Targets After Pummeling Texas, Midwest and Mississippi
text: After spawning tornadoes in Texas and floods in the Midwest, deadly storm systems continued to drift across the United States on Monday. The severe weather has in the last week led to the deaths of at least 43 people and the injuries of dozens more, according to a count by The Associated Press.

headline: 3,988,076: The Number of U.S. Births in 2014
text: The National Center for Health Statistics reports that the number of births in 2014 — 3,988,076 — was 1 percent higher than in 2013.

headline: A New Day of the Buttered Bread Has Dawned
text: I recently happened upon a mention of an old Irish custom of celebrating New Year’s Day as the Day of the Buttered Bread. What a marvelous idea, I thought. Good bread and good butter are two of the best things to eat in Ireland, no matter what the calendar date.

headline: Goodbye, Prison Loaf: Reporter’s Notebook
text: Albany — There are a few words that will set a journalist’s internal antennae abuzz — “federal corruption charges,” for example, or “confirmed Bigfoot capture” — and set him off on a quick journey of discovery, reporting, and hopefully, informed dissemination of his instant expertise.

headline: Kentucky’s New Governor Takes Back the Vote
text: Matt Bevin, Kentucky’s new governor, has only been in office a couple of weeks, but he’s already managed to re-disenfranchise tens of thousands of his state’s residents with the stroke of a pen.

headline: Puerto Rican Police Officer Held in Fatal Shooting of 3 Colleagues
text: PONCE, P.R. — A police officer who once had his department-issued firearm taken away while he underwent psychological treatment gunned down two superiors and a third colleague on Monday at a regional headquarters in this southern Puerto Rico city, police officials said.

headline: Donald Trump Takes On Bill Clinton’s Behavior Toward Women
text: Donald J. Trump and Bill Clinton used to be golfing buddies and occasional telephone friends. Mr. Trump donated to the former president’s charitable foundation. Mr. Clinton attended the billionaire developer’s lavish third wedding in 2005.

headline: No Real Surprise: Arizona Cardinals Are N.F.L.’s Most Dominant Team
text: The Carolina Panthers have been the story of the N.F.L. this season, easily surpassing preseason expectations on the way to a 14-0 start. But after Carolina’s loss at Atlanta on Sunday, the Panthers are not going to become the first N.F.L. team to finish a season 19-0. Even so, that does not mean there is not a historically dominant team this season. It just happens to be a different N.F.C. team.

headline: The Most Commented-On Articles of 2015
text: On the community desk, we like to say that comments enhance the news. But sometimes, the comments are the news. Such was the case this year when an exposé became the most commented-on news story in Times history (that story is revealed below). Also this year: One of our top commenters upstaged his famous sibling and another became a celebrity in his hometown. To see which stories resonated most with our readers, you need look no further. These are the five most talked-about stories of the year.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Rivals Are Hindered by Storm in Trying to Cut His Lead in Iowa
text: With Republican Senator Ted Cruz, the leader in Iowa polls, spending the week effectively off the campaign trail, his rivals seemed to sense an opening: zigzag the state, press the flesh and make an early impression before the field descends on Iowa after New Year’s.

headline: Lara Croft Has Company: More Female Heroes Appear in Big-Budget Games
text: In 1987 the video game Metroid was released in the United States. It featured a masked and armored space adventurer named Samus Aran navigating an alien planet, and it was one of the first games to blend exploration, action and puzzle-solving in a way that has become common. At the end of the game Samus Aran is revealed to be a woman. Her gender surprised gamers, but in some versions this powerful adventurer appeared in a bikini. In games of that era, women were generally damsels, princesses or sex objects, not heroes.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Again the Favorite Among Show Pirates
text: “Game of Thrones” once again reigned supreme as the most-pirated television show of 2015, according to the news site TorrentFreak, with its season finale amassing 14.4 million downloads via the filesharing system, BitTorrent, an increase of more than six million from the year before.

headline: I.P.O.s in U.S. End Weak Year With an Empty December
text: Initial public offerings by companies based in the United States sputtered out in December.

headline: Stars of India’s Online Video Scene Struggle to Make a Living
text: It’s not just the streaming video services that are struggling to make a profit in India. Even the country’s most popular YouTube stars have trouble making a living from digital video.

headline: Clinton and Obama Top U.S. Poll on Most Admired People
text: Americans named President Obama and Hillary Clinton as the most admired man and woman in the world, according to a Gallup poll released on Monday, with Donald Trump tying Pope Francis as the second most admired man.

headline: Museum of Writers to Open in Chicago
text: The greats will be there — Ralph Waldo Emerson, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Walt Whitman and many others — when the American Writers Museum opens in Chicago in March 2017.

headline: Verbatim: Jeb Bush Wants to Debate Donald Trump One-On-One
text: — Jeb Bush, when asked in West Palm Beach, Fla., what he would say to Donald J. Trump if Mr. Trump were to walk into the room just then.

headline: In British Columbia, a Stylish Hotel for Adrenaline Seekers
text: From 69 Canadian dollars ($52, at 1.33 Canadian to the U.S. dollar). The lowest-end rooms are quite basic and include bunks and a half-bath, with a shower down the hall. Deluxe rooms (99 Canadian dollars) are the most updated.

headline: Wedding Gift Cash Grab. What’s Too Little? What’s Too Much?
text: Carol Dodge of Glastonbury, Conn., was walking with two friends recently when she brought up a nagging question: “My husband’s partner’s daughter is getting married. What should I give?”

headline: Universities Race to Nurture Start-Up Founders of the Future
text: HOUSTON — The original charter of Rice University, drafted in 1891, established a school here dedicated to the advancement of literature, science and art. These days, Rice seems equally dedicated to the advancement of the next Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: An Oakland Restaurant With Food That Begs for Beer
text: In 2008, Jay Porter made national news for his then unheard-of decision to ban tipping at his San Diego restaurant, the Linkery. The policy, he recalled recently, made him a “lightning rod for people’s opinions.”

headline: Crisp Plantains for Party Dipping
text: Crisp ribbons of plantains, a munchable staple at Marjorie’s Restaurant in Seattle, are now sold nationwide. You will want them to dip into salsa, avocados mashed with jerk seasonings or even hummus and tzatziki, but they are just as good plain. Watch them disappear: Miss Marjorie’s Steel Drum Plantains, $4 for a two-ounce box from marjorierestaurant.com.

headline: Cleveland Officer Will Not Face Charges in Tamir Rice Shooting Death
text: CLEVELAND — A grand jury declined on Monday to charge a Cleveland patrolman who fatally shot a 12-year-old boy holding a pellet gun, capping more than a year of investigation into a case that added to national outrage over white officers killing African-Americans.

headline: Jeb Bush Succumbs to Selfie Craze and Offers Tips on Selfie Etiquette
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Jeb Bush, the man who once promised to run for president joyfully, on Monday added a new social media twist to his campaign — Jeb Bush 2.0 will even take selfies joyfully.

headline: A Lion Expert Who Isn’t Inclined to Turn Tail
text: MINNEAPOLIS — He saw the lioness as he walked back from the rocky outcropping in the Serengeti where, tired of sitting for hours in the car, he had gone exploring on foot.

headline: Valeant’s Latest Fix Underscores Its Challenges
text: Valeant Pharmaceuticals’ latest fix reinforces its challenges.

headline: Iran Hands Over Stockpile of Enriched Uranium to Russia
text: A Russian ship left Iran on Monday carrying almost all of Iran’s stockpile of low-enriched uranium, fulfilling a major step in the nuclear deal struck last summer and, for the first time in nearly a decade, apparently leaving Iran with too little fuel to manufacture a nuclear weapon.

headline: The Plant Had a Lovely Striation. Then They Got the Pruning Shears.
text: Q. Why do some variegated plants grow back without the original patterning after pruning?

headline: A New Chapter for Saffron
text: ISFAHAN, Iran — Saffron, an ancient medicinal plant and the most expensive of spices, has always had a magical, addictive power. Cleopatra took saffron-infused baths to enhance her allure. Alexander the Great used it to heal the wounds of battle.

headline: David Cameron Defends Flood Record as Northern England Is Drenched
text: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron walked the flooded streets of York on Monday as Britain’s Environment Agency warned that the country needed “a complete rethink” of its flood defenses.

headline: Escaping to a Galaxy Far, Far, Far Away
text: FRANK BRUNI: It’s that time of year, Ross: Conservatives grieve the death of Christmas, liberals rue the commercialization of all holidays and the director David O. Russell and the megastars Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper storm America’s multiplexes with a movie timed for awards-season glory. Three years ago it was “Silver Linings Playbook.” Two years ago, “American Hustle.”

headline: The Residents of Vanuatu, Then and Now
text: Analysis of skulls in the oldest known cemetery in the South Pacific suggests that the earliest inhabitants of Vanuatu may have descended from Asian and Polynesian populations, while modern residents share more physical similarities with people in Melanesia.

headline: Meadowlark Lemon: His Globetrotter Dream Came True
text: Lemon’s moves were a highlight of the traveling basketball show for nearly a quarter-century.

headline: 2015: The Year in Charts
text: The state of the union, for better or worse, in 10 charts.

headline: Notes From the Abyss: A Snowboarder Details His Paralyzed Life
text: STOWE, Vt. — About 10 times a day, Jake Burton Carpenter reaches for a note card and jots down thoughts and reminders. The index cards he uses are five inches by eight inches, made with brown recycled paper, and have 15 lines. They are stamped with the logo of Burton Snowboards, the company that Carpenter founded in 1977 and christened with his middle name.

headline: Thefts of Baby Jesus Statues Unnerve New Jersey Churches
text: In a holiday season teeming with traditions, the enduring (and illegal) practice of pilfering baby Jesus statues from nativity scenes appears to be alive and well, particularly in northern New Jersey, where at least five churches have reported such thefts since Christmas Eve.

headline: Programs Expand Schizophrenic Patients’ Role in Their Own Care
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The idea was to go out in an emotional swan dive, a lunge for the afterlife that would stretch his 17-year-old imagination. He settled on a plan and shared the details with a Facebook friend: He would drop DMT, a powerful psychedelic, and then cut his throat.

headline: Review: ‘Phalaris’s Bull,’ or How a Man Comes to Terms With Life
text: Steven Friedman is a lot of things — philosopher, poet, painter, student of medicine and molecular biology — but one thing he is not is a natural performer, which makes his one-man show at the Beckett Theater a bit of a slog.

headline: Chita Rivera Postpones Club Engagement After Injury
text: The Broadway diva Chita Rivera has postponed her January residency at Café Carlyle after suffering an injury over the Christmas holiday. “Following a fall, it was discovered that she has a pelvic stress fracture,” the venue said in a statement Monday.

headline: TasteMasters Tokyo: Video 3
text: Johathan Soble, Yuko Hasegawa and Hiroyuki Sasaki on how craft and fabrication drive exclusivity and creative freedom. Discover other pairings and learn more at nytimes.com/tastemasters.

headline: TasteMasters Tokyo: Video 2
text: Johathan Soble, Yuko Hasegawa and Hiroyuki Sasaki on how cultural autonomy is integrated into pop art. Discover other pairings and learn more at nytimes.com/tastemasters.

headline: New Type of Rock Is Discovered on Moon
text: A new type of basaltic rock has been discovered on the surface of the moon, according to a report in the journal Nature Communications. The rock is rich in a black mineral called ilmenite, which contains a high percentage of iron titanium oxide and has been found in other lunar rocks. The discovery was made by Chinese researchers operating the Chang’e-3 spacecraft, which landed on the moon in 2013 and was the first unmanned mission there since the Apollo and Luna explorations about 40 years ago. The researchers investigated the surface remotely using spectrometers. Chang’e-5, scheduled to land on the moon by 2017, is expected to bring samples of lunar soil and rock back to Earth.

headline: Exit of Freeport Chairman Eases Credibility Problem
text: James Moffett is riding into the sunset. Mr. Moffett, Freeport-McMoRan’s longtime leader, is resigning as executive chairman of the $9 billion copper, gold and petroleum company facing pressure from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn. It’s a needed step to restore confidence after faux pas including an ill-timed, cozy-looking 2012 oil deal. Mr. Moffett’s replacement, though, faces serious challenges.

headline: Videos and Photos Recall Meadowlark Lemon, an ‘Ageless Court Magician’
text: Meadowlark Lemon, who died on Sunday in Scottsdale, Ariz., at age 83, dazzled a generation of basketball fans with his halfcourt hook shots and his wit as a longtime member of the Harlem Globetrotters.

headline: Review: In ‘River,’ Stellan Skarsgard Is a Cop Searching for Answers
text: The cop-with-a-gimmick series and the cop-who-broods series are often different animals. In the first, the lead character has some sort of investigatory superpower — Carrie Wells’s total recall in “Unforgettable,” for instance. In the second, the lead character spends a lot of time brooding, often over a whiskey glass, about an ex-wife, estranged children, a botched case or all three.

headline: Saudi Arabia, Squeezed by Low Oil Prices, Cuts Spending to Shrink Deficit
text: Pressured by low oil prices and costly wars in the Middle East, Saudi Arabia announced a sharp reduction in its 2016 budget on Monday to control a worsening deficit, which is steadily draining the kingdom’s financial reserves.

headline: Christmas Brings Big Sales for Adele, Millions of Streams for the Beatles
text: For the music business, this Christmas was all about the Beatles and Adele.

headline: TasteMasters Tokyo: Video 1
text: Johathan Soble, Yuko Hasegawa and Hiroyuki Sasaki discuss whose point of view is privileged when determining consumer taste. Discover other pairings and learn more at nytimes.com/tastemasters.

headline: Destructive Long-Termism
text: One of my long-running gripes about much discussion of current economic issues is about what I consider the long-run dodge. By this I mean the attempt to change the subject away from unemployment and inadequate demand toward supposedly more fundamental issues of education and structural reform. Such efforts to change the subject seem to me to be both wrong and, to some extent, cowardly. After all, if the clear and present problem is inadequate demand, then we should have policies to deal with that problem — I don’t care how important you think the long run is, we should deal with the crisis at hand.

headline: Armory Drops One Fair, Amid Move to Cultural Programs
Milwaukee Art Museum Reinvigorates With Renovations
text: MILWAUKEE — The architect Santiago Calatrava’s addition to the Milwaukee Art Museum, completed in 2001, quickly became the symbol of this Midwestern city, plastered prominently on the official tourism website.

headline: For Many Shows, A Happy Holiday Week at Broadway Box Office

headline: In the Twin Cities, Local Leaders Wield Influence Behind the Scenes

Dvorak had reimagined Native American and African-American tunes as folk music, creating a symphony that “throbs with American feeling,” which voiced “the melancholy of our Western wastes, and predicts their final subjection to the tremendous activity of the most energetic of all peoples.”
