text: Few in agriculture have shaped the debate over water more than the several hundred owners of an arid finger of farmland west of Fresno.

headline: The More We Poll, the Less We Know
text: Polling of Republicans in the early-voting states of Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina has reached unprecedented levels, fueled by the number of candidates in the hunt and an obsession with the horse race rather than a meaningful debate over policy, a new Boston Globe study says.

headline: Holiday on Friday New Year’s Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Mayor of Chicago Announces Measures to Curb Use of Deadly Force by the Police
text: CHICAGO — Under intense pressure to change the behavior of the police force, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday announced a series of steps intended to rein in the use of deadly force, promising to buy hundreds of Tasers and to train officers to be less confrontational.

headline: In Bill Cosby Case, 3 Pills, Sips of Wine and a Charge of Sexual Assault
text: He was her mentor and one of the most famous people to ever have attended Temple University, where she worked as a director of operations for the women’s basketball program. One night in the winter of 2004 Bill Cosby called Andrea Constand on her cellphone and invited her to his home in Cheltenham, a leafy suburb just north of Philadelphia. The two chatted about her job and career prospects.

headline: Donald Trump Renews Attacks on Bill Clinton
text: Days before he is set to campaign within miles of Bill Clinton, Donald J. Trump ratcheted up his attacks on the former president over scandals involving women before and during his presidency, calling him one of “the great abusers of the world.”

headline: A Coney Island New Year’s Eve: Sword Swallowing. Fire Breathing. No Ball.
text: There is no challenging Times Square’s pre-eminence on New Year’s Eve, with its traditional ball drop and its three-two-one countdown turning the area into the thrumming, jostling, rollicking center of the universe.

headline: Egypt Officials Stop Facebook Program for Free Access to Internet
text: CAIRO — A program that provided more than three million Egyptians with free access to Internet services was abruptly shut down on Wednesday, according to Facebook, the social media company that provided the program in cooperation with an Egyptian cellphone company.

headline: Unbrotherly Feelings in Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — As he listens to old men who lament, “I’m never going to live to see a Super Bowl,” Bruce Graham, a playwright, has begun to wonder about himself.

headline: It’s Amazon and Also-Rans in Retailers’ Race for Online Sales
text: Two decades after Jeffrey P. Bezos started Amazon in his Bellevue, Wash., garage, his e-commerce juggernaut could be forgiven for letting up on its rapid growth.

headline: Climate Chaos, Across the Map
text: What is going on with the weather?

headline: Several Days After Christmas, Toys ‘R’ Us Closes in Times Square
text: Jen Saibel took her place in front of a 60-foot-tall indoor Ferris wheel on Wednesday afternoon, raised her fists to her cheeks in a pantomime of crying and frowned theatrically for her mother’s cellphone camera.

headline: Odell Beckham Jr. Continues Apologizing in Return to Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Odell Beckham Jr. returned to Giants practice Wednesday for the first time since his one-game suspension and was once again apologetic for his reckless and dangerous play in a Dec. 20 game against the Carolina Panthers.

headline: Connecticut Man Is Charged in 2011 Murder in Queens Over Double-Parked Car
text: There were plenty of witnesses to the deadly shooting on a Queens street corner in July 2011.

headline: Trevon Pendleton Has Body for Big Blocks and Nose for Huge Plays
text: DALLAS — The Michigan State senior Aaron Burbridge caught 79 passes this season and was named the Big Ten’s receiver of the year. His teammate Trevon Pendleton, a fullback, pulled in only four, but even Burbridge might admit that they were some of the biggest ones of the Spartans’ season.

headline: Frank Malzone, Star Fielder for Boston Red Sox, Dies at 85
text: Frank Malzone, a six-time All-Star third baseman whose steady presence in the Boston lineup tied together two of the city’s baseball eras, linking Ted Williams’s Red Sox with Carl Yastrzemski’s, died on Tuesday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Caetano Veloso Loves Israel, but Won’t Be Going Back
text: For most Brazilians, the Israeli occupation of the West Bank is far from a pressing concern. But in recent months, one of Brazil’s most prominent figures, a revered singer, has found himself wrestling with a dilemma directly related to Israel’s continuing control over the territory, which is home to millions of Palestinians.

headline: Round a Corner
text: Administrivial “Joke’s On Us!” Alert! It turns out that Mr. Tausig has played a meta-joke on us. In addition to today’s New York Times crossword, he also has a similarly-themed puzzle in three other venues: Buzzfeed, AVCX and Brendan Emmett Quigley’s site. Kudos to Mr. Tausig for monopolizing our time. You can read more about it in The Observer.

headline: Venezuelan Court Blocks 4 Lawmakers
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Supreme Court on Wednesday blocked four newly elected lawmakers from taking office, three from the opposition and one from the governing Socialist party.

headline: Federal Grand Jury Indicts Friend in San Bernardino Massacre
text: Enrique Marquez, who supplied his longtime friend Syed Rizwan Farook with two assault rifles used to carry out the massacre in San Bernardino, Calif., was indicted by a federal grand jury on Wednesday on five charges, including conspiring with Mr. Farook in an earlier, unrealized plot.

headline: Britain: 2 Plotters Sentenced
text: A man and his former wife who were found guilty of plotting a terrorist attack in London on the 10th anniversary of the transit bombings in the British capital were sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday. The defendants, Mohammed Rehman, 25, and Sana Ahmed Khan, 24, were sentenced by Judge Jeremy Baker one day after their conviction in a trial known as “the 7/7 bombers” case, named for the date in 2005 when suicide bombers in the transit system killed 52 people in London. Under British law, Mr. Rehman must serve at least 27 years and Ms. Khan 25 years. Mr. Rehman, who had referred to himself as the “Silent Bomber” on social media, was arrested in May after having posted a message that asked: “Westfield shopping centre or London underground? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.” According to evidence and testimony presented in court, the police seized explosives and bomb-making chemicals from Mr. Rehman’s house in the city of Reading, west of London. In sentencing the defendants, Judge Baker was quoted by the BBC as saying their intended actions “included a suicide bombing, an act which envisaged martyrdom, a notion specifically resurrected by Islamic State in order to encourage this type of venture.”

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: A dramatic evening of programming is set to welcome the New Year. One of America’s most ferocious rivalries plays out in Times Square between Ryan Seacrest and Carson Daly, the eminent presenters of seemingly anything televised. If you have reason to skip the festivities, you can instead laugh at “Shaun of the Dead” or become immersed in “No Country for Old Men.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “As scientists, it’s a little humbling that we’ve kind of been saying this for 20 years now, and it’s not until people notice daffodils coming out in December that they start to say, ‘Maybe they’re right.’”

headline: George Lucas Criticizes Latest ‘Star Wars’ Installment
text: George Lucas has criticized the latest installment of “Star Wars,” the series he created, in an interview with Charlie Rose, describing the film as too “retro” for his taste and jokingly comparing the Walt Disney Company, which bought the rights to the franchise in 2012, to “white slavers” who had bought his children.

headline: At the Mummers Parade, Philadelphia Celebrates a New Year’s Ritual
text: Every New Year’s Day, throngs huddle along Broad Street in Center City Philadelphia to behold thousands of (mostly) men, flamboyantly dressed in satin, sequins and feathers, faces painted with bright colors, strutting down the street with parasols, instruments and other props. This is the annual Mummers Parade, a tradition dating back officially to the early 1900s, unofficially much further, to working-class northern European immigrants in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

headline: Searching for Hate
text: To the Editor:

headline: America’s Bountiful Churn
text: GALLUP, N.M. — The main drag in Gallup runs along Historic Route 66, adjacent to the railroad. The Hotel El Rancho, where movie stars filming westerns once stayed, is still there. A host of trading posts sell Navajo jewelry, pottery and rugs, as well as artifacts made by the smaller Zuni Nation.

headline: Test Your Savvy About 2016 With a Quiz
text: Will Trump, Cruz, Clinton or Sanders win the presidency? Will the refugee crisis improve? Here’s a multiple-choice exam on what’s to come.

headline: Catchy Highway Signs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reducing the Stresses Students Face
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mr. Obama’s Trickle of Mercy
text: This month, President Obama announced the latest winners of the annual lottery otherwise known as the presidential clemency process.

headline: Appreciating the Virtues of the Maligned Cassette
text: To the Editor:

headline: What Should Chicago Celebrate?
text: Chicago — TODAY is the first Chi-Town Rising, a blowout New Year’s Eve party along the Chicago riverfront. It promises celebrity and musical guests, including, naturally, the band Chicago. As the countdown to 2016 begins, a 70-foot steel star will ascend 36 stories up the side of the Hyatt Regency, the celebration culminating in a fireworks show.

headline: Debt and the Racial Wealth Gap
text: IF you are black, you’re far more likely to see your electricity cut, more likely to be sued over a debt, and more likely to land in jail because of a parking ticket.

headline: The Counterfeit High School Diploma
text: Teachers unions and other critics of federally required standardized tests have behaved in recent years as though killing the testing mandate would magically remedy everything that ails education in the United States. In reality, getting rid of the testing requirement in the early grades would make it impossible for the country to know what if anything children were learning from year to year.

headline: Donald Trump’s Strongest Supporters: A Certain Kind of Democrat
text: Donald Trump holds a dominant position in national polls in the Republican race in no small part because he is extremely strong among people on the periphery of the G.O.P. coalition.

headline: China Frees 2 Brothers of U.S. Reporter for Radio Free Asia
text: HONG KONG — Two brothers of an American journalist who United States lawmakers say were jailed by China in retaliation for his reporting on ethnic tensions in the country’s Xinjiang region have been freed, the reporter’s employer said. Another brother remained in custody.

headline: Soak. Wash. Rinse. Dry. No Tilt!
text: Patrons at the Sunshine Laundromat in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, can lounge at the bar or play several rounds of pinball while waiting for their clothes to wash and dry.

headline: So You Think Your Sister’s Boyfriend Is Gay
text: My sister has been dating her boyfriend for two years. They live together and seem mostly happy. And I am happy for them, except for one thing: I am about 99 percent sure he is gay. Now, I have no problem with homosexuality, but you can understand my concern. Also, I am not the only one who thinks this. Several male friends have told me that he has tried to kiss other men or grab their crotches. I would like to bring this up with my sister. How should I do it?

headline: Cleaning Up at the Arcade
text: Laundry day at Sunshine Laundromat in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, has always been a little out of the ordinary. Droll portraits of dogs adorn the walls, and snack-size bags of potato chips are complimentary. More than 20 vintage pinball machines ding and ping. Lately, though, there have been some changes.

headline: For a Better Commute, the Upper West Side
text: After several years of living in assorted New York shares, sublets and rentals, most recently in Manhattan, Wayne Gerard found himself with just a few days to land a new place to live. So he made a hasty move to an apartment in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Alicia Vikander's Breakout Style
text: The star of “The Danish Girl” shows an easy assurance on the red carpet.

headline: Single, and Surrounded by a Wall of Men
text: At 37, a lawyer half-heartedly attends yet another singles mixer and awaits the dreaded mingling. It was all so deliciously awful, she thought.

headline: Facing Increase, Rent-Controlled Tenants Complain of Being Singled Out
text: At a time when rent-stabilized tenants in New York City are enjoying a freeze in their rents, another group of regulated tenants — the dwindling minority in rent-controlled apartments — is facing an increase of up to 9.6 percent over the next two years.

headline: Belgium Arrests 6 and Holds 2 Longer Over New Year’s Eve Plot
text: LONDON — The authorities in Belgium announced the arrests of six men on Thursday, and a court prolonged the detention of two others, in connection with a plot to attack the capital, Brussels, on New Year’s Eve.

headline: Corrections: December 31, 2015
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: 36 Hours in Tel Aviv
text: Young, modern Tel Aviv and ancient Jaffa pulse with energy and combine to offer bustling markets, night clubs and a beachside promenade just right for two wheels.

headline: Ask Well: Should You Filter Your Water?
text: Question:

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Bill Cosby, Donald Trump, New Year’s Eve
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

headline: New York Today: Making Resolutions
text: Updated 8:59 a.m.

headline: Britain to Review How Airport Shops Collect Sales Tax
text: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, announced a review on Thursday of how retailers at major airports in Britain collect sales tax from their customers.

headline: A Marine Ecologist Strives to Protect the Seas
text: In 2007, Enric Sala, a marine ecologist, quit his job in academia, saying he was “tired of writing the obituary of ocean life.” Only 1 percent of the ocean is currently protected, marine scientists say, and the rest is being disrupted by overfishing, pollution, climate change and species extinctions. Dr. Sala said he felt the need to take action.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Terro Liquid Ant Bait
text: Have you ever had an anxiety attack? One of those full-blown panic freakouts: Your hands are tingling, your head is swimming, your skin is crawling and — my God — you want to run away, but you can’t, so you crumple wherever you are, even if that means at your desk, in front of your entire office. How long does it last? Hours, days. Maybe it dissipates for a time and then you bolt upright sweating at 3:17 a.m., gulping for air in the darkness. Eventually it retreats, but never completely. Somewhere in the recesses of your mind, anxiety is still tucked away, quietly at work, plotting its next strike.

headline: Almost-Traditional Jewish Cooking
text: Living in New York, a spiritual homeland of the delicatessen, I have certain Pavlovian responses to the phrase ‘‘Jewish food.’’ I sniff around for the scent of fatty fish and smoke. I clutch my supply of Lipitor and fiend for a corned-beef sandwich bigger than my child’s head. I assume everything that is yellowish and disc-shaped is a fried potato pancake until proved otherwise.

headline: Ken Jeong Is Not Cracking Asian Jokes
text: You were a doctor for seven years before you switched to comedy and acting full time. Did your parents want you to do medicine first? Yeah, I always joke that I was Koreaned into doing medicine.

headline: Brie Larson Finds a Hectic Life After ‘Room’
text: ARCADIA, CALIF. — Fortified by coffee and a Red Bull on the Sunday morning before Christmas, Brie Larson was hopscotching down a path at the Los Angeles County Arboretum and Botanic Garden here.

headline: China Says It Is Building Its Second Aircraft Carrier
text: BEIJING — China is building a second aircraft carrier, the country’s Ministry of National Defense confirmed on Thursday. But unlike the first, this one will be produced entirely using China’s own designs and technology, the ministry said.

headline: New Year’s Eve Security Bolstered After Terrorist Attacks and Threats
text: New Year’s Eve is unfolding around the world in an atmosphere of heightened security, after recent terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., associated with or inspired by the Islamic State. The authorities in Turkey and Belgium announced this week that they had disrupted terrorist plots aimed at popular destinations in the capitals.

headline: When Journalism Catches Hollywood’s Eye
text: It is not every year that Hollywood produces two movies about journalism that are Oscar contenders, but 2015 appears to have been that year. First came “Truth” in October. Based on the memoir of a former “60 Minutes” producer, Mary Mapes, it purports to tell the story of her gutsy 2004 investigation into George W. Bush’s service in the National Guard when he was a young man. When it turned out that her story, which was broadcast on “60 Minutes II” months before the president’s re-election, had unwittingly relied on falsified documents, the network suits turned against her and her famous correspondent, the CBS anchor Dan Rather, costing them their jobs.

headline: Dance This Week: ‘Ballerina Swan,’ ‘Die Fledermaus’ and the Choreography of Merce Cunningham
text: Allegra Kent’s ‘Ballerina Swan’ Onstage

headline: Tessa Hadley: By the Book
text: The author, most recently, of “The Past” finds it “frightening to think about the books that form us. It’s not just Emma Bovary who makes her life decisions . . . based on something that she’s read.”

headline: Food Trends That Shaped 2015
text: Waste is becoming a dirty word in the world of high-end food. During Expo Milano 2015, the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura oversaw — with help from Mario Batali, Alain Ducasse and René Redzepi — the Ambrosian Refectory, a pop-up dining hall in a disused theater, where meals were made using surplus from the estimated 400 tons of food that arrive at the culinary fair each day. Batali and Ducasse also worked at New York’s wastED, a temporary restaurant at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill in Greenwich Village, which involved a cast of rotating chefs addressing food waste in their menus.

headline: Barge Set Loose in North Sea by Violent Weather Is Secured
text: LONDON — A 360-foot-long barge that was set loose by violent weather in the North Sea was secured on Thursday, after the oil companies BP and ConocoPhillips evacuated hundreds of workers from two oil platforms and temporarily halted production.

headline: A Son’s New Apartment
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 1941: Ringing In the New Year, Underground
text: LONDON — In many different parts of England at the stroke of midnight the faint sound of laughter and singing could be heard issuing from deep in the earth. These waves of sound, vanishing and swelling in turn, came from thousands of people who, like their primitive ancestors, have taken to the caves of England for protection, warmth and human companionship.

headline: Ben Carson Raises About $23 Million in Latest Quarter
text: Ben Carson collected roughly $23 million in the final fund-raising quarter of the year, a large haul at a moment when the candidate is trying to bolster his sagging poll numbers. Mr. Carson’s campaign spokesman, Doug Watts, confirmed the figure, which was reported first by Politico.

headline: 8 Handy Travel Tips From 2015
text: The New York Times Travel section publishes a lot of advice through the year. Here are a few favorites to put into practice in 2016.

headline: Man Falls to His Death Climbing the Four Seasons Hotel
text: A 20-year-old man fell to his death as he and a friend tried to take photos of the skyline from a catwalk above the roof of the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday night, the authorities said.

headline: Tamir Rice and the Color of Fear
text: A month ago, I was carrying groceries up my apartment-building steps when an old white woman, checking her mail in the lobby, watched me struggle with my bags. She froze at the sight of me, and while I fumbled for my keys, she didn’t take a step toward the door to open it for me. When I finally stepped inside, she sighed and apologized. “I’m sorry I didn’t get the door,” she said, “but I just didn’t know you. I kept looking, and I didn’t know you.”

headline: The Year in Illustration
text: ​A selection of notable art created for the Opinion section in 2015.

headline: Spain Has Little Appetite for Truffles, but Plenty for the Truffle Trade
text: SARRIÓN, Spain — On Saturday nights, prospective buyers gather on the outskirts of this small village, in the darkness of a parking lot next to a semi-abandoned railway station. Using flashlights, they inspect the offerings local farmers have piled in the trunks of their vehicles, then haggle over price.

headline: At the Mummers Parade, Philadelphia Celebrates an Old New Year’s Ritual
text: After they famously strut down Broad Street in Philadelphia, the Mummers go back to their gritty, blue-collar roots on South Second Street.

headline: Golden State Warriors Routed? It Happens to the Best of Teams
text: The mighty Warriors lost on Wednesday night; all teams do. But Golden State did not just lose; it was trounced by 23 points at Dallas. And it played without its star, Stephen Curry.

headline: Daily Report: A Happy Holiday for Amazon
text: It’s not your imagination: Every recycling bin on your block really is filled with Amazon boxes.

headline: Digging Deeper for Missing Mac Mail Messages
text: Q. I tried the Rebuild command to find missing messages in Mac Mail on the El Capitan version (OS X 10.11), but it didn’t fix my problem. What else can I try?

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’: Watched It All? Share Your Theories.
text: For armchair detectives, Netflix’s “Making a Murderer” is delicious fodder: 10 hours of a true-crime documentary, smartly released by the streaming service over the holidays, when free time is abundant. After watching the story of Steven Avery, it’s difficult not to immediately postulate theories and throw things at your screen as you rage against the imperfections of the American justice system.

headline: Trial of Chad’s Ex-President Brings Harrowing Accounts of Abuse
text: PARIS — The witness, a slight middle-aged woman, wanted to tell the court about something that had happened to her, something terrible that she said she had kept to herself for more than 30 years. As she faced the judges, she was just steps away from the man on trial, Hissène Habré, once Chad’s all-powerful and much-feared president.

headline: Blake Bortles’s Huge Leap Bodes Well for the Jaguars
text: A year ago, Jacksonville Jaguars quarterback Blake Bortles had a nondescript rookie campaign. He finished well below average in most passing metrics and had the lowest passer rating in the N.F.L. among qualifying quarterbacks.

headline: Paperback Row
text: CENSORS AT WORK: How States Shaped ­Literature, by Robert Darnton. (Norton, $17.95.) To understand the longstanding human predilection for censorship, Darnton examines three historical cases of political interference with literature: the monarchy in 18th-century France; British colonial rule in 19th-century India; and the 20th-century Communist dictatorship in East Germany. Exploring the various justifications governments have invoked in defense of censorship, the author draws inferences about its long-term cultural impact.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: BRIGHT SCYTHE: Selected Poems, by Tomas Transtromer. Translated by Patty Crane. (Sarabande Books, $17.95.) Until his death last year, the 2011 Nobelist was one of Europe’s greatest poets, producing work of austere beauty and mystery.

headline: Keeping Up With Firefox Updates
text: Q. Why does the Firefox browser on my computer constantly update itself? Is there a way to see what is actually being changed?

headline: Manila Social Club
text: Nostalgia suffuses the dishes at this Filipino restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: At Manila Social Club in Williamsburg, Rambling Filipino Cuisine
text: Björn DelaCruz never learned the name of the dish he ate at a roadside shack under a narra tree, not far from his grandmother’s orchid farm in Davao Oriental, the Philippines. It was simple, made with carabao (water buffalo) milk, chayote and fish likely caught in the river running alongside.

headline: Inside the List
text: Be Prepared: If your New Year’s resolutions include acquiring the know-how to build your own stun gun, dispose of a body and trick facial-recognition technology — in other words, the usual — you might want to skip the advice list and head straight to the monthly espionage list, available online, where Clint Emerson’s “100 Deadly Skills” was No. 2 in December. Emerson is a former member of the Navy SEALs who served with Chris Kyle, of “American Sniper” fame, and now runs his own security consulting firm in the Dallas suburbs. Among the 100 lessons in his crisply illustrated manual are such handy pointers as how to turn a plastic water bottle into a gun silencer and, for bibliophiles, how to build a bulletproof vest out of duct tape and books. “You have to learn from the predators,” Emerson told Texas Monthly this fall, “because your natural-born instinct won’t be good enough.”

headline: ‘A Strange Business,’ by James Hamilton
text: James Hamilton’s “A Strange Business” — the title is taken from an observation about the art market made late in life by the brilliant British painter J. M. W. Tur­ner — is every bit as quirky a book as you might expect from a onetime fellow at St. Antony’s College, Oxford. It has 31 pages of endnotes; a 14-page index; and six pages of bibliography, in reduced type, including a section for primary source material, one for secondary source material and another for “manuscripts consulted.” There are also four tiny-type pages devoted to recounting for the befuddled reader the names of the 180 or so “Dramatis Personae” that get name-checked continually, from George Ackermann, the art dealer and publisher, to John Young, the ­engraver and curator.

headline: After a Tumultuous Year for Investors, the Experts Look Ahead
text: The last year was a treacherous one for investors, including some top hedge fund and asset managers. Much of what happened in global markets can be traced to falling oil and commodity prices, which rippled through the economies and markets of most major oil-producing nations.

headline: 21 Injured on Air Canada Flight After Sudden Turbulence
text: OTTAWA — Sudden and intense turbulence during an Air Canada flight on Wednesday threw passengers out of their seats, with some hitting the ceiling of the airplane, and resulted in numerous injuries.

headline: ‘Up Against the Night,’ by Justin Cartwright
text: In the 1830s, the Boer commander ­Pieter Mauritz Retief led part of the Great Trek out of the British-occupied Cape Colony, intending to settle in Zululand, only to be massacred by the Zulu king’s warriors. Many years later, Retief’s legacy — a thorny mix of heroism, nationalism and racism — haunts his fictional descendant, Frank McAllister, the present-day narrator of Justin Cartwright’s latest novel, “Up Against the Night.” The battle provides the only sound archival root for what becomes a gratifyingly unsound psychological odyssey.

headline: ‘One Out of Two,’ by Daniel Sada
text: The Mexican writer Daniel Sada’s second novel to appear in English, “One Out of Two,” is a spry addition to the genre of spinster sister fiction. Sada, who died in 2011, was as prolific as he was mischievous. Between his birth in Mexicali in 1953 and his death at 58, he published 20 books of fiction and poetry, all of them consistently unpredictable. In “One Out of Two,” Sada’s interest in spinster escapades is foremost in the opportunities they create for playing around with sexual tension and transgression.

headline: ‘Suspicious Minds,’ by Rob Brotherton
text: For all the talk of Donald Trump’s unpresidential behavior, the Republican enfant terrible does share one notable trait with that paragon of presidentiality, George Washington: a fondness for conspiracy theories. Washington once wrote in a letter that he believed an Illuminati conspiracy was at work in America, while Trump is the figurehead of the birther movement, which claims Barack Obama is not a natural-born American citizen. The psychologist and science journalist Rob Brotherton’s new book, “Suspicious Minds: Why We Believe Conspiracy ­Theories,” helps explain why someone with such seemingly outlandish views can gain widespread public support. It turns out we are all conspiracy theorists.

headline: ‘Bird,’ by Noy Holland
text: After three widely praised story collections, Noy Holland’s first novel, “Bird,” is a whirling and feverish illustration of how much time can be contained in the present moment. A master of the domestic, Holland takes us again into that sphere: into the life of Bird, a stay-at-home mother of two children, as she moves through the events of a single day. Bird readies her son for school, sees her husband out the door, takes a bath with the baby. An old friend calls, and they share stories about the past. Bird takes the baby for a walk, and they stop by a pond, enjoying some time on the grass. Returning home, she flips through a photo album, talks on the phone again and hangs up in time to share the last moments of sunlight with the baby before greeting her son at the school bus.

headline: ‘Martin John,’ by Anakana Schofield
text: It’s not often you feel sympathetically disposed toward flashers, gropers, public masturbators or punchers of women’s private parts, and in fairness, you don’t often feel it while reading “Martin John” either — but you sometimes do, which makes Anakana Schofield either an extremely persuasive apologist for the sexually aberrant or a very fine novelist.

headline: ‘Abba Eban: A Biography,’ by Asaf Siniver
text: In December 1955, following Syrian har­assment of Israeli fishermen on the Sea of Galilee, Israel carried out a large attack on Syrian military positions, killing 50 soldiers and capturing 30. Abba Eban, Israel’s eloquent and admired representative to the United Nations, thought the response was over the top and wrote a letter to Prime Minister David Ben-­Gurion condemning the raid. At the United Nations, meanwhile, Eban defended the operation, assailing Syria’s implacable hostility. Ben-Gurion wrote back to Eban saying he himself had had doubts about the retaliation but “when I read the full text of your brilliant defense of our action in the Security Council, all my doubts were set to rest. You have convinced me that we were right after all.”

headline: ‘The English and Their History,’ by Robert Tombs
text: Even in free countries it is sometimes necessary to alter the past to suit the present. For instance, I recall the day at my English boarding school in the early 1960s when our sober, patriotic old history books were gathered up and carted away to a storeroom. In their place we were handed bright, optimistic replacements, with a good deal less to say about the empire, the Protestant martyrs or what we had been taught without embarrassment to call the Glorious Revolution.

headline: ‘Infectious Madness,’ by Harriet A. Washington
text: One hundred and sixty odd years ago, Ignaz Semmelweis realized that physicians who didn’t wash their hands were carrying tiny germs from bedside to bedside and causing the childbed fever that killed many women. After doctors began washing their hands, fewer women died. The series of realizations in the 19th century that germs — bacteria and viruses — caused diseases like cholera and tuberculosis and influenza ushered in modern medicine. Mortality rates declined; children lived longer. Germ theory had a dramatic clarity to it. It pushed medicine away from holistic conceptions of illness as imbalance toward conceptions of illness as a specific entity. You get the germ, you fall sick, you take antibiotics or fight it off (or die). Ironically, though, the tidiness of this relationship helped obscure cases where germs may have less direct but still devastating effects — a complex reality we are now beginning to understand better.

headline: Thomas Perry’s ‘Forty Thieves,’ and More
text: Nick and Nora Charles they’re not. But while Sid and Veronica Abel may be lacking in urbanity, these private investigators are no less brainy and far better marksmen. Appearing for the first time in Thomas Perry’s new thriller, FORTY THIEVES (Mysterious, $26), these former Los Angeles police detectives have been married for over 30 years and have children and grandchildren. That confers on them the wisdom of the ancients, along with the cloak of invisibility in a youth-obsessed society, which suits them just fine. (“Do you have any idea what gray hair is worth in our business?”)

headline: BBC Websites Said to Be Target of Online Attack
text: The British Broadcasting Corporation said on Thursday that its digital services had been shut down temporarily in what its news operation described as a hacking attack.

headline: 2 Sentenced to Death in Killing of Bangladeshi Activist in 2013
text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A court in Bangladesh sentenced two people to death and six others to prison terms on Thursday for killing a secular blogger and activist in 2013, the first sentences in a series of  killings of bloggers in Bangladesh.

headline: Food Memoir
text: HOW TO COOK A MOOSEA Culinary MemoirBy Kate Christensen292 pp. Islandport, $24.95.

headline: Pentagon Curbs Use of Psychologists With Guantánamo Detainees
text: WASHINGTON — The United States military has sharply curtailed the use of psychologists at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in response to strict new professional ethics rules of the American Psychological Association, Pentagon officials said.

headline: Ted Cruz Raises Almost $20 Million in Year-End Surge
text: Senator Ted Cruz raised significantly more money in the final three months of the year while Ben Carson maintained his pace in fund-raising during that period, according to numbers released by the Republican presidential hopefuls’ campaigns.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: You, New and Improved
text: This week, Heather Havrilesky talks about Amy Cuddy’s “Presence” and Shonda Rhimes’s “Year of Yes,” and Michael Ian Black discusses “Navel Gazing.” Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: 1966 | ‘We Could Not Move, We Could Not Take Cover’
text: It took decades to forge the legend of the correspondent R. W. Apple Jr. — a man known for his “Dickensian byline, Churchillian brio and Falstaffian appetites,” according to Todd Purdum, a former Times reporter who wrote Mr. Apple’s obituary.

headline: Fund-Raising Pleas Get Desperate as Year Winds Down
text: Senator Ted Cruz has “nowhere else to turn.” Jeb Bush is “counting on you.” Senator Marco Rubio “needs you to hear this.” Senator Rand Paul “needs all hands on deck.”

headline: Chris Christie’s Punch Lines vs. Marco Rubio’s Polish on Iowa Campaign Trail
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — It was the same question, on the same topic, asked on the same day to two different candidates: How, as president, would you hold down the crushing cost of a college education?

headline: ‘Manspreading,’ ‘Vape’ and ‘So’: Hated Words for 2016
text: If you are still trying to decide on a New Year’s resolution, there are some people in Michigan who might be able to help: Promise never to use the word “problematic” again.

headline: Polls Show Attacks on Bill Clinton May Only Help Hillary Clinton
text: Donald J. Trump made clear this week that nothing was off limits when it came to attacking the Clintons, dusting off names like Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones while calling former President Bill Clinton one of “the great abusers of the world.” Sexual indiscretions of the past, he said, are fair game in an election year.

headline: Soaking The Rich, Slightly
text: Good catch by Josh Barro. It’s been clear for a while that taxes on top incomes went up significantly in 2013; but we’ve had to rely on estimates of the change, not actual numbers. Now the actual numbers on income taxes are in, and sure enough, fairly big hikes at the top.

headline: Over 50 and Buying a First Home
text: Edith Shapiro was 36 when she and her husband, Nathan, moved in 1967 to a brand-new rental building at 200 East 62nd Street. Back then, $725 per month got them a four-bedroom duplex with four and a half baths.

headline: The Red Tape of New Windows in New York
text: In many parts of the country, replacing old, drafty, noisy windows is as simple as selecting products at a home improvement store and scheduling a contractor to install them. But that’s not the case in New York, where window replacement, like so many facets of home renovation, is governed by rules and procedures.

headline: Fino Sherry, for the Undaunted
text: Stick your nose into a glass of fino sherry and you may be in for a shock. Years of enjoying the usual sorts of fruity reds and whites will not have prepared you for the wave (some may say assault) of aromas. Instead of the gentle sweetness that sherry novices may expect, what arises is bone dry, pungent and savory, almost the antithesis of sweet and fruity.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Marsannay Burgundy
text: Next up, we visit what many consider the spiritual center for much that we worship about red wine: Burgundy.

headline: Iran Denounces U.S. Sanctions Over Missiles, Saying It Will Build More
text: Iran’s president denounced the United States on Thursday for suggesting the possibility of new sanctions over Iranian missiles, and he ordered his Defense Ministry to respond by swiftly building more of them.

headline: Top Ben Carson Aides Quit Amid Campaign Turmoil
text: New upheaval engulfed Ben Carson’s troubled presidential campaign on Thursday as his campaign manager and his spokesman resigned abruptly after a deep rift with an outside adviser to the candidate.

headline: The Selfish Side of Gratitude
text: THIS holiday season, there was something in the air that was even more inescapable than the scent of pumpkin spice: gratitude.

headline: Seinfeld and Obama, Chatting in a Corvette
text: President Obama wears one brand of underwear, always the same color. He shaves before working out in the morning. And he picks out his own suit.

headline: Murder Isn’t Black or White
text: IT was the spring of 1991 — more than two decades before Ferguson, Mo., would become a national symbol of racism — when my parents took my siblings and me to visit their hometown, St. Louis. We spent the week hanging out with our cousins, with whom we were close. I was 16, too young to tag along when, the night before we were supposed to return home to Maryland, my 19-year-old brother, Tom Cummins, and our cousins, Julie and Robin Kerry, were brutally attacked by four strangers. Julie was 20, Robin, 19.

headline: Review: In ‘Stories I Tell Myself,’ Life as Hunter S. Thompson’s Son
text: It’s not easy growing up a shy, sensitive, bullied, Dungeons & Dragons-playing child, the kind of friendless boy who hates sports, becomes a vegetarian and in college eats alone in the cafeteria, pretending to read a newspaper while dying inside.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘45 Years’
text: Andrew Haigh narrates a sequence from his film featuring Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay.

headline: Same Trail, Diverging Styles
text: Chris Christie and Marco Rubio showed strikingly different styles over two days of campaigning in Iowa.

headline: Allen Lacy, a Professor Turned Gardening Columnist, Dies at 80
text: Allen Lacy, an accidental gardening columnist whose cramped backyard inspired practical advice on down-to-earth subjects like expunging crab grass and erudite cerebrations about far-flung fields like global warming, died last Sunday at his home in Linwood, N.J. He was 80.

headline: You Can Now Call Him Sir Matthew (Bourne)
text: LONDON — The choreographer Matthew Bourne, the actress Imelda Staunton, the Blur frontman Damon Albarn, the ballerina Tamara Rojo and the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon are all on this year’s New Year’s Honors 2016, the list of awards announced by the British cabinet office to those who have distinguished themselves in a variety of professional or charitable fields. (These are wide-ranging, and this year include “honorable services to snooker” among many others.)

headline: The Next Big Voting-Rights Fight
text: Over the past year, The New York Times Magazine has chronicled the long campaign that led to the Supreme Court’s 2013 nullification of the Voting Rights Act’s most powerful provision — its Section 5 — and the consequences that decision has had for minority voters. As I’ve written in our Disenfranchised series, the gutting of Section 5 facilitated an onslaught of restrictive new laws that made voting disproportionately harder for minorities across the country, marking the biggest setback to minority voting rights in the half-century since President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Fire Engulfs Luxury Dubai Hotel, Forcing Evacuation of New Year’s Crowd
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — A luxury hotel skyscraper in Dubai was engulfed in flames after a fire broke out Thursday, causing an evacuation of a large crowd from the downtown area that had gathered for New Year’s Eve.

headline: Andrew Haigh Narrates a Scene From ‘45 Years’
text: A couple (Charlotte Rampling and Tom Courtenay) face a hurdle in their lengthy marriage in the drama “45 Years,” written and directed by Andrew Haigh. The British filmmaker’s previous film, “Weekend,” looked at the the brief relationship between two men after a one-night stand. In a recent interview at The Times, Mr. Haigh discussed how those films were alike and his decision to follow up a gay-themed film with one on heterosexual characters. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: On the 101st Floor, Saying ‘I Do’
text: Haley Swindal, an actress, and Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent, were married Dec. 12 high above Manhattan in One World Trade Center.

headline: An Actress and an Agent: ‘What Could Be a Better Match?’
text: Ever since his divorce in 2008, Jack Tantleff, a theatrical agent in New York, had struggled to find someone to fill the role of partner in his life.

headline: Video Review: The Scion iM Is Proud to Be a Hatchback
text: THEY’VE been embraced by Europeans and shunned by Americans. Lately, this could pertain to any number of things, but right now I’m describing hatchbacks.

headline: Ants Can Change Their Roles, Study Finds
text: Among Florida carpenter ants there are the so-called majors, brawny soldiers that guard the colony, and the smaller minors that act as foragers. But membership in these castes is not set in stone, a new study found.

headline: Gene Editing Offers Hope for Treating Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, Studies Find
text: After decades of disappointingly slow progress, researchers have taken a substantial step toward a possible treatment for Duchenne muscular dystrophy with the help of a powerful new gene-editing technique.

headline: Test Your ‘Downton Abbey’ Drama Quotient
text: “Downton Abbey” ends its six-season run on Sunday. How well do you know the characters and their tortured pasts?

headline: Russia Plans Survey in Crimea on Ukraine Electricity Contract
text: MOSCOW — In an echo of the referendum in 2014 on whether to join Russia, residents of Crimea are being asked if they want to reaffirm their choice.

headline: Jeb Bush Courts Iowa Supporters at Rose Bowl in California
text: With most political eyes on Iowa right now, and most Iowa eyes on the Rose Bowl — where their beloved Hawkeyes are taking on Stanford on New Year’s Day — the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush is heading to Pasadena, Calif., where the big game will be held.

headline: F.B.I. Is Asked to Investigate Chicago Police Shooting That Left 2 Dead
text: CHICAGO — The top county prosecutor here Thursday asked the F.B.I. to investigate the fatal shooting of two people by a Chicago police officer over the weekend, and Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s administration separately released a trove of emails showing how City Hall aides scrambled for months to address an earlier police shooting that was captured on video.

headline: Rochester Man Charged With Planning Attack on Behalf of ISIS
text: A 25-year-old man in Rochester has been arrested and charged with preparing to stage a New Year’s Eve machete attack on diners at a local restaurant on behalf of the Islamic State.

headline: A Turbulent Year in the Music Business
text: For the music industry, 2015 was a year of huge hits, big battles behind the scenes and the continuing evolution of an industry that has been transformed by technology and the Internet.

headline: The Last (and Most Expensive) Night of the Year
text: Vegas Dave knows what it costs to ring in the new year, Vegas Dave-style.

headline: Jewish-Arab Love Story Excluded From Israeli Classrooms
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s Ministry of Education has decided not to include a novel about a romance between an Israeli woman and a Palestinian man on the list of required reading for Hebrew high school literature classes, prompting a stormy debate over how Israeli society deals with its cultural divides.

headline: Review: Metropolitan Museum Looks at Photos That May Last
text: It is contemporary photography roundup time in New York, with major exhibitions appearing concurrently at the Museum of Modern Art (“Ocean of Images: New Photography 2015”) and the Guggenheim (“Photo-Poetics: An Anthology”). The Met’s contribution, “Reconstructions: Recent Photographs and Video From the Met Collection,” is not framed as a showcase of what’s new, hot or trending, but it relates both subtly and significantly to these two exhibitions. The show includes 18 works by 15 artists acquired during the past seven years – work that Met curators think will endure historically.

headline: The New Exponential Festival Opens in Brooklyn
text: Last spring, Theresa Buchheister, a founder of the experimental theater company Title: Point, and Eliza Bent, a playwright and performer, spent an evening lamenting all the shows they’d missed — friends’ plays that had overlapped with their own, short runs they’d discovered too late. “These were shows that should happen again,” Ms. Bent remembered insisting. But when? And where?

headline: Review: Praying to the Heavens, Looking at the Stars and Revising a Service
text: Starting around the 1960s, radical revisions to the Christian liturgy have resulted in a more accessible service and a great deal of music for the Mass. But not much of it has been by significant composers.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Jan. 1, 2016
text: The New York Times film critics review “Concussion,” “Anomalisa” and “Daddy’s Home.”

headline: Review: ‘Maestà,’ Piecing Together Part of a Lost Legacy
text: Sometimes you don’t know what you have until it’s gone. That’s a lesson viewers might take away from “Maestà: Gaddi’s Triptych Reunited,” a tiny exhibition at the New-York Historical Society that inadvertently prompts thought about museums and their responsibilities.

headline: A Recovering but Changed Auto Industry
text: United States automakers have emerged from their worst crisis in a generation, but they have lost much along the way.

headline: Auto Industry Sales Explode in an Ever-Changing Market
text: DETROIT — Automakers have enjoyed an unequaled run of success in the United States because of pent-up consumer demand, cheap gas prices and low interest rates. But despite record sales, manufacturers must continue updating their vehicles and improving technology to keep the good times rolling.

headline: Our Favorite Styles Photos of 2015
text: A look at some of the year’s most striking Styles section images.

headline: In Reversal, Twitter to Let Politwoops Collect Politicians’ Deleted Tweets
text: Politwoops will once again be able to collect and publish the deleted tweets of American politicians after Twitter announced Thursday that it reached a deal with the organizations that run the website.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Lush Colors
text: As we embark on the new year, the richness of colors, particularly pastels and flower patterns on winter coats, often reflects the hidden treasures of gemstones and of vegetables sliced open, revealing an intense color inside. A spectrum that ranged from amethyst to lavender was mirrored in cabbage roses. Blacks and grays remain a foundation of fashion for practical reasons.

headline: Escaped Convicts in Argentina Shoot 2 Police Officers
text: INTENDENTE ALVEAR, Argentina — Three escaped convicts shot and wounded two traffic police officers on Thursday, officials said, after a prison break that set off a round of finger-pointing between feuding politicians.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Daddy’s Home’
text: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Daddy’s Home.”

headline: New Year’s Day Offers Plenty of Free Chances at a Clean Slate
text: Whether you’re hoping to improve your body or your mind — or even just add to your cocktail conversation repertory — this weekend has plenty of events for self-improvement that, while opening the door for commitment, ask for nothing upfront.

headline: Friday File: When the Ball First Dropped on New Year’s Eve
text: The last newspaper printed before The New York Times left its building on Park Row appeared on New Year’s Day, 1905.

headline: Spurs Get a Laugh Track to Go With Their Five Titles
text: Phil Jackson, or, rather, a coarsely animated version of him, is sitting in a hotel room, threatening Gregg Popovich, the San Antonio Spurs coach, and pressing him to join the Knicks with a big-city sales pitch.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Concussion’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Concussion.”

headline: The Year in Weird Contentions
text: Seven of the stranger things that vexed the Internet in 2015 — and what they (maybe) tell us about ourselves.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Anomalisa’
text: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Anomalisa.”

headline: Review: Squeak Carnwath Speaks With Her Varied Palette
text: Over the decades, Squeak Carnwath has cultivated a distinctive blend of disparate 1970s art movements, including New Image painting, Conceptual Art and above all Process Art. In her first solo show in New York in over a decade, her paintings fluently speak several languages at once. Areas of flat color are adrift with abstract and representational elements as well as writing — passing thoughts, the news, quips — often partly submerged in the shuffle of erasures and new additions. Everything contributes to the commentary. Tracts of cursive consider the income gap or light pollution, while little blocks of color allude to abstraction and a compass rose conjures cartography and sign painting.

headline: Evening Hours | The Debutante Cotillion
text: A festive tradition continues.

headline: Review: Rudolf Stingel at Nahmad Contemporary, Making Crowd-Sourced Art
text: By 2000, the Italian-born painter Rudolf Stingel had made what he called paintings by covering floors or walls with bright orange carpet, and had sold D.I.Y. abstract painting kits. He then began to adopt more traditional formats while maintaining his hands-off attitude. The results, as demonstrated by the 10 paintings from 2000 to 2003 in this exhibition, continue to startle, taunt and seduce.

headline: N.F.L. Week 17 Previews and Picks
text: Vikings (10-5) at Packers (10-5)

headline: Review: In ‘The Himalayas,’ Two Climbers Form an Indelible Bond
text: “The Himalayas” is a broad comedy, a buddy movie, a mountain climbing adventure and a cornball weepie, not always in proportions that go well together. Inspired by a real-life mission to recover the bodies of mountaineering compatriots who died on Mount Everest in 2004, it spans roughly a dozen years in the lives of a team of South Korean climbers.

headline: ‘Dog Days’ Is Centerpiece of Prototype Festival
text: For new music, the main difficulty isn’t getting a premiere. It’s getting a second performance, and a third, and a fourth, the repetitions necessary for a piece really to enter the cultural bloodstream.

headline: More Hillary Clinton Emails Are Released, but State Department Falls Short
text: WASHINGTON — The State Department fell short of a court order requiring the release of the vast bulk of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton’s emails by the end of 2015, but promised on Thursday to catch up early in the new year.

headline: Review: In Barb Choit’s ‘Pronk,’ 1980s Shoes Are Back
text: Ms. Choit’s show at Rawson Projects raises questions about the overlapping of art and advertising.

headline: Review: ‘Only Yesterday,’ Isao Takahata’s Time-Jumping Anime
text: Isao Takahata, an Academy Award nominee and one of the twin pillars of the anime giant Studio Ghibli, brings the cleareyed grace of his animation to the lovely memoiristic story of a 27-year-old woman in “Only Yesterday.” As the woman, Taeko, goes on a vacation in the country that brings back grade-school memories, Mr. Takahata finds a poignancy in milestones and ordinary moments alike, showing her sense of self deepening over time.

headline: Review: Nathaniel Robinson’s Sculptures Tease Perceptions
text: The remarkably inventive sculptor Nathaniel Robinson makes technically impressive, philosophically provocative works that play in the gap between perception and cognition — between what you see and what you understand.

headline: Site of a Raging Fire in Downtown Dubai
text: A 63-story luxury hotel in Dubai caught on fire Thursday evening, interrupting New Year’s Eve celebrations.

headline: Review: In ‘Other People’s Children,’ a Woman’s Pain and Search for Artistic Solace
text: “Other People’s Children,” a painfully hackneyed first feature by the director Liz Hinlein, is doomed from the outset by its wearisome heroine, Sam (Diane Marshall-Green). Appearing in almost every scene, Sam — a filmmaker who has “victim” practically stenciled on her forehead — drifts vapidly through downtown Los Angeles, trying to untangle her feelings about her recently deceased father by engaging in mindless sex and binge drinking.

headline: Making a Show From Found Videos, Both Unsettling and Lighthearted
text: Everyone knows the YouTube sensations, the most popular cats and kiddos. But Sean McElroy and Tei Blow, the avant-garde theater duo who make up Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, were after the opposite: YouTube videos with almost no audience.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Jan. 1-7
text: Sometimes only a few days separate Christmas cheer from cabin fever. For families who’ve grown tired of staying at home, Brooklyn Botanic Garden offers a weekend event in which colorful paper and pungent pine have nothing to do with the holidays.

headline: A Year of Mourning Steeped in African Tradition Leads to a Theater Piece
text: Kaneza Schaal was 25 when her father died of malaria in 2010. Her first impulse was to stay in New York, not fly to the funeral in Burundi, where he lived when he wasn’t in the East Village. At the time, she was working with immigrant students at a school in Chelsea, and she saw no reason to interrupt that.

headline: Review: In ‘Yosemite,’ a Coming-of-Age Tale of 3 Boys in 1980s California
text: The young French-born filmmaker Gabrielle Demeestere can be an observant and resourceful simulator of lovely small moments. There’s a brief sequence in her debut feature, “Yosemite” (adapted in part from a couple of stories by its executive producer and co-star James Franco), in which a boy wakes up in the morning to find a spider walking up his bedroom curtain. He cups it in his hands, examines it, and some of his wonder and curiosity make their way off the screen.

headline: BTG Pactual Sells Distressed Debt Unit to Itau Unibanco
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s largest private sector banking group said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the distressed debt unit of the troubled investment firm BTG Pactual for about 1.2 billion reais, or about $307 million.

headline: A Desert Biennial Alongside Coachella Is in the Works
text: Ever since Ed Ruscha and friends threw a Royal typewriter out the window of a speeding Buick LeSabre near Los Angeles for his 1967 photographic book, “Royal Road Test,” the impact of the California desert has been visible in his work. Now, Mr. Ruscha is part of an effort to establish a biennial-like exhibition in the Palm Springs area that would be timed for February through April 2017 to overlap with Modernism Week and the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, two big crowd-pleasers.

headline: Review: Phish Settles In for Another New Year’s Run
text: Phish began its semi-regular New Year’s run at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the first of its four straight nights of shows there. The concerts are sold out. If you don’t have a ticket and don’t follow Phish, it means that you’ll see excitable, woodsy-looking men with beards in Midtown bars before 7:30 and after 11:30 p.m. The concerts will in no other way affect you. They do not intersect with contemporary aesthetics or dynamic social currents.

headline: Response to Paris Attacks Points to Weaknesses in French Police Structure
text: PARIS — Since the devastating Nov. 13 attacks in Paris, the French police have offered only a fragmentary outline of their response and of how they deployed antiterror teams and other forces. The somberness and solidarity in the weeks since have muted public criticism. No review of the police’s performance has been announced.

headline: Review: For the Crawleys and ‘Downton Abbey,’ the Beginning of the End
text: Downton Abbey — the country house, if not the wildly popular PBS drama — begins the show’s final season on Sunday night in a depleted state. Servants are not being replaced, and Robert Crawley, the Earl of Grantham, is hinting that further reductions may be needed. Upstairs, both Tom Branson and Rose MacClare (now Lady Rose Aldridge) have sailed for America, taking with them some of the show’s energy and audience good will. When the Granthams gather in the morning, it’s a sad showing, just Robert, Mary and Edith around a small table.

headline: Review: Drips, Dropped: Pollock and His Impact
text: Any exhibition of older art drawn from a museum’s permanent collection is a palm held out for us to read, a snapshot of the museum’s sense of its role over time, its present ambitions and its view of art history. Place two such exhibitions side by side and an especially intense and revealing frisson can occur.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 1-7
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Merkel Urges Germans to See Migrants as ‘an Opportunity,’ Not a Threat
text: As Germans prepared to ring in 2016 alongside at least a million migrants who were registered as new residents in 2015, Chancellor Angela Merkel dedicated a New Year’s Eve address to what she said her nation could gain from the refugee crisis.

headline: A Times Course for Young World Changers Asks, ‘Sustain What?’
text: Most visitors know I left full-time journalism in 2010 to teach courses on communication and environmental policy at Pace University. But you may not know that The Times, itself, is expanding its mission beyond traditional journalism and, with a partner, has launched The School of The New York Times, offering mini-courses on weekends to high school and older middle school students and courses for professionals in various fields. There’ll soon be online classes and much more.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 1-7
text: Three Kings Day Parade (Wednesday) Also known as the Epiphany, this Christian holiday, as the name suggests, celebrates the day the three Magi visited the newborn Jesus and gave him gifts.Different countries have their traditions; in Spain and Latin America, the holiday usually comes with fanfare: colorful parades with tributes to camels and kings in the streets.

text: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Subpoena Ordering Recipients Not to Disclose
text: An order by prosecutors “not to disclose the existence of this subpoena” was sharply rebuked by a federal judge. By law, recipients of subpoenas are free to tell anyone about them.

text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Winning Before God at Clemson
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — At the end of Clemson Coach Dabo Swinney’s news conference on Wednesday, I asked him a theology-based question.

text: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Reporters from The Times explored the answers to these questions and others in some of our most-read longer pieces of the year on the 2016 presidential campaign.

text: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

text: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: It’s an Unobtrusive Assistant Whispering in Your Ear (Not Little Brother)
text: Google Glass, the augmented reality assistant in the form of an omnipresent glass eye, failed largely because of the anxiety it created. In San Francisco, Glass wearers were quickly mocked, and Google reluctantly went back to the drawing board.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Jan. 1-7
text: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
text: South Korea and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Hostage at Bataclan Recalls Terrorists During Paris Attack
text: PARIS — He was one of a dozen-odd hostages captured by a group of terrorists as they finished their massacre in November at the Bataclan, living for over two hours in their grip in a narrow upstairs corridor at the Paris concert hall and then through the final assault of the police as bullets flew.

headline: Dec. 31, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from South Korea, Tokyo, Switzerland and Turkey.

headline: Decrease in Homeless Veterans in New York Far Outpaces National Drop
text: The bedraggled veteran draped in a flag, begging for spare change, has been one of the most persistent images of homelessness in this country.

headline: Television This Winter: 20 Shows to Keep on Your Radar Screen
text: “AMERICAN CRIME,” “American Crime Story, “The Americans” — the winter season of new and returning television shows has a patriotic sound to it (setting aside that the shows in question are about rape, murder and Soviet espionage). And you can throw in a PBS drama actually set in America, “Mercy Street”; an alternate history of an American tragedy, “11.22.63”; and the return of an American classic, “The X-Files.” Here are 20 shows to watch for during the next three months.

headline: Microsoft to Notify Users of Government Hackings
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft says it will begin notifying users of its online services if they have been targets of suspected state-sponsored online attacks, joining a growing list of Internet companies stepping up their security policies with similar measures.

headline: Gun-Friendly Texas Is Getting Even Friendlier
text: HOUSTON — Texas is so gun-friendly that it is easier to get into the Capitol in Austin with a firearm than without one — licensed, gun-carrying lawmakers and members of the public have their own no-wait security lane, and the unarmed masses have to stand in line and slog through the metal detectors.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Supporting Ted Cruz Plan a $1 Million Advertising Buy
text: A string of allied “super PACs” supporting the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is planning a $1 million television, digital and radio advertising buy in the early voting states, with the heaviest spending in Iowa, a spokeswoman for the group said.

headline: A Family in Transition Rebuilds Its Connections
text: When Karen Quinones’s son Tristian was almost 3 years old, a New Jersey Transit driver stopped the bus in the middle of the Lincoln Tunnel and pleaded with her to stop her son’s crying. He said the tantrum was so distracting that he could not drive.

headline: Chief Justice’s Report Praises Limits on Litigants’ Access to Information
text: WASHINGTON — Calling for “a change in our legal culture,” Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. devoted his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary to a plea that lawyers “avoid antagonistic tactics, wasteful procedural maneuvers and teetering brinkmanship.”

headline: A Roller Coaster Year Ends With U.S. Markets Mostly Down
text: Investors may be disappointed with the lackluster performance of the United States stock market in 2015, but, given all that happened, it could have been worse.
